fields.headline: Babayaro clear for Cup final
fields.trailText: Chelsea's left-back Celestine Babayaro has been cleared to play in the FA Cup final - which would be his first game in the competition this season - after anxiously waiting this week on a Nigeria decision which threatened to rule him out of appearing at Wembley a week tomorrow.
fields.body:
Chelsea's left-back Celestine Babayaro has been cleared to play in the FA Cup final - which would be his first game in the competition this season - after anxiously waiting this week on a Nigeria decision which threatened to rule him out of appearing at Wembley a week tomorrow.

The Nigerians, with whom Chelsea have had several clashes over Babayaro this season, announced earlier this week that he had been selected in their squad for a friendly in Qatar on May 21, a day after the Cup final.

Babayaro, who missed last month's semi-final victory against Newcastle at Wembley due to Nigeria commitments, would have been required to join up with his country three days before the Qatar game.

Chelsea appealed to the Nigerian FA to release him for the final against Aston Villa but there was no reply for a couple of days. Then it was announced the friendly had been postponed.

Babayaro will now contest the left-back place with the 20-year-old Jon Harley, who has appeared in all Chelsea's five Cup games this season. Graeme le Saux, recovering from a long-term ankle injury, is rated by club sources as "highly unlikely" to be fit for Wembley.

The final could well mark Frank Leboeuf's last appearance in a Chelsea shirt after the 32-year-old French central defender admitted he has held talks with Lyon, where he has also recently bought a house.

Leboeuf admitted yesterday: "Contacts have been made between Lyon and myself and without doubt they will be the last club of my career."

He would command a £4m transfer fee and Lyon will probably offer him something that Chelsea cannot do themselves next season: Champions League football.

Real Madrid's coach Vicente del Bosque must wait until after the all-Spanish Champions League final on May 24 to find out if he will keep the job next season, the club president Lorenzo Sanz said yesterday.

It looks as if Del Bosque will have to win the trophy against Valencia or lose his job, with Sanz demanding Real's requalification for the Champions League. Real face an uphill task to qualify via the Spanish League. Del Bosque's team are currently sixth, too low to earn a Champions League berth.

In Rome riot police fired tear gas and charged at Lazio fans protesting outside the Italian football federation's offices yesterday. Two people, suffering bruises, were taken to hospital.

Rocks and oranges were hurled at police as fans demonstrated against perceived pro-Juventus bias after Sunday's controversial refereeing decision in the leaders' favour left them two points clear of Lazio before this weekend's final games.

fields.headline: Doctors and curses
fields.standfirst: When a GP signs off an employee for "workplace stress", it spells grief for all concerned
fields.trailText: Maggie was grieving. Or rather she was following her employer's grievance procedure. This made her a "grievant" and all her managers "grievees". I am trying to view these words as playful back-formations, illustrating the fecundity of the English language.
fields.body:
Maggie was grieving. Or rather she was following her employer's grievance procedure. This made her a "grievant" and all her managers "grievees". I am trying to view these words as playful back-formations, illustrating the fecundity of the English language.

Anyway, there is a lot of grief to be had in this case. And stress. Sometimes I wish the concept of stress had been left with its friend, strain - in the world of physics - where it could cause less trouble.

Maggie had become stressed when her new manager criticised her work practices. She went home and did not come in again. Her helpful GP gave her medical certificates, diagnosed "workplace stress" and signed her off for six weeks at a time.

I can picture Maggie's GP. There is a waiting room full of pensioners, pregnant women, sniffling toddlers and old copies of The People's Friend. Maggie comes in and talks and talks until, in desperation, he writes out the certificate and doesn't have to see her for six weeks.

After being off work for nearly a year, Maggie consulted the employment procedures and commenced her grieving. So her employer set up a hearing. Three independent managers formed a panel and took statements from all Maggie's fellow employees and the grievee, and then sent the statements to Maggie and invited her to a hearing with the representative of her choice.

On the day of the hearing, the three managers sat there waiting. And the grievee sat in another room waiting. That is until Maggie rang up to say she was sending in a letter from her GP explaining that she was too stressed to attend.

Then Maggie put in an application to the employment tribunal. So one day, about six months ago, I and my wheelie bin-sized bag of documents and my six witnesses from the employer's side sat waiting in the tribunal. That is until a fax came through from Maggie's GP saying she was too stressed to come to the tribunal hearing and could she have an adjournment?

But this week she actually made it. Perhaps she got tired of being stressed. Her application to the tribunal (which had been filled out by her union) said that she had been subjected to sex discrimination. But her grievance documents just said "discrimination". So I asked her to clarify:

Me: "Are you saying that all of these things happened to you on the grounds of your sex?"

Maggie: "No, I'm saying I was discriminated against. I wasn't treated as well as other people."

Me: "Men and women?"

Maggie: "Yes."

As yet you cannot sue your employer for not being as nice to you as he or she is to other people, so that was the end of her case.

As I waited for the tube, savouring this remarkable linguistic triumph, a recorded voice (the same geezer that tells you not to smoke on the stations) came over the tannoy: "Would Inspector Samms report to the operations room?"

The fact that seconds later the station was abruptly evacuated led me to deduce that this Inspector Samms character might simply be code for "we think there's a big bomb on the train" or "the electrics are smoking".

If, however, he is a real person, it seems a bit rough if he has to report to the operations room in the midst of a potential inferno. I wouldn't blame him one bit for taking the issue up through his employer's grievance procedure.

fields.headline: Airlines to sell seats online
fields.standfirst:
'Get stuffed' venture will add to pressure on embattled internet ticket agencies

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Airways has joined forces with 10 other European airlines to create an online travel agency that will sell tickets direct to the public.
fields.body:
British Airways has joined forces with 10 other European airlines to create an online travel agency that will sell tickets direct to the public.

The venture could dramatically change the landscape of the industry by cutting out high-street agencies who act as "middle men" in selling airline seats.

It will also add to the pressure on internet retailers such as Lastminute.com and ebookers.com, which hope to capture the market for travel sales on the web.

The venture was the first major announcement to be made by BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington.

He said: "The site will revolutionise the way European customers arrange their travel plans. From the comfort of their own armchair, they'll now have access in their own language to the biggest international route network and some of the lowest fares available."

Among the other airlines involved are Air France, Lufthansa, British Midland, Aer Lingus and KLM.

BA said any discount prices offered through other retailers would be available on the new site, which is yet to be named.

News of the venture helped push Lastminute.com's shares down 7.5p to 197.5p. However, co-founder Martha Lane Fox flatly rejected suggestions that the business would be affected.

"This is good news," she said. "It shows people believe it's worth putting investment into e-commerce."

BA's announcement came 24 hours after Airtours declared it was using a £100m investment in the internet to prevent virtual travel agents from stealing its customers.

Ms Lane Fox said only a fifth of Lastminute.com's revenue came from selling airline tickets: "I really don't see this as a concern. We have a good relationship with 55 airlines in Europe.

"BA is not trying to build a complex network of on-line solutions. Our customers sometimes want gifts, they sometimes want restaurant bookings. That's very, very different from wanting to be a full-service travel portal."

Lastminute.com's shares have plunged from a placing price of 380p since the company's flotation in March.

Analysts were unconvinced by Ms Lane Fox's comments. Miles Saltiel of WestLB Pan mure, said: "BA's move is a signal of just how low the barriers to entry are in the travel business, and the intensity of the competition."

Another analyst said: "The biggest issue will be whether Lastminute.com can still get access to products. These airlines are all just saying 'get stuffed' and doing their own thing."

Online ticket sales have been pioneered by discount airlines such as Easyjet, which makes more than half its revenue on the net.

BA said it wanted to reach a similar level within three years, although at present just 2% to 3% of its sales come from the internet.

The Association of British Travel Agents, which represents high-street chains, said it would be concerned if the airlines' site offered any deals which were not available through independent agents. A spokesman said: "This could be of concern if it's in any way anti-competitive."

She said many customers would still prefer the personal service and experience offered by high-street agents:

"Our members are aware that in order for them to attract business, they have to add value," she said.

webTitle: Reforms on way for car sales

fields.headline: Reforms on way for car sales
fields.standfirst: EU commissioner puts his foot down
fields.trailText: Competition commissioner Mario Monti yesterday put the European automotive industry on notice to expect radical reform in the way cars are sold when the regulations expire next year.
fields.body:
Competition commissioner Mario Monti yesterday put the European automotive industry on notice to expect radical reform in the way cars are sold when the regulations expire next year.

Though Mr Monti was careful to stress he was "open-minded" about the need for any changes to the "block-exemption" mechanism which governs car distribution within the European union, his criticism leaves little doubt that changes are on the way.

The competition commission's investigations showed that the assumptions underlying the present regime - which Mr Monti described as the highway code for car distribution - were open to question and its objectives were not being achieved.

The block-exemption scheme which was renewed for a seven-year period in 1995 gives the automotive industry exemption from the competition provisions of the treaty of Rome and allows car manufacturers to sell vehicles only through their own dealer networks. But the system is not delivering the expected improvements in competition, Mr Monti said.

The three assumptions on which the regime rests are that it provides effective competition, that dealers must provide after-sales services, and that brand specialists are needed to repair cars.

With six manufacturers representing 75% of the European car market, Mr Monti described the position as "oligopolistic" while the right of manufacturers to demand dealers both sell cars and provide after-sales services is "questionable".

And though the complexity of modern cars meant repairers needed a high level of expertise, that did not mean they needed to be tied to manufacturers.

"For all three assumptions on which the regime is based, it seems to me that one can have some doubts as to whether they hold true today," said Mr Monti, who was even more scathing about the objectives of the regulations.

Dealer independence is limited, they are restricted in their ability to sell more than one manufacturer's cars, the rules governing relations with independent repairers are not transparent and cross-border trade is not developing as it should.

He pointed to the experience of the UK. High prices could, in part, be attributed to the strength of sterling and the need to supply right-hand drive cars but he argued prices had risen to their levels because non-UK manufacturers preferred "to earn greater profits and sell less cars".

Though parallel trading - customers buying in from abroad - had increased, he warned: "It is apparent that manufacturers are not too pleased if dealers engage in parallel trade and dealers are afraid to displease their manufacturer.

"Therefore I do not attach too much importance to the fact that parallel trade into the UK has tripled for some manufacturers in the last two years. What matters is that it is still insufficient to put downward pressure on UK prices."

He drew attention to the campaign by the Consumers Association in Britain which complained consumers were being "ripped off". He said he had been sent 20,000 protest notes signed by British consumers.

webTitle: Shares rebound as US consumers check spending

fields.headline: Shares rebound as US consumers check spending
fields.trailText: Stock markets rallied yesterday after the first belt-tightening by America's spendthrift consumers in two years raised hopes that a sharp increase in US interest may be avoided.
fields.body:
Stock markets rallied yesterday after the first belt-tightening by America's spendthrift consumers in two years raised hopes that a sharp increase in US interest may be avoided.

After a bout of global jitters concentrated in the high technology sector, share prices in Europe and North America rose steeply on news that US retail sales fell by an unexpected 0.2% in April.

Most analysts are braced for a half-point rise when Federal Reserve officials meet next week, but signs of a cooling after months of booming growth lifted some of the gloom.

However, the Paris-based Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said yesterday that borrowing costs would have to rise from 6% to 7% in the coming months to reduce the pace of economic expansion. It is poised to revise upwards its forecast of 4.5% growth for the US this year. "To safeguard a continued, if slower expansion, at just under 3% in 2001, further increases in short-term interest rates are needed," the OECD said in its annual health check of the US economy.

America's spending spree had left analysts convinced that overall retail sales would grow by 0.4% last month. One reason for the fall was the decline in sales of cars, which had been exceptionally strong in late 1999 and early 2000. Stripping out the auto sector, retail sales were flat, compared to expectations of a 0.3% increase.

"I think that if we start to see more statistics like this, then the Fed will have absolutely no ammunition to keep raising rates," said Peggy Farley, President of Ascent Meredith Asset Management.

However, Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers said: "I would like to think it takes the Fed out of it, but it does not. It is only one data point."

While London's TechMark list of hi-tech stocks resisted the trend and ended the day down 2.24% at 3396, the FTSE 100 Index finished up 145 points at 6245. Germany's DAX rose by 84 points to 7205 and France's CAC Index put on 52 points to 6315.

The recoveries followed hefty sell-offs on Wednesday night in shares quoted in the Dow Jones industrial average and the hi-tech Nasdaq, followed by a pronounced fall in Tokyo. By yesterday lunchtime in New York, the Dow was up 160 points and the Nasdaq by almost 100.

fields.headline: A butterfly Pierrot
fields.standfirst: Rambert Dance Company Apollo Theatre, Oxford ****
fields.trailText: American choreographer Glen Tetley may have settled into his laurels as one of the Grand Old Men of classical ballet, but back in the 50s and 60s he was a far more slippery character
fields.body:
American choreographer Glen Tetley may have settled into his laurels as one of the Grand Old Men of classical ballet, but back in the 50s and 60s he was a far more slippery character - a modern dancer who had trained in ballet and a choreographer who dared to gloss the stark rhetoric of modernism with the shiny elegance of classicism. His athletically hybrid style was demotic but classy, and in 1966 when Rambert made its own transition from ballet company to modern dance ensemble, Tetley provided much of its initial repertory. Three decades on the company is revisiting that debt by reviving two of Tetley's early works, Pierrot Lunaire (1962) and Embrace Tiger and Return to Mountain (1968).

Pierrot (premiered by Rambert in 1967) became a signature piece not only for the new-look company but for its leading dancer Christopher Bruce. Bruce's beautiful line and unworldly modesty made him an ideal Pierrot; now as Rambert's director he has the poignant task of helping Conor O'Brien recreate that role. O'Brien is uncannily like his mentor and the degree to which Pierrot looks as strange and vivid on stage as it once did owes much to his magnificent performance.

It is a herculean role, powered by eccentric changes of mood, and O'Brien not only has an instinctive feel for the choreography's line, he retains a purity of demeanour which stops him looking twee. He is a butterfly oddity trapped by the swooping lines of Schoenberg's score and he is thuggishly matched by Branden Faulls's Brighella and Deirdre Chapman as the erotically treacherous Columbine.

Inspired by Tetley's (slightly cursory) study of T'ai chi, Embrace Tiger laces snippets of martial arts with stylistic borrowings from Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham and ballet. The mix of sources is slightly distracting yet it is a strongly crafted piece, the slow gradations from zen stillness to powerhouse dancing ingeniously handled. It is also a blockbuster showcase for the dancers and most of Wednesday's cast looked admirably stretched and excited by it.

Rambert Dance Company is at Sadler's Wells, London EC2 (020-7863 8000), from May 31-June 10.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Principled pragmatism
fields.standfirst: The Novice Almeida Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText: What does Sartre's Les Mains Sales, written in 1948, mean to us today? Richard Eyre, who has adapted and directed it as The Novice, eloquently argues that it still resonates in a world where pragmatism confronts principle. But, although his version is perfectly entertaining, I find that the play has lost much of its fire in a period where ideology is suspect and communism in retreat.

But, although his version is perfectly entertaining, I find that the play has lost much of its fire in a period where ideology is suspect and communism in retreat.

Sartre uses a thriller format to explore moral and political ideas. His setting is a fictional European country, Illythia, at the end of the last war. His hero, Hugo, is a bourgeois revolutionary who has volunteered to assassinate a proletarian party leader, Hoederer, who plans to enter a coalition with the fascists and the social democrats.

But when Hugo takes a job as Hoederer's secretary, he finds himself drawn to the man though repelled by his policies. What Sartre goes on to explore is whether a political murder, such as Hugo is obliged to commit, has any validity when it is drained of moral meaning.

The play is drenched in the atmosphere of the late 1940s: a period when communism was both a living force and a magnet to idealistic intellectuals. But Eyre's version, though it preserves Sartre's structure, drains the play of much of its political detail. We never learn that one of Hoederer's potential allies has fought with the Germans against the Soviet Union; equally we lose Hoederer's key argument that his party alone has maintained contact with the Russians throughout the war and thus holds the real power.

What we get is a greater focus on Hugo's troubled conscience and a more generalised debate on purity versus pragmatism. In the play's best scene Hugo attacks compromise while Hoederer claims that "a party is only a means to an end and there is only ever one end: power."

But while you can easily relate this to Old and New Labour, Sartre was writing about a world where something bigger was at stake: where people were prepared to kill out of conviction and where the communist party had the power to deprive murder of meaning. But even if Eyre's version lacks a precise context, it works well as an atmospheric thriller. Mark Henderson's lighting is all sinister shadows, and Richard Hartley's music generates a tingling suspense.

Jamie Glover's clean-scrubbed Hugo acutely exemplifies the innocence of an idealist lost in a world of realpolitik and Kenneth Cranham's Hoederer has the weariness of the battle-scarred politician and the humanity of the paternalistic protector. Natasha Little as Hugo's erratic, upper class wife and Emer Gillespie as a party loyalist do what they can with peripheral roles.

But, though the play has a melodramatic intensity, it now feels like a strange relic from the post-war world.

Until June 17. Box office: 020 7359 4404.

fields.headline: After Harry Potter, the 'Business Bible'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bloomsbury Publishing, which brought the world Harry Potter, has unveiled a deal with US trade publisher Perseus Books to create what it claims will be a definitive global print and electronic database of business information. The project, called the Business Bible, is due to be completed by 2002.
fields.body:
Bloomsbury Publishing, which brought the world Harry Potter, has unveiled a deal with US trade publisher Perseus Books to create what it claims will be a definitive global print and electronic database of business information. The project, called the Business Bible, is due to be completed by 2002.

Nigel Newton, Bloomsbury's chief executive, said his firm was creating "an essential tool for anyone doing business at any level". The Business Bible, he said, will be promoted as a one-stop comprehensive reference and interactive tool covering all areas of business. Advertising agency J Walter Thompson has been appointed to market the book.

It is to be published simultaneously in the US, UK and around the world with up to 12 localised versions, including German, Japanese and Spanish editions. But Mr Newton conceded yesterday that it would "inevitably" have an American focus because of "the dominance of the US in strategic business thinking".

An announcement on rights to the electronic version is expected in three months.

Mr Newton, who also oversaw publication of Microsoft's Encarta encyclopedia, predicted that the Business Bible would at least match Encarta's success, with turnover projected at £40m in its first 10 years, and would have significant impact on Bloomsbury's earnings.

fields.headline: Pulsating puppets on parade
fields.standfirst: The Flaming Lips Glasgow Garage ****
fields.trailText: The mere appearance of a mini-Rank Films gong on the stage of the Glasgow Garage sparked crazed whooping throughout the audience in anticipation of the lo-fi multi-media extravaganza that was to follow. The assembled were distinctly hardcore fans of the Flaming Lips and knew what to expect. Kind of. As they swapped previous Lips' experiences - agreeing that no two gigs were the same - a patchwork of pixels materialised on the giant video screen at the back of the stage. The whooping turned cacophonous and a mourning guitar, which sounded like Air meets the Foo Fighters on a soporific Sunday afternoon, glided in above a filmic string chorus. Naturally, the night didn't remain so sedate.
fields.body:
The mere appearance of a mini-Rank Films gong on the stage of the Glasgow Garage sparked crazed whooping throughout the audience in anticipation of the lo-fi multi-media extravaganza that was to follow. The assembled were distinctly hardcore fans of the Flaming Lips and knew what to expect. Kind of. As they swapped previous Lips' experiences - agreeing that no two gigs were the same - a patchwork of pixels materialised on the giant video screen at the back of the stage. The whooping turned cacophonous and a mourning guitar, which sounded like Air meets the Foo Fighters on a soporific Sunday afternoon, glided in above a filmic string chorus. Naturally, the night didn't remain so sedate.

The Lips' opening proper came with their last single, Race for the Prize, which was fiercely frazzling and jubilant; an odd feeling, especially since nuclear detonations were screening on the video backdrop. Contradicting and enforcing the mood of the songs, the band take pride in their visuals. Like karaoke videos made by Stanley Kubrick, they are both weirdly dissonant and apposite. With a mini camera positioned in front of the band, there was no escaping the Oklahoma City trio's comic, poignant and hallucinogenic bents. Especially when the rubber glove puppets came out. A sperm, a nun and a monkey forced home the absurd genius of the clearly bonkers trio.

Somewhere Over the Rainbow (accompanied by a slack-jawed Judy Garland stuck in a freeze frame), the sunny pathos of Waitin' for a Superman and She Don't Use Jelly gave the crowd every opportunity to holler along with lead singer Wayne Coyne. Never once did they catch up with his playful, undulating tones. As the all-too short set drew to a close, the Lips' trademark surrealism - mixing guitar pop with psychedelic balladry and a hint of 50s lounge music - permeated. What is the Light? was an emotional highpoint and their encore, The Spark that Bled, complete with fake blood, pushed the boundaries of what makes music (and indeed, what makes a concert) with sirens, megaphones and the angst-ridden Coyne's voice petering away to oblivion. Bloody visionary.

 The Flaming Lips play the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242) tonight.

webTitle: Bank of Ireland expansion plan fails to convince City

fields.headline: Bank of Ireland expansion plan fails to convince City
fields.trailText: Bank of Ireland is to expand its business on this side of the Irish Sea despite the collapse of its merger talks with Alliance & Leicester last year.
fields.body:
Bank of Ireland is to expand its business on this side of the Irish Sea despite the collapse of its merger talks with Alliance & Leicester last year.

The Irish bank, which suffered an almost 10% share price fall after releasing its annual profit figures yesterday, might consider small acquisitions to alter its reliance on mortgages and savings through Bristol & West.

The bank wants to expand its small business custom and its fund management business. The bank disclosed that it would close about 37 of its 300 branches.

But Maurice Keane, chief executive, said the bank would resist closures in rural areas, which caused such a furore for Barclays last month.

"There aren't huge payoffs from closures (in rural areas) and there's a huge customer backlash," Mr Keane said.

Instead, most of the closures will be in urban areas where customers are more ready to adapt to automated systems, he said.

The bank wants to move 80% of its customers' "routine transactions" to cash points or the internet within the next three years.

Mr Keane, who saw his counterpart at Alliance & Leicester ousted after the merger debacle, said he had the confidence of his board and expected to stay in his role until his contract ended in January 2002.

While analysts said yesterday that the bank had not done enough to outline its strategy, Mr Keane countered by saying the bank was pursuing growth through expansion in Britain and joint ventures in Europe, similar to the one announced this week with Nova, a US payments firm.

The bank's pre-tax profits before exceptional items rose by 10% to 920m euros in the year to the end ofMarch.

Mr Keane said he was a "little perplexed" by the fall in the shares yesterday. Meanwhile, Abbey National restructured its business yesterday into four areas and highlighted the appointment of a woman, Yasmin Jetha, to its executive team. Ms Jetha is the bank's IT and infrastructure director.

From June 1, Abbey said it would have a new "business to consumer banking" area to control its e-commerce activities including the launch of its separately-branded internet bank, cahoot, next month.

fields.headline: Microsoft's compromise rejected
fields.standfirst:
The future of Microsoft: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The US Justice Department yesterday dismissed proposals by Microsoft put forward to appease the regulator and prevent the software company from being broken up.
fields.body:
The US Justice Department yesterday dismissed proposals by Microsoft put forward to appease the regulator and prevent the software company from being broken up.

"Microsoft's proposal is ineffective and filled with loopholes," a statement from the department said. "It would not have prevented Microsoft from engaging in many of the illegal acts found by the (federal) district court, nor would it prevent the company from using its monopoly power in the future to engage in the same kind of illegal behaviour to crush new innovations."

The department was responding to a petition presented by Microsoft to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who last month ruled the company had violated anti monopoly laws.

The company has suggested that constraints governed by a court injunction would be a better way to remedy any anti-competitive behaviour. As part of its submission, Microsoft has offered to allow computer manufacturers to hide its internet browser icon and to offer other rival features on desktops.

But the Justice Department said "the proposal fundamentally fails to repair the damage to competition caused by Microsoft's illegal acts, or prevent Microsoft from committing similar violations in the future."

webTitle: Valencia inflict shock of the Nou

fields.headline: Valencia inflict shock of the Nou
fields.standfirst:
Barca broken by Mendieta away goal as all-Spanish final awaits
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
F de Boer 78, Cocu 90 | Mendieta 70
Valencia win 5-3 on aggregate
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  at the Nou Camp
fields.body:
The romantics will not like it, and the thousands of Barcelona fans who called for Luis van Gaal's resignation certainly did not, but it will be Valencia who take on Real Madrid in the all-Spanish Champions League final after a surprisingly comfortable passage last night.

Steely in defence and impressive on the counter-attack, the one-time 40-1 shots to win the competition deserved their draw. By the time Frank de Boer headed in from a corner and Philip Cocu scored from close range to salvage some pride for Barcelona the contest was over, Mendieta's goal having given Valencia a 5-1 aggregate lead.

Barcelona had sounded confident beforehand, spurred by memories of their stirring comeback against Chelsea in the previous round. That night Luis van Gaal's team had overturned a 3-1 deficit; this time it was a 4-1 away defeat they had to overcome. "We have done it once," the Dutch coach said, "and we can do it again."

Van Gaal had implored his players "to be prepared to die out there on the field", a roundabout way of warning Valencia that they would progress over his dead bodies. The last thing Valencia can have expected was an easy ride.

A 3-0 league defeat here a little over a month ago stood as a warning to Valencia to be strong in defence and incisive in attack.

It was a sign of local hopes that this huge, vertigo-inducing stadium was only a little short of its 98,000 capacity. But the worrying news for those who had come was that, unlike Chelsea, Valencia were clearly not content to sit back and wait for waves of Barcelona attacks to drown them.

Closing down quickly from the front and forcing Barcelona back whenever possible, Valencia's gameplan was clear: smother when they did not have the ball and, when they did, look to hold it or strike on the counter-attack. The discipline and team ethic which is at the root of their unexpected Champions League surge was evident.

Near the touchline Valencia's Argentine coach Hector Cuper was constantly at the edge of his technical area, urging his players to harry and hustle and waving them back. For the most part his experienced defence (average age almost 33) and young, energetic midfield (average age under 24) frustrated Barcelona but Van Gaal's team are impossible to contain permanently.

They were far from their fluent, surging best - Valencia did not allow them to be - but hopes were raised when Patrick Kluivert headed over from Luis Figo's cross. Then Rivaldo forced Canizares to tip round the post, and Michael Reiziger twice found Kluivert in promising positions early on.

But Barcelona struggled after that to carve out anything of note despite the promptings of Figo and as Valencia came more into the match, Claudio Lopez and Kily Gonzalez had chances on the counter-attack. With the score 0-0 at half-time Cuper could start dreaming of Paris and the final.

Angulo should have settled matters shortly after the restart from Lopez's cross but allowed Ruud Hesp to save. Valencia continued to dominate, with their captain Gaizka Mendieta particularly impressive. He, though, wasted a glorious chance on the hour, shooting wide from a Lopez pass.

It said much for Valencia's security in defence that they could afford that. They are not a team of stars but Cuper, who worked miracles in taking Real Mallorca from the Second Division to last season's European Cup Winners Cup final, has moulded a hard-working, organised side who strike with skill and pace given the chance.

After a poor start to the season there were widespread calls for Cuper to be sacked and Valencia hardly looked Champions League finalists when they lost 3-0 at Old Trafford in December. They have, though, peaked at the right time, destroying Lazio 5-2 at home in the quarter-final and now seeing off the favourites with much to spare.

Barcelona's mounting frustration heightened when penalty appeals for fouls on Figo and Rivaldo were turned down. For Valencia there are new heights of rejoicing after Mendieta made sure of victory with a fine curling shot from Lopez's cross. The Copa del Rey they won last season was their first trophy for 19 years. Now they are on the verge of landing the biggest prize of all.

Barcelona (3-3-1-3): Hesp; Reiziger, F de Boer, Abelardo (Litmanen, 77); Xavi, Guardiola (Sergi, 69min), Cocu; Rivaldo; Figo, Kluivert, Zenden (Simao Sabrosa, 63).

Valencia (4-4-2): Canizares; Angloma (Gerardo, 86), Djukic, Pellegrino, Carboni; Mendieta, Farinos (Sanchez, 90), Gerard, Kily Gonzalez (Albelda, 74); Angulo, Lopez.

Referee : V Pereira (Portugal)

webTitle: Lander of a scoop and laughter in the box

fields.headline: Lander of a scoop and laughter in the box
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: Frank Keating remembers the late Chris Lander, cricket correspondent of the Daily Mirror
fields.body:
I once wrote the front-page splash for the Daily Mirror. And the subs never changed a single comma or exclamation mark. Ever since I have considered myself a real journalist - although the truth is that only one other person knew about my scoop. And now, alas and grievously out of the blue, he is dead.

On May 21 1980, in the one-horse Afrikaans stronghold of Potchefstroom, I was sharing a hotel room with Chris Lander of the Daily Mirror. The Lions that afternoon had beaten a South African Select XV and, after both of us had telephoned our reports back to London over the crackly, intermittent landline, Chris decided on a night in the city, telephoned a lady (he had a phone book more female-full than any veteran matelot's) and set off on the two- or three-hour drive to wine her in Johannesburg. He was now incommunicado.

In no time an angry phone rang from London: "Where's Lander?" barked the Mirror. "Er, just popped out," I stalled. "We've had an exclusive tip that the Lions' next match against Zimbabwe in Harare is off because of the Lions' connections with apartheid, so will you tell Lander when he 'pops back' that a copytaker will ring him in 10 minutes and I want 15 paragraphs."

I shedded my inborn Guardian pretentiousness and cobbled together some breathless, deathless Mirrorese . . . "IN A DRAMATIC SNUB TO BRITISH SPORTSMEN LAST NIGHT, NEW TYRANT 'RED BOB' MUGABE BANNED . . ."

Chris arrived back in the morning, bleary and amazed to find the next leg of the tour was off. A wire, a "hooray-o-gram", was waiting for him from London. Congrats on front-page splash scoop. He would, of course, have done the same for me - and made a much better fist of parodying the Guardian style.

He was 59 when he died. He joined the Mirror, to cover cricket and rugby, more than 30 years ago and his scintillating company made him the life, soul and heartbeat of press boxes the world over - fun and laughter.

Chris will doubtless already be writing out the batting order - or chewing it over with eminence Jim Swanton, who died in January - for his Celestial Press XI, and no problems with numbers either, for our trade and once merry freemasonry has been suddenly and wretchedly blighted of late.

In less than three years, sadness upon sadness, cricket has lost - most well before their time - such writing stalwarts (heavy and light, posh and pop) as Alan Gibson, John Parker, David Lemmon, Doug Ibbotson, Geoff Nicholson, Christopher Wordsworth, Don Mosey, Harold Abel, John Kay, Michael Melford and even, at 50, Lander's buddy and soul mate from the Mirror, Colin Price.

When Ian Botham, another with whom Lander was enduringly bonded in fraternal mateship, embarked on his first epic John o'Groats walk for leukaemia, ghost-writer Lander walked the first day for a wheeze. He ended up tramping alongside the big, bold baron of beef for, in all ventures, nearly 3,000 more miles.

His aim had been to log as many miles as Botham had test runs - 5,200. Ah me. Chris's smile of satisfaction on first reaching Land's End was wondrous to behold - and I saw it bettered only once.

Twenty years ago he was charged with writing a book for another friend, the bowler Derek Underwood. webTitle: Pakistan clears its players of match-fixing

fields.headline: Pakistan clears its players of match-fixing
fields.trailText: In a move that will probably be seen within the cricket world as a 'whitewash', the pakistan Cricket Board last night announced that the long-awaited report by Judge Malik Abdul Qayyum had found "no planned match-fixing".
fields.body:
The chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board last night announced that Judge Malik Abdul Qayyum's long-awaited judicial report had found "no planned match-fixing".

Pakistan cricket has emerged from the match-fixing crisis without a stain on its character according to Lieutenant General Tauqir Zia. "Pakistan's image will not be stained over this: we are giving a lesson to others," he continued.

The elusive report, compiled by a Lahore judge, after an inquiry into match-fixing allegations which lasted two years, does suggest bans and fines for players, as has been suggested by previous leaks.

But these have been recommended only because certain players allegedly refused to co-operate with the inquiry and not as a product of any other wrongdoing.

It will not be made public for eight to 10 days, and even then only a summary of the report is promised rather than the report itself. Initially it will be circulated to the International Cricket Council chairmen and discussed at the next ICC meeting towards the end of next month.

"It seems very odd, " said the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket, Lord MacLaurin, who initiated the ICC's emergency meeting, yesterday. "But at the moment we have to wait and see the report before commenting on it further."

And so Pakistan is throwing the gauntlet down to the rest of the cricket world, much of which will be muttering the word "whitewash".

If it emerges that the report, or the summary of it, is significantly different from that which Qayyum intended, there is the real prospect that England's winter tour to Pakistan might be cancelled.

Qayyum's report, commissioned in the wake of allegations of attempted match-fixing and bribery against the Pakistani cricketers, involved interviews with 70 players and officials and was completed last October. Since then it has been gathering dust, with the Pakistan board saying that it was unable to release the findings as the inquiry was instigated by the government.

Zia's pronouncements on the contents of the report are significantly at odds with a series of selective and apparently well-informed leaks over the past six months.

All these pointed to the fact that Qayyum had found strong evidence of irregularities and had actually recommended life bans for three players for reasons other than non-cooperation.

Qayyum, who recently expressed his frustration at the delay in publishing the report, has already said that he would be fully prepared to go public if there was evidence that his report had been watered down. "The report is final," he said at the weekend. "I have a sealed copy with me and if they change it then everybody would know. I would make it public."

If indeed the report has been altered, and specifically, if it has been altered to protect the image of Pakistan, and Qayyum is then prepared to be true to his word, then the ICC will have no alternative, if it is not to be seen to be toothless, but to suspend Pakistan in accordance with it resolution at last week's emergency conference. England's tour, due to begin on October 16, would then be in jeopardy.

Bobby Simpson, who was Australia's coach when Salim Malik, the Pakistan captain, allegedly approached three Australian players, Shane Warne, Mark Waugh and Tim May, with offers of bribes during their 1994 tour said last night: "I think the important thing is to wait and see how the judge reacts and what his report contains.

"Until we know what exactly is in his report, it is all conjecture. Then it is up to the ICC committees to decide how to deal with it." Warne and Waugh gave evidence to the Qayyum inquiry in open court in Melbourne. Simpson is at present coaching Lancashire.

"The public must get the truth," Zia added last night. "We want to close the issue of match-fixing for ever and after making this report public this issue will be buried. I assure you we will implement the report 99.9%."

Fears have always been rife that when it came to the crunch, Pakistan's priority would not be to provide a full exposure of their match-rigging conclusions, but to save as much face as possible.

That prospect became more apparent last week when Imran Khan, now a politician of high ambitions, accused the International Cricket Council of anti-Pakistan bias.

Imran, 47, who now heads the Movement For Justice party, pinned most blame on Australia, stating: "I don't know why the ICC has not taken the Australian Cricket Board to task for hiding facts. The ICC instead put pressure upon Pakistan for its match-fixing report."

webTitle: Time to try out England's own white lightning

fields.headline: Time to try out England's own white lightning
fields.standfirst: Durham's Steve Harmison has the talent but has he the temperament?
fields.trailText: Durham's Steve Harmison has the talent but, as David Hopps asks, has he the temperament to hit the big time with England?
fields.body:
In the week that England's selectors will ponder whether to give Steve Harmison a test debut, the bowler might have hoped for a better fate than to be afflicted by the bout of wides that hastened Lancashire's victory against Durham in the Benson and Hedges Cup quarter-final and left him rushing for the Old Trafford exit in self-disgust.

In a career that has known a few crises of confidence, the blow could not have come at a worse time. As test debuts go, to turn out at Lord's next Thursday against a mediocre Zimbabwe side is about as inviting as it gets.

The question is whether Harmison would see it that way. To some, like Justin Langer, Middlesex's Australian batsman, he is England's "white West Indian", a 6ft 4in fast bowler whose supple limbs and high action can extract awkward bounce from the most benign surface.

Others question whether his temperament can survive the rigours of test cricket and are even moved to recall the Somerset batsman Mark Lathwell, who played two England tests in 1993, aged 21, and could not wait to return to the security of his pub darts team in Devon.

Harmison has certainly attracted praise. Two seasons ago Langer, who is not given to overstatement, pronounced: "This kid is seriously fast, capable of bowling as quick as anyone in the world. He's a sort of Curtly Ambrose: very quick, very awkward."

So what are England waiting for? Dean Headley is out for the season, Chris Silverwood and Alan Mullally are barely over injuries and Harmison bowled splendidly in Durham's defeat of Surrey at the Riverside last week. The chairman of selectors, David Graveney, Durham's inaugural county captain, is an avowed fan.

What England are waiting for, more than anything, is a conviction that Harmison, at 21, will relish the pressures of test cricket. It is a sensitive subject, especially for Durham's director of cricket Geoff Cook, who has nurtured Harmison since the day he was first discovered playing club cricket for Ashington when, like many a lad from the famous old pit village - the birthplace of the Charlton brothers - he was still fantasising about playing football for Newcastle United.

"As far as the mental side goes, it is the task of both Durham and England to ensure he progresses at the right rate and to ease any problems," Cook said. "He is not alone in that. The consideration for every player is to give him his debut at the right time. A home series against Zimbabwe seems a good opportunity. I think he would enjoy the challenge."

Harmison's Durham debut could hardly have been more stressful. It came as a spindly 17-year-old in the final game of the 1996 season, a summer in which Durham failed to win a single game. They lost to Leicestershire by an innings and 251 runs and Harmison was pummelled so mercilessly by Phil Simmons that his nine overs cost 77 runs.

That winter he returned home early from the England Under-19 tour of Pakistan when a bout of homesickness was made worse by a back injury. He retreated to Ashington 2nd XI, playing as a batsman, and was largely forgotten, apart from by Cook, who regularly headed north to chat to his family and prompt him to attend a few indoor nets.

Only a freak accident for Simon Brown gave Harmison another opportunity in 1998. That winter, buoyed by the succinct promptings of David Boon, his Durham captain, to think like a fast bowler, he joined the England A tour to South Africa and Zimbabwe and became stronger as the tour progressed.

Frustratingly a knee injury prevented further monitoring with England A in New Zealand last winter but Cook believes Harmison has all the assets. "He is unlike most English fast bowlers," he says. "There is a lot of Bob Willis about him in his high bounce and awkward angle."

True fast bowlers, however, have rarely needed much motivation. The finest are fast bowlers to the depths of their soul. It might be the time to find out the truth about Steve Harmison.

webTitle: Ticket sales for Lord's test at all-time low

fields.headline: Ticket sales for Lord's test at all-time low
fields.trailText: Unless ticket sales pick up there will be a record low attendance for the opening day of a test at Lord's when England begin their two-match series against Zimbabwe next Thursday.
fields.body:
Unless ticket sales pick up there will be a record low attendance for the opening day of a test at Lord's when England begin their two-match series against Zimbabwe next Thursday.

Only 7,500 tickets have so far been sold for the first day with a figure of 10,000 for the second and third days. No tickets have been sold for the final two days. The record opening-day low attendance was in 1986 when only 11,854 turned up to watch the start of England's test against India.

The England and Wales Cricket Board has been attempting to put a brave face on the sluggish sales and claimed that it could represent a rare chance for "walk-up" spectators to pay at the gate.

An ECB spokesman said: "You can't turn up at football matches and pay at the gate so this is a great opportunity for people who do not normally stand a chance of getting into Lord's of buying a ticket for a test match."

Theories put forward to explain the poor sales ranged from bad weather, the long football season, the early start to the test series and a lack of awareness about Zimbabwe cricket in general or even that the country's first tour of England was taking place at all.

But there are no plans to increase publicity for the test series in the hope of boosting sales. ECB officials are hoping that word will spread on the amount of tickets available and that many fans will turn up and pay on the day.

The chief executive Tim Lamb said: "There are plenty of tickets available for next week's Zimbabwe test match and we would urge the wider cricket public to take advantage of this opportunity to come along and enjoy the unique atmosphere."

Yesterday staff answered a handful of calls in a valiant attempt to shift tickets priced at £18, £24, £28 and £32. "We've got thousands of them available," said one seller. "You can have as many as you want and sit where you want. Nobody is interested in this test match."

Normally, tickets for tests have to be purchased months in advance and many fans complain that they have been driven out by corporate guests who show more appreciation of the food and drink that is served up than they do of the cricket on show.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Unreadable attachment | Line trouble
fields.body:
This new fortnightly column is an experiment that may not last a week. What's more, its success or failure will owe a lot to you, and your problems. Ideally they will be general enough to interest other readers, and simple enough for answers to be short.

The reality, alas, may well be different. Many computer problems boil down to interactions of hardware and software that are so obscure that they've sometimes been blamed on the phases of the moon.

The number of possible combinations of hardware and software is so vast that they're bound to throw up problems that have never been seen before... and may never be seen again.

Since it would take forever to eliminate all possibilities, we often take what we hope will be the easy way out: reinstall the application that's causing us grief, reinstall the software drivers for the malfunctioning hardware, reinstall Microsoft Windows. It doesn't always work, but it doesn't take very long, so it's usually worth a go.

I'll try to offer more help than that here, but I don't have a hope if you don't provide basic information about your system. With Windows applications, the name and version number usually found in the Help| About box is a good start.

Unreadable attachment
I have Word 7 for Windows 95. Much of the time email attachments come through in a straightforward manner, but sometimes the message I get when I try either to view or save an attachment is "Word cannot start the converter Doswrd32.cnv". Can you give me any advice? Naomi Connelly
naomi.connelly@virgin.net

Jack: Microsoft Word probably can't start the converter - that is, run Doswrd32.cnv - because it isn't there. (Try looking for it using Start | Find Files or Folders.) That particular file is used to load files created with Microsoft Word for DOS versions 3.x to 6.0, so you could ask the person using that to send you plain text or use a different file format instead: Rich Text Format (.rtf) would be a good choice. Alternatively you could install the converter yourself, either from the Microsoft Office Converter Pack (run Setup.exe from the \PFiles\ORKTools\ToolBox\Tools\OCP\ folder on the Office 2000 Resource Kit CD-rom) or by downloading it from the Microsoft website at www.microsoft.com/office/ork/2000/appndx/toolbox.htm

Although Microsoft is widely criticised because not all its programs will load all types of file, it does offer a great collection of converters at www.microsoft.com/downloads

Line trouble
We have just up-graded our computer to a Hewlett-Packard Pavilion 8650. The PC we had before had a 33Kbps modem and connected at 31Kbps. However, despite having an 56Kbps modem, the new machine only connects at 26400 to 28800Kbps. We also have two phone lines at home, one for voice mail and the other for fax/internet use. Before, we had one line for both purposes, with no problems. Could you tell me what I should be doing to try and "up" the modem speed of the new machine? Peter Robinson
Robinson@bosinternet.com

Jack: It sounds as though BT has provided two lines by splitting the one you already had, using a Digital to Analogue Conversion System (DACS). This works fine for voice calls but, having only half the capacity, will give only half the data throughput. Beg BT on bended knee and you might get a real extra line, but I wouldn't bet on it.

Your options are to get a second line from another supplier if possible, such as a cable company, or pay BT a lot more money for its ISDN voice and data service, Home Highway.

Wake up call
About once a week of heavy usage this PC won't wake up from stand-by. I have to use reset to boot it. Any thoughts on how this might be corrected short of reinstalling Windows 98? Denis Postle
denis@postle.net

Jack: I had a similar problem with Advanced Power Management and "solved" it by using Start | Settings | Control Panel | Power Management to disable the feature altogether. You could try removing your screen saver, if any, and also see if there are more recent drivers for your graphics card and monitor, before re-installing Windows. However, you may be interested to hear that you can restart Windows 98 correctly even if there's no image on the screen. Simply press Ctrl + Esc to pop up the Start menu, press U to Shut Down Windows, press R for Restart and hit Enter. Do it fast enough and everyone will think you're a geek.

Could you tell me what I should be doing to try and "up" the modem speed of the new machine? Peter Robinson Robinson@bosinternet.com Jack: It sounds as though BT has provided two lines by splitting the one you already had, using a Digital to Analogue Conversion System (DACS). This works fine for voice calls but, having only half the capacity, will give only half the data throughput. Beg BT on bended knee and you might get a real extra line, but I wouldn't bet on it. Your options are to get a second line from another supplier if possible, such as a cable company, or pay BT a lot more money for its ISDN voice and data service, Home Highway. Wake up call About once a week of heavy usage this PC won't wake up from stand-by. I have to use reset to boot it. Any thoughts on how this might be corrected short of reinstalling Windows 98? Denis Postle denis@postle.net Jack: I had a similar problem with Advanced Power Management and "solved" it by using Start | Settings | Control Panel | Power Management to disable the feature altogether. You could try removing your screen saver, if any, and also see if there are more recent drivers for your graphics card and monitor, before re-installing Windows. However, you may be interested to hear that you can restart Windows 98 correctly even if there's no image on the screen. Simply press Ctrl + Esc to pop up the Start menu, press U to Shut Down Windows, press R for Restart and hit Enter. Do it fast enough and everyone will think you're a geek.

fields.headline: Sierra Leone relives its terror
fields.trailText: The surge of foreboding among Freetown's long-suffering citizens is not made any easier by the realisation that their peninsula city is little better than a sprawling trap.
fields.body:
The surge of foreboding among Freetown's long-suffering citizens is not made any easier by the realisation that their peninsula city is little better than a sprawling trap.

Foreigners may scan the skies for rescue helicopters, but there is nowhere for Sierra Leoneans to run if Foday Sankoh and his Revolutionary United Front rebels fight on after the shooting at a peaceful protest on Monday. Four died and a city was left in terror of the consequences.

The West African country, brutalised by a cruel civil war that ended last year with the signing of an uneasy peace accord in the Togo capital, Lomé, is being forced to relive its fears after seven United Nations peacekeepers were killed and more than 300 went missing in rebel-held territory last week.

For now, Freetown's streets are controlled by what passes for a government army - partially trained, partially disciplined and only partially concerned about whom it kills.

UN and British troops are in abundance, tearing through the city in four-wheel-drive vehicles with blue stickers and Union flags, and offering a fleeting feeling of security. But people wonder whom they are here to protect, and if they will leave once all the white foreigners are evacuated.

No one in the capital needs reminding of what happened last time the RUF attacked. Just 16 months ago the rebels seized the east of the city and set about hacking the heads off the government's servants. The amputations by machete, gang rapes and abductions of young boys and girls as fighters or sex slaves are fresh in the city's memory.

Just in case Mr Sankoh was unaware of the brutalities perpetrated by his men, among the protesters at his gate on Monday were several small children waving stumps where once there were hands or arms.

Thousands of people joined the "peace demonstration" to Mr Sankoh's home to demand his rebels release about 500 UN peacekeepers being held hostage. They carried placards reading, "We want peace" and chanted, "Sankoh, Sankoh, you have a bad mind." As the march snaked through the city it grew in size. Many shops and businesses closed in solidarity - or because they feared the consequences.

It was a remarkable act of defiance. For 10 minutes they lobbed slogans outside the gate of the RUF leader's home. Then some switched to stones.

The gunfire that rattled from the house was not designed to deter. It was aimed to kill. Some of the rebels had rocket-propelled grenades. The crowd fled as screams competed with the thud of firing. Some were killed execution-style.

It was not long before the calls started coming in to selected homes from the British high commission, telling them it was time to go. The BBC World Service, listened to slavishly in Sierra Leone, told British citizens to head for the main evacuation point, the Mamy Yoko beach hotel. There were two lines at the gate: Brits and The Others.

Squaddies outside told people which line to get into. The Brits line included European Union citizens, those from the Commonwealth - so long as it was a country with a recog nisable name - and Americans. The rest, mostly Lebanese, shouted denunciations about discrimination.

Most of the evacuees were headed across the river to the relative safety of Lungi international airport, protected by hundreds of British paratroopers. RAF Hercules aircraft flew in on Tuesday to start evacuating more than 850 foreign nationals in the biggest military operation since the Kosovo conflict. The UN has ordered 266 of its civilian personnel to leave the country.

A Royal Navy taskforce was also heading for Sierra Leone this week.

Africa watchers warned last year that Mr Sankoh would not honour the Togo peace deal. When the UN began to deploy last December, replacing Ecomog, a Nigerian-led force, it rapidly became clear that the demobilisation camps where RUF fighters were expected to disarm would be impossible to organise. Disputes developed over UN "incursions" into RUF-held territory, especially the diamond-producing areas that hold the key to Sierra Leone's wealth - and its misery.

Any failure in Sierra Leone will cast doubt on Washington's current effort to put together a UN peacekeeping force for the Congo, where a war of even bigger dimensions is raging.

fields.headline: Nuba face destruction
fields.trailText: In a few weeks, barring miracles, the children in this region of southern Sudan will begin to die - if not from hunger, then from disease. Most families are living in the open, without clothes, blankets or clean water. The mud hut that calls itself a hospital contains nothing but flies. The young man in charge, a farmer-turned-health worker, says 200 children and 50 old people are already in urgent need of medical care. He is treating them with tree leaves and bark, but he needs anti-malarials and antibiotics.
fields.body:
In a few weeks, barring miracles, the children in this region of southern Sudan will begin to die - if not from hunger, then from disease. Most families are living in the open, without clothes, blankets or clean water. The mud hut that calls itself a hospital contains nothing but flies. The young man in charge, a farmer-turned-health worker, says 200 children and 50 old people are already in urgent need of medical care. He is treating them with tree leaves and bark, but he needs anti-malarials and antibiotics.

Less than a year after international pressure forced Sudan's Islamist government to allow United Nations relief into the Nuba mountains for the first time in more than a decade, Khartoum is attempting to put the Nuba beyond the reach of relief by cutting off all access to the mountains and starving civilians out of areas controlled by the rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

In the past two months, moving in whenever United Nations teams move out, government forces have captured two of the three rough airstrips that make relief operations possible and have mounted a surprise assault on some of the Nuba's most productive land around the village of Tabanya.

The UN's silence has been almost as shocking to the Nuba as the attack on Tabanya that displaced 15,000 people and propelled them towards Kadoro - a mountain village of 150 families that has shared its own meagre supplies for more than a month and now has nothing more to offer.

"The UN's own first mission to the mountains was heavily shelled - but it has never said a word of criticism of the government," said Walid Hamed, assistant to a rebel commander, Yusuf Kuwa. "When it comes to the government, the UN is on its knees. All we are asking is equal treatment so people can decide freely whether they stay in SPLA areas or go to the government."

The Nuba are in their 13th year of struggle for a democratic, secular state in which the country's African south would be the equal of its Arab north. Since the fundamentalist generals of the National Islamic Front came to power in 1989, an attempt to defeat the Nuba rebellion has grown into a scorched-earth holy war of annihilation against a people whose tradition of political and religious tolerance threatens the Front's whole project of a conformist Islamic extremism.

Today hundreds of thousands of Nuba starved out of the mountains are imprisoned in "peace villages" where men are armed and compelled to fight against fellow Nuba; where children are separated from their parents and conscripted into Islamic militias; where women are raped to dilute Nuba ethnicity.

Nuba who refuse to leave SPLA-controlled areas are being driven off the fertile plains and into the mountains where survival is a struggle. Even the UN acknowledges that women venturing down to the government-controlled plains to fetch water and mangoes are subjected to rape "often of the most horrendous kind".

As evidence of human rights abuses piles up, the government promises relief but fights with the oldest, and cruellest, weapon in its arsenal - hunger.

Rahila Kuku, a mother of five, was put to work gathering in the sorghum that was thick in the fields surrounding Tabanya at the time of the attack on the village on March 17. She says hundreds of prisoners, working at gunpoint, stripped the sorghum fields bare and loaded every grain on to trucks bound for government garrisons in other parts of the mountains.

Rahila escaped to Kadoro after being raped repeatedly over a month, but at the hospital has found only words of comfort - not the painkillers she wants. She says her body still hurts from the beatings she received and her breasts are sore. She suspects she is pregnant.

Phoebe Tutu fled to Kadoro with nine children and a jerrycan when the first government troops attacked Tabanya. Forced off Kadoro mountain by hunger, she joined a group of 30 women foraging for food on the edge of government-controlled areas a four-hour walk away. The women were ambushed and four died. Phoebe was shot and wounded. Reduced to one small plate of sorghum a day, all her children are suffering from diarrhoea.

The government's capture of Toro airstrip near Tabanya has put the displaced almost beyond the reach of help. The nearest airstrip is now 120km away - a three-day trek up granite mountains and down valleys where water holes are drying up and government troops lay ambushes for defenceless civilians.

"At one stroke, the attack on Tabanya has cut people off from their harvest and also from easy access from outside," said Paul Savage of the British charity Christian Aid. "It now takes a huge logistical effort across insecure and dangerous areas to bring the smallest amount of help to the displaced. This is a planned and purposeful undermining of the Nuba's resilience and capacity to cope and exist."

Zakariah Suleiman, an elderly farmer, was among those captured in the Tabanya offensive. For three days he was forced to work for the government forces. "They burned all the far sorghum and collected all the near sorghum," he said. "They sent us out every day in large groups protected by soldiers. This is their weapon against us: hunger. They have taken everything from Tabanya - sorghum, beans and maize. Nothing is left."

Like Rahila Kuku, Suleiman succeeded in escaping from Tabanya and fled to Kadoro - fully aware that he was running from hunger to hunger.

"I'm happy to be here whether I find food or not," he said. "I have left everything behind, but I don't care if I'm naked or clothed. Here I can go wherever I want to without asking for permission . . . I may die of hunger here, but I'll die free - not penned in like an animal." The Observer

webTitle: Just a phone call away from disaster

fields.headline: Just a phone call away from disaster
fields.trailText: It began the usual way, with a late night phone call. "Are you available? Are you interested?" an urgent voice asked. "Yes," Nicola Adams answered without hesitation. The next morning, the 25-year-old public health engineer told her boss at Ove Arup she'd be away for three months. She packed her bags and boarded the first flight to Mozambique, to her "other life".
fields.body:
It began the usual way, with a late night phone call. "Are you available? Are you interested?" an urgent voice asked. "Yes," Nicola Adams answered without hesitation. The next morning, the 25-year-old public health engineer told her boss at Ove Arup she'd be away for three months. She packed her bags and boarded the first flight to Mozambique, to her "other life".

Adams is one of more than 1,000 professional engineers, environmental health workers, water specialists and, more recently, logisticians, project managers and accountants, who are members of Engineers for Disaster Relief - or RedR. They are ready to leave families and secure jobs for three to six months to go on emergency missions with frontline humanitarian agencies such as Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières, in regions devastated by war, floods, earthquakes and other disasters.

In Mozambique Adams is tackling temporary housing and water purification for thousands of refugees. Last year she worked with Oxfam in Albania, preparing water and sanitation facilities for refugees. It was her first mission. "Setting up the camps was a daunting task because of the state of the refugees and the local resources available," she says. "I had to learn very quickly."

Like Adams's boss at Ove Arup, many firms feel they benefit by letting their staff work overseas either on unpaid or subsidised leave, as it provides them with an unmatched level of experience.

RedR was founded in 1979 by Peter Guthrie, a British engineer who worked for Oxfam in Vietnamese refugee camps in Malaysia. He saw that engineers could make an important contribution to emergency work, along with medical staff, but that relief agencies had a hard time recruiting them. Back in England, he decided to create a register of specialists who were available and suitable for humanitarian relief work.

Prospective RedR members are carefully screened not only for their professional experience but also commitment to humanitarian work and, more importantly, personal qualities. Jerome Oberreit, RedR recruitment and placement manager, says: "We are looking for people who are flexible, able to work in a team and under pressure, relate well with people from different cultures and adapt to different environments."

They also have to be able to take on responsibilities quickly, deal with bureaucracy and corruption, and understand the mandate of the organisation they work for, he says.

There are currently about 200 RedR members in the Balkans, Sierra Leone, East Timor, Sudan, Tibet and many other countries, and the charity is increasingly trying to bring training courses on site and recruit local experts abroad. "The idea is to have people who know the area, the system and the problems," Oberreit explains. "They are able to cope better with the language and culture, and they can hit the ground faster. It's not just North helping South, but South helping South."

webTitle: Cost of drink abuse put at £3.3bn

fields.headline: Cost of drink abuse put at £3.3bn
fields.trailText: Alcohol abuse is costing the British economy £3.3bn a year, with the majority swallowed up through premature death, unemployment and drink related illnesses, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Alcohol abuse is costing the British economy £3.3bn a year, with the majority swallowed up through premature death, unemployment and drink related illnesses, according to a report published today.

Britain's Ruin, published by Alcohol Concern, also highlights a 50% increase over the past two years in the number of women drinking above the recommended daily amount, as well as the fact that between 60% and 70% of men who assault their partners do so under the influence of drink.

According to the report, £2.8bn is lost by industry every year through sickness absence, unemployment and alcohol related deaths.

The NHS spends £200m every year treating drink related illnesses, while road accidents where drink is a factor account for a further £189m.

Alcohol related deaths officially recorded by hospitals have increased by a third, from around 3,000 in 1986 to approximately 5,000 in 1997, although the report claims that the real number of all deaths connected with alcohol misuse is closer to 33,000.

Criminal activity linked with alcohol abuse costs the taxpayer another £68m, while 41% of violent crimes, including assaults and muggings, are committed by somebody who has been drinking.

Other findings link alcohol with 65% of suicide attempts and 23% of child neglect calls to national helplines.

Another trend identified by the study is alcohol abuse involving children. Among 11 to 15-year-olds who drink, the mean weekly consumption has risen from 5.3 units in 1990 to 9.9 units two years ago.

Among proposals which Alcohol Concern wants to see adopted are a cut in the drink-drive limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood.

webTitle: Home a thousand miles from home

fields.headline: Home a thousand miles from home
fields.standfirst: Lost White Tribes: Journeys Among the Forgotten by Riccardo Orizio, Secker & Warburg 270pp £15.99
fields.trailText: Some years ago Molly Dineen made a wonderful TV documentary called Home From The Hill. It charted the homecoming of Hilary Hook, who for 40 years had served as a colonial administrator in the highlands of Kenya. Now, returning from the tropics to a London suburb, he floundered about his kitchen struggling to work out how to use a tin opener. Profumo, pop music, non-stick frying pans - all these had passed him by. He was home, but not at home.
fields.body:
Some years ago Molly Dineen made a wonderful TV documentary called Home From The Hill. It charted the homecoming of Hilary Hook, who for 40 years had served as a colonial administrator in the highlands of Kenya. Now, returning from the tropics to a London suburb, he floundered about his kitchen struggling to work out how to use a tin opener. Profumo, pop music, non-stick frying pans - all these had passed him by. He was home, but not at home.

Younger viewers in particular, who thought of colonialism as a backdrop to the costume dramas of the early 1980s, found it strange to watch someone who was both a product and an agent of such an antique world order. Here was a man who saw modern life as a foreign country: this twinkling octogenarian came across as a time-traveller. After all, doesn't colonialism belong to some other, long-gone universe?

Not according to Riccardo Orizio, the Italian journalist who has produced Lost White Tribes, a superb and beguiling work in which he travels in search of the long-forgotten descendants of those Europeans who voyaged to the colonies and, unlike Hook, never came back. These include Dutch burghers in Sri Lanka; German workers and acrobats who sailed to Jamaica after Abolition and ended up as slaves themselves; American confederates from Texas and Alabama who fled to Brazil after the Civil War, hoping to fashion a new Dixieland out of the cotton and slaves available to them there; and Polish soldiers sent to quell the slave rebellions in the French colony of Saint-Domingue at the start of the 19th century, and who ended up fighting on the side of the insurgent Haitians.

Most of these groups are missing from both hipster tour guides and the colonial archive. Often they've become apocryphal creatures within their own countries, mistaken for missionaries or dismissed - correctly, in the case of the Blancs Matignon in Guadeloupe - as incestuous peasants. They're torn between the desire to be heard - to reach out to a wider world that might rescue them from penury - and a survivalist suspicion that their long-guarded secrets may be exploited by novelty-chasing outsiders. So they teeter on in straitened circumstances: many Germans died from disease or malnutrition when they first arrived in 19th-century Jamaica, and their descendants, still straggly and emaciated, were deemed just right to play prisoners when the film Papillon was shot there.

This is emphatically not a history of the white colonial elites. Orizio's white tribes may live in the shadow of opulent resorts or Great House plantations, but their own communities can often be reached only by pot-holed mud tracks. The Poles in Casales live in dried mud houses on a treeless mountain. They have no electricity, running water or school; their church collapsed years ago.

Orizio finds that these dispersed communities have much in common, chiefly a fear of extinction (the Basters of Namibia have had their land confiscated and are forced to speak English rather than Afrikaans at school) and an ambivalence towards miscegenation. An ambience of embattled loneliness hovers over most of them.

Orizio does not try to weave these disconnected peoples' complex political and historical trajectories into a single grandiose theory: he's fascinated by poignant specificities, the enigma of each arrival. Warmly solicitous but never sentimentalising, the book bears comparison with such masterpieces about migration as Nicholas Lemann's The Promised Land, and John Berger and Jean Mohr's A Seventh Man.
