fields.headline: Ravelstein by Saul Bellow
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to Saul Bellow's long-awaited Ravelstein
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Saul Bellow's Ravelstein has been treated less as a novel than a minor miracle: a cause more for celebration than criticism. That an 85-year-old should produce a novel at all was regarded as remarkable; that it should be passably good little short of sensational.
fields.body:
Saul Bellow's Ravelstein has been treated less as a novel than a minor miracle: a cause more for celebration than criticism. That an 85-year-old should produce a novel at all was regarded as remarkable; that it should be passably good little short of sensational.

"Just when we didn't expect it, there now wonderfully comes a large new novel from the master," wrote Malcolm Bradbury in the Times, at the conclusion of a review that started sensibly but ended on a cloud of euphoric tosh: "Our world is a world of ideas, pervaded by minds, thoughts, notions, beyond which lies what we seek with such difficulty: wholeness, silence and love. Via print, Ravelstein survives; and Bellow survives. So does fiction itself."

James Wood, in a profile of Bellow in the Guardian, was equally delighted at the appearance of his first full-length novel for 13 years, but happily more prosaic in expressing his welcome: "How extraordinary that Bellow's substantial new novel should be so full of the old, cascading power, its prose displaying that august raciness one remembers from Herzog (1964) and Humboldt's Gift (1975), darting with metaphor and wit... Who are the other great writers who have done anything like this in their 80s? Tolstoy's late stories, I guess. Otherwise, I can only think of Thomas Mann."

The book is a fact-into-fiction exploration of the life of Bellow's great friend, Allan Bloom - a conservative intellectual and polemicist, the defender of absolute cultural values in a relativistic age - who died of Aids in 1997.

"Ravelstein covers only the last years of the hero's life," said John Sutherland in the Sunday Times. "Nothing very much happens except hospitals and talk. A lot of Ravelstein is like overhearing two old codgers rabbit on about what it is like to be two old codgers. They reminisce, bicker, and tell, yet again, their favourite Jewish jokes."

But behind the gossipy form were some big themes. "The novel explores, in its attractively rambling way, two dauntingly large and touchy themes: death and American Jewishness," said Sutherland. "The first half of the narrative describes Ravelstein's [the Bloom character's] struggle with full-blown Aids. 'What is it to die?' the old men ask each other. 'No more pictures' is the best they can come up with. The second half of the novel chronicles Chick's [the Bellow character's] own struggle with the grim reaper after consuming some toxic fish in the tropics... Not quite American (as the Canadian-born Jew, Bellow, is not quite American), Abe Ravelstein is the American mind and Bellow its finest living (thank God) voice. We should all have such friends."

In his profile, Wood quoted Bellow's defence of the hybrid form of memoir novel: "There is a strange literalism that's become a habit in America. People only want the factual truth. Well, the truth is that Allan was a very superior person, great-souled. When people proclaim the death of the novel, I sometimes think they are really saying that there are no significant people to write about. Allan was certainly one. Yet I can't help being a fiction-writer. It's a curious process. Life is obviously feeding you, yet Ravelstein is a composite, taken from 100 different streams, like all of my characters."

Galen Strawson, in the Financial Times, defended Bellow from charges that the portrait of Bloom did his friend a disservice. "When the first chapter of Ravelstein was published in the New Yorker last November, some said Bellow should not have 'outed' Bloom in this way, and Bellow was troubled by this reaction," wrote Strawson. "But he has in fact no reason to worry before the gods, or before Bloom for that matter, and at bottom he knows it. In the event he has got the whole thing right."

The need to explain the autobiographical aspects of the book and sketch in Bloom's cultural significance left some reviewers too little space to tell us what they actually thought of it. William Leith, for one. "I almost forgot to say that Ravelstein is a brilliant novel," he said breathlessly at the end of his review in the Independent on Sunday.

It takes courage to knock an 85-year-old, especially one who has won the Nobel Prize for literature and is by general consent America's finest novelist, but Justin Cartwright did just that in the Sunday Telegraph. "How do you assess a book, by one of the greatest writers of our time, which should perhaps never have been published?", he asked challengingly. "Most of Bellow's lightness and irony have been lost in a welter of repetitive and often tedious descriptions of Ravelstein's uniqueness, which we must take more or less on trust. The persistent preoccupation of all Bellow's work - the determinedly intellectual man's attempts to engage with the American material world - here falls horribly flat."

But it would be churlish to end on a downbeat note. Anthony Russell, in the Mail on Sunday, had some doubts about the book too, but in overcoming them he approached the generosity of tone towards this (in Leith's words) "late, late Bellow" that characterised most of the coverage.

"One of the peculiarities of Ravelstein is that it is both an old man's novel, much preoccupied with the imminence of death, and a book which plays games with the whole idea of an old man's novel," said Russell. "Ostensibly, the narrative drifts about in a hazy, at times even slightly gaga, sort of way. But while there are definite signs of frailty, one feels he's also having a good deal of fun with readers' assumptions about his state of health... Ravelstein may not be great Bellow - the structure is a little too wobbly for that - but in terms of richness of metaphor, fecundity of ideas and sheer undiminished curiosity, there's still no one to beat him."

webTitle: Catholic to head Ulster civil service

fields.headline: Catholic to head Ulster civil service
fields.trailText:
Northern Ireland's civil service, long seen as a bastion of
                                                  Protestant bias, is to be headed for the first time by a Catholic,
                                                  it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's civil service, long seen as a bastion of Protestant bias, is to be headed for the first time by a Catholic, it was announced yesterday.

Gerry Loughran, 58, permanent secretary at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Industry, is to succeed John Temple, 59, who retires in the summer. He has a no-nonsense approach, which some ministers have disliked in the past.

The announcement underlined the change afoot in Northern Ireland and the appointment was backed by Ulster Unionists.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, and SDLP deputy leader, Seamus Mallon, approved the decision. They will be Mr Loughran's chiefs as first and deputy first ministers if devolution returns, as the government hopes, on May 22.

Sir Reg Empey, a leading Ulster Unionist, welcomed the decision. He worked with Mr Loughran while he was trade minister in the executive.

Mr Loughran, who declined requests for interviews yesterday, will be in charge of 23,000 workers and the biggest employer in Northern Ireland. He will attempt to knit together the work of the 10 government departments.

Three years ago Mr Loughran lost out on the most powerful non-political post in Northern Ireland government after he was pulled into a row with Lady Denton, a Tory minister, over allegations of sectarianism. She denied accusations that she was trying to scupper his chances, but the job went to Mr Temple.

webTitle: Lara to tour England after all

fields.headline: Lara to tour England after all
fields.trailText: In a decision as spectacular as one of his flashing cover drives, Brian Lara has decided he will tour England with the West Indies after all.
fields.body:
In a decision as spectacular as one of his flashing cover drives, Brian Lara has decided he will tour England with the West Indies after all.

Roger Skerrett, West Indies tour manager, confirmed that Lara, who holds the record for the highest individual Test and first-class scores, will come to England this summer - in spite of reports that he would miss the trip and was ready to retire from international cricket.

Skerrett said that Lara, 31, had been concerned about his mother's illness but added that having seen her he was satisfied that she "was a little better" and had decided to undertake the tour.

In a prepared statement Lara said: "I am pleased to inform you that I will be available for the upcoming tour of England. I am looking forward to the tour of England and I wish to thank the board for their understanding. My family circumstances have not changed but I have put in place arrangements while I am away,"

Skerrett, explaining the circumstances behind Lara's agonising decision over whether or not to tour England, said: "Brian Lara's mother is ill. That was why, on the spur of the moment, he initially made himself unavailable.

"Since then he has had discussions with people close to him and has made himself available again. He is fully committed to West Indies cricket," he added.

webTitle: Switch cash to cities, Rogers tells Labour

fields.headline: Switch cash to cities, Rogers tells Labour
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A government urban task force led by the international architect, Lord Rogers of Riverside, will next week challenge New Labour's fragile "one nation" coalition by urging Tony Blair to divert Whitehall funds from rich parts of England to poor cities.
fields.body:
A government urban task force led by the international architect, Lord Rogers of Riverside, will next week challenge New Labour's fragile "one nation" coalition by urging Tony Blair to divert Whitehall funds from rich parts of England to poor cities.

In a report certain to be seized upon by restless backbenchers after Labour's dismal local election showing last week, ministers will be warned that they cannot avoid tough political choices if provincial cities and towns are to be turned round.

The report highlights growing concern by Lord Rogers over delays in responding to key recommendations from his task force, published in a blaze of publicity 11 months ago.

With English cities performing well below Continental counterparts in the European wealth league, Lord Rogers called for a national crusade to improve the quality of urban life and create more jobs. Sources say next week's report will bluntly tell the government that the diversion of resources into "stressed" urban areas at the expense of more prosperous parts of the country cannot be "ducked" any longer.

The report marks the opening shots in a campaign to press the Treasury and Downing Street for hundreds of millions of extra funding for urban regeneration in Gordon Brown's forthcoming three-year comprehensive spending review. While the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has largely backed Lord Rogers' recommendations - which included low-tax zones in special urban priority areas - the task force is concerned that the government machine remains sceptical.

fields.headline: Straw's brother charged with assault
fields.trailText: The home secretary's brother has been charged with common assault on a teenage girl.
fields.body:
The home secretary's brother has been charged with common assault on a teenage girl.

Police said that 46-year-old William Straw was arrested in Nottingham last night after they were called to his house in the Bramcote area of the city at 9.45pm on Wednesday.

Mr Straw spent several hours in the cells at Beeston police station, during which he was questioned by officers, and he was later charged with common assault. He was bailed pending an appearance before Nottingham magistrates on Monday May 15.

Neighbours said the arrest had been very low key. "I was at home last night and I did not hear a thing," said retired engineer John Maud.

He added: "You do not expect the police to turn up to arrest someone who is supposed to be a pillar of the community."

Another neighbour said that Mr Straw had been upset since his wife left him before Christmas.

In March this year he walked into Beeston police station and told officers he wanted to confess to committing a serious sexual assault on a 14-year-old boy. He was seen by a police surgeon and declared fit for interview before making a confession which he later declared was a "cry for help". Mr Straw was not charged when an investigation by Nottinghamshire police failed to find evidence.

Mr Straw is regional secretary of the Open University in Nottingham.

fields.headline: Perth, Play-offs and Pennants
fields.trailText: WHY AYE, IT'S ALMOST LIKE A FOREIGN COUNTRY!
fields.body:
WHY AYE, IT'S ALMOST LIKE A FOREIGN COUNTRY!

"How big is this for Australian soccer? One of the biggest names in the world game is coming to play for the Western Australian State champions!" babbled an excited Joondalup manager Paul Simmons earlier today, before undermining his argument by sheepishly admitting the man he had in mind was Geordie waster Paul Gascoigne.

But no sooner had Gazza worked out how to put his Aussie for beginners tape ("Wye eye me wongas!") into the car stereo, than his proposed summer move to Oz was elbowed into touch by a furious Bryan Robson. "I couldn't believe what I was hearing this morning," spluttered the Boro boss. "I was sitting having my breakfast watching Sky Sports News," well, it was Claire Tomlinson presenting, "when this guy came on and did a 10-minute interview about one of my players. I have never even heard of them, let alone talked to them."

The rest of the planet may take that as the end, but the Fiver, ever mindful of the role Gazza could play in the 2002 World Cup, certainly doesn't. So we phoned deepest Joondalup to assess the state of play. "There's plenty of stuff to do here," publicity officer Laurie Brennan told us, in between popping another snag or two on the barbie. "There's good fishing, plenty of nice beaches, and some lovely looking Shelias too. I am sure he would fit in well."

The Fiver still isn't convinced and inquires as to the availability of Gazza's beloved Newky Broon. "Don't worry mate," Laurie reassured us, "there's a English pub called the Old Bailey - it's got as much of that dark brown stuff as he'll ever need." If Five Bellies comes along for the ride, the Fiver doubts that somehow - but Laurie tells us the bright lights of Perth are only 25 kilometres away. Mel Stein, clinch that deal!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

YOU'RE THE DADDY NOW!

The Euro, the fruit of the Fiver's Euro 2000 loins, is swimming free. It's brought to you in association with breathe, and will impregnate your intray each morning, keeping you up to date with everything that goes on in the lowlands this summer. To face up to your responsibilities and do the honourable thing, send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line.

By the way, if you get a incomprehensible mail back, blame our software. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, you're fine.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JUVE GOT BE JOKING

You've got to hand it to the Italians. Two seasons ago, there was a ruck in parliament after Ronaldo was denied a penalty in Internazionale's title showdown with Juventus. Last year, a nation's eyebrows were raised in unison at the number of late winners scored by champions AC Milan. This year, it's the scandal of Cannavaro's disallowed equaliser - which could lead to the first Serie A playoff since 1964. It's enough to make you renounce Catherine Cookson forever.

And none of it would have happened without referee Massimo de Santis. De Santis it was who blew up for pushing as Cannavaro nodded in his injury time goal for Parma against Juventus on Sunday. De Santis it was who immediately gave a press conference to claim he had stopped play for an infringement before Cannavaro had touched the ball - despite video evidence to the contrary. De Santis it was who received death threats and, this afternoon, a five-hour grilling from the Italian FA. Poor man.

The Italian FA hasn't reported yet, but it's left everybody doubting the result. So hurrah for club secretary Antonio Giraudo, who today put his weight behind a league decider. "I would prefer a play-off," he said. "This way all the insinuations would go away and we can find out who is the better team."

This may go down well with mouthy Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti, who has already announced his side "moral winners" of the Scudetto. Although perhaps it would be wise not to put too much stock in the words of the man who today declared his intention to bring £31m Christian Vieri back to Rome a season after he sold him to Internazionale. Those crazy Mediterraneans.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have heard it said that England are not going to get through the first round but I think they will achieve that comfortably and eventually they will win" - Fifa executive David Will on the 2006 World Cup bid. Just in case you were wondering, Mr Will is British.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OLD STORY

Some people don't know what to do with themselves once they retire. They either potter about the garden, try to force whole packets of Werther's Original down the throats of frightened children, or lie about in a cold bath all day waiting for someone to rescue them. But you won't catch Alex Ferguson OAP doing any of those things - because when he turns 60 and jacks it in at Old Trafford, he's got more plans than you can shake a stopwatch at in an aggressive manner.

Having already decided to become a roving ambassador for Manchester United - selling strips in shanty towns, pinning pennants on peasants, etc. - Alex the antique has now announced he intends to turn Scotland into a world power. "Other managers contact me all the time for advice and if Scotland were to ask when I retired I'd be delighted to help. I'm still a very partisan Scot," he told the Record today as he sharpened his claymore with a stale shortbread round.

"By the time I chuck it, Craig Brown and I will be heading into the sunset together," he predicted, suggesting he won't be throwing his bunnet in the ring when the respected Scotland boss eventually steps down. "There would be no question of a position," Fergie insisted. "Let me emphasise my advice would be free and it would be pleasant to help a young manager." webTitle: Inquiry finds strong evidence of CPS racism

fields.headline: Inquiry finds strong evidence of CPS racism
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Strong evidence of institutional racism exists in the crown prosecution service, an independent inquiry into allegations of race discrimination against CPS staff concludes in a preliminary report today.
fields.body:
Strong evidence of institutional racism exists in the crown prosecution service, an independent inquiry into allegations of race discrimination against CPS staff concludes in a preliminary report today.

Black and Asian staff are seriously under-represented in senior jobs and have been left to languish for years in low grade posts without any action by managers, says Sylvia Denman, chairman of Camden and Islington health authority.

Ms Denman, a leading Afro-Caribbean academic lawyer, was called in by the CPS in January to carry out an inquiry and stave off a threatened formal investigation by the commission for racial equality after a flood of race discrimination claims by ethnic minority lawyers. Since 1993 staff have launched 22 claims, and last October a tribunal made the third finding of race discrimination against the service in less than a year.

David Calvert-Smith, director of public prosecutions, said: "This is a hard-hitting report which makes uncomfortable reading for all managers in the CPS. I have said many times that I will not tolerate racism, which is why diversity is a key aim in our business plans this year.

"I am determined that equality and diversity will be woven into the fabric and ethos of the CPS so that we become a truly diverse organisation."

Ms Denman, who will deliver a final report later this year, said it would be "precipitate" to reach a firm conclusion on institutional racism in her preliminary report. "However, the evidence given so far to the inquiry, seen in the light of the persistent pattern of under-representation of ethnic minorities at higher grades and the serious findings of discrimination made against the CPS by employment tribunals, provides strong prima facie evidence that some forms of race discrimination and institutional racism have operated to the disadvantage of black and Asian staff."

Last February, a tribunal awarded a record £30,000 for injury to feelings to Maria Bamieh, a crown prosecutor, after finding that the CPS wanted to "rub her nose in the dirt" following her two earlier successful claims for race discrimination and victimisation. The tribunal said the service's conduct fell below the standard "we would have expected of a corner shop".

Ms Denman suggested barriers to recruitment and promotion for ethnic minority lawyers might be due to the dominance of a clique of white managers, the discriminatory conduct of promotion boards, and a lack of sensitivity by management to race issues. These will have to be examined in more detail before firm conclusions are reached. Barriers to recruitment undoubtedly operate in some areas, which have no or virtually no black staff, she said.

Many ethnic minority staff believed they had been discriminated against - far more than those who had lodged formal grievances or taken cases to tribunals. "There is a particularly strong perception that white managers have discriminated in relation to the advancement and promotion of black and Asian staff."

Ms Denman said recent statements and action plans by management "lack coherence and are heavy on ambitious declarations of intent". There was "a tendency within the service to overreact and panic in the face of allegations of race discrimination".

Faced with the evidence, managers continued to deny that there was racism. "When confronted with the statistical evidence, their first reaction was to seek an 'innocent' explanation. It is a matter of concern that there was a noticeable reluctance on the part of some managers to contemplate the possibility of a serious problem."

webTitle: Bragg bests Coetzee in final prize

fields.headline: Bragg bests Coetzee in final prize
fields.standfirst: Buy The Soldier's Return from BOL at 10% off
fields.trailText: Melvyn Bragg's The Soldier's Return has beaten JM Coetzee's much-feted Disgrace, winner of the Booker and Commonwealth awards, in the 42nd and final WH Smith Literary Award.
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg's The Soldier's Return has beaten JM Coetzee's much-feted Disgrace, winner of the Booker and Commonwealth awards, in the 42nd and final WH Smith Literary Award.

Bragg's novel is set in the aftermath of the second world war, as the hero returns from Burma to rural England to be reunited with his wife and son, and charts their struggle to pick up the pieces of their war-shattered lives.

John Carey, chair of a judging panel which also included writers Ken Follett and Lucy Hughes-Hallett and critic Mark Lawson, said it "draws on personal memories, but raises problems that still concern us - family breakdown, fatherhood, the nature of masculinity."

This will be the last year of the Literary Award, which from 2001 will become the WH Smith Book Prize. The new prize will be awarded over a number of categories, including first books, children's books and lifestyle, and the public will be invited to vote on the category shortlists.

The Soldier's Return is released in paperback on May 18.

webTitle: Mobile phone safety debate left up in the air

fields.headline: Mobile phone safety debate left up in the air
fields.standfirst:
Science correspondent James Meek finds a report on the issue is hedged about with doubt and caution
Mobile Phones and Health - read the report
fields.trailText: Science correspondent James Meek finds a report on the issue is hedged about with doubt and caution
fields.body:
The real meat of today's report on the safety of mobile phones is contained in a 66-page section in the middle headed "scientific evidence."

The investigators have spent months trawling through mounds of existing literature on the topic - scientific research on everything from birth rates of mice kept near a forest of radio transmitters in Greece to the effects of radio waves on the Polish army.

For anyone seeking a clear answer to the question "Are mobiles dangerous?" their conclusions are disappointingly vague. Time and time again the phrases "little evidence", "contradictory findings" and "no persuasive evidence" crop up.

None of this means that mobiles are unequivocally safe. Perhaps the most telling recommendations of the report are the urgings that more research should be done - for instance, a study of people who have been using mobiles continuously since their early, clunky days in the 1980s.

Scientists are simply not yet ready to give mobiles a clean bill of health. They do not want to replicate the devastating scientific and political fallout from the BSE crisis, when another scientific panel, the Southwood Committee, concluded that there was no risk to the public. So today's report, while generally saying that mobiles are valuable tools and OK to use, is hedged about with doubt and caution.

The nub of the doubt is that the radio waves produced by mobiles are not powerful enough to produce what is called a significant "thermal effect" in the human brain - in other words, they heat brain cells by a fraction of a degree, far less than their natural temperature variation in the course of an ordinary day.

But the nagging question remains whether radio waves, in a manner as yet unknown, can generate harmful changes in brain cells without heating them.

One experiment suggests they can. Tests on a primitive creature called a nematode worm show that radio waves can cause certain genes to be "switched on", although these can generally only be switched on by stress.

If radio waves can do that, what more could they do? scientists wonder. Hence the call for more research, and the advice to warn the children to ease off on mobile yakking.

In the long term, today's report is likely to have an impact on the risk versus usefulness debate about mobiles similar to that of past warnings about sunshine or coffee: a reminder that moderation is all, and that over-use of a pleasant or useful thing may be risky.

The report does nothing to demonise the mobile as a powerful new threat to public health - except in one distinct area, that of using a mobile while driving.

"There is strong experimental evidence that engaging in a mobile phone conversation impairs drivers' ability to react to potentially hazardous road situations," it says. "The impairment appears to be greater than that associated with merely listening to a radio  and is unaffected by mode of phone use, handheld or hands-free."

fields.headline: Labour seals pack with Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
Gavron sets out conditions as she accepts deputy role

New Labour in power: special report
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Labour yesterday set aside months of political warfare with Ken Livingstone and signed up to join his London mayoral administration.
fields.body:
Labour yesterday set aside months of political warfare with Ken Livingstone and signed up to join his London mayoral administration.

After days of negotiation and internal argument, Labour's nine-strong Greater London assembly group finally gave the go-ahead yesterday for Nicky Gavron to accept Mr Livingstone's offer to become his deputy for a year. But they sent out a clear warning that she would pull out if there was conflict with the government.

Ms Gavron, a longstanding north London Labour councillor, said she had agreed to take the deputy's job - a representative, rather than decision-making role - only after the mayor pledged to set up an independent panel to report on the merits of the government's and Mr Livingstone's rival proposals for the tube.

Labour's Lord Harris has also accepted Mr Livingstone's nomination to be chair of the Metropolitan police commit tee. The appointment will be decided by the assembly. Both will be free to pursue Labour's own policy agenda within the administration.

A party spokesman said there was now an understanding that Mr Livingstone had abandoned his threat to take the government to court if it refuses to abandon its part-privatisation scheme for the tube, though that was denied by the Livingstone camp.

As Labour maneouvred over the terms of its deal, William Hague targeted Mr Livingstone's proposal to introduce a charge on motorists in central London as the best way to cause trouble between the mayor and pro-car ministers led by the prime minister.

"Will Labour members stand by their own pledge not to introduce congestion taxes in their first term?" he asked after meeting the Tories' own nine-strong GLA group, which has refused Mr Livingstone's offer of a place in his cabinet.

"Or will they prefer to flirt with Ken Livingstone and his dangerous ideas, in the hope of winning some office from him?" Mr Hague's calculation is based on the knowledge that, between them, the Tories and Labour have a blocking majority against the mayor's budget.

The Tory leadertook his challenge directly to Mr Blair at Commons question time, where the prime minister said Labour GLA members would stand by their manifesto. He added: "I'm not responsible for the new mayor - I am responsible, however, for the Labour members".

He said he had spoken to Nick Scheele, chairman of Ford Europe, and would be working with the company, the government and local councils to ensure that what could be an "absolute disaster" instead offered "new opportunities" for the area.

After days of negotiation and internal argument, Labour's nine-strong Greater London assembly group finally gave the go-ahead yesterday for Nicky Gavron to accept Mr Livingstone's offer to become his deputy for a year. webTitle: Over-population warning as India's billionth baby is born

fields.headline: Over-population warning as India's billionth baby is born
fields.standfirst: Astha's birth in Delhi is being used by the UN to highlight the dangers of food and water shortages if population growth is not curbed in India
fields.trailText: 11 May, 4.45pm: Astha's birth in Delhi is being used by the UN to highlight the dangers of food and water shortages if population growth is not curbed in India.
fields.body:
India's population hit 1bn today with the birth of a baby girl in a Delhi hospital.

The birth puts India in an exclusive club with China as the only nations with populations exceeding 1bn. But on current trends, India will become the world's most populous country as it grows by 15.5m people a year.

The billionth baby - named Astha, Hindi for faith - was born to a poor Delhi couple. An estimated 42,000 children are born in India each day, so government officials decided that a baby girl born after noon on May 11 in the 1,500-bed Safdarjang hospital would symbolically mark the 1bn milestone. The child was born at 12.32pm local time.

"The one billionth baby, symbolically selected and born at Safdarjang hospital, represents the human being that brings India's population up to 1bn. Thus this baby is very special and very unique," said the UN population fund's representative in India, Michael Vlassoff.

"But 42,000 other babies are also being born in India today on May 11, as they are on every day. What world will they inherit? Will their hopes and aspirations be fulfilled?" he added.

The UN has warned of widespread shortages of food and water if India's demographic growth does not slow down.

Almost every measure of progress India has made since independence has been checked by its growing population: food production has trebled but many people go hungry; literacy has increased but so has the total number of illiterate people.

India was the first country in the developing world to initiate a state-sponsored family-planning programme in 1952 and official figures suggest a measure of success. Since independence in 1947, the fertility rate has been cut from six births per woman of child-bearing age to 3.5.

But efforts to encourage family planning among poorer Indians suffered a setback in the 1970s when the government sponsored a mass sterilisation campaign, in which illiterate people were duped or paid to have vasectomies or removal of the fallopian tubes.

The emphasis has changed in the past decade toward educating women, raising their status and providing better health care. Non-governmental organisations tour rural areas distributing condoms and discussing birth control, but sex education is not taught in schools.

webTitle: Day two: Songs of innocence and experience

fields.headline: Day two: Songs of innocence and experience
fields.standfirst: Fiachra Gibbons reports on Ken Loach's moving and emotional Bread and Roses, and Cannes' youngest ever director
fields.trailText: Fiachra Gibbons reports on Ken Loach's moving and emotional Bread and Roses, and Cannes' youngest ever director
fields.body:
Nearly a third of it is in Spanish, the romantic interest is a cleaning lady and the most exciting action scene involves a dust trolley and a mop. It could only be Ken Loach. Bread and Roses (pictured), his latest slice of 'authentic experience', lit up an another otherwise indifferent second day at Cannes, where the main talking point so far has not so much been the films but the mayor's ban on late-night beach parties.

Adrien Brody, late of Spike Lee's Summer Of Sam, plays a union organiser - think of a young, thin tanned and intelligible Jimmy Knapp - who falls for Maya, a feisty Mexican cleaner (Pilar Padilla) who tries to organise the illegals working for a very nasty, non-union Los Angeles cleaning firm. A strike ensues and although the women win, Maya gets deported.

Even if at times you feel you are being led by the nose down a familiar road, Bread and Roses is hugely moving and emotional, and could be the film that brings Loach to a wider American, and particularly, Latino audience.

Like the godawful Vatel, whose ultra lavish party took over half the Palais du Cinema last night, Loach is sparing no expense on his film. He is rumoured to have reserved two tables in a nearby bar and may even crack open a packets of crisps.

The first big behind-the-scenes drama of the festival concerns the Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf, who barely out of her teens, is the youngest ever chosen to take part in the main competition with her film, The Black Board.

The 20-year-old shot the film in the mountains of Kurdistan without official government permission, and her Italian producers smuggled the film out of the country to avoid possible intervention from Iranian censors. The producers, however, were at pains to point out that Makhmalbaf was not involved in the cloak-and-dagger operation: they do not want to jeopardise her ability to continue making films in Iran. Makhamalbaf made her international debut at 17 three years ago with her acclaimed The Apple.

webTitle: RELSA TEFL: a cheaper way to make the grade

fields.headline: RELSA TEFL: a cheaper way to make the grade
fields.trailText: RELSA (Recognised Language Schools Association) TEFL was founded in 1991 as a training course for those in the Irish Republic wanting to teach English as a foreign language. However, Britons have increasingly taken to crossing the Irish Sea to get their TEFL qualifications because RELSA is so cheap.
fields.body:
RELSA (Recognised Language Schools Association) TEFL was founded in 1991 as a training course for those in the Irish Republic wanting to teach English as a foreign language. However, Britons have increasingly taken to crossing the Irish Sea to get their TEFL qualifications because RELSA is so cheap.

Schools that teach RELSA charge only about £200 (250 Irish punts) for courses that typically last for three weeks - seventy hours of lessons and practice. This compares very favourably with British TEFL equivalents, for example, International House in London, which asks £970 for its four-week course. Nor are entry requirements too strict. Theoretically a student should be at least 21 and have finished third-level education. In practice these requirements are often waived.

The one big failing of RELSA, in respect to British TEFL courses, is the little time given over to teaching practice. A friend who trained in Britain was assessed while teaching for about six hours. In my RELSA course I 'taught' other TEFL students for one hour - an inevitably contrived situation - and real students for only 45 minutes, in three fifteen-minute units.

Some RELSA courses are even worse in this area. I heard of one school where there was teaching practice only with fellow TEFL students - probably because there were no foreign-language learners available. This is clearly something to ask about before enrolling.

The final mark - an A, B or C - is given on the basis of teaching assignments, an exam and an interview after the course. Standards in RELSA are high and less than five percent of students receive an A. I have no figures for the pass-rate, but in my group about a third did not finish the three weeks or failed outright.

Someone who wants to dedicate his or her life to TEFL and wants the best training possible would be well advised to look for a weightier certificate - something that, in private, my Irish teachers admitted. However, RELSA is internationally recognised and language schools abroad are not usually fussy about which particular TEFL qualification their teachers have.

This, at least, was my experience while recently looking for a teaching job in Spain. None of the school-directors that interviewed me commented on the fact that I was RELSA-trained; they were interested simply in my grade. For those who plan to work in the sector for only a few years, or who are not sure, RELSA could be the perfect launch pad into the world of TEFL.

Dublin School of English, 10-12, Westmoreland Street, Dublin 2, tel. 35316773322; 250 Irish punts for three weeks.

Language Centre of Ireland, 45 Kildare Street, Dublin 2, tel. 35316716266; 290 Irish punts for three weeks.

webTitle: Editor with stains on his character

fields.headline: Editor with stains on his character
fields.standfirst:
Piers Morgan still has his job, but one more strike and he's out

Press Complaint Commission
fields.trailText: For those enraged about Piers Morgan continuing to hold the Mirror editorship because of the City Slickers share scandal, the Press Complaints Commission's adjudication will not change their minds. Critics may argue that there remain many hostages to fortune in the PCC's nine-page adjudication. For a start, he is found to have breached the editors' code of practice twice, in letter and spirit. He is also said to have failed to carry out his duties as editor, enshrined in the preamble to the code, which states: "Editors and publishers must ensure that the code is observed rigorously . . . by their staff."
fields.body:
For those enraged about Piers Morgan continuing to hold the Mirror editorship because of the City Slickers share scandal, the Press Complaints Commission's adjudication will not change their minds. Critics may argue that there remain many hostages to fortune in the PCC's nine-page adjudication. For a start, he is found to have breached the editors' code of practice twice, in letter and spirit. He is also said to have failed to carry out his duties as editor, enshrined in the preamble to the code, which states: "Editors and publishers must ensure that the code is observed rigorously . . . by their staff."

Clearly, he didn't police the activities of his City Slickers (James Hipwell and Anil Bhoyrul), who were found guilty by the PCC of "repeated and flagrant breaches of the code".

The commission has censured Morgan by deciding "to register its concern about the general application of the code" to Trinity Mirror's management because of "the unsatisfactory state of affairs revealed by this episode". To some, it will seem like a slap on the wrist, but in the context of the PCC's history and the nature of self-regulation, it amounts to a damning indictment. Clearly, the difficulty for the PCC is that it has no investigative powers, so it cannot decide who is telling the truth. That is obviously the reason it has taken no view on whether Morgan's deputy, Tina Weaver, might have breached the code.

But most interest is bound to fall on the details surrounding Morgan's £20,000 purchase of Viglen shares. The fact that he bought the stock on the same day that the Slickers were tipping the company remains a remarkable coincidence and will add fuel to the conspiracy theories of media rivals. Similarly, his failure to take any action when he finally read their story that night is puzzling. As the PCC laconically notes: "It did not occur to him that the piece would have the effect on the Viglen share price which it did."

But there are factors which weigh heavily in Morgan's favour. Most importantly, he didn't sell his Viglen shares and take a profit when they leapt in price the day after the Slickers'0 column appeared. He didn't even cash them in as the price began to slide. And if Morgan was in league with the Slickers, why are there only two examples of his share purchases coinciding with their tips?

Yet why didn't Morgan distance himself from them? In a fascinating revelation, it transpires that six months before the Viglen scandal, Morgan had been informed that Hipwell was being investigated over his share dealings. He told his Trinity Mirror bosses, during an internal investigation, that Bhoyrul alleged in June 1999 that Hipwell might be buying shares they were tipping. Morgan questioned Hipwell, who denied it.

My understanding is that, quite separately, the board of Trinity Mirror was also concerned about the Slickers in late 1999 and had instituted an investigation of their activities. But they failed to give it priority and the Viglen scandal broke before it had got properly under way.

Since his dismissal, Bhoyrul has become a loose cannon. His latest set of accusations, and a third change of story, appeared in the Daily Express this week. He now claims, in a sworn affidavit, that Morgan knew exactly what he was doing when buying the Viglen shares and that five other Mirror journalists also bought the shares on the same day. When a story changes so radically it is difficult to give it credence; we may have to wait for the Department of Trade inquiry to get the bottom of these tales.

All that having been said, it is hard not to conclude that if Morgan had not been re garded as responsible for reversing the fortunes of the Mirror during his five years of editorship, he might well have been dismissed. Pragmatism rather than principle must surely have played a part in his company's decision to keep him.

My own belief is that Morgan is innocent, if silly, and will eventually be cleared by the DTI. He certainly won't lose his job over the PCC censure. But it is his second major breach of the code. As editor of the News of the World he was found by the PCC to have intruded on the privacy of Countess Spencer during her stay in a clinic.

Trinity Mirror are unlikely to do anything on this occasion, but they and Morgan surely know that if there is a third strike he will be out.

One positive outcome is likely to be a sensible amendment to the code to clear up any possible misunderstanding. Trinity Mirror disingenuously argued that certain words in the code, such as "significant" and "recent", were imprecise. The Mirror also claimed that the code offered no guidance on the conduct of editors holding shares. Doubtless, these problems will be eradicated.

No one ever imagined that this kind of situation would emerge. Aren't editors paid enough?

fields.headline: Card tricks
fields.standfirst: They were meant to lure in shoppers and make them stay. But paltry savings and customer indifference have taken the shine off store loyalty cards. As Safeway dumps its points system,  Esther Addley  asks if such reward schemes were ever anything more than a cheap gimmick
fields.trailText: They were meant to lure in shoppers and make them stay. But paltry savings and customer indifference have taken the shine off store loyalty cards. As Safeway dumps its points system, Esther Addley asks if such reward schemes were ever anything more than a cheap gimmick
fields.body:
Supermarket loyalty cards are past their sell-by date, according to Safeway. The company announced last week that after five years it is cancelling its ABC card, arguing that shoppers have got bored with collecting points and would prefer to see the money spent on price cuts. "People don't think they give value," said Safeway's chief executive Carlos Criado-Perez. "They'll never get tired of great deals."

The move follows Asda's decision last year to abandon its own trial scheme in favour of the "rollback" price-cutting strategy. But are high-street reward schemes really nearing the end of their shelf-life? The schemes have certainly been a phenomenal success since Tesco launched the first supermarket card in 1995 and was swiftly imitated by most of its big rivals. The idea is that when customers collect points in exchange for money spent in the store they are likely to be more "loyal" in where they chose to shop. Retailers in turn can collate detailed data on their shoppers' spending habits.

For a while retailers and shoppers couldn't get enough of reward cards; Boots, WHSmith, Homebase and BhS were quick to follow the supermarkets. But loyalty cards have been a victim of their own success. Three-quarters of us now use them, and the more we can sign up for the better. Over half of those with a Sainsbury's Reward card hold a Tesco Clubcard; 42% of Tesco cardholders have a Sainsbury's card. Consumers' wallets are bulging with plastic and they simply produce the right card for whichever shop they are in. So much for loyalty.

If shoppers are becoming jaded it is also because they have recognised that the return on cards is minimal. According to the Consumer Association's magazine, Which?, the average annual grocery spend is £2,900. So the standard supermarket reward of 1% would give a return of just £29 a year. It's better than nothing, but hardly enough to buy a customer's unstinting loyalty.

As shoppers collect a full pack of loyalty cards, supermarkets are having to be increasingly imaginative in the rewards they offer. Safeway has routinely been offering double and treble points on the ABC card, while Tesco launched a parallel reward scheme in August, where customers get a "key" for every £25 spent, 50 of which can be exchanged for travel-related deals. Sainsbury's, oddly, has halved the denomination of its points, "so one old reward point is worth two new reward points", as a spokesperson carefully explained. It's something to do with "flexibility", apparently. The company also introduced a number of high street tie-ins; shoppers get double the usual value of their points if they are redeemed at Burton, Top Shop or Principles.

Even high-street favourite Boots is planning a relaunch - its Advantage card will evolve in September into a "loyalty credit card". This curious hybrid will function like a normal visa card (run by Egg, the banking offshoot of Prudential), but cardholders will accrue one loyalty point for every £1 spent on the card, or five points per £1 if the purchase is at Boots. Once you have collected 4,500 - that's £900 worth of shampoo and toothpaste - you can have a day out at a leisure club.

"The market has slowed down now," says Tess Sullivan, senior researcher at Which? "People are more aware of cards, and in particular how long it takes to get decent rewards from them. I don't expect we'll see many more new schemes."

Customer familiarity aside, Safeway is also abandoning its scheme because of the huge cost. Profits have been falling, and the £50m saved by cancelling the loyalty cards is to be redirected into a price-cutting strategy. "We have got a new chief executive, and his strategy is based on stealing other people's customers," says Emma Mason, the company's head of PR. "Loyalty cards allow you to talk to existing customers, but they don't help you reach new customers. We are going to spend the money on big cut-price deals."

Meanwhile, Sainsbury's appears to be piggybacking on the publicity generated by its competitor's new tack, announcing yesterday that Safeway shoppers will get 500 free points on if they exchange their old ABC card for a Sainsbury's one.

So why do supermarkets continue to operate the schemes if customers aren't learning to be more loyal? A survey by the market analysts Mintel found that Morrison's, a relatively small supermarket chain, has the highest proportion of loyal customers. According to Morrison's, the secret of its success is that it doesn't run a reward scheme.

"If a supermarket operates a loyalty scheme just to give away points, it's not good value," says Richard Caines of Mintel. "The value is in the data generated on shoppers' habits. If they use it for planning, then it's very useful." When Boots, for example, analysed shopping patterns among its loyalty cardholders, it found a link between the purchase of baby products and photographic goods - when you have a baby, goes the logic, you want to send pictures to grandparents. The store now puts its camera films close to its nappies.

This sort of information can be enormously valuable to a retailer, but not, according to Mason, so valuable that is justifies the huge cost of the schemes. The company announced last week that after five years it is cancelling its ABC card, arguing that shoppers have got bored with collecting points and would prefer to see the money spent on price cuts. "People don't think they give value," said Safeway's chief executive Carlos Criado-Perez. "They'll never get tired of great deals." The move follows Asda's decision last year to abandon its own trial scheme in favour of the "rollback" price-cutting strategy. But are high-street reward schemes really nearing the end of their shelf-life? The schemes have certainly been a phenomenal success since Tesco launched the first supermarket card in 1995 and was swiftly imitated by most of its big rivals. The idea is that when customers collect points in exchange for money spent in the store they are likely to be more "loyal" in where they chose to shop. Retailers in turn can collate detailed data on their shoppers' spending habits. For a while retailers and shoppers couldn't get enough of reward cards; Boots, WHSmith, Homebase and BhS were quick to follow the supermarkets. But loyalty cards have been a victim of their own success. Three-quarters of us now use them, and the more we can sign up for the better. Over half of those with a Sainsbury's Reward card hold a Tesco Clubcard; 42% of Tesco cardholders have a Sainsbury's card. Consumers' wallets are bulging with plastic and they simply produce the right card for whichever shop they are in. So much for loyalty. If shoppers are becoming jaded it is also because they have recognised that the return on cards is minimal. According to the Consumer Association's magazine, Which?, the average annual grocery spend is £2,900. So the standard supermarket reward of 1% would give a return of just £29 a year. It's better than nothing, but hardly enough to buy a customer's unstinting loyalty. As shoppers collect a full pack of loyalty cards, supermarkets are having to be increasingly imaginative in the rewards they offer. Safeway has routinely been offering double and treble points on the ABC card, while Tesco launched a parallel reward scheme in August, where customers get a "key" for every £25 spent, 50 of which can be exchanged for travel-related deals. It's something to do with "flexibility", apparently. fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
One-hour delivery services

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: One-hour delivery services
fields.body:
Wish fulfillment is what the internet is all about. Today's shopper wants everything, well, yesterday. Next-day delivery isn't much use if you're ordering lunch.

www.bagsoftime.com promises delivery within about an hour. It launched at the end of March with a range of books, music and DVDs and has just joined up with the Shirt Press and Pavarotti's, a sandwich chain. Delivery is free and orders can be placed as late as 5pm for delivery by 6pm. It's a London-only service at the moment, but is set to expand soon.

Soon to come is www.ziparound.com, which will serve London and another as yet unspecified city. The site will feature a range of convenience and luxury items, again promising to deliver in around an hour.

There's no official launch date yet for the London arm of www.urbanfetch.com. But for a taste of things to come, check out the original New York site, which offers one-hour delivery on a wide selection of books, music, videos and DVDs, as well as food from a range of NY eateries. The London service will be similarly localised, but let's hope that doesn't mean we miss out on the range of ice creams including varieties of Ben & Jerry's you could never have guessed existed.

 helen.brooks@ theguardian.com

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a dog lead?
fields.trailText: ... a dog lead?
fields.body:
A dog may be man's best friend, but even friendship comes at a price. There are the vets' bills, the Harrods food bowl at £89, the Fortnum and Mason luxury grooming kit at £91.50 and then there is the Gucci dog lead.

This masculine black leather collar and lead sports engraved silver squares that spell out "Gucci Dog". It would suit a short-haired dog such as a rottweiler or pit bull terrier (long fur would mask the label and what's the point of that?) The ensemble costs £220, but for an extra £170 you could have your own pair of Gucci snaffle-bit loafers for logo-coordinated walkies.

For a further £30, you can throw your pet a vanilla-scented Gucci rubber ball. If Rover gets tired, pop him in the Gucci canine carrying case with gauze panel for easy breathing. This comes in classic fawn with logos all over it and will set you back a mere £420. When you get home, tuck him into his perspex Gucci bed (£995). For a bitch or a chihuahua, try the more delicately designed strap lead for £145. It comes in this year's floral print with matching handbags. Gucci: 020-7235 6707.

fields.headline: Mobile phone safety
fields.standfirst: As a new report fails to reach any definitive conclusions, Owen Bowcott examines the present state of health concerns
fields.trailText: As a new report fails to reach any definitive conclusions, Owen Bowcott examines the present state of health concerns
fields.body:
Why are we worrying about mobiles again?
The long-awaited report by Sir William Stewart, the government's chief scientific adviser, on the effect of mobile telephones on our health is finally published today. It does not give the phone industry a completely clean bill of health.

So how safe are they?
The report revives concerns about what happens in our heads when we spend hours on our mobiles talking to friends and colleagues. In particular, there are fears that young children might be damaged by radio waves emitted. Sir William suggests that youngsters should be discouraged from using them regularly or for "non-essential" calls.

Didn't a previous report say there was no danger?
A study last year by researchers at Bristol University concluded that mobile phones do not seem to harm habitual users. Indeed, rather than cooking the brain or scrambling one's memory, a 30-minute handheld conversation, it was reported in the International Journal of Radiation Biology, could speed up reaction times. Tests on volunteers showed no effect on short-term memory or attention span after exposure to microwave radiation of up to 30 minutes. The only noticeable effect was that subjects reacted faster in one test involving a visual choice after the transmissions. That improvement was thought to be due to a slight warming of the brain leading to increased blood flow.

So what has changed now?
The new report did not find any dangers but adopted a "precautionary principle". The balance of evidence to date does not suggest that emissions from mobile phones and transmitters put the health of the population at risk. But if there were any, so far unrecognised, adverse effects, young children would be much more vulnerable than adults, Sir William warned. More research may change our understanding of the problem. A leaflet providing clear understandable information on mobile phone technology and related health aspects should be circulated to every household by the government, the report said.

Why are children deemed to be at greater risk?
The report said that preliminary scientific evidence found exposure to radio frequency radiation might have subtle effects on biological functions, including the brain. Children may be more vulnerable because of their developing nervous system, the greater absorption of energy in the tissues of the child's head, and a longer lifetime of exposure. The tiny pulses of microwaves emitted by mobile phones are of the same type as the radiation used in microwave ovens.

What should parents do about these warnings?
The report recommended that parents take greater responsibility for deciding whether their children should use mobile phones. Children should limit the time spent on their handsets. "The widespread use of mobile phones by children for non-essential calls should be discouraged". Around one in four of Britain's 25m users is aged under 18 and more are expected to be signed up when the new generation of phones allow email and internet access. The National Family and Parenting Institute said parents would be disappointed with the recommendations. The NFPI's chief executive, Mary MacLeod, said: "Parents need to have accurate information about the health risks so that they can make judgments about their children using mobile phones. Since there have been conflicting messages about the health risks of mobile phones many parents may not be in a position to make an informed judgment."

What about the mobile phone industry?
The report recommends that companies refrain from promoting the use of mobile phones by children. Despite the proposal, the Federation of the Electronics Industry, which represents the UK's mobile phone industry, described the report as comprehensive and balanced. The FEI said that it particularly welcomed Sir William's confirmation that "the balance of evidence does not suggest mobile phone technologies put the health of the general population at the UK at risk". The mobile phone company One2One described the report as "comprehensive and hard-hitting". Bill Best, network services director, said: "The report contains many recommendations for us, the government, and local government, and we will play our part in addressing them, continuing to take policy forward in response to public concern."

Aren't hands-free mobile devices supposed to give better protection?
No. A recent report by the consumer magazine Which? concluded that such phones may actually increase the levels of radiation experienced by the user.

What about mobile telephone radio masts?
The panel of experts working with Sir William, which included physicists, engineers and neuro-scientists, recommended stricter controls on the location of mobile phone base stations and masts. The report concluded that the balance of evidence indicated there was no general risk to the health of people living near base stations, but there could be indirect adverse affects on their well-being in some cases. It recommended no further development should be permitted at existing base stations, including those with masts under 15 metres, and the location of new stations should be subject to the normal planning process. In relation to base stations located near schools, the inquiry team recommended that the beam of greatest intensity should not fall on any part of the school grounds or buildings without agreement from school and parents.

What about research in other areas?
Two experiments, one at Nottingham University and the other at the University of Washington, Seattle, have suggested that microwaves could produce stress in animals.

And is Sir William following his own advice?
He said that when his grandchildren, now four and two, were a few years older, he would not recommend allowing them "unfettered access" to mobile phones. He could see the benefit for children who might be out late at night having access to mobile phones for essential calls. The inquiry team could not provide further guidelines about how many minutes a day a child should use a mobile phone because it depended on variables such as how the phone was held, the type of phone, or whether it was hands-free. "The shortest time that a child needs for essential calls is the amount of time it should use," he said.

The report into mobile phones and health
Special report

webTitle: Mobile phones are safe, official report insists

fields.headline: Mobile phones are safe, official report insists
fields.standfirst:
A new government report says mobile phone emissions present negligible health risks. But children may face some adverse effects - and more research is needed

The Stewart report
fields.trailText: 11 May, 3pm: A new government report says mobile phone emissions present negligible health risks. But children may face some adverse effects - and more research is needed.
fields.body:
Mobile phone emissions do not adversely affect the health of the general population - but children may face greater risks, according to a long-awaited report published today. It calls for a "precautionary approach" until more research is done.

According to the government-funded report by Tayside university researchers, children are believed to be more susceptible because their skulls are thinner, allowing their brains to absorb more radiation.

"There is now scientific evidence which suggests that there may be biological effects occurring below [UK] guidelines," the report says. "In the light of these findings, the group recommends a precautionary approach to the use of mobile phone technology until more detailed and scientifically robust information on any health effects becomes available."

Expressing concern for the effects on children, it says: "The widespread use of mobile phones by children for non-essential calls should be discouraged." It also calls on mobile phone companies not to aim their advertising at children.

The report acknowledges that emissions from mobile phones may cause subtle biological changes in some cases. But the research scientists, led by Sir William Stewart, stressed that emissions do not necessarily cause illness.

"This is a new technology and we are recommending  that a precautionary approach be adopted until more information becomes available," Sir William said. He said he would continue to use his mobile phone - but would not recommend that his young grandchildren do so.

About one in four of Britain's 24m users of mobile phones is under 18, and more are expected to be signed up when the new generation of phones allow email and internet access, appealing to the younger end of the market.

Last month the Consumers' Association published research which showed hands-free kits - promoted as a way of reducing microwave interference on the brain - could actually amplify the energy and channel it directly into the user's head - a finding that compounded confusion on the subject.

David Hart of the National Association of Headteachers welcomed Sir William's report, and said he was interested to see what the government would say on the issue. "Many schools have banned the use of mobile phones, principally because they are an unwarranted nuisance and interfere with lessons and other school activities," he said. "But if it is now being suggested that they are harmful to the health of children then that will strengthen the schools' case for banning them altogether." Mr Hart said the numbers of children using mobile phones had "exploded out of all recognition in the last couple of years or so".

But Michael Repacholi, a World Health Organisation expert who helped draw up the report, insisted that it was safe for children to use mobile phones. Dr Repacholi said his own children used mobile phones. He said: "This report will raise questions in the minds of parents about is it safe, and at the moment we say 'yes it is', because it complies with the international standards and we've got other things that are precautionary, so targeting children may be going overboard."

The 10-month inquiry took evidence from experts across the country and its panel included experts in physics, telecommunications, engineering, and neuroscience. It was commissioned in response to fears that mobile use could be linked to memory loss, and even Alzheimer's disease. The latest contribution is unlikely to end the debate on the safety of mobile phones, and acknowledges that there is little scientific work on their safety because the technology is so new.

webTitle: Arrogance of doctors led to organ scandal

fields.headline: Arrogance of doctors led to organ scandal
fields.standfirst: Inquiry says removal of children's hearts ignored views of parents
fields.trailText: Arrogance, born of indifference to the views of parents, led doctors in Bristol routinely to remove children's hearts and other organs and retain them for years while mothers and fathers buried bodies they did not for a moment suspect were incomplete, an inquiry concluded yesterday.
fields.body:
Arrogance, born of indifference to the views of parents, led doctors in Bristol routinely to remove children's hearts and other organs and retain them for years while mothers and fathers buried bodies they did not for a moment suspect were incomplete, an inquiry concluded yesterday.

Ian Kennedy QC, chair of the Bristol Royal Infirmary (BRI) public inquiry whose main work is to investigate the deaths of babies in heart surgery at the hospital between 1984-95, produced an interim report yesterday that called for a code of practice - preferably entrenched in law - to ensure that organs and tissue are removed from children's bodies only with the explicit consent of parents.

In what will be seen as setting the tone for his final report at the end of the year, Prof Kennedy spoke of a culture that treated patients as commodities, cocooned in the assumption that doctors were doing good.

"The past was characterised by a type of professional arrogance which ignored - indeed, did not acknowledge - the views and the voices of parents," he said at a press conference in London.

"It was an arrogance born of indifference. The medical profession acted with good intentions, as they saw it." But they never thought to wonder whether their view was shared by others.

The sort of code he has in mind would ensure that parents were given detailed information about what would happen to their child, even to the extent of being offered lists of body parts - or human material as the report calls it - that they might not consent to being removed.

There are two types of postmortem - one ordered by the coroner to establish cause of death and the other requested by a hospital. Figures published in Prof Kennedy's report for the first time demonstrate that the vast majority are coroner's postmortems - 121,584 in 1998, compared with 3,524 others.

Michaela Willis, of Nacor (the National Committee for Organ Retention), said that at the 42 hospitals her organisation knew to have retained organs, "at least 97% [of the organs kept] were at coroner's postmortem". There was an assumption, she said, on the part of the pathologist that because he had permission (which a parent cannot refuse) for a coroner's post-mortem, he also had permission to take and keep organs, tissue or body parts without discussion with the parents.

"The saddest thing is that they [the hospitals] retained part of the child, but did absolutely nothing with it," she said. Her one-week-old son Daniel's heart had not been used for medical research, and nor had the organs of most of the children the group knew about.

"The focus of change seems to be the Department of Health. The Home Office is crucially involved yet seems barely engaged. If ever there was a case for joined-up government at the very highest level, this is it. No progress of the sort which we contemplate will be made unless both these departments and any others which may have an interest work together and take the matter seriously," he said.

They had no idea that large collections of organs existed at hospitals nationwide "Fundamentally, there was a social and ethical time bomb waiting to go off. It is no surprise that the explosion of anger, when it came, was huge," said the report.

The fuse was lit in April 1996 when Helen Rickard, whose daughter Samantha died after open-heart surgery at the BRI in 1992, asked to see the medical notes, seeking to establish whether her daughter might have lived if she had been operated on elsewhere. Mrs Rickard found out that Samantha's heart had been removed and retained.

Once the Bristol Heart Children Action Group had been formed, word began to spread among parents that their children's hearts had been taken. There was distress and outrage. "They thought that when their daughter or son had died they had said their goodbyes at the funeral. Now they were faced with the fact that what to them was still part of their child was preserved somewhere in a hospital.

He told the panel that collections of organs existed in the Royal Brompton hospital, London, in Alder Hey, Liverpool, and in hospitals in Newcastle, Sheffield, Manchester and Southampton. It has since been revealed at Alder Hey that not just hearts or livers but organ systems, including spinal cords, have been stored.

Prof Anderson acknowledged that what had happened was wrong. "If it were possible to undo it, I am sure we would all go back and undo it, and we would recognise that we should have tried to explain to them why we wanted to retain the organs," he told the inquiry.

Parents who gave evidence were shocked, angry and bewildered. Diana Hill said she was adamant with hospital staff that she did not want her daughter Diana's organs donated. Janice Wilcox said: "If they had asked us whether they could have retained Lewis's heart for whatever reason we would have said no because we believe that the heart is the soul of the person."

Angela Good said: "What makes their action even more baffling is that we actually offered Joseph's organs for transplant after he died but were told that they would not be of any use."

webTitle: Government and Ford seek to soften job losses

fields.headline: Government and Ford seek to soften job losses
fields.standfirst: Ford is still committed to Britain, despite its intention to axe a large number of jobs at Dagenham, insists Downing Street
fields.trailText: Ford is still committed to Britain, despite its intention to axe a large number of jobs at Dagenham, insists Downing Street
fields.body:
The government confirmed today that there would be significant job losses at Ford, as the car manufacturer told union officials of its plans to end vehicle production at its key Dagenham plant in Essex.

Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's official spokesman, said the prime minister had today briefed cabinet colleagues, along with trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, on Ford's expected announcement tomorrow.

Mr Campbell admitted there would be a net effect of jobs lost in Britain, although he hinted that Ford would contribute money to help the government's plans for retraining those who lose their jobs. "Ford are taking seriously their long-term commitment to Britain," he said.

The general secretary of the TUC, John Monks, said: "This is a bleak day for Dagenham and for the British motor industry."

Big companies must recognise their responsibilities to communities and the government should introduce greater protection for workers, he told the Today programme.

"One of the reasons that Dagenham and some other places are likely to be affected by closure is because it is easier and cheaper for British workers to be put out of work than it is anywhere else in the European Union. One of the reasons why Ford are concentrating on Germany is that it would be too expensive to run down the German end of their operation."

In a formal announcement tomorrow, Ford is expected to seek to offset the loss of 2,000 jobs at the plant, and thousands more among firms which supply the factory, by increasing investment elsewhere in Britain.

An additional 200 jobs will be created at its diesel-engine plant, which will continue at Dagenham, and there is speculation of further investment at the engineering centre in Dunton, Essex, the Transit-van factory in Southampton, and the engine plant in Bridgend, south Wales.

Ford will also recommit itself to a multi-million-pound plan to regenerate the Thames corridor around the Dagenham factory.

Ford has refused to confirm any of the speculation about the future of its 8,000 workers at Dagenham, which produced its first vehicle in 1931 and today manufactures the ailing Fiesta.

Following Ford's Europe-wide review of its operations, car assembly is expected to be phased out by November next year, leaving the site reliant on engine production and other manufacturing work.

Ford said earlier this year it was axing 1,300 jobs at Dagenham, so the plant would be left employing just over 4,000 workers after the fresh job losses.

Martin O'Neill, Labour chairman of the Commons trade and industry select committee, blamed "gross overcapacity" across the motor industry for the current problems and urged manufacturers to "adopt a more realistic approach" rather than "lurch into crisis situations".

Mr O'Neill said: "It's not the fault of the workers. It's the fault of the marketing people in the car industry who look at the world through rose-coloured glasses."

Mr Byers said Ford's review of its operations had been motivated "not by the strength of sterling, not by the employment laws in the UK, but as a result of over-production in the European market.

"Tomorrow's announcement will be a mixture of good and bad news. But what will be clear from it, is that Ford will remain committed to the UK and that we will still have Ford as a major employer within this country."

webTitle: MPs press for debate on Sierra Leone

fields.headline: MPs press for debate on Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook is facing demands for a full parliamentary debate as British troops stand alongside UN peacekeeping troops defending the capital, Freetown
fields.trailText: 11 May, 3.30pm: Robin Cook is facing demands for a full Parliamentary debate as British troops stand alongside UN peacekeeping troops defending the capital, Freetown
fields.body:
Pressure was building today in parliament for a full debate on Britain's role in Sierra Leone as British paratroopers dug in alongside UN peacekeeping forces in the Aberdeen peninsula to the west of the capital, Freetown.

Although the area is not in the path of rebels, whose advance on Freetown was blocked by forces loyal to President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, British army officials delivered a blunt message. "We hope we won't be having to get into a fight with anyone - but we are well prepared if we have to do so," said an army official when asked whether British troops were on standby to help UN troops.

The tough warning will do little to ease the concern among MPs, who are clamouring for answers from the government. MPs from all sides are pressing for a debate on Sierra Leone and the Commons leader, Margaret Beckett, promised to convey their demands to Robin Cook, the foreign secretary.

But she reprimanded Tories who said there was an urgent need to discuss it, saying British soldiers would be no safer if MPs deliberated on their fate. To Tory protests, she said: "I accept these are very important matters but I very much doubt whether the welfare and safety of a single British soldier will be affected by whether or not we discuss these matters next week."

Mrs Beckett was responding to Tory MP Ian Bruce, who asked why HMS Ocean had been diverted from a Nato exercise to take part in the Sierra Leone mission while Britain's allies were not helping out. She dismissed Tory MP John Wilkinson's argument that Britain should now pull out because its national interest was not affected.

Her comments came after Downing Street said the prime minister had emphasised to ministers at their weekly Cabinet meeting that British troops "were there for evacuation and not for combat". The government has repeatedly stressed that was the limit of their mission.

In Sierra Leone, a coalition of new and former Sierra Leone Army soldiers and militiamen has repulsed Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels from Waterloo, 15 miles from Freetown, as UN peacekeepers braced themselves for an attack on the capital. But David Wimhurst, a spokesman for Unamsil, the UN force in Sierra Leone, stressed that the capital was safe. "Freetown is not going to fall to the RUF," he said.

British troops committed four RAF Chinook helicopters to move Jordanian troops to defensive positions near the capital, while British army planners began helping UN forces to prepare new positions, plans and tactics. Defensive lines are being consolidated along the road into the capital from Waterloo, where fleeing residents said they heard the sound of gunfire last night. "Waterloo is now the front line," said Joseph Jalloh, a pro-government army commander.

The massing of pro-government forces followed a night of sporadic gunfire in three locations within 50 miles of the capital. Fuelling the tension is the mystery of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh's whereabouts. He disappeared on Monday after his bodyguards shot and killed at least four demonstrators outside his home.

Paratroopers had arrived originally to evacuate British and other foreign nationals, but are now playing a supporting role for the UN. Besides putting helicopters at the UN's disposal, British troops are also guarding Lungi airport.

the glamour
