fields.trailText: the glamour
fields.body:
the glamour

a room of smoke/with tiny lights glistening, red and green/instrument control patterns/figures in the gloom
-hey up
somebody speaks/turns on a lamp/the scene gets focused
three of them/two women, one man, seems like/and there I am, all eyes upon me
-you made it then?
it's the voice/the smile/the one I've been following since last night/donna, that's all I know/just this girl who came up to me after the gig, said she liked what I was doing with the beat and that she had a thing of her own going on, and maybe I could put some flavour to it
-just about, I answer
and who wouldn't/who wouldn't follow/round about nineteen, twenty at the most/check the style/the twisted nest of the hair-do/the tight, capped tee-shirt/the tattoo on her arm, a playing card/and the dark dazzle of the skin/oh yeah, she's black/kinda black/ with the deep pool of the eyes/the big bold mouth, smeared with purple/all things about her filled to the brim/and so easy with the smile, it was there even when it wasn't/but now it was, most definitely/and it's aimed right at me
-what yer looking at? she asks
-you
-who the fuck's this? says the other woman
-tommy, isn't it? asks donna
ah shit, this girl is doing me down
-elliot
come on then, elliot/don't be shy
laughter
-yeah, fuck you as well
and then step right into it/the studio, cramped to the walls with stuff/amps and mics and recording equipment/one entire wall, floor to ceiling, is vinyl records/the whole shebang wreathed in smoke/no outlet/ok, I've had a few thousand spliffs here and there, all down the line/but this is serious fog stew/gets me dizzy, just by breathing
now the woman who's invited me, this donna, she's leaning against an amp, smoking one of these rollmop constructions/smiles through the hit, and I smile right back when she holds out the joint to me
-no ta
-what? she says/you don't want any?
-not right now
-what's wrong with yer?
-tell yer what/I wouldn't mind a drink
now that gets her funny somehow/gets her looking around at the other two, with a feeling I can't catch a hold of
-got this, she says handing me a bottle of juice, like orange juice
-a drink I'm after
-it's sunday morning, she says
-yeah/and you're at the dope already
-fuck me, says the other woman/we got one here
-that you have/and what of it?
donna does the intros
the second woman, the one who just spoke up/introduced as the dj, given the name jody/she's sitting lonely behind a turntable deck, examining the grooves of a twelve-inch single/I get to see her frown one more time, that's it/except/oh but the way she's running her fingers over the vinyl surface, as though tracing/searching/buried treasure
now the guy/he's lying on a small couchbed affair, holding a pair of drumsticks/just tapping out some off-planet rhythm of his own/like, erm, the drummer I guess
donna nods towards him
-and this is 2spot, she says
2spot/well there yer go/neat black shirt, buttoned high to the neck/pale skin, drawn along the cheeks/high, dense sweep of blond hair greased back into a flattop quiff/sideburns sharpened, right down the groove of the bones/toughnut style, but something a little bit fluffed about him, you know/a touch of the flowers/too sweet a smell, and a softness around him/like never a day's work has been done/and maybe I've seen him around, maybe playing the drums somewhere, I don't know/whatever, something coded passes/just in the brief nod he gives me/just that
and then donna points out the cat, curled atop an amplifier
-and this is gallagher, she says
-noel, or liam?
-paul, she says/and that's the whole crew
meanwhile, the smoke's really getting at me, bringing back stuff I don't really need/so I take a swig of the juice offered/just to cool the throat of memories/and then donna says
-glam damage
-yer what?
yeah, what do you think of that, as a name?
-well I can see the glamour
looking at mad jody as I say this/and then at donna
-and I can see the damage
the singer smiles deeply at the drummer/and then turns to jody
-there you go/he loves it/told you so/I told you it was a good name
now this jody woman, she looks up at me, right at me/not a trace of expression
-you're late, she says/supposed to be here at nine
-it's what? I reply/twenty past?
-how would it be, if you turned up twenty minutes late/for a gig/how would that be?
-I got lost
-how would it be if you got lost?
fuckin' passwords and all that
-you get lost, on the way to a gig? would that be good?
-that wouldn't happen/fuckin' hell/what's wrong with yer?
-Yeah, come on jody, says donna/give him a chance
-you can fuck off as well
-oh, says jody/the guy's got problems
-I'm getting pissed off, that's all
so this jody stands up then/and for the first time I realise just what a specimen she is/a touch older than the other two, almost my age/but weird with it/I mean, there's weird and weird, right/but jody was off the edge of normal and right along some/nothing to do with how she dressed, because that was scruff central, with a touch of couldn't-give-a-monkey's-tutu hippie shit/but her face, her whole manner, every last vein spoke of jitter, of flex, of what the fuck/body pinched shut, and so thin, the skin stretched taut over wire/black hair scraped to fit the skull, knife-edge whisper/and two of the coldest eyes that ever did view the world, I swear/they were eyes detuned, right through zero, and into the minus
reminds me of a bathroom mirror I once knew, the one I had to veil/turn to the wall/the peeling silver skin on the back of it/and that too, eventually, I could not dare approach
-you been here before? she asks
-what, down here?
-the zuum club?
-no
-you don't like dance music?
-dance music, that's what you do?
-kinda
-kinda?
-the next step, you know what I'm saying?
-fine/the next step/whatever
-how old are you?
-twenty-four
-twenty-four, and you don't like dance music?
-ah, been off the scene a little/you know, out of it
-oh yeah, how far?
-what?
-how fuckin' far have you been out?
-look/maybe I should go/eh?
-you backing out? says donna
-just wanna know what the score is, that's all/I mean, you want a bass player/I am a bass player/I play the fuckin' bass
-five or six bands, he's in, says donna/right this moment
-five, six or seven bands, by the way
-nothing serious though, says donna/pub bands
-ooh, he's played in bands before, says jody, with a darkside sneer/now us, you see, we ain't played in any bands but this/this is a pure band
-no bands but this? how many gigs?
-no gigs
-together how long?
-together three months
-oh fuck me, a buncha babies/this really isn't what I'm after, my friends
-just listen to us, says donna/that's all we want
I mean, tell me please, what would you do/come on, just to get the thing over and done and outa there/get myself some air, some proper juice inside me/some lube/some breakfast at the very least/so I give the nod, and
-right, says jody/scorched out for love/let's do it
the drummer gets up from the lounger/this is a guy who hasn't said one word to me/not one single word the whole time, not even to the other two/he gets up and just kinda slides into position behind the drumkit, sticks at the ready
well then, here we are/down to the wire - crack it open, says jody
and the drummer hits the skin/down hard

down hard/creeping patterns/snares and rimshots, like a fall of rain/the held crackle of a cymbal/bass drum coming on the third beat/caught in a loop/rhythm dancer/drums, and nothing but, until donna dares to sing this downtime lament

waiting for the world to learn
the contours of your skin
I wonder what colours you'll turn
when the world burns

I was expecting some impassioned outburst/but her voice has a calmness to it/degrees of control, almost on the edge of becoming something else/she sounds lost, uncaring/stretching out the words/bruised with hidden knowledge
drums and voice/a flat chant
jody comes in on the second verse/working a shimmer from the turntables/fingers dragging plastic, holding it/releasing/holding/releasing/building a noise/a caress of stolen notes surrounding the song, tightly bound/by the end of the verse she's managed to twist the feel entirely/making it tremble, succumb
and then explode/she must've hit a switch somewhere/turned on some pre-recorded kaleidoscope/this sudden howl from stretched strings/vinyl pops and screeches/machines crying and scratching fire, right up the nerve scale/until the sheer blade of it gets stuck tight in the darkness, shoots right back at me/into the chorus, with donna allowing a slice of emotion to cut through

and down/ further down

fields.headline: Review Vatel ees a disastaire
fields.standfirst: For the second year running, the Cannes film festival has opened with a real turkey.  Peter Bradshaw is dismayed by Roland Joffé's Vatel
fields.trailText: For the second year running, the Cannes film festival has opened with a real turkey. Peter Bradshaw is dismayed by Roland Joffé's Vatel
fields.body:
Cannes 2000 began last night with a curtain-raiser every bit as uneasy as last year's opening night film. This time it was Vatel, a Franco-British co-production directed by Roland Joffé, with an adapted screenplay by Tom Stoppard. Gerard Depardieu stars as François Vatel, a 17th-century "master of the revels" reputed to have killed himself when the fish failed to arrive for an enormous three-day banquet-cum-spectacle he was directing for Louis XIV.

The story's obvious possibilities for black comedy are ignored in favour of producing a flatulent and self-important costume drama. The film makes Vatel a smouldering hero and man of principle who gets to have sex with Uma Thurman, coolly despises the greedy and heartless courtiers, yet is bafflingly unconcerned by the fact that he is a key part of all this excess. Creaking under the weight of its expensive costumes and lavish set-pieces, Joffé's movie is paralysed within its single location, the Chantilly estate where it has been laboriously filmed. Ill-natured noblemen are always hissing unfortunate things like: "The King is bored: eet ees a disastaire!"

Joffé coaxes unhappy performances from all his stellar cast, but the king of wooden acting here is Depardieu, who lumbers about on auto-pilot, dealing with every horrendous crisis with the air of someone who has had to get out of the bath to answer the phone. A stable-boy is accidentally hanged by the rope-pulley mechanism which flies a cherub through the air for a masque, mounted for the smirking King's diversion. Vatel's noble disgust at this waste of a man's life is a very material factor at getting Uma into bed, yet it doesn't occur to her or anyone else to point out that it is really Gerard's fault.

The screenplay, reworked from Jeanne Labrune's French original, dies an agonising death in almost every line. Tim Roth, playing a villainous courtier and wearing a wig that makes him look like an electrocuted poodle, has to say: "Vinegar! It makes the King irritable - especially around his... anus ." There are lots of very irritable-anus moments in this wretched script; its fundament is positively twitching when Depardieu has to say: "Let me quote Descartes, who I knew..." Stoppard has quite a few Hail Marys to say for this one.

It looks worryingly as if Vatel, and last year's The Barber of Siberia by Nikita Mikhalkov, might be setting the trend for a kind of generic "opening night"-type film at Cannes: a film not submitted to the rigours of competition, plausibly grand - and so appropriate to kick off the festival - yet not too demanding. This year and last year the films have been squawking, gobbling turkeys and the festival must surely smarten up this important part of its act.

That said, Vatel was not technically the first film to be shown here. It was preceded by a new 17-minute short by Jean-Luc Godard, De l'origine du XXIe siècle, shot on video and punctuated with dates from the bygone century flashed up as captions - 1930, 1945, 1975, etc. Godard's film is a succession of harrowing and disorienting images, taken mostly from the theatre of political extremism - Nazism, Stalinism, hangings, and a particularly unlovely sequence showing someone urinating onto the face of a woman. What these add up to exactly is arguable: they possibly exhibit a glib or shallow sense of history, but something in the piece's very brevity and inscrutability gives it a certain power. It was definitely a more acceptable opening film for the first Cannes of the new century.

webTitle: Journalist detained as Milosevic tightens reins on opposition

fields.headline: Journalist detained as Milosevic tightens reins on opposition
fields.standfirst: Police seize respected Serbian correspondent's passport and computer files
fields.trailText: A journalist critical of Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic has been arrested by Serb security forces as the embattled military regime clamps down on growing opposition across the country.
fields.body:
A journalist critical of Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic has been arrested by Serb security forces as the embattled military regime clamps down on growing opposition across the country.

Miroslav Filipovic, 49, a Serbian freelance correspondent for Agence France Presse and the Institute of War and Peace Reporting, was transferred to a military prison in the Serb town of Nis this morning after being arrested at his home in Kraljevo on Monday night.

The district court in Kraljevo yesterday referred the case to the military prosecutor and ruled that Mr Filipovic - who also writes for the Belgrade daily Danas - could be held in temporary detention for up to thirty days. Police claim to have enough evidence to charge him with espionage.

Mr Filipovic's wife, Slavica, said security forces had interviewed her husband for three hours, producing a warrant for his arrest which stated that he was being detained to prevent him from destroying or hiding "evidence" necessary for judicial proceedings. Mr Filipovic's passport, notes and his computer hard drive were seized.

Two days ago, Serb police cancelled an opposition rally and arrested several other journalists, along with members of the youth resistance movement and an opposition leader in Pozarevac, the Yugoslav president's home town.

In the Yugoslav capital, Belgrade, opposition television station Studio B and the radio station B92 (which became a cause celebre after being forced off air last year during the Kosovan war) were both temporarily shut down.

The opposition parties have announced a rally against the Milosevic regime to be held in Belgrade on Monday. Opposition leaders will be hoping for a turnout as high as last month, when more than 100,000 people filled Republic Square in the capital to protest against the Serb leader.

webTitle: What goes up must come down

fields.headline: What goes up must come down
fields.standfirst:
This week's fall in sterling has come as a relief to the government. But it will be hoping that any further movement will be gradual, to ease inflationary pressures

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week's fall in sterling has come as a relief to the government. But it will be hoping that any further movement will be gradual, to ease inflationary pressures, argues the Guardian's economics editor Larry Elliott.
fields.body:
After months in which the pound has surged ever higher on the foreign exchanges, the past week has seen it come back down to earth with a bump.

As far as the government is concerned, sterling's fall has not come a moment too soon. Both the prime minister, Tony Blair, and the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, have made it clear in recent days that the pound is overvalued and is making life difficult for those British firms selling abroad by making UK exports dearer.

The reason that sterling has begun to fall is the recognition in the foreign exchanges that UK interest rates may have peaked at 6%. The cost of borrowing is currently higher than it is in the rest of Europe, and the feeling in the markets up until a week ago was that rates here would go still higher over the coming months, thereby attracting investors looking for a high return on the thier money.

But when the Bank of England decided a week ago to leave interest rates at 6%, investors were forced to rethink.

Three important questions arise from what has happened over the past few days. The first is how much further the pound will fall. Manufacturers would like to see the pound decline by at least another 15-20% against the dollar so that British goods have a better chance of competing in cut-throat global markets.

While a fall of this magnitude is certainly justified, it may not happen. The euro has fallen by a third against the dollar since it was launched 16 months ago, and any further weakness in the fledgling single currency would probably boost the level of sterling. Still, the likelihood is that the pound has peaked.

The second issue is what the impact on the wider economy will be. Changes in the level of the pound take time to have their full effect, and the consequences of the pound's overvaluation will be felt for some time to come. In some cases, customers have already been lost and will not be replaced.

Finally, there is a cloud to the silver lining of the pound's fall. The strength of sterling has made imports cheaper and helped keep UK inflation down. A falling pound will push up the cost of imports, adding to inflation. As the Bank warned yesterday, this may mean that interest rates have to go up even as the pound comes down.

So while the government will welcome the foreign exchange movements of the past week, it will want any fall in sterling to be gradual and not too pronounced.

fields.headline: Population growth
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the world's inexorable expansion on the net
fields.trailText: 1. With the birth of a baby girl called Astha Arora, India's population today hit one billion.
fields.body:
1. With the birth of a baby girl called Astha Arora, India's population today hit one billion.

2. According to government estimates, one baby is born every two seconds. Statisticians say that if the current birth rate continues, by 2050 India will overtake China as the world's most populous country.

3. The world's population passed six billion on October 12 1999. At two minutes past midnight a baby boy in Bosnia was designated the world's six billionth person by United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan.

4. India's government is using the birth of Astha Arora to highlight the problems caused by the nation's growing population and the need to control it.

5. Since independence in 1947, India's population has more than tripled - so has food production, but many people still go hungry.

6. Globally, population itself is not the problem: 30 years ago the world's food supply represented 2,360 calories per person; today that figure has increased to 2,740 calories and food supplies are expected to outstrip population growth for the next 10 years.

7. If the world was shrunk to 100 individuals (with all the existing human ratios the same) six people would own 59 per cent of the wealth and 50 would suffer from malnutrition.

8. As the world grows, it is feared that pressure on resources, such as water, in the poorest southern half of the world will lead to rising tensions within and between countries.

9. For now population control is a feminist issue. More and more women are becoming educated and entering the workforce, which means they delay starting a family and have fewer children.

10. The world is not growing uniformly. Unlike India, Japan and Italy are experiencing a decline in population.

Since independence in 1947, India's population has more than tripled - so has food production, but many people still go hungry. 6. Globally, population itself is not the problem: 30 years ago the world's food supply represented 2,360 calories per person; today that figure has increased to 2,740 calories and food supplies are expected to outstrip population growth for the next 10 years. 7. If the world was shrunk to 100 individuals (with all the existing human ratios the same) six people would own 59 per cent of the wealth and 50 would suffer from malnutrition. 8. As the world grows, it is feared that pressure on resources, such as water, in the poorest southern half of the world will lead to rising tensions within and between countries. 9. For now population control is a feminist issue. More and more women are becoming educated and entering the workforce, which means they delay starting a family and have fewer children. 10. The world is not growing uniformly. Unlike India, Japan and Italy are experiencing a decline in population.

fields.headline: Questions and ancestors
fields.standfirst: Now public records are online, tracing your family tree is a click away. But be warned: distant relatives may come knocking, warns  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: Now public records are online, tracing your family tree is a click away. But be warned: distant relatives may come knocking, warns Emma Brockes
fields.body:
You can choose your friends, the saying goes, but you can't choose your relatives. That was before public records went online and you could put your name into a search engine and call up whole pages of distant cousins, planning a holiday around the better-located of them. Genealogy has always been popular with bearded men who enjoy reading charts. But the transference of the social security index on to the web has seen a more general rise in enthusiasm for tracing ancestors who fought in the civil war or went down with the Titanic, preferably with a descendant in Bali.

Most family historians are compelled by two things: one, to construct a narrative for themselves that is more interesting than the one they've got; two, to identify in the family tree a strain of talent they might claim heir to, if only at molecular level.

"I had a client who was convinced she was descended from Johann Sebastian Bach," says Eric Probert, genealogical consultant and computer editor of Family Tree magazine. "But I traced her records back and she came from a family of Backs in the Midlands. She wouldn't accept it, though. She died still believing she was related to Bach."

Her suspension of disbelief is in keeping with the slightly fantastical nature of the pur suit. Several years ago, I typed my mum's maiden name - De Kiewiet - into a US search engine. It returned one name, Mark De Kiewiet, with an email address in Oregon. We calculated that our grand-parents had been first cousins and he sent me a family tree going back eight generations. Then, one night, I wobbled in from the pub to a ringing phone and there he was, calling from the US, threatening to drop by on a forthcoming trip to London. I recoiled. Mark only existed for me as a repository for the faith that I was connected to something distant and exotic. I didn't want him on my doorstep acting like a mortal or, more probably, a nutter. My mum was exasperated. We have enough weird relatives, she said, without digging up more.

Tracing dead ancestors doesn't present this problem, but it does come from the same slightly desperate drive to retrieve for oneself a secret history, a refuge from the fear of being ordinary. It is a motivation well known to the makers of family tree web sites and CD-Rom packages. The underlying sell is: bad day at work? Raise your chin, soldier, for you are descended from the Warrior King of Bohemia and his third wife, Ethel (you and everyone else who cares to look).

If you're not too worried about the facts, it's an easy trick to pull off. You go to a web site such as www.familysearch.org. With access to 600m names, it's one of the biggest genealogy sites in Britain and run, like most of them, by the Mormon Church. (The Mormons are the chief distributors of genealogical data, since it's their aim to find Mormon ancestors and rebaptise them into the church.) Anyway, you go to the site, enter a surname, and with any luck a whole raft of spicy ancestors will pop up.

Within an hour of logging onto the Family Search website, I have found a possible branch of my dad's family in Czechoslovakia (a marriage certificate exists for Dorothy Brockes and Johan Lebeda in Litomysl, 1723), a lead on the maternal grandmother front (a christening record for a Michiel Doubel, Cape of Good Hope, 1869) and - yes! - a celebrity. I am related to none other than radical theorist and social revolutionary, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, a fact established by feeding each new surname back into the search engine. Grandma Doubel's mother was (possibly) Rosa Erasmus, whose mother was Rosa Rossouw, whose alternative spelling was Rousseau. Bingo.

This is the kind of blind, acquisitive research that infuriates professional genealogists. "You've got to work back from yourself, stage by stage," says Christine Morris, who has traced her own family back to the 16th century. "You can't just appropriate a name you find in the middle of America and assume you are related to them."

"The internet has made it easier," says Eric Probert. "But you always need to go back to the original source - the parish register, for example - because there may be mistakes in the translation." Probert has traced his own roots back to an 18th-century stone mason in Herefordshire - William Probert - where he has been stuck for 15 years. "I can't find his baptism or death certificate," he sighs.

"A lot of people don't take up genealogy until they retire," says Michael Armstrong, who founded Family Tree magazine in 1985 and has seen it grow to a circulation of 42,000. In a recent poll of 500 of its subscribers, the majority were found to be in the 50-59 age group. Only six were under the age of 29, and while nearly 300 respondents had a computer, only eight had ever found a family connection via the internet.

The new generation of family historians differs considerably in their methods and motivations from their older counterparts. "A lot of people get into genealogy now, not through their interest in family history, but through their interest in computers," says Armstrong. "They are a different type of people."

In other words, they are the dilettantes whose first resource is the free, online databases that stop 100 years short of the present day and are useless unless you have done some primary research to cover the gap. For this, the dedicated computer user can turn to more comprehensive packages such as the Genera tions Family Tree Grande Suite, a set of 15 CD-Roms boasting access to more than a billion names. It's linked to the www.ancestory.com website and is heavily tailored for the American market (US states are listed separately, while Europe appears as a conglomerate).

Its big selling point is its databases, including Civil War muster rolls for five million soldiers, national archives for both world wars and the Titanic passenger list, an indication that there is nothing a user likes better than to imagine himself at the scene of a disaster, or at least, its film version.

The problem with using a package like this as a first resource is that unless you are lucky with your surname you'll fall into one of two camps. De Kiewiet returns no names; Heaney, my paternal grandmother's name, returns 1,115. At several turns, the program suggests I might like to buy the 1870 Maryland census for $295, or the International Directory of Brockes in Salt Lake City, which at $39.99 is a series of maps and charts locating everyone of that surname in the entire world and strikes me as a bit creepy. The other service is the virtual photo album, where you can turn all your findings into an Ancestry World Tree, with pop-up boxes, a mottled background and the swirly typefaces that characterise the set.

A more sensible first stop is something like the World Family Tree, a resource of 143,000 privately researched histories and 98 million names. That allows you, before embarking on your search, to ensure that you're not going over the same ground an unknown cousin in Ontario spent five years on. The average family tree contains 600 names and although you can't download the results without paying £10, it does mean you can find out if you're listed before buying the £60 CD-Rom.

This is known as 'shareware' software, a program that allows you to download a free version before you commit to buying. It's what Wayne Younge relied on to trace his family tree back seven generations. Two years ago, Younge, a lecturer at City University in London, took a trip to Barbados, where his parents were from, and started researching his family tree. His first resource was human - talking to as many old people as possible. His next was paper - going to the archives and trying to consolidate what he had been told. It was only after this that Younge turned to the web.

"I posted a message on the West Indian newsgroups, asking if anyone had information on a list of surnames," he says. Younge downloaded two free applications - from www.brotherskeeper.com and www.gendex.com - which allowed him to save his findings in a clickable family tree. Thus armed, he went to FamilySearch.org and was able to eliminate the dozens of Younges who bore no relation to him.

"On sites such as Family Search, most of the information is at least 100 years old and to get back that far, the best sources of information are archives or family members. Where the internet makes a huge difference is in sharing information. Newsgroups allow one to share information with people who are researching certain surnames, and/or geographical locations."

There are books available from the Society of Genealogists, with Ladybird-type titles such as My Ancestors Came with the Conqueror and my Ancestor was a Merchant Seaman.

And if you get tired of dead relatives, there is always that international directory of the living, the white pages. My very living cousin Mark did come and visit. He turned out to be extremely nice, with an authentic stamp of history in the form of a bump in his nose - just like me, my mum, and Rousseau.

Online archives
<A HREF="http://www.familysearch.org"" TARGET="_NEW">www.familysearch.org
The biggest UK site, with a searchable database of 600 million names.

<A HREF="http://www.ancestory.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.ancestory.com
Heavily tailored for the American market, but with a useful archive of names, addresses and telephone numbers of living relatives.

<A HREF="http://www.bannerblue.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.bannerblue.com
The home of Family Tree Maker, this is more of a stepping stone to other resources and a shop window for family tree software.

<A HREF="http://www.genealogy.com"" TARGET="_NEW">www.genealogy.com
470 million names, but culled from existing family trees on the web, rather than primary sources like birth, deaths and marriage certificates.

Family tree software
GED2HTML
www.gendex.com/
A free download allowing you to produce HTML pages and create a sorted, hierarchical index with a hypertext link to each person in the family tree.

Brother's Keeper
http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/Brothers_ Keeper
A shareware package allowing you to organise your family history in charts.

Generations Family Tree Grande Suite
15 CD boxed set with searchable databases and software to arrange your findings. (for windows 95/98). Boasts 1.5bn names for £49.99

Other resources
www.cyndislist.com/genuk
Cyndi's List links to family tree sites all over the world.

www.deja.com/usenet
A good introduction to newsgroups and message boards.

www.theultimates.com
The ultimate directory of White Pages.

<A HREF="http://www.familytreemaker.com/wftonline/"" TARGET="_NEW">www.familytreemaker.com/wftonline
The World Family Tree, 143,000 privately researched family trees at your disposal.

fields.body:
door code

the nightclub/a stonecold zombie with a look of shock on its face, the kind that happens when nocturnals get caught in the daylight/check that feeling/something about turned-off neon always does it for me, turns on the sadness, gets me thinking about where all the shine goes to/like it should've been raining, like it should've always been raining
what the hell
just this guy, you know, standing alone on ian curtis boulevard/sunday morning frozen, just gone nine/and even the moon has been left behind by the night, so careless, looking like a stain of bleach/like a close-up photo of how my head is feeling/oh please, I could do with some doghair right now/something wet to get the heart in tune, to keep my finger from shaking on the door buzzer/until this low-pitch squawk gets back to me
-Who is it?
-I'm here to see donna
-who is it?
-it's elliot, look...
-who is it?
oh shit, the door's got nasty bouncer attitude/I only met this donna last night and I'm pretty sure she never mentioned a password
-who is it?
-shut the fuck up will yer, I'm thinking
-who is it?
I press my lips closer to the grille
-the bass player

sticky stuff

the door slides open, smooth as yer like/and I have maybe five seconds to get myself and the big case through before it closes again/closes like a bad-breath mouth around me/some kinda foyer, shuttered cloakroom to the left, ticket booth to the right/suddenly warm, like the building has a pulsebeat/and no one around so I walk ahead, through into blank space
club zuum/the dancefloor, shining away into the distance/ heat-shivering
and dirty/with my shoes sticking to the spillage so much, feels like I can carry on walking, right up the walls, make out like a fly for the day/around the circle of the floor, where a couple of old ladies are cleaning up the plastic glasses, the cans, the swill, the vomit, the debris/I give the bomb squad a wave, and they look up and smile, and wave back, like a mirage/the club has that glazed ozone feel/molecules of evaporated sweat and perfume/the thousand-and-one come-ons still lingering, sticky ghosts of young desperate sex
-where's the studio? I shout over
the women point me towards some steps/down/where a lone stiletto lies discarded, as though cinderella has turned sluttish/a regular trash palace/ along a corridor now/deserted/past offices all empty of life/maybe I got the wrong day or something
holy shit/what am I doing here? somebody tell me
just tracking down the traces/the sizzle and the traces of a stranger's smile when this big, old domestic cat saunters out of one of the offices/a mangy, battle-scarred affair, all black and tattered fur/the flea magnet looks at me, like I'm a fool to even be here/and then waddles off down the corridor, flicking its tail like it owns the world
well what the hell/I follow/into another doorway
some fat guy, standing near a kitchen counter, eating a breakfast burger
-what the fuck do you want?
-the studio?
-downstairs! down the fuckin' stairs!
hey, nice people/I walk back into the corridor, thinking it's maybe time to leave/no, really/when I see the cat again, sitting on its backside right next to a door/a wooden door this one, looks like a broom cupboard/open it/and there you go, more stairs, leading further downwards/into darkness/I look around for a light switch, find one/but it doesn't work/of course it doesn't
this is getting stupid
the old cat's looking at me/one eye is glued together with a clog of scum/the other's giving me this real voodoo manic stare
ok, cat/let's get to it
holding the case behind me, I follow the creature downwards/feeling for each step in turn/musty, cloying air/the damp on the walls meets the sweat on my skin/the drink being squeezed out of me/and down, and further down
some other kind of door at the bottom/no answer to my knocking/louder now, and still nothing/and then swing the door open, letting the cat nip through my legs/I follow it through, into a recording suite/empty/a glass partition shows a room beyond/darkness/near darkness/people/another door leads to them/I push it open
just standing there, holding the bass/ looking through

heavy on the download

oh yeah, I play the bass/the bass plays me/the four-stringed, thick-bellied electrified monster, you know, the one that eats all other noises alive
and I've gone walking down these four strings most every hour of every day, of every year and every busted heartbeat, just trying to get along to where the last riff kisses the dark/the subsonic groove, we call it
dub culture/midnight's vibration/something to reach for
some throat, some bottom, some neck and some deep clutch of riverpulse/gets you hot just strapping yourself into the thing/and the more you play, the hotter it gets, the slicker the slide/and all for nothing much because none of the songs you discover, ever come anywhere near to what you hear in your dreams
and I guess all that follows is about me taking a chance on the journey of the bass/and finally getting to reach the end of it/the end of the last tune, and what I find down there, in the grooves of the soul/and how come the music is always that one step beyond all the love you play it with/and how the bass ain't got four strings at all
just when you think you're getting the grip of it
how it's got these other strings, invisible like/below the low, and deepcore/you gotta dive down underload to get a finger on them/and watch yourself doing it, watch yourself
those strings can pull you under, believe me
ah shit/believe me please

fields.headline: Diary:  Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: Ever since he allowed himself to be quoted on the record, concern has mounted that my old friend Alastair Campbell has lost his touch, but until now - more through reflex than anything, perhaps - I have always defended him.
fields.body:
 Ever since he allowed himself to be quoted on the record, concern has mounted that my old friend Alastair Campbell has lost his touch, but until now - more through reflex than anything, perhaps - I have always defended him.

Word arrives, however, that shakes even my confidence. It concerns the recent fiasco in which Mr Tony Blair "wrote a 975 word hand-written letter" to the Sun in response to a savage attack. Or so we were told.

The truth may be slightly different. After Ali faxed over his own usual "I'm doing the best I can but much more to do" rot in Mr T's name, the paper rang back expressing a certain ennui and requesting some more personal touch.

Perhaps inspired by a preview tape of Rory Bremner's recent show, Ali walked into the office and instructed Mr T to copy out a few lines, remembering to stick in some convincing crossings-out. This was faxed to the Sun, and widespread ridicule inevitably ensued.

To be honest, while it's no struggle to visualise Mr T taking dictation from Ali, it's hard to believe Ali could make such a howler - nor will I believe it until he issues the furious denial and threat of legal action.

 A colleague calls in from the Cannes film festival, where he had the honour of waiting behind Andie MacDowell at airport immigration. At the sight of the film star, five gallant passport officers surrounded the actress, asking her such searching questions as "Who are you?" and "Why are you visiting Cannes?"

They even made her fill in immigration forms, and then "lost" the first set so that she had to fill them in again - a very long-winded route to an autograph. As for Andie, she allied herself with those readers who feel that the recent mayoral coverage was evidence of tiresome metrocentricity. Asked where she had just travelled from, she replied: "Er, what do you call that place... London?"

 At the Mirror, little threatens the serenity. At yesterday morning's news conference, while awaiting the unusually savage PCC verdict on the share dealing, editor Piers Morgan whipped up morale by swearing his senior officers to total loyalty and confidentiality - such a success, that it was almost three minutes before the first of them rang the Diary.

After the PCC's ruling, meanwhile, Piers and the top management went into the inevitable period of purdah, and when last heard of were going into hiding at Langan's Brasserie, where the paper's Pride of Britain awards do was being held.

 In today's visit to website of the month, www.ruthgledhill.com, we come to a segment headed "St Caedwalladr and The Jacket". This is accompanied by a snap of the Times religion correspondent in a coat of many colours, known as "the jacket".

In the third person, Ruth takes up the tale. "Through the Rathbone family [Basil Rathbone was a cousin, you will recall] and an intermarriage generations back with the Roberts family of Wales, Ruth is directly descended from Prince Owain Gwynedd of Wales, and through him St Caedwalladr". And here's more. "St Caedwalladr was said to be descended from Joseph of Arimathea. It is in fact possible using the Bible to trace the family's line back to Adam." More soon.

 And so, reluctantly, to my prosecution for speeding in the car lent to me by BMW. Scandalised, my colleague Richard Adams rings press officer Jo Slater to accuse her of grassing me up to the Bill.

"I have to forward the ticket to the driver in the car at the time," says Jo. "It's company policy." Ah, just following orders? "Well, yes." Would you do the same thing to Jeremy Clarkson? "Yes, we treat everyone the same."

Right then, we'll take it to Axel Obermuller, global head of economic and corporate affairs in Munich. "Axel Obermuller!" Jo exclaims. Yes, Axel Obermuller. I'll subpoena him, if necessary. I may be going dahn, see, but I ain't going dahn wivout a fight.

webTitle: Hague tries to look on the bright side

fields.headline: Hague tries to look on the bright side
fields.standfirst: Political editor Michael White considers the Tory leader's prospects in the light of an apparent improvement in his party's fortunes
fields.trailText: Political editor Michael White considers the Tory leader's prospects in the light of an apparent improvement in his party's fortunes
fields.body:
William Hague's spin doctors were understandably keen to share what they judged to be the good news. There has not been an abundance of it since he emerged from John Major's election catastrophe three years ago.

Few commentators believe the Tories have a remote chance of winning the general election expected next year. Mr Hague must keep his troops' morale up, ward off threats to his leadership after election day, and find issues that work - ''tunes people can whistle.''

So at Wednesday night's meeting of the shadow cabinet the Conservative leader was able to tell his colleagues that his headline-grabbing tactics before the local election results had paid off, despite uproar in some sections of the media and the byelection defeat in Romsey, hitherto a Tory stronghold.

If it is more significant than just another twitch on a flatlining monitor of the Tory Party's health, then the Hagueites will claim their young leader has finally struck that elusive chord with voters on law and order (for instance, condemning Tony Martin's conviction for murdering a burglar) and calls for a tighter line of asylum.

Labour has been ahead even on law and order in the Blair era. But according to private poll findings for the party, conducted among 1,000 voters last weekend by ICM, the gap between Tories and Labour shrank to 8% - the lowest it has been since sterling fell out of the exchange rate mechanism in 1992.

''This is the end of flatlining,'' Mr Hague, told fellow-MPs, a reference to the depressing fact that ICM has found Tory support stuck between 27% and 32% since the election save for the occasional, brief twitch.

The Tories have risen by 3% to 35% since April, Labour has fallen to 42% while the Lib Dems remain steady on 15%. Smaller parties are on around 8%.

Never to trust selective leaking of private polls is good advice. The ICM team has not yet confirmed the trend, if that is what it is, in its public findings for the Guardian. And ICM's methodology usually puts Labour's poll share lower than its rivals at Mori and Gallup.

The Tories should beware. While Mr Hague told the chums that Romsey was a local problem, a good Lib Dem candidate vigorously supported from party HQ, Charles Kennedy believes it means he can take 50 more seats from both rivals next year. That is, on top of the post-war record 47 seats he already has.

They both can't be right. And Labour believes that a surge for the Tories will work to Tony Blair's advantage. Labour voters are disaffected and apathetic. They feel the government hasn't delivered enough on key public services and they do not feel the Tories are a threat.

That prospect could create a low turnout and hurt Labour as the 1999 EU elections and this month's local elections ( 600 Labour losses) underline. Labour has big plans to target the kind of voters who might just stay away. Millbank planners also look to the flood of extra cash which Gordon Brown plans to pour all over the NHS and education system.

That's fine, provided things go according to plan. But if the economy dips, if further disasters hit the manufacturing sector ( before the £ falls enough to relieve it), if British troops get trapped and killed in a distant land like Sierra Leone ... Mr Hague has proved surprisingly resilient during the lean years. He still believes he can make the euro a campaign winner and plans to attack Mr Blair on tax rates and red tape.

He now has a poll which makes the election outcome look interesting. But don't bet the farm on a different result.

fields.headline: Northern Ireland timeline: January 1999 - May 2000
fields.standfirst: January 2003 - October 2003 | September 2002 - December 2002 | September 2001 - August 2002 | May 2000 - September 2001
fields.trailText:
January 2 1999
After 5,000 Orangemen accompany a march through Portadown town centre in the first Drumcree protest of the new year, Sinn Fein accuses Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble of encouraging the Order.
fields.body:
January 2 1999
After 5,000 Orangemen accompany a march through Portadown town centre in the first Drumcree protest of the new year, Sinn Fein accuses Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble of encouraging the Order.

January 21 1999
The rise in paramilitary punishment attacks prompts the Conservative party to call for a halt to prisoner releases. Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor predicts the imminent failure of the Good Friday agreement unless the IRA takes steps to decommission its weapons.

January 27 1999
Eamon Collins, a leading IRA figure turned informer, is killed in Newry.

March 15 1999
Leading solicitor Rosemary Nelson is killed by a car bomb at her home in Lurgan, Co Armagh. Loyalist groups on ceasefire are implicated.

April 1 1999
The Ulster talks on the Good Friday peace agreement are adjourned, missing the deadline for the creation of the Northern Ireland executive.

April 13 1999
Sinn Fein rejects the Tony Blair/Bertie Ahern initiative to break the deadlock on paramilitary arms decommissioning.

May 15 1999
David Trimble dismisses Downing Street's latest attempt to broker a deal which would see the establishment of the Northern Ireland assembly by June 30. His deputy John Taylor says: "We reiterate our policy that Sinn Fein cannot take up their seats in government without prior IRA decommissioning."

June 17 1999
Soldiers who shot dead 14 Catholics on Bloody Sunday in Londonderry 27 years ago win the right to remain anonymous when giving evidence at the inquiry into the incident.

June 22 1999
IRA terrorist Patrick Magee, whose bomb killed five people in Brighton in 1984, is released after serving 14 years of a 35-year prison sentence. He is the 277th beneficiary of the early release scheme for convicted terrorists, a key aspect of the Good Friday agreement. David Trimble calls on Tony Blair to sack the then Northern Ireland secretary Mo Mowlam.

June 28 1999
The Parades Commission bans the forthcoming Drumcree Orange Order march down the nationalist Garvaghy Road in Portadown.

July 2 1999
After five days of frantic negotiations in Belfast and the passing of the June 30 deadline, the Ulster Unionists are given two weeks to agree to a deal which paves the way for a power-sharing executive in Northern Ireland. There will be a legislative failsafe in the arrangements which would terminate the assembly if any part of the agreement fails.

July 4 1999
On the day of the planned march down Garvaghy Road, the Orange Order disperses within minutes of its annual church service at Drumcree. Mo Mowlam confirms she expects Tony Blair to remove her as Northern Ireland secretary, prompting speculation that such a move is a sop to the unionists.

July 13 1999
A special parliamentary bill is rushed through the Commons which will allow Sinn Fein into the new Northern Ireland executive ahead of IRA disarmament. Mo Mowlam attempts to win David Trimble round by indicating that she will halt the release of IRA prisoners if republicans fail to disarm after the formation of a new power-sharing executive.

July 14 1999
Ulster Unionists refuse to back the British and Irish governments' blueprint providing for a power-sharing executive next week and IRA decommissioning in the summer.

July 15 1999
The British and Irish governments are forced to initiate a review procedure of the 15-month-old Good Friday agreement. Deputy first minister designate Seamus Mallon resigns his post.

August 6 1999
The IRA leadership denies allegations that it was behind a plot to smuggle weapons from the United States to Ireland and claims that an apparent punishment killing in west Belfast was not a breach of the ceasefire.

August 8 1999
The Irish National Liberation Army becomes the first paramilitary group to declare that the armed struggle is over.

August 25 1999
It is revealed that Chris Patten's long-awaited report on reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary will next month recommend a radical transformation of the 77-year-old force, with the dropping of the name, badge and oath of the 13,000-strong RUC.

August 26 1999
Mo Mowlam rules the IRA's ceasefire remains intact, despite conceding that the terror group murdered a Belfast man last month and was behind a US gun-running plot.

September 5 1999
US senator George Mitchell, the architect of the Good Friday agreement, flies back to Ireland to begin new negotiations to attempt to broker an agreement on IRA disarmament and the putative Northern Ireland assembly.

September 9 1999
Chris Patten calls for more Catholics to join the Royal Ulster Constabulary as his report on RUC reform is published.

September 29 1999
David Trimble and Martin McGuinness make conciliatory noises at government meetings during the Labour conference. The Ulster Unionist leader tells Tony Blair he would be prepared to share power with Sinn Fein if the IRA promises to disarm within days of the formation of the executive.

October 11 1999
Peter Mandelson is made Northern Ireland secretary by Tony Blair. Mo Mowlam's removal is widely interpreted as a move to appease the Unionists.

November 16 1999
After 11 weeks of talks led by senator George Mitchell, David Trimble and Gerry Adams issue conciliatory statements preparing to go into government together.

November 19 1999
George Mitchell leaves Belfast after a positive end to his review of the Good Friday agreement. The talks' success is widely attributed to him and his low-key style, which attracted much less media publicity than previous discussions at Hillsborough Castle last April, Downing Street in May and at Stormont in July.

November 23 1999
The Royal Ulster Constabulary is to be awarded the George Cross by the Queen, a move announced four days before David Trimble was due to persuade the Ulster Unionist council it should back the Northern Ireland assembly with Sinn Fein.

November 27 1999
The Ulster Unionists narrowly back David Trimble and agree to sit down with Sinn Fein in a power-sharing executive.

November 29 1999
Northern Ireland's political parties take less than an hour to select the country's first all-inclusive government. Sinn Fein chief negotiator Martin McGuinness controversially gets the education post.

December 8 1999
Gerry Adams claims his car was bugged by the British government when he travelled to meet the IRA during the all-important review of the Good Friday agreement. "I feel shafted by the discovery of this," he says.

January 5 2000
The IRA's new year message warns that any move on decommissioning depends on a dramatic reduction in the British military presence in Northern Ireland.

January 12 2000
The Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, meets Bill Clinton in a blaze of publicity. The US president urges him to make progress on decommissioning. David Trimble threatens to resign if the IRA fails to meet a February deadline.

January 31 2000
Paratrooper Lee Clegg is finally cleared of criminal wrongdoing over the shooting of two teenage joyriders in west Belfast in 1990.

February 11 2000
Peter Mandelson suspends the 72-day-old power-sharing executive and restores direct rule to Northern Ireland from Westminster. The move follows reports from General John de Chastelain's decommissioning commission that it has "received no information from the IRA as to when decommissioning will start."

February 15 2000
The IRA pulls out of disarmament talks with General de Chastelain.

February 19 2000
Renegade spy David Shayler alleges that British intelligence services believe John Lennon secretly helped to fund the IRA.

March 10 2000
Belfast shipbuilder Harland & Wolff loses a crucial £400m contract to build the passenger ship Queen Mary II, which could seal the 139-year-old yard's demise.

March 25 2000
David Trimble narrowly defeats a leadership challenge from Ulster Unionist MP the Rev Martin Smyth. It is feared Mr Trimble's weakened position, and the resurgent right wing of his party, could further jeopardise the peace process.

March 27 2000
The Bloody Sunday public inquiry opens.

April 23 2000
It is rumoured Peter Mandelson will quit as Northern Ireland secretary and return to Britain to help Labour fight the next general election.

May 6 2000
Two days after Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern arrive in Northern Ireland for a fresh round of talks, the IRA agrees to open up its guns to inspection and says it is prepared to "initiate a process that will completely and verifiably put IRA arms beyond use".

May 8 2000
The government promises to cut troop numbers in Northern Ireland if the Ulster Unionists return to government with Sinn Fein and the IRA sticks to its unprecedented pledge to put its weapons beyond use.

webTitle: Fire emergency at US nuclear weapons lab

fields.headline: Fire emergency at US nuclear weapons lab
fields.trailText: A raging fire swept through the abandoned streets of Los Alamos, New Mexico today, burning at least 100 homes and "singeing" the biggest nuclear weapons laboratory in the US. Firefighters admitted they had been forced to retreat in the face of high winds and a water shortage.
fields.body:
A raging fire swept through the abandoned streets of Los Alamos, New Mexico today, burning at least 100 homes and "singeing" the biggest nuclear weapons laboratory in the US. Firefighters admitted they had been forced to retreat in the face of high winds and a water shortage.

At least 18,000 people were evacuated from the city this morning, including 7,000 in the White Rock suburb. No injuries were reported, but President Bill Clinton declared New Mexico a major disaster area.

Flames reached a Los Alamos national laboratory building, but it did not ignite. The laboratory has been shut down and officials stressed that explosives and radioactive material were protected in fireproof facilities.

"We can assure the country and New Mexico that our nuclear materials are safe," said the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, a former New Mexico congressman.

Flying embers have set off spot-fires in the grounds of the laboratory, but officials said plutonium and high explosives were securely sealed in concrete and steel bunkers.

"Of all the things that could threaten the nuclear material, a forest fire is very low on the list of threats," fire information centre spokesman Chris Judson said.

The fire was started by the national park service a week ago to clear brush, but it quickly flared out of control, racing through stands of ponderosa pine across a 4,500-acre area. Winds gusted to 50 mph yesterday - and forecasters said there was a danger that they might increase today and fan the blaze.

Los Alamos, which is 70 miles north of Albuquerque, is a company town for the federal lab. In the 1940s it was used as the operations base for the Manhattan Project, which built the first atomic bomb.

Residents of the community began to flee as winds rose yesterday, hurling flames into tinder-dry, tree-filled residential areas. Police, sheriff's and fire department officials visited each of the 6,000 households in Los Alamos in an effort to evacuate the town.

"We are in a retreat situation," said county firefighting spokesman Bill Lehman last night. The fire was too dangerous to battle head-on, and firefighters were even forced to move their command post. This fire's got a mind of its own," he said. Firefighters were reluctant to back off, but "there was just nothing we could do, because of the wind." Water-dropping helicopters and aeroplanes dropping pink fire retardant bombarded the blaze, hoping to narrow its westward and northward thrust.

The Los Alamos laboratory declared a general emergency yesterday, saying there were grass and brush fires at three of its research facilities. Its weapons-engineering tritium facility was swept by fire, but the masonry building was left intact, lab officials said. The public service company of New Mexico has shut off natural gas service to the laboratory.

fields.headline: Building Britain's political prisons
fields.standfirst:
The proposed detention centres for refugees are driven by politics not necessity, argues Alan Travis, home affairs editor
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The proposed detention centres for refugees are driven by politics not necessity, argues Alan Travis, home affairs editor
fields.body:
The Guardian's disclosure today that ministers have considered detaining asylum seekers in army camps with military guards is one of the clearest indications yet that party politics is now driving the treatment of would-be refugees in Britain.

The leaked document shows that the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, asked her civil servants to look at the option to be used only if there is a new sudden surge in asylum numbers - something on the scale of the Kosovo refugee emergency for example. Although the Home Office paper does not spell it out, the underlying fear facing ministers is that Britain's asylum system, currently in the recovery ward, will once again find itself unable to cope. The leaked document warns that a new crisis will kick in if monthly applications - currently about 6,000 - rise above the 10,000 mark.

The political danger is, of course, that any new breakdown in the asylum system will not only be a tragedy for those genuine refugees trapped in the queue but would also leave the door open for William Hague to mount a renewed campaign calling for even more draconian measures.

What is interesting and different about this morning's leak is that for once it appears that those running the immigration and asylum system were prepared to tell Jack Straw and Ms Roche that such a military option would prove extremely difficult. Not only are there no empty army camps which can be taken out of mothballs, but the prison service certainly do not have the staff to guard them and the army couldn't guarantee to have sufficient men available to do the job.

Even more interestingly, the immigration chiefs say they do not believe it is necessary. By this September they hope to have the capacity to process 13,000 asylum applications a month and now believe that an asylum system that produces a decision within months rather than years will prove sufficient deterrent to prevent the numbers rising much higher than current levels. They believe they can cope "even if the projected asylum intake doubles".

So if the army camps won't happen why is the Home Office looking to open three more detention centres to increase the number they can hold from the current 900 to about 2,700 by next April? Ministers insist that - unlike William Hague's plan - these places will only be used for those whose claims have been rejected both by the immigration service and by the appeals adjudicators and face imminent removal from Britain. The idea is to hold them in detention while the legalities of the deportation process are gone through so they cannot abscond and disappear when the time to leave finally arrives.

Refugee welfare groups have long accepted the use of detention is necessary in these exceptional circumstances but fear that the new places will quickly be used for random detention of those the authorities fear will abscond. They point out that the latest figures show that of 734 people in detention only 11 were facing deportation and most were still waiting for an initial decision.

fields.headline: François Truffaut: Jules et Jim
fields.trailText: The film is full of idyllic moments that translate into doubt and retreat. The atmosphere of gathering gloom with which the film ends is thus totally logical, matching the storm clouds over Europe
fields.body:
One of the most remarkable things about François Truffaut's Jules et Jim, now regarded as the audacious apotheosis of the French New Wave, is that it was adapted from a novel written by a 75-year-old writer, Henri Pierre Roché. What we think of now as a perennially "young" film was thus the product of an old man's sensibility.

Truffaut adapted it with an exceptional panache and flair that was often not present in his later films, despite their other virtues. It wasn't characteristic of the two earlier films of Truffaut himself, and certainly not of Godard and Chabrol's first efforts, but it was at least as daring and definitely richer and more mature.

The film chronicles some 20 years in the lives of its three central characters, starting off in the era of La Belle Epoche, just before the first world war, and ending at the time of the Great Depression and the rise of Hitler. What is so astonishing about it is not just its freshness and vitality - the feeling that life is always exciting if sometimes dangerous - but the way the young director managed to mould his characters so accurately to the events of their time.

He did this with the aid of copious references to old movies, photographs, paintings, novels, music and theatre. Few other films illustrate better the axiom that the best film-makers have to know something about all the arts. But it is the changing reactions of the menage à trois to each other that most of us remember.

Although the film is called Jules et Jim, the dominant character in it is Catherine. She is independent, unpredictable and silly enough to throw herself into the Seine when the two men discuss a Strindberg play without her participation. She is prepared to bear Jules a child but not ready to be either an orthodox wife or mother. She even starts an affair with Jim, half knowing that both men are too fond of each other and of her to break off their friendship. Besides, as she says, "one is never completely in love for more than a moment".

Jeanne Moreau was the perfect choice for Catherine: she gives a performance full of gaiety and charm without conveying an empty-headed bimbo. She makes the watcher understand that this is no ordinary woman whom both men adore. It is possibly the most complete portrait of any feminine character in the entire ouevre of the New Wave and it made her an international star.

The film is full of idyllic moments that translate into doubt and retreat. The atmosphere of gathering gloom with which the film ends is thus totally logical, matching the storm clouds over Europe. "They left nothing behind them," is the commentary's epitaph after the death of Catherine. The whirlwind of life continues but without the three friends.

Jules et Jim seemed revolutionary at the time, but Truffaut's revolution, unlike Godard's, implied not so much the destruction of the past as a turning back to the humanism of Vigo, Renoir and the French cinema of the 30s. The film's "rondo of love" represents both a backward glance at the best of the past and a forward glance into the cinema's future. Its enthusiasm for what the cinema is and can be is what makes it so special.

Credits

Director: François Truffaut
Writers: Jean Gruault, François Truffaut
Original music: Georges Delerue
Starring: Jeanne Moreau, Oskar Werner, Henri Serre
France, 1962, 110 minutes

fields.headline: Unfunny business
fields.standfirst: After 20 years in the movies, comedian Steve Martin is moving back to television. But why did he head for Hollywood in the first place?  Jacques Peretti  explains why he belongs on the small screen
fields.trailText: After 20 years in the movies, comedian Steve Martin is moving back to television. But why did he head for Hollywood in the first place? Jacques Peretti explains why he belongs on the small screen
fields.body:
"I am very excited to be working for TV, but even more excited to be not dead." No, seriously, ha, ha. No really, ha, ha, harr! Steve Martin could be his earnest New Yorker self. Maybe even his self-deprecating novelist self... or high-brow playwright self. But, instead, he chooses to catch you in an arm lock, twist you about a bit, kick you up the arse (sorry, assss), throw you down the stairs. GET OUTTA HERE! (Ah, his Saturday Night Live self).

It's a standard Martin gag. Once upon a time (1976), it would have been for real. But now, there's a line of nodding-dog publicists behind Martin, laughing fakely at the hollow horseplay.

Martin is the perfect example of why comedians should never go into the movies. Somewhere along the line - let's call it the moment they read a script - they stop being funny.

In one way, it's nothing to do with the performer at all, but simply the structure, sorry stricture, of movie-making. Martin's entire film career is an inevitable glacial slide towards schmaltz-mediocrity. It's as if, movie by movie, Hollywood has ground the talent out of the man, ending up with a husk of the original genius, but a perfect Hollywood machine-actor.

Exactly the same thing happened to Eddie Murphy. But it wasn't always so. The Three Stooges inhabited their own comedic world on the big screen. (Martin has always namechecked The Three Stooges) - so, too, Abbott and Costello. When did it go wrong? When another Martin - Dean Martin - was teamed with Jerry Lewis. Hollywood had everything covered with this krazy komedy dream-team: we get the wild guy stuff from the little Jewish one, and the ladies swooning over the tall dark cardboard guy.

It was the beginning of formula comedy. And the beginning of the end for anything resembling originality, spark or danger on the big screen. From the mid-50s onwards, the strait-jacket of the story (boy-girl-conflict-resolution) mattered far more than any wise-cracking shyster the studio might hire to play in it.

Steve Martin's debut big screen outings - The Jerk, Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid and The Man With Two Brains - demonstrate how ill at ease Martin was with movies. They each subvert the crass stupidity of the format film. They're basically a laugh at the expense of the medium in which Martin had suddenly been plonked.

As time went on, and the movies rolled by, Martin got sucked into the system, and started to become the sort of person he would have ripped the shit out of at the beginning of his career. Martin's capitulation of his talent was a victory for Hollywood, proving they could tame the wildest beast.

There's a darker side to the movies Martin produced as his creativity sunk from view: LA Story, Parenthood, House Sitter, Father Of The Bride. Each is a progressively more twisted take on the white neurotic middle-aged male. There's comedy in there somewhere, but you'd be hard pressed to find it amid all the snarling, suppressed anger.

There's another unpalatable side to Martin's act: his pass-the-sick-bag sincerity, always disconcertingly the wrong side of parody. Martin shares the heart-on-sleeve approach of his contemporary, Andy Kaufman, who could never reconcile himself to the system. Martin could, because he was basically Kaufman with a business plan. Bottom line, Martin was always a strange and dislikeble man. Hollywood gave him a chance to escape his comic genius and live out his real life weirdness in straight roles.

Watching Martin do Wild Man physical comedy now is like watching a fat fortysomething John Lydon say: "I Am The Anti-Christ." It lacks that ring of authenticity. It's a self-abasing comment on how far he's moved away from his original self, and perhaps how little that original self meant anyway.

So why does Martin want to return to TV, signing a three-year deal with Carsey-Werner, home of NBC's Third Rock From The Sun?

Because American TV comedy has rediscovered its Martinesque roots: Third Rock is pure Martin circa Saturday Night Live. There's an appetite once more for the kind of comedy that Martin, John Belushi, Dan Ackroyd and Bill Murray pioneered in the mid-70s (Seinfeld's Kramer was an SNL steal, plain and simple).

More importantly, there's an acknowledgement that TV is a more open, radical environment for comedy than the big screen could ever be. Comedians are turned into heroes on the big screen, and it just doesn't fit.

But since Martin's heyday, TV comedy has been revolutionised. And if shows like South Park are as big and mainstream now as Johnny Carson was in the 60s, then how is Martin going to play it? Funny ha, ha or funny peculiar? Or maybe just not funny at all.

fields.headline: Web life: films
fields.standfirst: Paul Trueman on how to beat Barry Norman to all the Hollywood gossip
fields.trailText: Paul Trueman on how to beat Barry Norman to all the Hollywood gossip
fields.body:
Being a film fan in the UK used to be a simple affair - you'd buy a film magazine once a month, read reviews of new films that had already been out for months in the US, and pick up the odd titbit about long-awaited blockbusters. But that's all changed. Nowadays, internet-savvy cinephiles can log on to web sites devoted to a film that may be months away from completion, conduct Q&As with directors and actors while they are still shooting, check out unauthorised photos and reports from on-set spies, and debate online with fellow fans the minutiae of casting and locations.

Even the studios are getting in on the act. The Lord of the Rings (LOTR) is currently being filmed in New Zealand as a trilogy of two-hour films, a mammoth 18-month shoot from which the first film won't even be released until Christmas 2001. Despite this, the films' official web site is already up and running, and a few weeks ago a few minutes of very rough "preview" footage was put up on the web. The site had more than 1.7 million downloads of the footage in the first 24 hours - not bad for a trilogy of films whose debut is still 18 months away, and the last of which won't be out for another three and a half years.

The recent LOTR preview was the first time that a major Hollywood studio has released footage of a film that is still 12 months away from even finishing its shoot, let alone releasing a trailer. If you had spent $200m on a very long strip of celluloid still light years from making a return, you'd want to protect your investment too. This explains why the film studios are so keen on interactive web sites at the moment: it's a way of getting an audience before you even have your film in the can. An increasing chunk of a film's marketing budget is spent online, not necessarily on adverts, but in using the film's official web site as part of the film itself.

For the release of Scream 3, the web site was a mock-up of the web site for Stab 2 - the film based on the original film (still with me?). In a suitably post-modern twist, some pages on the site appeared to have been "hacked" by someone claiming to know something about the murders in the first two Scream films.

Forthcoming animated film Titan A.E will be running a fictional newswire service on its site following the final days leading up to the destruction of the earth, which is the premise of the start of the film. In another blurring-the-lines exercise, Cameron Crowe's forthcoming film about fictional rock band Stillwater has seen an official web site set up, not about the film, but all about the band. A band that doesn't actually exist, mind.

It's not just the studios that have grabbed on to the internet to get closer to the fans. Hollywood beefcake Ben Affleck, has his own site, which he uses to rebuff some of the odder gossip generated by the entertainment rumour mill, as well as fill with pictures of him looking suitably smug and chiselled.

One of the most enjoyably idiosyncratic actors web sites out there is that of Sir Ian McKellen. His site is currently delighting LOTR fanboys, including as it does his on-set online diary, called the Grey Book, full of small revelations about how filming progresses and his fellow cast members.

The lucky studios have fans setting up their own sites in competition. This new league of web-savvy "fanboys" can spend a couple of years working on their web sites, based around films that only last a couple of hours.

Magazines like Total Film and Empire have wisely reduced the amount of space they give to film gossip and news, since the web beats them to the punch every time. A now-famous Lord of the Rings 'spy' shot of the fearsome Nine Riders taking a fag break on set was on the web a month or two before it was in any film magazines.

And, despite all the media attention, Harry Knowles' Ain't It Cool News Site is still streets ahead of most of the competition. Dark Horizons is also well worth checking out, as are specialist sites for the really big films like www.theonering.net for Lord of the Rings, and www.theforce.net for Star Wars.

After a shaky start where all of its news seemed to be gotten from US sites, the UK movies site Popcorn now gets its fair share of scoops, while Mr Showbiz in America is one of the best for hardcore Hollywood movie news. But both these sites are owned by large media companies, Carlton and Disney respectively - so if you want the news told like it is, which films are going to "suck" and which will "rule", the fanboys are your best bet.

Last words should really go to fanboy 'Clem' and his succinct description of the Lord of the Rings preview footage in an Ain't it Cool News discussion: 'I'm speechless - this looks absofreakinglutely PHENOMENAL'

Sight and Sound eat your heart out.
