For the release of Scream 3, the web site was a mock-up of the web site for Stab 2 - the film based on the original film (still with me?). In a suitably post-modern twist, some pages on the site appeared to have been "hacked" by someone claiming to know something about the murders in the first two Scream films. Forthcoming animated film Titan A.E will be running a fictional newswire service on its site following the final days leading up to the destruction of the earth, which is the premise of the start of the film. In another blurring-the-lines exercise, Cameron Crowe's forthcoming film about fictional rock band Stillwater has seen an official web site set up, not about the film, but all about the band. A band that doesn't actually exist, mind. It's not just the studios that have grabbed on to the internet to get closer to the fans. Hollywood beefcake Ben Affleck, has his own site, which he uses to rebuff some of the odder gossip generated by the entertainment rumour mill, as well as fill with pictures of him looking suitably smug and chiselled. One of the most enjoyably idiosyncratic actors web sites out there is that of Sir Ian McKellen. His site is currently delighting LOTR fanboys, including as it does his on-set online diary, called the Grey Book, full of small revelations about how filming progresses and his fellow cast members. The lucky studios have fans setting up their own sites in competition. This new league of web-savvy "fanboys" can spend a couple of years working on their web sites, based around films that only last a couple of hours. Magazines like Total Film and Empire have wisely reduced the amount of space they give to film gossip and news, since the web beats them to the punch every time. A now-famous Lord of the Rings 'spy' shot of the fearsome Nine Riders taking a fag break on set was on the web a month or two before it was in any film magazines. And, despite all the media attention, Harry Knowles' Ain't It Cool News Site is still streets ahead of most of the competition. Dark Horizons is also well worth checking out, as are specialist sites for the really big films like www.theonering.net for Lord of the Rings, and www.theforce.net for Star Wars. After a shaky start where all of its news seemed to be gotten from US sites, the UK movies site Popcorn now gets its fair share of scoops, while Mr Showbiz in America is one of the best for hardcore Hollywood movie news. But both these sites are owned by large media companies, Carlton and Disney respectively - so if you want the news told like it is, which films are going to "suck" and which will "rule", the fanboys are your best bet. Last words should really go to fanboy 'Clem' and his succinct description of the Lord of the Rings preview footage in an Ain't it Cool News discussion: 'I'm speechless - this looks absofreakinglutely PHENOMENAL' Sight and Sound eat your heart out.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A real feast today as all the latest rumours are cut into thin succulent slices, placed on a warm plate and soaked in gravy
fields.trailText: Liverpool have launched a £4m bid for French international Christian Karembeu, reports the Mirror. The versatile midfielder certainly seems interested, admitting last night: "I have a lot of admiration for Gerard Houllier and I am certainly interested in Liverpool's proposal."
fields.body:
Liverpool have launched a £4m bid for French international Christian Karembeu, reports the Mirror. The versatile midfielder certainly seems interested, admitting last night: "I have a lot of admiration for Gerard Houllier and I am certainly interested in Liverpool's proposal."

But according to the Sun, it is Middlesbrough who will sign the 29 year-old Karembeu - in a cut-price £2.1m deal. They claim the Real Madrid star flew into Teesside last night to complete negotiations on a £2m a year contract - having been convinced by Boro manger Bryan Robson that his club, not Liverpool, will suit him best.

The Sun also report that Brazilian World Cup star Junior Baiano heads Arsenal's summer shopping list. The 30-year old Vasco Da Gama defender is apparently seen as the long-term replacement for Tony Adams. Arsene Wenger is also close to signing French internationals Sylvain Wiltord and Robert Pires as part of a £20m Highbury shake-up.

The paper also claims that Terry Sheringham has been offered a two-year contract by Portuguese club Sporting Lisbon.

Paul Gascoigne will spend the summer down under on loan to Joondalup City in Perth, according to the Daily Mail. Middlesbrough have agreed the deal with the Western Australia State League side, who will pick up Gascoigne's wages of more than £20,000 a week. Joondalup beat off interest from the U.S. and other Aussie teams by promising Gascoigne, a keen angler, some of the best fishing in the world.

Gerard Houllier is after Newcastle left-back Didier Domi. The Liverpool boss has already had a £4m offer turned down, and is now considering increasing the bid.

Teamtalk claims that Didier Deschamps will quit Chelsea this summer. "I want to play in the Champions League next season," he told French radio yesterday - Lyon are lining up a £5m double swoop for Deschamps and Frank Leboeuf.

Lilian Thuram has told Manchester United that he is flattered by their interest. "Manchester United are one of the best clubs in the world, and it is very gratifying to be wanted by them," he says. "I have heard their interest in me, and who could pass up the chance of going to play for them?" But don't expect him to sign up any time soon. "I have just extended my contract and I didn't do so with the intention of changing my mind straight away," he insists.

Gustavo Poyet could quit Chelsea to become manager of his former club Real Zaragoza. Teamtalk report that Zaragoza are set to lose current coach Chechu Rojo to Athletic Bilbao and they want the Uruguayan international to replace him.

Turkish club Fenerbahce claim they not only have an agreement with Chelsea star Gianfranco Zola - but may sign his team-mate Gabriele Ambrosetti as well. "Zola is ours," Fenerbahce's general secretary, Vidat Olcay, tells Planet Football. "We have an agreement with the player, and are in direct contact with him." Olcay also suggests that Ambrosetti may join his Italian counterpart at the club: "Zola wants to come here, but he has also asked to bring another couple of Italians - one of which could be Ambrosetti."

Planet Football also report that Chelsea may enter into a bidding war with West Ham for Lyon's Frederic Kanoute - and will make an offer much closer to the French club's valuation of the player.

Chilian international Clarence Acuna is being strongly tipped to join Tottenham, according to Planet Football. But his dream move to England may be in doubt after he failed a dope test while on international duty with Chile, although the player claims: "I never took anything - not even an aspirin."

The Star claims that Sheffield Wednesday have put Barnsley boss Dave Bassett on the top of their managerial wish list, ahead of Joe Kinnear and Steve Bruce.

And Manchester City will make a £3m for Ipswich skipper Matt Holland - if the Suffolk side fail in the play-offs.

webTitle: Satisfied customers at a discount in Marks & Spencer

fields.headline: Satisfied customers at a discount in Marks & Spencer
fields.trailText: Morrisons is keeping its shoppers, predominantly in the north of England, happier and more loyal than any of its rivals, while Marks & Spencer is losing the satisfaction war .
fields.body:
Morrisons is keeping its shoppers, predominantly in the north of England, happier and more loyal than any of its rivals, while Marks & Spencer is losing the satisfaction war .

According to research by Verdict, the retail consultants, and Forum Europe, brand experts, Marks & Spencer has suffered a dramatic fall in its rating among customers.

"There can be little doubt that services levels, and the shopping experience in general at M&S, is not what it was.

"Nevertheless, it is important to judge this customer feedback in the context of a past, when the company represented the standards by which other retailers measured their own performance," the research, to be published today, concludes.

Based on asking shoppers to give their experiences at high street retailers marks out of 10, the research established that Morrisons received a higher score of "advocates" - marks of nine or 10 - than any other re tailer.

Asda also scored highly and was the most improved retailer for its food business and its personal care departments in the survey, which is to published twice yearly.

Superdrug and Next are also improving fast, the survey found. B&Q, the do-it-yourself retailer, is also cited in the research, for its higher loyalty ratings among consumers.

M&S's "advocate" score was just 12%, and Dixons, the electrical retailer, also attracted few high scores from shoppers.

Forum indicated that 70% of customer defections to other brands were the result of dissatisfaction with the shopping experience, rather than price or quality of products.

fields.headline: Airtours to fly by internet
fields.standfirst:
Travel agent warns off the dot.com upstarts

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Airtours yesterday launched itself into the internet travel wars and warned newcomer rivals such as Lastminute.com that their days could be numbered.
fields.body:
Airtours yesterday launched itself into the internet travel wars and warned newcomer rivals such as Lastminute.com that their days could be numbered.

The company said it would to use its £100m e-commerce offensive to prevent the new breed of virtual travel agents, including groups such as e-bookers and Expedia, from making a significant impact.

Chairman David Crossland said: "We are not in the business of helping new entrants trying to establish their business on the back of our investment.

"As far as we are concerned, we are not a supplier to Lastminute.com and the like who cannot offer us anything in return."

He said the group had already established links with the major tour operators and received a commission for selling a rival's holiday via its network of shops. New entrants, however, offered little in the way of compensation, he said.

Mr Crossland said that while the online holiday firms were technologically advanced, Airtours' support structure was superior. "In terms of back office they are 10 years behind us and the major operators," he said.

He suggested that the new internet companies were profiting from the investment in aircraft and resorts made by the traditional bricks and mortar firms.

Airtours' plans centre on Mytravelco which will offer holidays from Airtours and other tour operators and airlines including package deals, cruises, car hire and modular travel, the company said.

Access to the site will be via the internet, new generation mobile phones, digital television, in-flight and on-board entertainment systems, in-room hotel systems and through all Airtours retail shops and hypermarkets.

Mytravelco's current internet site is being developed and upgraded. Technology partners include BT, BroadVision, MediaBridge, Oracle and Sun Microsystems.

The company said it is expanding Late Escapes bargain and last minute offers, currently available via Teletext, to include the world's largest travel leisure travel auction site, www.lateescapes.com. Late Escapes will be re-launched in June 2000.

It is also planning a virtual low cost airline named flycheap.com, to be launched by the end of 2000, created by pooling the seat-only sales of Airtours' European airlines: Airtours International, Premiair and Fly FTi.

webTitle: The Test cricketer executed for murder

fields.headline: The Test cricketer executed for murder
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing questions? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who played for England before the Second World War, and was hanged for murder after it? asks Mark Seymour
fields.body:
Who played for England before the Second World War, and was hanged for murder after it? asks Mark Seymour

Actually the player concerned played against England. His name was Leslie Hylton, and he was a fast bowler from Jamaica who played six Tests for West Indies in 1934-35 and 1939 (he took 16 wickets at 26.12). He was later arrested for murdering his wife, and was executed in Kingston in 1955.

Am I correct in thinking that Brian Close lost an eye in a car accident yet returned to play first-class cricket? A colleague's nephew has just lost an eye through a tumour, and as he's a keen cricketer himself I thought it would cheer him up if this is right, asks Tom Wilkinson

It wasn't Brian Close, although his driving was famously bad (one colleague recalls spotting Close's car in a ditch at the side of the road, with the uninjured Close still inside, trying to find the horse-racing commentary on the radio). Colin Milburn, the heavyweight Northants batsman, lost an eye in a car accident in 1969. He did recover sufficiently to play first-class cricket again, but he was never quite the same, and did not play any more matches for England. Someone who did go on to play Test cricket after a similar accident was the Nawab of Pataudi (later Mansur Ali Khan), who played 46 Tests for India - 40 of them as captain - after losing an eye in a car accident in 1961. He had been a record-breaking schoolboy batsman - and was still good enough after his accident to score 2793 Test runs, with a double-century against England at Delhi in 1963-64 and five other hundreds.

What were Imran Khan's first-class stats for Sussex in 1983 and 1985? asks Faisal Ahmad

Imran topped both Sussex's County Championship batting and bowling averages in 1983. He scored 1260 runs at 57.27 and, bowling only 46.2 overs because he was recovering from a leg injury, took 12 wickets at just 7.16, including a remarkable spell of 6 for 6 against Warwickshire at Edgbaston. That put him top of the national bowling averages - and he was also sixth in the batting. In 1985 he again finished at the head of Sussex's Championship averages in batting (846 runs at 70.50) and bowling (48 wickets at 19.83). That left him fifth in the batting and sixth in the national bowling averages.

Where can I find facts and figures from last winter's England A tour? asks Andy Turner

Full details of the tour can be found on Cricinfo at http://www-uk.cricket.org/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/1999-2000/ENG-A_IN_BDESH/ (this is the Bangladesh leg: the New Zealand part of the tour is nearby).

Could you please let me whether an Abraham Charles Miller played for either Lancashire or Yorkshire during the 1870s or 1880s? asks Mike Simms

I'm afraid that no-one of that name has ever played first-class cricket in England. It's possible that he played in a minor game that wouldn't show up in the first-class records. To find that out you'd need to contact Yorkshire and Lancashire and ask to be put in touch with a local cricket historian.

Could you please tell me over how many overs the one-day tournaments in England are being played this year? asks Pete Farrow

In the Norwich Union National Cricket League (mostly played on Sundays) both teams will face 45 overs in an uninterrupted match. All the other major one-day competitions - the NatWest one-day internationals, the Benson & Hedges Cup and the NatWest Trophy - involve 50-overs-a-side games.

I have been trying for some years to get hold of the Wisden Cricketers' Almanackfor 1965. Can you advise on any sources? asks Richard Leake

Copies of Wisdenfrom the 1960s are not too difficult to find, and not terribly expensive, unlike the very early editions. If you have the new Almanack, there is a directory of dealers who specialise in cricket books on page 1565. Or you could try Amazon or Barnes & Noble on the web - both have extensive secondhand sections. I've just looked on Amazon and found a 1965 Wisdenbeing offered for £50: if you shop around you may be able to find one cheaper than that.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: 11 May: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 11 May: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Halle Berry sentenced over hit and run incident, Julia Roberts to produce a romance and Jerry Zucker takes the reins of Rat Race
fields.body:
 Bulworth actress Halle Berry has been sentenced to three years probation and ordered to pay a $13,500 fine after pleading no contest to a misdemeanour charge in Hollywood. Beverly Hills Superior Court Judge Charles Rubin also stipulated that the actress must perform 200 hours of community service. Berry, 33, had been charged with a hit and run incident in February when she jumped a red light, ploughed into another car and fled the scene. She suffered minor head injuries in the accident, while the driver of the other car was left with a broken wrist. The subsequent investigation ruled that Berry had not been under the influence of drugs or alcohol when the incident took place.

 Julia Roberts will make her debut as a bona-fide movie producer when she oversees the development of an as yet untitled romance in tandem with an as yet unnamed studio. In fact, the only named player in the deal so far is Roberts's production company Shoelace, which has signed a five year agreement with an independent studio currently being established by former Disney executive Joe Roth. Shoelace have purchased the rights to a love-story script by Sue Kramer, which they will develop in collaboration with Roth's company. Roberts will serve as producer and may well also star in the film. For the time being, the unnamed movie's cast remain unnamed.

 Airplane! creator Jerry Zucker will return to directing comedy features when he takes the reins of the zany road movie Rat Race. Produced by Zucker Co and Alphaphille and distributed by Paramount, Rat Race follows the fortunes of six greedy contestants in a Las Veags gambling wager who clamour to find the whereabouts of a secret locker crammed with $2m in cash. The Hollywood Reporter claims that Ashley Judd and Matthew Broderick are being lined up for the lead roles.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Delivery suite
The proliferation of online shopping has brought with it inevitable complaints of concealed costs and delivery problems. But plenty of conventional mail-order companies are still giving hi-tech outfits a run for their money when it comes to shoddy service.

MA Godfrey of Leeds, Terry Duffy of St Helens, S Cann of Doncaster and Renata Harvey of Cornwall are all waiting for goods they ordered months ago from Home Selections, part of a company called Temps L, which is based in Sittingbourne. Duffy's experience was typical. On ringing to inquire about his order, he was informed that he was 26th in the queue. When an operator finally answered, Duffy was transferred straight back to the automated answer service. "I was instructed to press option two, was treated to a Latin mass, overtures from most of the world's musicals and finally another operator, who did the same as the first and so on," he says. Duffy's next phone bill showed the call had cost £21. "This means I have spent an extra £21 trying to buy an item worth £48," he says.

 "We're sorry, all our lines are busy. Please try again," intones a recorded message each time Consumer tries to ring Temps L. In desperation, we appeal to Kent Trading Standards, which admits that it has received a number of complaints from empty-handed customers.

"We have had meetings with the company to try to sort out their problems, but we don't see them as a problem company," says a spokesman. The difficulty seems to be an over-zealous advertising campaign which attracted an unexpected multitude of orders. "They are having problems meeting demand, the warehouse is not fully staffed and there were not enough people to answer the phones," says Trading Standards. "They are recruiting new people but it all might take some time because they seem to have lost a lot of customers' details." Those still waiting are advised to write to the company detailing their order. Two months after the first attempt, Consumer has a last shot at reaching the firm. "I'm sorry," says the familiar voice, "all our lines are busy..."

Musical jeers
Several readers feel they have been suffering at the hands of book and music clubs, the kind that offer you the complete works of Jane Austen for £1.99 provided you buy a full-price book each quarter for the next two years. They are enticing to join but not, it seems, so easy to leave.

Britannia Music Club, which sells discounted CDs to its members, obliges them to buy a recommended recording each month unless they write to refuse each dispatch. When Evelyn Mann of Clacton-on-Sea tried to cancel her membership, having fulfilled all her requirements, she was told that the recommended recording could not be cancelled on a permanent basis. This meant she faced having to write to refuse it every month ad infinitum. Philip Freeman of Wolverhampton says he can't break free of Britannia either because, he says, "they've disqualified all but one of my purchases from their required six regular CDs in two years, on the grounds that they were not 'regular', although a search of their monthly catalogues failed to disclose any alternative descriptions for them".

 Britannia says Mann's account was cancelled as requested but the wrong letter was sent. Someone has now rung her to apologise. As for Freeman, the club says some offers are heavily discounted and are therefore excluded from members' required quota of purchases. "These prices and conditions are highlighted in special sales information provided at the time of mailing."

Cold comfort
Won't-take-no-for-an-answer cold calls from salesmen, so often featured on this page, have been exercising Michael Grosvenor Myer of Cambridge. "People are too polite to these nuisances," he says. "My own technique with them is simply to put the phone down on them as soon as they have identified themselves as being Wobbly Windows or Krumbly Kitchens with 'a wonderful piece of news you'."

My tip, for those feeling sorely vengeful, is to ask said salesman to hang on while you turn the hob down or answer the doorbell. Then don't return. The joy of this method lies in calculating the phone bill - and man hours - the company is wasting as it hovers for your custom. If anyone has other advice, please share it.

Dead letters
Last week we discovered why so much junk mail addressed to either the long dead or the long since moved clogs our doorsteps. The owner of a small mail order firm had written in complaining that the address list he'd purchased via a broker was fearsomely out of date, a fact he only realised after receiving 3,000 of his mail shots "returned to sender".

Now D Kelly of Leeds has received an offer of tampons addressed to her 90-year-old grandmother. Not only did her grandmother die last year, but she had never lived at the Leeds address. Ian McRobert of Peterborough is not surprised. "I'm a postman and can tell you that even reputable firms use rubbish mailing lists," he says. "One this morning had 25% of its names wrong and one earlier this week had addressees who'd died years ago. It's unlikely that the mailing list people would even know when someone had died as the Royal Mail no longer returns mail marked 'deceased', merely 'gone away'."

Meanwhile the Royal Mail writes to say it has launched a booklet to tell householders how to avoid junk mail. Requests addressed to Freepost, Fair Play will, apparently, suffice.

Off the hook
In January 1996 Suzanne Williams of Gwynedd both wrote and telephoned Vodafone to cancel her contract with the necessary 28 days' notice. Weeks later an invoice arrived for February line rental and, when she queried it, Vodafone denied having received the cancellation. Williams claims numerous letters from her since then have gone unanswered, including two sent recorded delivery this year, and her case is now in the hands of a debt collection agency.

 Vodafone maintains it never saw or heard the cancellation notices but promises Consumer it will drop its demands and restore Williams' credit status.

Net loss
It seems cruel to attack lastminute.com when it is still reeling from the recent stock market blip, but Jane Creaton of London feels some flak is justified. She booked a hotel room through the website then found it available elsewhere for £20 less. The sales blurb promised customers they would be refunded the difference if they found a cheaper alternative, so Creaton emailed... and emailed, and emailed. Five messages in all over two months and not a single reply. Two phone calls were no more successful due, says Creaton, to "their spectacularly unhelpful sales assistants".

 Lastminute.com's eager new PR firm is far more forthcoming. "Due to a small administrative oversight, we regret that Ms Creaton's emails were directed to an incorrect mailbox," says a spokesman. "She has now accepted our apology and the £20 she is owed, plus a goodwill voucher."

webTitle: Georgia O'Keefe movie gets green-light at last

fields.headline: Georgia O'Keefe movie gets green-light at last
fields.trailText: A long-gestating movie based on the life of American painter Georgia O'Keeffe has been finally given the go-ahead
fields.body:
A long-gestating movie based on the life of American painter Georgia O'Keeffe has been finally given the go-ahead. A last minute injection of German cash has allowed the project to progress despite the US backing falling through.

The film, called Till the End of Time, will focus on the stormy relationship between O'Keeffe and the photographer Alfred Stieglitz. Linda Fiorentino (best known for her ballsy performances in The Last Seduction and Dogma) will star as O'Keeffe. Stieglitz will be played by Ben Kingsley.

Known for her sensuous, stylised depictions of nature (flowers, rock formations), Georgia O'Keeffe is generally regarded as one of the leading female artists of the 20th century. The film, directed by Marek Kanievska, will begin shooting on June 12 in Santa Fe, New Mexico, where O'Keeffe produced her most famous work.

webTitle: Moral virtue hard to stomach as City come up

fields.headline: Moral virtue hard to stomach as City come up
fields.trailText: "The Premiership deserves Manchester City as much as Manchester City deserve the Premiership." Discuss.
fields.body:
"The Premiership deserves Manchester City as much as Manchester City deserve the Premiership." Discuss.

Actually, there don't seem to be that many people around who would care to disagree with Joe Royle's statement after his side had beaten Blackburn to win automatic promotion out of the First Division.

Presumably he meant that a club with a big fan base, new stadium on the horizon and 9.9% owned by Sky is just what the Premiership is lacking. While City's well-documented travails in the Second Division had earned them, or at least their fans, a place in the sun.

It's true that City deserve to be in the Premiership, for the simple reason that they accumulated more points than the team that came third in the First Division. But the alleged moral virtue of their long-suffering fans, hinted at even more strongly by others than by Royle in the past week, is a bit hard to stomach.

There are plenty of other clubs which have fallen further, and for far longer periods, whose fans have stuck by them in similar fashion. Wolves, Bolton, Burnley and Sheffield United have all tasted life in the old Fourth Division, Middlesbrough and Sunderland the Third. Their crowds may have sunk much lower than City's over time, but that was in the days when the idea of screening lower division football live on television would have seemed about as likely as BBC gardening-show presenters posing for saucy calendars.

City, although they have been down pretty deep, have not been down for that long. Their last Premiership season was in 1995-96, which even in the short attention span world of big football is still within most people's living memory.

The explanation for City's popularity, of course, is not hard to find. Manchester City are not Manchester United. In fact they have successfully (though mostly accidentally) built an image that is diametrically opposed to that of their neighbours.

First there was the claim that City were Manchester's real club, while United fans tended to be out-of-towners. Since United now have fans in every town and village in the UK (and, soon, the world) this is probably true, though surveys suggest the geographical differences between fans who actually attend matches at Old Trafford and Maine Road are not that great.

More gripping for outsiders, though, has been City's determination to pursue failure with the same vigour Alex Ferguson has hounded success. The loveable losers, the cock-up kings who do everything the hard way. Well, maybe, though don't try telling that to Ipswich fans.

The problem is that the other side of Joe Royle's equation demands that City sharpen up their act. When he says the Premiership deserves them, he presumably doesn't mean as court jesters. If City want to be loved by the Premiership, they are going to have to be Sky blues in more ways than one. Contenders, in other words. If that happens they might win respect, but no one will want to cuddle them any more.

webTitle: Shipyard jobs vital for peace process

fields.headline: Shipyard jobs vital for peace process
fields.standfirst: The new deal to build ferries at Harland and Wolff is important for political as well as economic stability in Belfast
fields.trailText: 11 May, 10am: The new deal to build ferries at Harland and Wolff is important for political as well as economic stability in Belfast, argues Observer Belfast correspondent Henry McDonald.
fields.body:
On July 21 1920 a mass meeting of Protestant workers was held in the yard of Workman, Clark and Co in Belfast. After the meeting, during which some "very hot" unionist speeches were made arguing for the removal of Sinn Fein and Roman Catholics from the shipyards, bodies of men carrying sticks and clubs descended on Harland and Wolff - the site of the third most important centre for shipbuilding in the British empire.

A police report at the time described the subsequent violence as a "general hunt" for Catholic workers, some of whom were severely beaten and were thrown into the water, having to swim for their lives.

Thus began, in the middle of the IRA's war against British rule and the establishment of a separate northern/unionist state, the mass expulsion of Catholic workers from the shipyard, which built the "unsinkable" Titanic that sunk in 1912.

The expulsion of thousands of Catholic workers left a deep psychological scar on northern nationalists. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that when news broke in April 2000 that the shipyard was on the verge of closure, there was a certain amount of schadenfreude within the city's republican community.

Nationalists point to the fact that the yard's workforce continued to provide the shock troops for loyalist street protest right up until the 1980s.

During the 1974 Ulster workers' strike, which brought down the last power-sharing government in Northern Ireland, the shipyard was closed thanks to a combination of outright intimidation and loyalist militancy among the stagers who built the scaffolding around ships under construction.

But the delight shared by republicans over the shipyard's uncertain future is short-sighted, because the loss of shipbuilding will have a negative effect on the entire economy in Northern Ireland.

Today the area around Harland and Wolff represents the old and the new Belfast. Yellow cranes tower over the terraced streets of loyalist east Belfast, where support for the union is as strong as ever.

Yet less than a quarter of a mile from the 300-acre Harland and Wolff site is a new belt of luxury flats, the Hilton hotel, the Waterfront Hall and multistorey offices for companies such as British Telecom. Dublin-based consortiums have also moved their newly-earned money from the Celtic Tiger in the south into property in Northern Ireland and own many of the new apartments, which cost up to a quarter of a million pounds each.

The prospect of closure at Harland and Wolff impacts politically on the loyalist psyche and fuels paranoia about a British economic withdrawal from Northern Ireland. In an age of uncertainty the shipyard's closure could only drive many of them further towards rejectionist unionism rather than the new unionism of David Trimble.

Most mainstream politicians and commentators from both sides of the Irish border recognise the economic and political dangers in allowing shipbuilding to die in Belfast.

That is why they will be relieved that the new deal to build four roll-on/roll-off ferries at the yard secures, in the short term at least, not only 1,700 jobs but also shores up stability in unionist areas unsure of their political future.

webTitle: Forrest Gump director takes the B-movie route

fields.headline: Forrest Gump director takes the B-movie route
fields.trailText: A-line Hollywood director Robert Zemeckis - best known for his big-budget, high-returning blockbusters Ð has turned to B-movies, remaking a series of schlock William Castle horror films
fields.body:
A-line Hollywood director Robert Zemeckis - best known for his big-budget, high-returning blockbusters Ð has turned to B-movies, remaking a series of schlock William Castle horror films. Having already served as a producer on two Castle remakes, Zemeckis will now direct a third. Macabre, based on a cheap 1958 horror flick, will be costed at a relatively paltry $15m - a far cry from the budgets usually enjoyed by Zemeckis.

Zemeckis and producer Joel Silver set up a company, Dark Castle, at the start of 1999 with the specific aim of remaking forgotten William Castle creepers for today's teenage audiences. The decision paid instant dividends when Dark Castle's first picture, The House on Haunted Hill (starring Geoffrey Rush and Famke Janssen), converted an initial outlay of $15m into box-office returns of over $80m. The second Dark Castle offering, 13 Ghosts, will begin shooting in July, directed by Steven Beck. Once that is in the can, Zemeckis will direct his version of Macabre.

William Castle, who died of a heart attack in 1977, enjoyed a prolific and sporadically profitable career making cheap and tatty horror films, mainly for the drive-in market. In cinema folklore, he occupies a place somewhere between Ed Wood and Roger Corman and was always regarded as more of an entertainer than a serious artist. His most notorious film remains The Tingler, for which Castle wired the cinema seats to a low electronic voltage in order to literally shock the viewer when the monster first appears.

Early signs are that Zemeckis may have found a profitable niche re-fitting Castle's inherently cheap films for the MTV generation. But the director of such big-budget pictures as Forrest Gump and the Back to the Future series hasn't completely given up the day job. Zemeckis has recently completed work on the Hollywood pictures Cast Away and What Lies Beneath. Both boast budgets well over the $50m mark.

fields.headline: A poem for Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: To celebrate the opening of Tate Modern, the Guardian commissioned a new piece from acclaimed poet James Fenton
fields.trailText:
This turbine hall, these galleries of light

Are freighted with a purpose and a power.

This bridge is like a contract, and this tower

Evidence of a legacy, a right.
fields.body:
This turbine hall, these galleries of light

Are freighted with a purpose and a power.

This bridge is like a contract, and this tower

Evidence of a legacy, a right.

Massive with possibility they stand

Open to such surprise as may exist

Deep in the pulse, the chambers of the heart;

Exacting fresh precision from the hand,

Risk in the brush, resilience in the wrist,

New thoughts to paint, new passions to impart.

fields.headline: Chris Lander
fields.standfirst: Cricket ghost-writer strode in Botham's shadow
fields.trailText: Crash. It would have been hard to find a more appropriate nickname for the cricket journalist Chris Lander, who has died of cancer aged 59.
fields.body:
Crash. It would have been hard to find a more appropriate nickname for the cricket journalist Chris Lander, who has died of cancer aged 59. Crash because that would be the sound that accompanied a life into which he seemed to pack a hundred years. Six weeks ago, when a group of us gathered for our traditional pre-summer golf day, he had seemed fine, biffing away with his customary lack of success but unbending enthusiasm.

Crash was a journalist brought up in the old school. Born in Plymouth and educated at the same Wellington School as Jeffrey Archer, he cut his teeth on the Express and Echo in Exeter and the Devon News Service, before joining Reg Hayter's Sports Agency, the academy from which so many accomplished sports journalists have emerged.

Apart from a three-year sabbatical at the Sun in the mid-80s - he was hired because of his close relationship with Ian Botham, whose column he ghosted for many years - he was a Mirror man for the best part of 30 years, writing about cricket zestfully, incisively and with full use of the exclamation mark.

Once, at Queen's Park Oval in Trinidad, at the insistence of his sports editor, he filed his copy from a swimming pool, placed on the boundary edge by sponsors, and was caught on television, mobile phone in one hand, beer in another, and surrounded by bikini-clad lovelies. In the latter years he became irked by these demands for "an angle", although he always supplied it.

Occasionally players would get upset, but none ever held it against him, because they knew how much he cared for the game. His relationship with Botham (or The Legend, as Lander was prone to calling him) extended beyond professionalism or even simple friendship into something fraternal. Through the triumphs and the tribulations, Lander was there, not just as ghost but as confidant.

Not a naturally athletic man but one of immense willpower, Lander accompanied Botham through 2,500 miles of charity walking. The very first, the inaugural stroll from John O'Groats to Land's End, created its own Lander legend, for he had driven to the north of Scotland to cover just the opening leg for the Mirror.

When the Sun's own man pulled out after the first day, however, Lander, who had decided for the hell of it to go a bit further, was persuaded to change papers, and, with no training whatsoever, completed the entire walk. He then returned to the start to retrieve his car, which had remained in a John O' Groats car park.

His personal life was delightfully convoluted and he never married. But an early relationship produced a daughter, Christine, with whom he was reunited when she was an adolescent, and he also leaves two grandchildren, Justine and Claudia, and countless friends who will miss him enormously.

 Christopher Lander, sports journalist, born April 9 1941; died May 5 2000

fields.headline: Florentines try to silence Hannibal
fields.trailText: Belatedly discovering his all-consuming appetite, some Florentines have tried to thwart Hannibal "the cannibal" Lecter from killing in their city today lest their tranquil image be ruined.
fields.body:
Belatedly discovering his all-consuming appetite, some Florentines have tried to thwart Hannibal "the cannibal" Lecter from killing in their city today lest their tranquil image be ruined.

The Greens and Popular party want to stop a gruesome murder scene from the sequel to The Silence of the Lambs being filmed inside the Palazzo Vecchio, a renaissance monument to good taste.

The giddiness that surrounded the arrival of the actor Anthony Hopkins, who will portray Lecter, and director Ridley Scott has turned to concern that tourists who see the film may never again look at Florence the same way.

In an open letter to the mayor, Leonardo Domenici, the two parties begged him to retract the authorisation for the three-day shooting of the sequel, called Hannibal.

"This will add nothing to Florence's prestige in the world," they said in the letter. "We believe instead that the most intimate location in the city would become the setting for morbid thrills and vulgar horror."

Although the parties are members of the city's ruling centre-left coalition, it was thought unlikely the mayor will oblige.

Nevertheless, the Florence newspaper, La Nazione, has queried the value of transforming the city's image from sun-kissed culture and civilisation to that of blood and cannibalism.

Thomas Harris, whose best-seller spawned the Oscar-winning Silence of the Lambs, was inspired to base his sequel in the Tuscan capital by a 1992 visit.

He attended the trial of the so-called monster of Florence, Pietro Pacciani, who was accused of killing eight courting couples in the woods in and around Florence between 1968 and 1985.

However, one of the investigators suspected that Pacciani was too stupid to have arranged the killings and may have been following the orders of a respected local professional, a notion that is said to have intrigued Harris.

The farm labourer was acquitted on appeal but faced another trial until he died of a heart attack in 1998.

In the new film, Hannibal flees an American hospital for the criminally insane and reinvents himself as the cultured, Dante-quoting custodian of the Capponi library, after brutally creating a vacancy.

He is tracked down by a mutilated former victim, played by Gary Oldman, and FBI agent Clarice Starling, played this time by Julianne Moore instead of Jodie Foster. Mayhem ensues.

Taking his cue from the novel, Mr Scott said he envisaged the film as partly a twisted love story - a "dark opera".

When Hopkins arrived last week and joked about eating only beans, Florentines assumed his character would be less destructive than the previous Hannibal, who crossed the Alps with elephants. But the Greens and the Popular party fear that the fortress-like Palazzo Vecchio's treasures, which include renaissance masterpieces by Michelangelo, Giorgio Vasari and Cecchino Salviati, by might never escape the cannibal's shadow.

 Hannibal is due for release in February 2001.

webTitle: Lara pulls out of England tour

fields.headline: Lara pulls out of England tour
fields.trailText: Brian Lara has pulled out of the West Indies squad to tour England this summer, according to a report in the Independent.
fields.body:
Brian Lara has pulled out of the West Indies squad to tour England this summer, according to a report in the Independent.

The former Windies skipper is reported to have told his country's selectors he wants to extend his exile from the international arena on Tuesday.

The 31-year-old left-hander's self-imposed break from the game - he missed the home series with Zimbabwe and Pakistan - had been expected to come to an end in time for the tour, which starts in three weeks' time.

Lara, who underwent psychic counselling, had been told not to return to the Test arena until he felt the motivation to do so.

The rest from the game was taken after Lara's side's disastrous display in New Zealand. He resigned the captaincy following a whitewash against the Black Caps, having lost both Tests and all five one-day internationals.

A week later he announced he would "use the time away to seek the assistance of appropriate professionals to rebuild all facets of my games so as to sustain the remainder of my cricketing career".

Former West Indies team manager Clive Lloyd said: "It is a shame that a man with so much talent is not taking part in the game he loves.

"I am really saddened by that. I thought the little break he had would have been the sort of rest he needed to come back and show his talents."

Asked on Radio 4 if Lara was dismayed at the Windies' demise after years of dominating the game, Lloyd said: "Brian perhaps got a bit disillusioned because the young talent was not coming through quickly and the team were not doing well.

"I don't think anyone had any indication that he wanted to give it up. I would love to see Lara back playing again - he is poetry in motion in full flow.

"He got on well with his players; there was never a particular problem there. He sets such high standards and if you don't meet them he feels disappointed.

"Brian is a lovely young man but at the moment he can't come to grips with things."

fields.headline: Verne's Danube rewritten by son
fields.trailText: Almost 100 years after he finished writing it, one of Jules Verne's last novels finally appeared in French bookshops yesterday as the author wrote it - although readers may prefer the adulterated version.
fields.body:
Almost 100 years after he finished writing it, one of Jules Verne's last novels finally appeared in French bookshops yesterday as the author wrote it - although readers may prefer the adulterated version.

Le beau Danube jaune, which the author of Around The World In Eighty Days completed in 1901, was comprehensively rewritten by Verne's son, Michel, years later in what the Editions de L'Archipel publishing house called "one of the biggest deceptions in literary history".

The Beautiful Yellow Danube does not bear comparison with Verne's romances like Journey to the Centre of the Earth and Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea, written in the 1860s and 1870s.

"It's the work of an elderly man, a travel yarn stuffed with tourist notes and gastronomic recollections," said Sébastien Le Fol of Le Figaro.

According to Olivier Dumas of the Jules Verne Society, Verne's publisher, Jules Hetzel, was embarrassed when he was presented with the manuscript, found after Verne's death in 1905, and asked Michel to 'correct' it for publication.

Michel rewrote 15 of the 16 chapters and changed the title to The Danube Pilot. In 1997 a collector discovered the original manuscript of The Beautiful Yellow Danube in Hetzel family archives and realised what had happened.

fields.headline: When darkness met light
fields.standfirst:
Lucy Partington was 21 when she disappeared. For two decades, her family desperately hoped she was living elsewhere, under a new name. Then the world learned that she had been murdered by Frederick West. In the final exclusive extract from his memoir Experience, Martin Amis remembers his gentle, artistic cousin; and describes the agony of failed marriages - his father's and his own

Extract one: Kingsley and me
Extract two: The daughter I didn't meet for 19 years
fields.trailText:
Lucy Partington was 21 when she disappeared. For two decades, her family desperately hoped she was living elsewhere, under a new name. Then the world learned that she had been murdered by Frederick West. In the final exclusive extract from his memoir Experience,  Martin Amis  remembers his gentle, artistic cousin; and describes the agony of failed
marriages - his father's and his own
fields.body:
When I go back to the core of my childhood, my cousin Lucy seems always to be in the peripheral vision of my memories. She is off to one side, always off to one side, with a book, with a scheme or a project or an enterprise. Or with an animal. I keep thinking that if I could only shift my head an inch and change its angle, then I would see her fully. Just as Marian, her sister, a year my senior, was magnified in my mind, so Lucy, two and a half years younger, was additionally reduced. Only their brother David did I see four-square... In my clearest image of her she is crossing the small courtyard between the stable and the house, looking downwards and smiling secretively, privately, as if sharing a joke with the mouse I knew she had in her pocket. Some people, alas, live and die without trace. They come and they go and they leave no trace. This, at least, was not Lucy's destiny.

On the night of December 27 1973, Lucy Partington, who was staying with her mother in Gloucestershire, was driven into Cheltenham to visit an old friend, Helen Render. Lucy and Helen spent the evening talking about their future; they put together a letter of application to the Courtauld Institute in London, where Lucy hoped to continue studying medieval art. They parted at 10.15. It was a three-minute walk to the bus stop. She never posted the letter and she never boarded the bus. She was 21. And it was another 21 years before the world found out what happened to her.

At certain times, for certain periods, David was able to persuade himself that Lucy was still alive - alive, but elsewhere. Naturally all the Partingtons attempted something of the kind. My mother, too, attempted it. I attempted it. Lucy was serious, resolute, artistic, musical and religious. Even when we were children, the message I always took away from Lucy was that she wasn't going to be deflected, she wasn't going to be deterred.

Only with difficulty could you imagine her having the inclination to vanish; but it was the work of a moment to imagine her having the will. So she was in a nunnery, somewhere; she was a violinist in Melbourne, a pseudonymous poet in Montreal. Of course, these reveries kept running up against an obstacle: the fact that Lucy was gentle, was kind, was sane. To which the one available rejoinder would be: well, I must have been wrong about that, and I suppose it can deeply surprise you, the people who turn out to be prepared to disseminate hurt. Thus the argument continued (very faintly after a while, and then almost inaudibly, given my distance from the event) for 21 years.

In early March 1994, I had been abroad and knew nothing until I opened a newspaper in the taxi from Heathrow. There was the photograph I had last seen on a missing persons poster 20 years ago. David would later tell me that the moment he heard about the exhumations in Gloucester, he knew that Lucy would be among the dead.

She had been abducted by one of the most prolific murderers in British history, Frederick West. We knew what had happened to her after death. She was decapitated and dismembered, and her remains were crammed into a shaft between leaking sewage pipes, along with a knife, a rope, a section of masking tape, and two hairgrips.

But the terrible imponderable was what had happened to her when she was still alive. Records showed that just after midnight on the morning of January 3 1974, West appeared at the casualty department of Gloucester Royal Hospital with a serious laceration to the right hand. "It seems only too possible that she was kept alive for several days," writes one commentator. And yet the evidence remains entirely circumstantial. "It is possible," writes another, "that [West's] wound occurred as a result of the dismemberment of a corpse, but it is just as possible that it did not, which is the inference I should prefer the family to make."

From the moment Lucy's fate became public knowledge, David had needed to nerve himself to open a newspaper. Because it was all ready to begin again: waking in the middle of the night and getting up to sit for hours weeping and swearing. This was his condition on the day after the disappearance. "Lucy didn't come home last night." There was nobody in her room and the made bed had not been slept in. There was certainty of disaster. And there was my poor cousin (I hate thinking about this), out in the courtyard, crying and raising his clenched fists and saying: "If anyone has done anything to her..."

It was David who drove Lucy into Cheltenham on December 27 1973.

- I could so easily have driven her back. I offered to.

But Lucy had decided to take the bus; and there was no point in arguing with her about a thing like that.

- If I had insisted...

- You could go on for ever, I said, with this chain of ifs... As you drove into town, do you remember what you talked about?

- I was trying to justify my current girlfriend, who was - you know, sexy, but thick. Lucy was being very accommodating. Not at all critical. But I still felt I had to justify myself.

- Six years after she disappeared - remember? When we talked about it. You were saying that you wanted to avenge her. With your own hands. Do you still?

- No. But now, or at any other stage, I would give up my life so that Lucy could have hers. Because my life is... And hers...

- I understand. But don't be hard on yourself. I think you're a paragon.

- Me?

I told David, - I've read all the books, and there's no hard evidence that it wasn't all over there and then at the bus stop. And I added, hoping to give comfort (but why would this give comfort?), - Lucy was just very unlucky, David. Your sister was just incredibly unlucky.

Like well over 100 other souls, we converged on the Religious Society of Friends Meeting House, in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, to attend a memorial gathering for Lucy Katherine Partington, 1952-1973. The funeral itself had been postponed because Lucy's remains were still being held as evidence by the police.

This was Elizabeth Webster, a teacher at the Arts Centre:

"...She came to see me when she was at Exeter, just before the last year, and I said to her, 'Now that you are grown-up, what are you going to do?' and she said, 'I don't mind what I do, as long as I do it absolutely to the hilt.' And then I said, 'Yes, that's fine, but where are you going?' and she thought awfully hard, then she said, 'Towards the light... Towards the light.'"

I never again want to hear anyone ask me how Lucy Partington got "drawn into" the orbit of the Wests. West said he killed my cousin because she wanted him to go and meet her parents. He and Lucy were having an affair ("purely sex, end of story"), and Lucy, now pregnant, had "come the loving racket" and "said I wanna come and live with you and all this crap, and I just grabbed her by the throat". "[H]er wanted me to see her parents, her wanted me to do bloody everything."

That is what it said, in the press, unchallenged. I rebut it. This book rebuts it.

Everything about her, even her name, pointed towards the light. Given this, I cannot find order or meaning in a darkness so deep and durable. The death of Lucy Partington represents a fantastic collision (collide: "from col- 'together' + laedere 'to strike'"). It is what happens when darkness meets light, when experience meets innocence, when the false meets the true, when utter godlessness meets purity of spirit, when this -

Sweethearts and sacrificed empires

As a child, my parents' marriage, I believed, loomed like a translucent horizon - a belief memorably reaffirmed by my father in Deya, Majorca, where (late at night, admittedly) he had said to my brother and me: Never doubt that I love your mother. Never doubt that we will always be together... And I didn't doubt it.

It is very difficult, it is perhaps impossible, for someone who loves his mother to love the woman whom your father left her for. Because the Other Woman has made you cautious about love: she herself has created caution in you about love. However this may be, I got very close to loving Jane. "I'm your wicked stepmother," said Jane, after the wedding. And she was my wicked stepmother - but only in the sense meant by my son, Louis, when he tells me (for instance) that he is "wicked at Latin".

Jane was my wicked stepmother: she was generous, affectionate and resourceful; she salvaged my schooling and I owe her an unknowable debt for that. One flaw: sometimes, early on, she would tell me things designed to make me think less of my mother, and I would wave her away, saying, Jane, this just backfires and makes me think less of you. And she worked on this little vice, and overcame it.

The day I finished reading my father's 1978 novel Jake's Thing, I went over to the house in Hampstead. When Jane left the room I said,

- All that sex therapy stuff. Did you really do any of that?

I knew something about my father's sex life. One source was Jane, who even in 1975 was telling me more about my father's growing remissness in that area than I really wanted to know. Another source was Jake's Thing.

- Yes!

- Christ! That genital-focusing stuff and going to bed with a ring round your cock?

- Yes! Some of it.

- Christ!

- Well, in a case like this you have to show willing...

- Yeah, but the novel didn't show willing, did it?

And he gave me that look. Incapacitated: gently incapacitated.

[Elizabeth Jane Howard left Kingsley in 1980. He moved in with Hilly, his first wife, and her husband Alastair Boyd, Lord Kilmarnock. The arrangement lasted until Kingsley's death in 1995.]

To the end of his life, Kingsley maintained the following: "the idea was" that he would have his holiday with Jane, and then return to the family (and then go on seeing her as often as he could).

"It's only half a life without a woman," he said to me, later; the woman, the wife, the other half, was gone - and no successor would be sought. My father never again kissed a woman with passion. This from a man who used to live for adultery...

When my parents' marriage broke up, in the 60s, the newspapers covered it. And when my marriage broke up, 30 years later, the newspapers covered it (with noticeable differences in the journalistic approach). When my father had his teeth fixed, in the 60s, the newspapers didn't cover it. And when I had my teeth fixed, 30 years later, the newspapers covered it. My teeth made headlines. But let me tell you something about experience. It outstrips all accounts of it - all ulterior versions. A man having a full scale epileptic fit on the street corner does not mind about the tittering of nearby children. He is involved in his own triage.

In 1993, over dinner, my father said,

- Say as little as you want or as much as you want.

And I told him about my recent visit to Cape Cod to see my children, and their mother - to whom I had become a stranger, from whom I was estranged. The boys sensed that there was a possibility of reconciliation. On the first morning, Jacob pushed my coffee cup an inch nearer my right hand and said, "Enjoying your stay so far?"...

Five days later, as I prepared to leave, the pond outside the house was obediently reflecting the mass of doom stacked up in the sky. My sons were constructing a miniature zoo on a patch of grass; Louis showed me the little stunt where you dropped a coin down a complicated tunnel and were then issued with your ticket of admission. But I wasn't staying, and they knew it. They knew I was leaving. They knew the thing had failed - the whole thing had failed. I said goodbye and climbed into the rented car.

- I just can't stop thinking about it. I just can't get it out of my mind.

- There's nothing you can do with things like that. You can only hope to coexist with them. They never go away. They're always with you. They're just - there...

Yes, always available for delectation, and always undiminished in their power. On the night flight back to London, I performed what seemed to me to be the extraordinary feat of shedding tears throughout the full six hours, even during the shallow sleep I kept snapping out of. I wondered about the physiology of weeping: questions of storage and supply. In my delirium, I was vexed by the parenthetical thought that there was an indicator flashing in the cockpit, something like the watering can symbol on the dashboard of a car, telling me that I had at last used up all my spray.

In leaving home, I did what I did for love. But how does it look, the love ledger, by the time you're done? Because you are also the enemy of love and - for your children - its despoiler. "I hate love," said my son Louis at the age of five or six (he was complaining about the love interest in a book we were reading). He didn't mean that, but he could now say: "I no longer trust it."

When Dryden retold the story of Antony and Cleopatra, he called his tragedy All For Love (or The World Well Lost). Those stupendous sweethearts sacrificed empires, but they were certain that love, the primary value, was being exalted even in their defeats and their suicides. I envy them the flourish. We who absent ourselves from the daily company of our children must reckon it differently. Love comes out of it with gains but also with losses. And whenever death is losing, the force of death makes gains. Divorce: the incredibly violent thing. What parent, involved in it, has not wished for the death of the once-loved one? This is universal. And this is why your heart feels gangrenous inside your chest. This is why (as I put it to myself) you want men in white to come and take you away and wash your blood.

"Stopping being married to someone," my father had written, 10 years earlier, "is an incredibly violent thing to happen to you, not easy to take in completely, ever." He knew I was now absorbing the truth and the force of this. And he knew also that the process could not be softened or hastened. All you could do was survive it. That surviving was a possibility he showed me, by example. But he did more. He roused himself and did more. "Talk as much as you want about it or as little as you want." These words sounded like civilisation to me, in my barbarous state, so dishevelled in body and mind.

Talk as much or as little... I talked much. Only to him could I confess how terrible I felt, how physically terrible, bemused, subnormalised, stupefied from within, and always about to flinch or tremble from the effort of making my face look honest, kind, sane. Only to him could I talk about what I was doing to my children. Because he had done it to me.

fields.bodyText: When I go back to the core of my childhood, my cousin Lucy seems always to be in the peripheral vision of my memories. She is off to one side, always off to one side, with a book, with a scheme or a project or an enterprise. Or with an animal. I keep thinking that if I could only shift my head an inch and change its angle, then I would see her fully. Just as Marian, her sister, a year my senior, was magnified in my mind, so Lucy, two and a half years younger, was additionally reduced. Only their brother David did I see four-square... In my clearest image of her she is crossing the small courtyard between the stable and the house, looking downwards and smiling secretively, privately, as if sharing a joke with the mouse I knew she had in her pocket. Some people, alas, live and die without trace. They come and they go and they leave no trace. This, at least, was not Lucy's destiny. On the night of December 27 1973, Lucy Partington, who was staying with her mother in Gloucestershire, was driven into Cheltenham to visit an old friend, Helen Render. Lucy and Helen spent the evening talking about their future; they put together a letter of application to the Courtauld Institute in London, where Lucy hoped to continue studying medieval art. They parted at 10.15. It was a three-minute walk to the bus stop. She never posted the letter and she never boarded the bus. She was 21. And it was another 21 years before the world found out what happened to her. At certain times, for certain periods, David was able to persuade himself that Lucy was still alive - alive, but elsewhere. Naturally all the Partingtons attempted something of the kind. My mother, too, attempted it. I attempted it. Lucy was serious, resolute, artistic, musical and religious. Even when we were children, the message I always took away from Lucy was that she wasn't going to be deflected, she wasn't going to be deterred. Only with difficulty could you imagine her having the inclination to vanish; but it was the work of a moment to imagine her having the will. So she was in a nunnery, somewhere; she was a violinist in Melbourne, a pseudonymous poet in Montreal. Of course, these reveries kept running up against an obstacle: the fact that Lucy was gentle, was kind, was sane. To which the one available rejoinder would be: well, I must have been wrong about that, and I suppose it can deeply surprise you, the people who turn out to be prepared to disseminate hurt. Thus the argument continued (very faintly after a while, and then almost inaudibly, given my distance from the event) for 21 years. In early March 1994, I had been abroad and knew nothing until I opened a newspaper in the taxi from Heathrow. There was the photograph I had last seen on a missing persons poster 20 years ago. David would later tell me that the moment he heard about the exhumations in Gloucester, he knew that Lucy would be among the dead. She had been abducted by one of the most prolific murderers in British history, Frederick West. We knew what had happened to her after death. She was decapitated and dismembered, and her remains were crammed into a shaft between leaking sewage pipes, along with a knife, a rope, a section of masking tape, and two hairgrips. But the terrible imponderable was what had happened to her when she was still alive. Records showed that just after midnight on the morning of January 3 1974, West appeared at the casualty department of Gloucester Royal Hospital with a serious laceration to the right hand. "It seems only too possible that she was kept alive for several days," writes one commentator. And yet the evidence remains entirely circumstantial. "It is possible," writes another, "that [West's] wound occurred as a result of the dismemberment of a corpse, but it is just as possible that it did not, which is the inference I should prefer the family to make." From the moment Lucy's fate became public knowledge, David had needed to nerve himself to open a newspaper. Because it was all ready to begin again: waking in the middle of the night and getting up to sit for hours weeping and swearing. This was his condition on the day after the disappearance. "Lucy didn't come home last night." There was nobody in her room and the made bed had not been slept in. There was certainty of disaster. And there was my poor cousin (I hate thinking about this), out in the courtyard, crying and raising his clenched fists and saying: "If anyone has done anything to her..." It was David who drove Lucy into Cheltenham on December 27 1973. - I could so easily have driven her back. I offered to. But Lucy had decided to take the bus; and there was no point in arguing with her about a thing like that. - If I had insisted... - You could go on for ever, I said, with this chain of ifs... As you drove into town, do you remember what you talked about? - I was trying to justify my current girlfriend, who was - you know, sexy, but thick. Lucy was being very accommodating. Not at all critical. But I still felt I had to justify myself. - Six years after she disappeared - remember? When we talked about it. You were saying that you wanted to avenge her. With your own hands. Do you still? - No. But now, or at any other stage, I would give up my life so that Lucy could have hers. Because my life is... And hers... - I understand. But don't be hard on yourself. I think you're a paragon. - Me? I told David, - I've read all the books, and there's no hard evidence that it wasn't all over there and then at the bus stop. And I added, hoping to give comfort (but why would this give comfort?), - Lucy was just very unlucky, David. Your sister was just incredibly unlucky. Like well over 100 other souls, we converged on the Religious Society of Friends Meeting House, in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, to attend a memorial gathering for Lucy Katherine Partington, 1952-1973. The funeral itself had been postponed because Lucy's remains were still being held as evidence by the police. This was Elizabeth Webster, a teacher at the Arts Centre: "...She came to see me when she was at Exeter, just before the last year, and I said to her, 'Now that you are grown-up, what are you going to do?' and she said, 'I don't mind what I do, as long as I do it absolutely to the hilt.' And then I said, 'Yes, that's fine, but where are you going?' and she thought awfully hard, then she said, 'Towards the light... Towards the light.'" I never again want to hear anyone ask me how Lucy Partington got "drawn into" the orbit of the Wests. West said he killed my cousin because she wanted him to go and meet her parents. He and Lucy were having an affair ("purely sex, end of story"), and Lucy, now pregnant, had "come the loving racket" and "said I wanna come and live with you and all this crap, and I just grabbed her by the throat". "[H]er wanted me to see her parents, her wanted me to do bloody everything." That is what it said, in the press, unchallenged. I rebut it. This book rebuts it. Everything about her, even her name, pointed towards the light. Given this, I cannot find order or meaning in a darkness so deep and durable. The death of Lucy Partington represents a fantastic collision (collide: "from col- 'together' + laedere 'to strike'"). It is what happens when darkness meets light, when experience meets innocence, when the false meets the true, when utter godlessness meets purity of spirit, when this - Hi May it your Dad Writeing to you. or lette me have your telephone number... or Write to me as soon as you can, please may I have to sort out watt Mr Ogden did to me, my new solicitors are Brilliant I Read What you sead about me in News of the that was loylty you read what Scott canavan sead he had - meets this - things are as big as you make them - I can fill a whole body, a whole day of life with worry about a few words on one scrap of paper; yet, the same evening, looking up, can frame my fingers to fit the sky in my cupped hands. Sweethearts and sacrificed empires As a child, my parents' marriage, I believed, loomed like a translucent horizon - a belief memorably reaffirmed by my father in Deya, Majorca, where (late at night, admittedly) he had said to my brother and me: Never doubt that I love your mother. Never doubt that we will always be together... And I didn't doubt it. It is very difficult, it is perhaps impossible, for someone who loves his mother to love the woman whom your father left her for. Because the Other Woman has made you cautious about love: she herself has created caution in you about love. However this may be, I got very close to loving Jane. "I'm your wicked stepmother," said Jane, after the wedding. And she was my wicked stepmother - but only in the sense meant by my son, Louis, when he tells me (for instance) that he is "wicked at Latin". Jane was my wicked stepmother: she was generous, affectionate and resourceful; she salvaged my schooling and I owe her an unknowable debt for that. One flaw: sometimes, early on, she would tell me things designed to make me think less of my mother, and I would wave her away, saying, Jane, this just backfires and makes me think less of you. And she worked on this little vice, and overcame it. The day I finished reading my father's 1978 novel Jake's Thing, I went over to the house in Hampstead. When Jane left the room I said, - All that sex therapy stuff. Did you really do any of that? I knew something about my father's sex life. One source was Jane, who even in 1975 was telling me more about my father's growing remissness in that area than I really wanted to know. Another source was Jake's Thing. - Yes! - Christ! That genital-focusing stuff and going to bed with a ring round your cock? - Yes! Some of it. - Christ! - Well, in a case like this you have to show willing... - Yeah, but the novel didn't show willing, did it? And he gave me that look. Incapacitated: gently incapacitated. [Elizabeth Jane Howard left Kingsley in 1980. He moved in with Hilly, his first wife, and her husband Alastair Boyd, Lord Kilmarnock. The arrangement lasted until Kingsley's death in 1995.] To the end of his life, Kingsley maintained the following: "the idea was" that he would have his holiday with Jane, and then return to the family (and then go on seeing her as often as he could). "It's only half a life without a woman," he said to me, later; the woman, the wife, the other half, was gone - and no successor would be sought. My father never again kissed a woman with passion. This from a man who used to live for adultery... When my parents' marriage broke up, in the 60s, the newspapers covered it. And when my marriage broke up, 30 years later, the newspapers covered it (with noticeable differences in the journalistic approach). When my father had his teeth fixed, in the 60s, the newspapers didn't cover it. And when I had my teeth fixed, 30 years later, the newspapers covered it. My teeth made headlines. But let me tell you something about experience. It outstrips all accounts of it - all ulterior versions. A man having a full scale epileptic fit on the street corner does not mind about the tittering of nearby children. He is involved in his own triage. In 1993, over dinner, my father said, - Say as little as you want or as much as you want. And I told him about my recent visit to Cape Cod to see my children, and their mother - to whom I had become a stranger, from whom I was estranged. The boys sensed that there was a possibility of reconciliation. On the first morning, Jacob pushed my coffee cup an inch nearer my right hand and said, "Enjoying your stay so far?"... Five days later, as I prepared to leave, the pond outside the house was obediently reflecting the mass of doom stacked up in the sky. My sons were constructing a miniature zoo on a patch of grass; Louis showed me the little stunt where you dropped a coin down a complicated tunnel and were then issued with your ticket of admission. But I wasn't staying, and they knew it. They knew I was leaving. They knew the thing had failed - the whole thing had failed. I said goodbye and climbed into the rented car. - I just can't stop thinking about it. I just can't get it out of my mind. - There's nothing you can do with things like that. You can only hope to coexist with them. They never go away. They're always with you. They're just - there... Yes, always available for delectation, and always undiminished in their power. On the night flight back to London, I performed what seemed to me to be the extraordinary feat of shedding tears throughout the full six hours, even during the shallow sleep I kept snapping out of. I wondered about the physiology of weeping: questions of storage and supply. In my delirium, I was vexed by the parenthetical thought that there was an indicator flashing in the cockpit, something like the watering can symbol on the dashboard of a car, telling me that I had at last used up all my spray. In leaving home, I did what I did for love. But how does it look, the love ledger, by the time you're done? Because you are also the enemy of love and - for your children - its despoiler. "I hate love," said my son Louis at the age of five or six (he was complaining about the love interest in a book we were reading). He didn't mean that, but he could now say: "I no longer trust it." When Dryden retold the story of Antony and Cleopatra, he called his tragedy All For Love (or The World Well Lost). Those stupendous sweethearts sacrificed empires, but they were certain that love, the primary value, was being exalted even in their defeats and their suicides. I envy them the flourish. We who absent ourselves from the daily company of our children must reckon it differently. Love comes out of it with gains but also with losses. And whenever death is losing, the force of death makes gains. Divorce: the incredibly violent thing. What parent, involved in it, has not wished for the death of the once-loved one? This is universal. And this is why your heart feels gangrenous inside your chest. This is why (as I put it to myself) you want men in white to come and take you away and wash your blood. "Stopping being married to someone," my father had written, 10 years earlier, "is an incredibly violent thing to happen to you, not easy to take in completely, ever." He knew I was now absorbing the truth and the force of this. And he knew also that the process could not be softened or hastened. All you could do was survive it. That surviving was a possibility he showed me, by example. But he did more. He roused himself and did more. "Talk as much as you want about it or as little as you want." These words sounded like civilisation to me, in my barbarous state, so dishevelled in body and mind. Talk as much or as little... I talked much. Only to him could I confess how terrible I felt, how physically terrible, bemused, subnormalised, stupefied from within, and always about to flinch or tremble from the effort of making my face look honest, kind, sane. Only to him could I talk about what I was doing to my children. Because he had done it to me.  © Martin Amis 2000. Experience by Martin Amis is published by Jonathan Cape, price £18. webTitle: 2,000 Ford jobs to go at Dagenham

fields.headline: 2,000 Ford jobs to go at Dagenham
fields.standfirst: Ford at Dagenham: special report
fields.trailText: Relief in the car industry at the Phoenix rescue deal for Rover turned to despair yesterday with predictions that 2,000 jobs are to be axed at Ford's Dagenham plant tomorrow.
fields.body:
Relief in the car industry at the Phoenix rescue deal for Rover turned to despair yesterday with predictions that 2,000 jobs are to be axed at Ford's Dagenham plant tomorrow.

The move will effectively bring an end to Ford car production in Britain after 69 years - but the company will attempt to soften the blow by announcing heavy investment in engine production at the east London plant.

Union leaders accused Ford of breaking promises to build its new Fiesta model in the UK and called for government intervention.

But Tony Blair appeared resigned to the end of car manufacturing at the plant, while the new mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, warned that the company would face a backlash from angry British consumers if it ended mass production in one of London's most deprived areas.
