fields.headline: Opposition may boycott election
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe's Movement for Democratic Change has had 19 members killed in six weeks. The time has come for stiffer resistance
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), is considering a national strike, a call for international sanctions and a boycott of the coming election to protest at the unrelenting state-sponsored violence against its members.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), is considering a national strike, a call for international sanctions and a boycott of the coming election to protest at the unrelenting state-sponsored violence against its members.

Reeling from the killing of 19 members since April 1, the MDC will hold an emergency national council meeting on Saturday.

"Faced with this situation of lawlessness and murders against our members, the MDC must consider new strategies, including a possible boycott of the parliamentary elections, mass action and an appeal to the international community for more drastic action," said the MDC's president, Morgan Tsvangirai.

President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party is facing a strong challenge from the MDC in the parliamentary elections, due by August.

The MDC previously said it would not boycott the elections because the party is committed to change by democratic means. "But with this level of government violence against our members, we have now reached a stage where we must review participation in the elections," said Mr Tsvangirai. "To talk of free and fair elections with this state of affairs, this amount of violence and intimidation, we are just fooling ourselves."

A national strike is a very real option for the MDC, with the party drawing support from Zimbabwe's trade unions. Mr Tsvangirai, as the leader of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU), called three successful general strikes in 1998 and 1999 that brought the country to a halt.

"What can Mugabe and Zanu-PF do if we just stay at home?" said Mr Tsvangirai when asked if a strike would provoke Mr Mugabe to further violence. "Obviously our workers are pressing for mass action. There is no sense in pretending that things are normal."

Turning to the possibility of international sanctions, Mr Tsvangirai said: "So far the international community has acted diplomatically with calls for Mugabe to allow free and fair elections. We will consider whether we should urge the international community to use more drastic action beyond diplomatic appeals. Sanctions is one of those options."

Mr Tsvangirai said the whole country was suffering from the ongoing state violence. "This government has no respect for the constitution, for democratic processes or for the rule of law. Every Zimbabwean, regardless of race, tribe or belief who does not support Zanu-PF has become an enemy of the state and is threatened with elimination. "The state has promoted lawlessness, anarchy and violence to a point where it is now commonplace."

He said there was only one way his party could fight back. "The answer is that we must compete with the only weapons we have. These are truth and the people's determination for democratic change."

webTitle: Money and class still affect exam results and future

fields.headline: Money and class still affect exam results and future
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Boys are still matching girls' performance in maths and science subjects but in arts subjects, including English, French, history and geography, girls are now doing much better than boys across the board at GCSE level, according to the ONS social inequalities report.
fields.body:
Boys are still matching girls' performance in maths and science subjects but in arts subjects, including English, French, history and geography, girls are now doing much better than boys across the board at GCSE level, according to the ONS social inequalities report.

But poverty and class differences are still an important influence on educational attainment. The report says high levels of children eligible for free school meals generally correspond with lower GCSE attainment levels.

When it comes to social class, the differences are even more striking. In 1998 only a fifth of those whose parents were in unskilled manual jobs achieved five GCSE passes at grades A to C. In contrast, more than two-thirds of children of the professional and managerial classes got five GCSEs at this standard.

Educational success is also linked to ethnic background but not necessarily in a straightforward way. The 1998 figures show that children from Indian families are outperforming white children when it comes to examination success. But black, Pakistani and Bangladeshi pupils do less well - though the latter appear to be improving the most rapidly with the proportion getting five GCSEs more than doubling from 14% in 1992 to 33% in 1998.

Also of concern is the fact that 8% of all boys and 5% of all girls received no graded GCSEs or their equivalents in their final year of compulsory education. Men without qualifications are four times more likely to be unemployed in 1999 than those who had a degree level education.

The report highlights the changing place of women in higher and further education. The number of university students trebled from 620,000 in 1971 to almost 2m in 1998, mostly as a result of the rising number of women entering higher education. Thirty years ago, 33% of university students were women; now there are more women than men.

fields.headline: Blunkett rounds on 'snobbish' universities
fields.standfirst: HREF="http://www.educationunlimited.co.uk/">Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Snobbish admissions officers were helping to keep working class youngsters out of universities and medical schools, David Blunkett, the education secretary, suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Snobbish admissions officers were helping to keep working class youngsters out of universities and medical schools, David Blunkett, the education secretary, suggested yesterday.

Announcing student bursaries of up to £1,000 for poor students as part of a £4m drive to open up access to higher education, Mr Blunkett told the Association of University Teachers annual conference in Eastbourne that universities would have to change. Someone from a private school was nearly 30 times as likely to get into one of the top universities as someone from a disadvantaged background.

Mr Blunkett said he had been the only one from his working class area of Sheffield who had gone to university. There was a cocktail of problems, including low aspirations among some families and schools. But some universities recruited less than half their students from state schools and he singled out medical schools in particular.

"It is not simply prejudice by admissions tutors - although it would be interesting to see the social background of some of them to find out whether we need summer schools for admissions tutors and not just for students seeking entry."

He added: "We are in a new century. For universities to be taking such a small proportion of students from deprived areas or even from the state sector is no longer acceptable. "We are not talking about diluting entry standards but of equal treatment for those who get high scores at A-level."

The conference was also told that British universities were missing out on millions of pounds of income because they were "bloody useless" at patenting and exploiting their inventions. David Triesman, the association's general secretary, accused universities of failing to help themselves by making sure they benefited from inventions.

fields.headline: £300,000 for teacher driven to breakdown
fields.standfirst: HREF="http://www.educationunlimited.co.uk/">Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teacher who suffered a nervous breakdown triggered by a headteacher who shouted at him, criticised him to pupils and allowed discipline in school to collapse has been awarded £300,000 in a record settlement.
fields.body:
A teacher who suffered a nervous breakdown triggered by a headteacher who shouted at him, criticised him to pupils and allowed discipline in school to collapse has been awarded £300,000 in a record settlement.

The teacher, 45, a married father of two, became irrational and suffered delusions after he was pushed down stairs by a pupil in the Shropshire school in February 1996, about a year after the new head plunged the school into crisis. The teacher took early retirement and believes he will never work again.

The man accepted a payment into the court by Shropshire county council, which he claimed had ignored his tearful pleas for help, after negotiations between its insurers and the National Union of Teachers. The union said it was the largest known payout to a public employee for a stress-induced illness.

The man is said to be fearful and haunted, "constantly looking over his shoulder", and unable to cope with strangers. He rarely leaves home and has not slept properly for two years.

Neither his nor the school's identity has been revealed. But the union said Mr A, as it called him, wanted details of his case publicised to ensure employers took seriously their duty to free their employees' working environment of unnecessary stress.

According to the NUT, the head, appointed in January 1995, ignored staff, promoted "divide and rule", was inconsistent in disciplining pupils, and told experienced staff to look for new jobs.

Four months after her arrival, Mr A, who specialised in working with disturbed children, began suffering stress-related symptoms. According to the NUT, he felt exhausted, lost weight, became short-tempered, and turned from a non-smoker into a chain-smoker.

Mr A said through the NUT: "As time went on, I often did not know whether I had just arrived at work or was about to go home. I was completeley disorientated."

Six months into the head's regime, Mr A went to see a county council officer to tell him the school was a disaster. He broke down during the meeting. He said he was told that the council was aware of the problems and would get back to him, but it did not, and other pleas by staff were ignored.

In a statement, Liz Nicholson, corporate director of education at Shropshire county council, said: "The county council was aware of these difficulties in the management of the school and steps were taken to address these."

Doug McAvoy, the NUT's general secretary, said: "This teacher has suffered dreadful stress which could have been dealt with if the authority had intervened as soon as it was aware of the problems."

The union said it was processing 150 legal cases involving allegations of stress-induced illness among teachers.

Tomorrow, the education department will for the first time release figures for teacher absence through sickness.
fields.bodyText: A teacher who suffered a nervous breakdown triggered by a headteacher who shouted at him, criticised him to pupils and allowed discipline in school to collapse has been awarded £300,000 in a record settlement. The teacher, 45, a married father of two, became irrational and suffered delusions after he was pushed down stairs by a pupil in the Shropshire school in February 1996, about a year after the new head plunged the school into crisis. The teacher took early retirement and believes he will never work again. The man accepted a payment into the court by Shropshire county council, which he claimed had ignored his tearful pleas for help, after negotiations between its insurers and the National Union of Teachers. The union said it was the largest known payout to a public employee for a stress-induced illness. The man is said to be fearful and haunted, "constantly looking over his shoulder", and unable to cope with strangers. He rarely leaves home and has not slept properly for two years. Neither his nor the school's identity has been revealed. But the union said Mr A, as it called him, wanted details of his case publicised to ensure employers took seriously their duty to free their employees' working environment of unnecessary stress. According to the NUT, the head, appointed in January 1995, ignored staff, promoted "divide and rule", was inconsistent in disciplining pupils, and told experienced staff to look for new jobs. Four months after her arrival, Mr A, who specialised in working with disturbed children, began suffering stress-related symptoms. According to the NUT, he felt exhausted, lost weight, became short-tempered, and turned from a non-smoker into a chain-smoker. Mr A said through the NUT: "As time went on, I often did not know whether I had just arrived at work or was about to go home. I was completeley disorientated." Six months into the head's regime, Mr A went to see a county council officer to tell him the school was a disaster. He broke down during the meeting. He said he was told that the council was aware of the problems and would get back to him, but it did not, and other pleas by staff were ignored. In a statement, Liz Nicholson, corporate director of education at Shropshire county council, said: "The county council was aware of these difficulties in the management of the school and steps were taken to address these." Doug McAvoy, the NUT's general secretary, said: "This teacher has suffered dreadful stress which could have been dealt with if the authority had intervened as soon as it was aware of the problems." The union said it was processing 150 legal cases involving allegations of stress-induced illness among teachers. Tomorrow, the education department will for the first time release figures for teacher absence through sickness.

fields.headline: A boy's own story
fields.standfirst:
How did a 17-year-old land a £50,000 book deal? Emma Brockes meets Anselm Audley

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: How did a 17-year-old land a £50,000 book deal? Emma Brockes meets Anselm Audley
fields.body:
It is a commonplace of teenage novelists that the story of how they came to be published is more arresting than the books that they write. Jenn Crowell, 19, was paid £200,000 for her traipse through the outer reaches of bereavement in Necessary Madness; Bidisha, 15, pumped out prose like a random adjective generator and even got her picture on the front of Seahorses; and Vanessa Walters, 17, produced Rude Girls between making a rap video and studying ancient Greek. The reader who takes up these novels does so to learn something of the strange creatures who write them: teenagers with the gall and discipline to play a very adult, cognitive game.

Now Anselm Audley, 17, has won a £50,000 three-book deal on the strength of his first novel, Heresy. It is guided by more obviously teenage preferences, set in a fantasy world called Aquaselva where the hero, Cathan, defends the minority beliefs of his clan against an oppressive regime. This is not an allegory for Audley's adolescent rage against the machine: he is quiet and measured, sitting in his agent's house looking mildly alarmed at having to explain something that just popped out as a diversion from A-level revision. "I had been reading fantasy and sci-fi books for a long time and I'd been writing short stories for a couple of years, so I was looking for a subject for a novel. In Heresy I found one that wasn't too long."

Audley doesn't speak like a precocious teen. He is reluctant to embark on long sentences or sell himself as a personality with which to market the book. He is dressed sensibly, not fashionably. He doesn't represent the angry youth of his native Dorset. He plays the bassoon to grade eight and dislikes PE. He is the sort of boy who, in the 80s, used to spend his lunch hours playing epic games of Dungeons and Dragons but now dedicates it to computers. The first fantasy story he wrote was at the age of nine and it was returned to him underscored in red ink, with the judgment, "There are no volcanoes in Cumbria."

All of which contributes to the rare possibility that Anselm Audley will be a teenage novelist whose book is more interesting than him.

His writing regime was not structured by an ambitious plan - it just evolved. Audley was a day scholar at Millfield public school and would not get home before 7pm, sometimes writing until 11pm. His parents, both translators of German, French and eastern European languages, worried that he would jeopardise his exams, but last year he won a place to read history at St John's College, Oxford, on the strength of three A grades at A-level.

The idea for Heresy came while Audley was on holiday with his parents in the south of France. "We were in a region where they had a lot of heresy and things," he says, quietly. "It's their main tourist point. I had written stories of over 10,000 words before, and was looking for something to write a novel about. The central character gets caught up in the whole religion and heresy thing." He adds rather quickly, "It is not a children's book."

Audley wrote Heresy in eight months and sent it to the agent James Hale, a friend of his parents who represents Iain Banks. Hale made a couple of suggestions about the book's chronology, before sending it to the publishers Simon and Schuster. Audley was "stunned", he says, when the publisher came back with a £50,000 three-book deal. Judging by his demeanour, he's still getting over it.

He hasn't seen any of the money yet but is expecting a cheque to arrive within the next couple of weeks, although he softly admits that he is not one for spending sprees. For his year out, he has chosen to study for two more A-levels in physics and ancient history, "just for fun". That takes up his mornings, and he spends the afternoon working on Inquisition, part two of his trilogy. He may permit himself the luxury of going to America in the summer, but nothing is planned yet. He is 17. He will probably spend most of his spare time in Aquaselva.

webTitle: News: Novelist seeks to bring a sense of reality to Cannes

fields.headline: News: Novelist seeks to bring a sense of reality to Cannes
fields.trailText: Arundhati Roy brought a sharp dose of reality to the Cannes film festival by calling for an end to a massive Indian dam project she said would impoverish millions of the world's poorest people
fields.body:
Arundhati Roy brought a sharp dose of reality to the Cannes film festival yesterday by calling for an end to a massive Indian dam project she said would impoverish millions of the world's poorest people.

The emotional plea from the Booker prize-winning novelist - a member of the jury which will decide the Palme d'Or - came as a typically Cannes tantrum over a ban on late night beach parties threatened to overshadow the first day of the festival.

Roy, 36, who was a screenwriter in India before The God of Small Things brought her worldwide fame, said that having just arrived from the Narmada valley in central India, where farmers have been arrested for protesting against their land being flooded, she found it "hard to connect" to the media circus of Cannes.

She said: "I have just come from a world where terrible things are happening and the lives of millions of people are being ruined. One journeys between powerlessness and power. I wish that only a few of the cameramen and journalists who are here today could have been in the Narmada valley to witness the terrible things I have been seeing."

Roy, who has campaigned against the network of 165 dams, the world's biggest, since she won the Booker three years ago, said: "It's a sign of the times that I have been called an activist here today. It's a writer's business to comment on the world we live in - but when you do you get called an activist."

She said the dam would be an environmental as well as an economic disaster for the valley, swamping a 150-mile stretch of some of the most beautiful and fertile land in India.

Her comments were met with an awkward silence in the Palais du Cinema, where the main films in the Cannes competition are shown. Roy was hurried out of the building by security guards when the Guardian tried to question her further.

Meanwhile, most festival goers were more preoccupied by the late night beach party ban imposed by the mayor of Cannes, Maurice Delauney. Revels must cease by midnight and partygoers have to be off the Croisette half an hour later after complaints from the locals last year when Tom Jones entertained hundreds of the glitterati into the small hours.

The organisers of an alternative Cannes festival, the Porn d'Or, have already said they will defy the ban. Bad weather, however, is likely to put more of a dampener on the al fresco frolics than the gendarmes.

The opening film, Vatel, was something of a damp squib, despite a starry British supporting cast including Tim Roth, Richard Griffiths, and Timothy Spall. An Anglo-French co-production, directed by Roland Joffe of The Killing Fields fame, it stars Uma Thurman and Gérard Depardieu. The latter said he "felt liberated by doing the film in English, even if I didn't always understand what I was saying".

British hopes this year rest on Ken Loach, whose new film, Bread and Roses, about Mexican workers in Los Angeles, premieres tomorrow.

Audio report from Fiachra Gibbons in Cannes at www.filmunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Whatever you do, don't mention the election

fields.headline: Whatever you do, don't mention the election
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The next election is already upon us. It seems barely three years - it is barely three years - since that glorious summer when the prime minister came on the radio and told a sombre and fearful nation that we were at war, mainly with each other.
fields.body:
The next election is already upon us. It seems barely three years - it is barely three years - since that glorious summer when the prime minister came on the radio and told a sombre and fearful nation that we were at war, mainly with each other.

The fields were yellow with oilseed rape, the hedges stiff with mayflower. The heat lay heavily upon the land, like an incontinent labrador. It seemed impossible that anything could destroy the peace of that tranquil springtime.

But even as we sheltered in the open air, next to munitions dumps if necessary, to escape the deafening barrage of the election broadcasts that threatened our whole way of life, we could see the first press plane climb in the sky, carrying the brave young men and women of the media towards the political struggle. Day and night, the battlebuses rumbled through the streets, each laden with their vital cargo of fax machines, mobes, speechwriters and spin doctors.

Goodness, it was awful. People in Britain used to enjoy elections, but that was because there wasn't much else to do. Now we have theme pubs, soap operas and swimming pools with waterslides, so politics has become not a source of fascination, but an annoying distraction.

I spent those hot, oppressive days driving around the countryside, reflecting how much of it is still beautiful, but how the view can easily be spoiled if a politician is standing in front of it. The most glorious hamlet in North Yorkshire seems less idyllic if you are at the back of the village hall listening to William Hague say: "And my eighth point is _"

And it was a bad session for Mr Hague yesterday. You would think that, having won nearly 600 council seats, he would want to rub Tony Blair's nose into his party's failure. But he couldn't. His manner was as it always is: ironic, relaxed, with a dash of phoney anger. In politics, however, you cannot treat the two impostors, triumph and disaster, both the same. You must gloat, exult, glory in your opponents' misery.

Charles Kennedy looks more impressive each week, though he does have a tendency to blush. Labour MPs who sit opposite him tell me they believe the colouring begins at his feet, then rushes quickly up the body, reaching the neck halfway through his question and finally suffusing the entire face. With his bright red hair, he ends up like a cross between a beetroot and Ronald McDonald.

He said that the most telling message from "the vast diet" of last week's elections came from Romsey (well, he would, wouldn't he? He's not going to draw on the deep significance of all those councils the LibDems lost).

"It was a triumph for the politics of hope and the future," he said, as opposed to the Tory "politics of fear, division and prejudice".

Tories jeered, since Romsey has been blanked out of their minds, just as people who suffer traumas such as car crashes find it impossible to recall what happened.

Mr Blair turned to the jeering Tories and said: "They're on about us losing our deposit. I would have thought it rather worse to have lost one of your safest seats. I think if that had happened to us just before the election, we'd have been slightly concerned.

"But don't worry," he said to the opposition, "carry on being unconcerned!"

"Just" before the election! In the febrile world of politics, no hint could be broader, no blind horse oblivious to such a nod or wink.

So at any time we could be back at war, our demob suits dusted off, chewing dried egg sandwiches, drinking coffee made of acorns and stealing each other's ration books. To misquote Churchill: "It was the nation which had the lion's heart. I was called upon to give the groan."

fields.headline: Telecity float values company at £700m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Telecity, a fast growing internet infrastructure and services company, is likely to be valued at around £690m when it floats on the stock exchange later this month.
fields.body:
Telecity, a fast growing internet infrastructure and services company, is likely to be valued at around £690m when it floats on the stock exchange later this month.

Bankers for the Manchester firm have set an indicative price range of 867p to £11.41, with the mid-point of £10.04 valuing it at £689m. The wide range is understood to have been set to cope with volatility in the technology sector.

Around 13.9m shares will be offered to institutional investors with the aim of raising net proceeds of £130m.

Telecity operates internet exchanges that provide customers, including QXL.com and UUNet, with connectivity to the web via a choice of telecommunications carriers, including British Telecom, Cable & Wireless and NTL. Each exchange, which houses banks of servers and routers in high-security vaults, cost around £7m to own.

The float will crystallise a £200m paper fortune for its chief executive, Dr Mike Kelly, 42, who quit Manchester University's computing department to found the company in 1998. The shares are expected to start trading on May 23, with Goldman Sachs as global coordinator to the offering.

fields.headline: Army camps plan for refugee 'surge'
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The government has been drawing up contingency plans for big increases in the number of new asylum seekers detained in camps, in the event of a sudden surge in applications this summer.
fields.body:
The government has been drawing up contingency plans for big increases in the number of new asylum seekers detained in camps, in the event of a sudden surge in applications this summer.

A document seen by the Guardian reveals that the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, wanted a radical toughening of the government's stance to be considered.

Plans studied include military personnel guarding refugees sent, on entering the country, into a network of disused army camps. The aim would be to deter other asylum seekers from coming. Ministers fear a large rise in asylum applications would knock the recovering asylum system off course and expose it to William Hague's plan to lock up all new asylum seekers.

A letter sent by Stephen Boys Smith, director general of the immigration and nationality directorate, to the home secretary and Ms Roche reveals the options ministers have been considering.

Why these plans were being drawn up is a mystery since in his letter Mr Boys Smith says there is no reason to expect a surge this summer.

Mr Boys Smith wrote: "We were asked to provide advice on the possibility of taking on, for example, a disused army camp as emergency accommodation should there be a sudden influx of asylum seekers over the summer."

Mr Boys Smith's letter continues: "We have no contingency plan for detention which can simply be taken off the shelf to meet the point you [Ms Roche] raised, namely to detain a much higher proportion of people to act as a deterrent in the event of a surge."

The letter then discusses how Ms Roche's wishes could be met. One option is to place refugees in mothballed army camps. Mr Boys Smith says close to 20,000 detention places would be needed if this course were followed.

He wrote: "An increase to 10,000 [asylum applications a month] or more might take us into crisis mode. We have also assumed that you might wish to have the ability to detain all or the vast majority while their cases were considered."

The letter then spells out the logistical difficulties of meeting the minister's wishes: "There are some vacant camps, but they would all require substantial investment to bring them up to the necessary standard of accommodation and security. Nor could we hope to find all the places we need on just one or two sites. We would be looking at a few hundred places at around 20 locations, supplemented by Portakabins."

The letter goes on to suggest that asylum seekers might be guarded at gunpoint. "Perhaps the more serious problem is how to staff the facilities. Most satisfactory for us would be for military personnel to secure the perimeter. The MoD are clear that they cannot give a commitment always to have sufficient personnel available.

"There will be numerous legal issues to resolve about this use of detention and any further proposals we might want to make for accelerating the consideration of cases. We should clearly not get into mass detentions unless we can see a way through the legal, procedural and practical issues associated with resolving the cases and removing failed applicants."

Last night a spokeswoman for the Home Office said it was prudent for the government to examine all options but there were no plans to implement the proposals.

A spokesman for the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture said: "We can see no reason for the use of military personnel in any circumstances. Asylum seekers have a right to be treated in a humane manner."

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said: "It would be a nightmare for Britain and a nightmare for Britain's reputation. The government should move quickly to squash this."

webTitle: We've closed the gap to 8%, says Hague

fields.headline: We've closed the gap to 8%, says Hague
fields.standfirst:
Hague claims poll boost

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, last night told the shadow cabinet that his tough approach to issues such as asylum and law and order had closed the gap between Labour and the Tories to just 8% and put a general election victory next year within his grasp.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, last night told the shadow cabinet that his tough approach to issues such as asylum and law and order had closed the gap between Labour and the Tories to just 8% and put a general election victory next year within his grasp.

"This is the end of the flatlining. We have made enough progress to know we can win the next election, but we must redouble our efforts," an upbeat Mr Hague told his colleagues, after nearly three years in which the Tory poll rating has flickered weakly between 27% and 32%.

Labour's share of the poll is now 43% against 35% for the opposition, according to private research conducted for Conservative Central Office last weekend after the Tories won 600 local council seats - but lost the Romsey byelection - officials revealed last night.

That is almost half the gap that existed in April and the highest level of support the Conservatives have enjoyed since 1992, when voters re-elected John Major.

ICM, which is also the Guardian's pollster, interviewed 1,000 people on Saturday and Sunday when most media attention was focused on Ken Livingstone's election as the mayor of London. Buoyed by ICM's findings that suggested his populist stance on the Tony Martin case and asylum seekers resonated with voters, Mr Hague now plans to broaden his attack to include the plight of manufacturing.

Manufacturing is as much a victim of Labour's high taxes and regulation as of the high level of sterling, Mr Hague and his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, will both say in speeches this week. Unlike sterling, tax and red tape are within the government's control, the Tories are now saying.

Coincidentally, Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, revealed yesterday that his party stategists had set their sights on winning at least another 50 Tory seats at the expected 2001 election following their surprise victory in Romsey, Hampshire, early on Friday morning.

Nationally, the Lib Dems are on 15% according to the private Tory poll, the same share which ICM reported for the Guardian in mid-April when Labour's lead over the Tories was 45% to 32%. Both the Lib Dems and Tories now believe they can benefit from tactical voting at Labour's expense, but also from each other. Labour remains confident that it will win a convincing second term mandate in May, June or, possibly, October 2001.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Kennedy said he believed his party could aim to more than double its present post-war record of 47 MPs by capturing Conservative and Labour marginals. He also believes the party can hold all its existing seats against the likely Tory counterattack, especially in the south.

The ambitious target, outlined to Lib Dem MPs in a private meeting last night, reflects a "revision" of the party's strategy in the aftermath of Romsey, where the Lib Dems overturned a Tory majority of 8,585 to gain the seat with a majority of 3,311.

He reinforced his message with a cheeky intervention at prime minister's question time, claiming that the Romsey result was "a triumph for the politics of hope" over the politics of "fear, division and prejudice". Mr Blair agreed and praised the Lib Dems' courage in confronting "an irresponsible campaign" by the Tories.

But Mr Hague, also talking strategy for two hours in private at Westminster last night, has drawn a very different conclusion. The Tories are now ahead on both the asylum and law and order issues for the first time in the Blair era.

Tory strategists have been wary of false dawns, not least because they closed the gap to 10% in November after a strong run of Hague performances.

A series of embarrassments, including Jeffrey Archer's legal trouble, Shaun Woodward's defection and the Aitken and Hamilton court cases, pushed them back down.

fields.headline: World Online hires Microsoft man
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: World Online, the pan-European internet service provider, yesterday turned to a senior Microsoft executive to fill the shoes of former chairwoman Nina Brink.
fields.body:
World Online, the pan-European internet service provider, yesterday turned to a senior Microsoft executive to fill the shoes of former chairwoman Nina Brink.

James Kinsella, president and chief executive of MSNBC.com, a joint venture between Microsoft and NBC, has been given the task of rebuilding confidence in the re cently floated Dutch-based firm. Goodwill towards the company was shattered when it emerged that Ms Brink had sold the bulk of her shares at a knockdown price before the flotation.

World Online's share price was driven down on the news from €43 (£25) to euro11.2 by May 5 as investors sold in their droves. Ms Brink subsequently resigned, and ABN Amro and Goldman Sachs, the invest ment banks that coordinated the offering, face the threat of legal action from furious shareholders.

Analysts were last night hopeful that the appointment of Mr Kinsella, who is due to take up his new post on June 1, will herald a turnround in fortunes for the company. "I expect we will have seen the bottom of the shares," said Bert Siebrand, analyst at SNS Securities.

Despite criticism of the company, users have not been put off World Online. By the end of the three months to March 31 subscriber numbers had jumped by 84.5% to 2.2m, according to figures released yesterday.

Revenues climbed 39% to euro40.5m, although losses mounted to euro9m, from euro50m during the previous period. World Online now has 20% more active subscribers than Freeserve, despite the British company being valued five times higher.

Some analysts argue that investors are better advised to buy into internet service providers with a dominant position in one country, rather than a company like World Online which has a presence in several states but none of them market leading.

Last night the shares closed at euro13.95.

webTitle: Britain rejects call to join UN peacekeepers in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Britain rejects call to join UN peacekeepers in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The British government yesterday rejected pleas from Sierra Leone to commit troops to the UN peacekeeping force as thousands of terrified refugees headed towards Freetown, fleeing from advancing rebel forces.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and Chris McGreal  in Jui, Sierra Leone
fields.body:
The British government yesterday rejected pleas from Sierra Leone to commit troops to the UN peacekeeping force as thousands of terrified refugees headed towards Freetown, fleeing from advancing rebel forces.

Confusion and controversy mounted during the day about Britain's role in the deteriorating security situation in its former colony.

Senior ministers are expected to hold a crisis meeting today to confront the dilemma Britain faces: getting involved in a war that cannot be won, or suffering the opprobrium that will come if UN peacekeepers are left in the lurch by British paratroopers sent to Sierra Leone to oversee an evacuation of expatriates.

The most likely outcome, Whitehall sources said last night, was that the paras would go on holding Lungi airport outside Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, awaiting the arrival of reinforcements for the UN force in the next few weeks. They are due mainly from India, Jordan, and Bangaladesh.

It was "very unlikely", the sources said, that ministers would commit British troops to the UN force proper - though yesterday RAF Chinooks were moving Jordanian troops to defensive positions near the capital. A Commons announcement is likely today.

If the strife in Sierra Leone intensifies into a battle for Freetown, the UN admitted yesterday its forces might have to fight. Peacekeeping mandates allow this only in self-defence.

"We'll do what we have to do to defend ourselves," said Fred Eckhard, spokesman for the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan.

"We hope that it won't come to a pitched battle but in effect we are preparing for one", he said in New York. This could make it difficult for British forces to stand back.

Last night British officials acknowledged that if - as reported - the anti-government forces of the Revolutionary United Front were heading for Freetown, the position of the paras there would be "very difficult".

The RUF was said to be 25 miles from Freetown and up to 10,000 people were estimated to be on the move from Waterloo, 18 miles away - the rebels' likely next target.

Julius Spencer, Sierra Leone's information minister, urged Britain to contribute "men and materials" to the inadequate UN peacekeeping force, complaining that London was not doing enough. He maintained that British military intervention would end the crisis.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said British paras would "certainly defend the airport".

He said he would investigate a report in yesterday's Guardian that a young black man, William Floode, was denied a place in any airlift out of Freetown because, though born in Wales and carrying a British birth certificate, he did not have a British passport.

webTitle: Mobile phones risk to child health

fields.headline: Mobile phones risk to child health
fields.standfirst:
Mobile phone fears: special report
IEGMP on setting-up the Stewart report
fields.trailText: A government-backed panel is expected to deliver a blow to the mobile phone industry today when it announces that concerns about their safety are real enough to warrant curbs on their use by children.
fields.body:
A government-backed panel is expected to deliver a blow to the mobile phone industry today when it announces that concerns about their safety are real enough to warrant curbs on their use by children.

The independent panel of scientists was set up by the government last year after fears that microwave radiation produced by mobile phones sending and receiving calls could damage brain cells.

The results of the panel's inquiry will be announced today. Yesterday it emerged that the panel had found "a risk of a risk" in their experiments, and would recommend that children be discouraged from using mobile phones for "non-essential purposes".

The Department of Health refused to comment before the announcement. But a source close to the inquiry said the panel was unhappy with the way mobile phone advertising targeted the youth market.

"Sometimes letting a child carry a mobile is fine. But we're talking about the fashion aspect," the source said.

One of the findings to cause concern was that though the microwaves generated by mobile phones might not be strong enough to damage brain cells by heating them, they could "switch on" genes normally switched on by stress.

Another source said: "While there is no evidence of risk, some biological findings indicate there is a risk of a risk. If there is a risk, children are always the most susceptible."

It is not clear what age limit the government would set at which new guidelines on mobile phone use would come into effect. Under-16s are not allowed to smoke, but if under-16s were discouraged from using mobile, it would hurt the phone companies. Young people account for about 25% of the mobile phone market.

The government may face a backlash from the big mobile phone operators, which have just agreed to pay £22.5bn for licences to operate a new generation of services.

Nicky Scott, an analyst for the Ovum consultancy, said: "It depends on what they call children. If you're talking about under-10s or under-12s it's going to have a minimal impact. If you're talking about the teenage market, the effect is slightly worse, but I don't think panic will set in."

webTitle: Police fear revenge attack by Leeds fans

fields.headline: Police fear revenge attack by Leeds fans
fields.trailText: Police officers from Yorkshire are to fly to Copenhagen on Monday after intelligence reports suggested that Leeds United fans were planning to cause trouble in the city when Arsenal take on the Turkish club Galatasaray in the Uefa cup final.
fields.body:
Police officers from Yorkshire are to fly to Copenhagen on Monday after intelligence reports suggested that Leeds United fans were planning to cause trouble in the city when Arsenal take on the Turkish club Galatasaray in the Uefa cup final.

The killing of two Leeds fans in Istanbul last month, the night before their team played Galatasaray in the semi-final, has led to fears that English and Turkish fans might clash in the run-up to the final next week.

Danish police have been warned by their British counterparts that some Leeds fans might cause trouble to avenge the deaths and that they might get into the stadium with some of the large number of tickets available on the black market.

Several Leeds fans paid for flights to Copenhagen before their team was eliminated. It is thought many might still fly to the city as they will not receive refunds.

Yorkshire officers will attempt to identify known Leeds United troublemakers and prevent them entering.

Metropolitan police officers will also be in the city after claims by Arsenal that it knew of London hooligans planning to travel. The information has been passed to police.

Both finalists have been allocated 12,000 tickets, but another 9,000 have been sold for neutral areas of the ground.

Mogens Lauridsen, a Danish chief superintendent, said: "We have received information about the possible arrival of Leeds United fans in Copenhagen.

"We are very aware that this is a real threat. Anybody arriving in Denmark without a ticket for the match will be turned away."

Danish police have decided not to close any bars. Copenhagen has a large Turkish community which is believed to have bought many of the tickets on sale locally, leading to fears over segregation in the Parken Stadium where the final is to be played.

webTitle: 2,000 jobs to go at Dagenham as Ford ends UK car production

fields.headline: 2,000 jobs to go at Dagenham as Ford ends UK car production
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford is to confirm 2,000 job losses at its Dagenham plant tomorrow, ending car production by the company in Britain after 69 years.
fields.body:
Ford is to confirm 2,000 job losses at its Dagenham plant tomorrow, ending car production by the company in Britain after 69 years.

The decision means that after November 2001, none of the 442,000 Ford cars bought annually in the UK will have been made in this country.

Ford is to sugar the pill by announcing heavy investment in engine production at the plant, in east London. For the first time Jaguar and Volvo engines will be made alongside Ford diesels. Other engine work also will be transferred from Detroit to Dagenham.

But Ford's plan to end car production in Britain, where it enjoys 20% of the market, and transfer production to Germany, where it has 6% of sales, triggered union protests.

The government, relieved at the rescue of Rover's Longbridge plant this week, faces new pressure to intervene and save car making at Dagenham.

Union leaders last night said Ford had broken a promise to build its new Fiesta model in the UK when the current version is scrapped in 18 months.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, yesterday appeared resigned to the end of car production at Dagenham when he said the government would help those put out of work.

"We will be there to help with money, investment and advice for anyone who does lose their job," he said.

Ford makes luxury Jaguar models in the West Midlands and at Halewood on Merseyside. Its Transit vans will still be produced in Southampton.

The number of redundancies at Dagenham has been scaled down from 3,000 to 2,000 in an attempt to defuse anger. Payoffs, which union negotiators estimate are worth up to £55,000, are being offered to assembly workers to encourage them to go quietly.

Notices pinned on walls of the Dagenham plant by workers read: "Closing down sale - everything must go."

Union leaders claim Dagenham is now more efficient than Cologne, where the new Fiesta will be made. They say it takes 24.4 hours to build a car in the UK plant, compared with 25.3 hours in Germany.

Sir Ken Jackson, the general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "Ford will have broken the commitment they made to us guaranteeing car production at Dagenham.

"We have a number of meetings and it is too early to say exactly what will happen, but if car assembly does end it will have a severe impact on the local economy."

Tony Woodley, of the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "Ending car as sembly at Dagenham is pure corporate greed. Workers are to be sacked in Britain because it is cheap and easy for Ford. To sell 442,000 cars and not build one here is a disgrace."

Dagenham's fate became clearer as it emerged that the £575m BMW made available to Phoenix to take over Longbridge was effectively a sweetener. Company sources said £75m is a donation and £500m is an interest free loan not payable for 50 years unless the firm is sold on.

The newly-elected London mayor, Ken Livingstone, said the end of mass car production at Dagenham would be a "body blow" to one of London's poorest areas. He warned that Ford could face "a backlash" from angry Britons.

William Hague, the Tory leader, said 206,000 manufacturing jobs had been lost under Mr Blair's government.

fields.headline: Tissue banks:  Tackling the problems
fields.trailText: • There are two types of postmortem. The coroner's postmortem is solely to establish the cause of death under the Coroner's Act 1988. Other postmortems are performed when hospitals want to study the cause of death. The removal of any organs is governed by the Human Tissue Act 1961 which merely requires that there is no objection from parents.
fields.body:
 There are two types of postmortem. The coroner's postmortem is solely to establish the cause of death under the Coroner's Act 1988. Other postmortems are performed when hospitals want to study the cause of death. The removal of any organs is governed by the Human Tissue Act 1961 which merely requires that there is no objection from parents.

 Nacor (National Committee for the Retention of Organs) believes 42 hospitals were involved in removing and retaining organs and tissue.

 A number of separate inquiries are taking place. One at Alder Hey, which had the largest collection of organs, has just begun. The report is due in the summer. That and the Kennedy report will go to the chief medical officer (CMO), Liam Donaldson, who is carrying out his own investigation to find out how many tissue banks exist and how they are operated. Professor Donaldson will present the government's conclusions later this year.

 Guidance to hospital pathologists has already been issued by the Royal College of Pathologists and the CMO has sent out interim advice. Both documents state that parents must sign explicit consent forms for the retention of organs or tissue and must understand the implications.

 The Kennedy report states that the ruling principle "must be respect for the dead child" and for the concerns of parents. Medicine can benefit from retaining tissue, but only with "the informed cooperation of parents". It says human material in any postmortem may be removed only with the fully informed consent of parents and should if possible be reunited with the body before the funeral, unless parents have agreed for it to be retained. Exactly what has been retained and the use to which it will be put must be stated.
fields.bodyText:  There are two types of postmortem. The coroner's postmortem is solely to establish the cause of death under the Coroner's Act 1988. Other postmortems are performed when hospitals want to study the cause of death. The removal of any organs is governed by the Human Tissue Act 1961 which merely requires that there is no objection from parents.  Nacor (National Committee for the Retention of Organs) believes 42 hospitals were involved in removing and retaining organs and tissue.  A number of separate inquiries are taking place. One at Alder Hey, which had the largest collection of organs, has just begun. The report is due in the summer. That and the Kennedy report will go to the chief medical officer (CMO), Liam Donaldson, who is carrying out his own investigation to find out how many tissue banks exist and how they are operated. Professor Donaldson will present the government's conclusions later this year.  Guidance to hospital pathologists has already been issued by the Royal College of Pathologists and the CMO has sent out interim advice. Both documents state that parents must sign explicit consent forms for the retention of organs or tissue and must understand the implications.  The Kennedy report states that the ruling principle "must be respect for the dead child" and for the concerns of parents. Medicine can benefit from retaining tissue, but only with "the informed cooperation of parents". It says human material in any postmortem may be removed only with the fully informed consent of parents and should if possible be reunited with the body before the funeral, unless parents have agreed for it to be retained. Exactly what has been retained and the use to which it will be put must be stated.

webTitle: Mirror editor rebuked over share scandal

fields.headline: Mirror editor rebuked over share scandal
fields.trailText: The editor of the Mirror, Piers Morgan, last night expressed regret for breaching the newspaper industry's code of practice after he was criticised by the press complaints commission for his share dealings.
fields.body:
The editor of the Mirror, Piers Morgan, last night expressed regret for breaching the newspaper industry's code of practice after he was criticised by the press complaints commission for his share dealings.

Lord Wakeham, the commission chairman, criticised the "cavalier" culture that had led to the scandal: "It was a very bad case," he said. The PCC report concluded that Mr Morgan had "fallen short of the high professional standards demanded by the code".

The Mirror editor was accused of selling shares whose value had risen after they were tipped in his paper's financial column, City Slickers. The authors of the column, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, have already been sacked for dealing in shares they tipped.

The PCC found that Mr Morgan sold shares in a company that had recently featured in City Slickers, a column for which as editor he was responsible. This was a breach of the code, the commission ruled.

Mirror Group Newspapers said it regretted the breaches and "Mr Morgan's failure to enforce the code". It said procedures had been strengthened to try to ensure there would be no repeat of the scandal.

In a statement, Mr Morgan said: "I regret my failure to enforce the code's provisions on financial journalism. I remain strongly committed to the code and to its observation."

Lord Wakeham said: "It was a clear climate of slack. It was all gay abandon. These things just seemed to happen. I suspect it was more cavalier than anything else."

Mr Morgan had breached the code in a serious way, Lord Wakeham said. As editor, he had a responsibility to enforce that code. "We have criticised him pretty severely. We have sent a copy of the ruling to the chief executive of the Mirror Group to indicate our considerable concerns but I am pleased to say the Mirror has instituted very tough rules."

Last night, Mr Morgan appeared to have survived the ruling - the second in his career as an editor - but he is understood still to be under investigation by the Department of Trade and Industry.

The PCC code forbids journalists from profiting from financial information gained before it is published; writing about shares they own without informing their editor of such holdings; or buying or selling shares about which they have written recently or intend to write in the near future.

Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell profited by buying shares and then tipping them in their column, which sent the price up. They then sold the shares and reaped the rewards. Mr Hipwell did this 25 times, Mr Bhoyrul 16, the PCC said.

Mr Morgan knew of Mr Hipwell's trading in June 1999 and warned him not to repeat the action. But the editor's actions were insufficient to prevent a repeat, the PCC judged.

Later, Mr Morgan dealt in shares in Viglen, a computer company. He bought £20,000 worth of Viglen shares on January 17, the day before City Slickers tipped the company. Viglen shares jumped in value when the report was printed.

Mr Morgan has since sold the shares and donated the profits to charity but has always claimed not to have known in advance that Viglen would be tipped.

Mr Bhoyrul initially confirmed the editor's account, but in an affidavit delivered to the PCC earlier this week he said Mr Morgan had discussed buying shares in the firm the day before the tip appeared.

The commission said the conflicting accounts did not matter, as Mr Morgan had, in any event, breached the code .

The commission made no finding against Tina Weaver, the deputy editor of the Mirror, who had been implicated in the affair.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The sell off continued. With both the Dow and Nasdaq under pressure in New York, London could only follow suit as investors continued to pull money out of the tech sectors.
fields.body:
The sell off continued. With both the Dow and Nasdaq under pressure in New York, London could only follow suit as investors continued to pull money out of the tech sectors.

Now that there are so many new economy companies in the FTSE 100, the effects are quickly seen on the British blue chip indicator. And so while there were strong gains in the banking and oil sectors, sharp falls in the likes of BSkyB (down from £15.12 to £13.34 after the Sports Internet deal) left the Footsie 23.2 points weaker at 6110.6 at the close. The techMARK 100, meanwhile, suffered a drop of 160.67 points, or 4.4%, to 3473.20.

Other big new economy losers included Psion , down from 798p to 698p in its freshly split form, internet security specialists Baltimore Technology , which fell 436p to £62 and also internet service provider Freeserve , which shed 28.5p to 405p as the market digested the news that Dixon's is looking to sell a further tranche of its remaining 80% stake .

Part of the reason for the continuing sell-off of tech issues was put down to an aggressive downgrade of mobile maker Motorola by Salomon Smith Barney in the US. The bank's highly-rated telecoms analyst Alex Cena had chopped his price target on the shares from $200 to $120, causing the market price to fall $13 to $91.

But in London the biggest Footsie faller of the day proved to be Hilton , which slumped from 273p to 228p. Market makers were running for cover as investment bankers Deutsche placed a line of 40m shares at a discount to the prevailing market price.

Yet even this move was overshadowed by shocking news from British Energy, which is halving its dividend and warned investors to expect losses this year. The stock slumped from 168p to 132p - the lowest level since the group was floated in July 1996. Against this, the Top 100 board saw some bottom fishing in J Sainsbury , up from 346p to 373.5p, and also British Airways , which moved up from 326.5p to 358.5p.

Lower down the corporate scale, pet food maker Armitage Brothers warned of poor trading and watched its shares fall 30p to 185p. But news that private equity group Cinven is in advanced talks to buy metal basher McKechnie saw the bid target's shares hiked from 317.5p to 377p, valuing the group at just over £400m.

Race course operator Arena Leisure ran 14.5p higher to 149p after reports that Hilton's Ladbroke betting operation might table a bid. The two have talked in the past.

fields.headline: Glorious victory
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: From warmth to warmth - we returned from the Midi and the Medoc to find our Burren, if anything, warmer. Bluebells, early purple  orchids and just flowering mountain avens line the  roadsides from Poulnabrone Dolmen downhill to  Ballyvaughan.
fields.body:
From warmth to warmth - we returned from the Midi and the Medoc to find our Burren, if anything, warmer. Bluebells, early purple orchids and just flowering mountain avens line the roadsides from Poulnabrone Dolmen downhill to Ballyvaughan.

Last month I wrote about how the Burren action group opposed for nine years a government project to build a visitor centre at isolated Mullaghmore. In this opposition they put their livelihoods on the line because of legal fees costing I£150,000. I wrote that the minister had her team searching for a technicality on which to appeal the decision of the highest planning authority against the construction of the visitor centre. She has now decided not to appeal - a well deserved victory for the group.

Now we are dipping into our pockets to help pay their legal fees. A race night is to be held later this month. For I£20 a horse, jockey and trainer may be entered for the race, their names chosen by the contributor. Our horse is called Escargot! We hope to win. This recalls the word we, as children in Co Wexford, used for snail - shellacapookie. Lovely. And where did it originate?

So spring glides into summer in a hazy warmth and a sense of happiness that a part of the environment of these islands has been saved, not by money but by real devotion to, by the constancy of love for a place of beauty, remote, tranquil, austere. This morning very early dawn had not broken in glory on sea or land, only a few pale fingers of light stroked the darkness - I saw what looked like a short post about two feet high. It was a hare standing on its hind legs and gazing intently at the window. I was afraid to breathe. We each stood immobile - I never relaxed my watching the hare and it matched my attention, though what it saw I know not.

Gradually the fingers of light joined, dispelling the dark. The hare turned its head, dropped on all fours and sauntered away in silence, not even inviting me, as the March Hare invited Alice, to "take some more tea".

fields.headline: Bank's sterling solution - do nothing
fields.standfirst: Notebook: No reality in the rhetoric
fields.trailText: Rather belatedly, the government has accepted that the strong pound is a bit of a problem.
fields.body:
Rather belatedly, the government has accepted that the strong pound is a bit of a problem. After last week's electoral drubbing, it is now felt that the previous wall of silence seemed a tad unfeeling and that it is time for a little tender loving care. Both Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have gone out of their way this week to stress that sterling is overvalued.

But changing the rhetoric is one thing, changing the reality is quite another, and nothing that has been said either by the first and second lords of the treasury this week - or by the Bank of England - suggests that the government will do anything about the strong pound.

Mr Blair hinted at the government's real thoughts yesterday when, mischievously quoting Michael Portillo, he said that a strong currency was the reflection of a strong economy.

There is an element of truth in this. The Economist Intelligence Unit issued a survey yesterday saying Britain was rated as the second best place in the world to do business over the past five years, and was expected to retain this position over the next five. So, important though the pound is, it is clearly far from the only factor affecting the economic climate.

That said, a seriously overvalued exchange rate can, if it persists, damage an economy's industrial base. It is often said that Germany flourished for many years with a strong mark, but the counter argument is that Germany's sluggish performance in the 90s has been the result of all those years of an overvalued currency finally catching up with it.

Ideally, then, the government would like a slightly lower pound, but would prefer the decline to be gentle rather than precipitate. But it has no faith in any of the remedies suggested - intervention, pre-announcing a medium-term exchange rate for joining the euro, cutting interest rates - believing that they will either be ineffective or do more harm than good.

In fact, the evidence of the past week suggests that one of the three remedies - lower interest rates - might work. Sterling has fallen back against the euro since the markets digested the fact that rates might have peaked. It would drop still further if the markets believed that the next move in rates would be down rather than up.

But to do that, the Bank would have to be convinced that this is a different world from the 70s and 80s, where the risks of inflation are much less than they were. And, sadly, there is no certainty that it is.

Dash for cash

A sudden urge to dash for the cash seems to have infected a number of Britain's most entrepreneurial boardrooms. Over the past few days we have had news that Mike Lynch, our first "internet billionaire" and founder of software group Autonomy," is turning £26m of his paper fortune into spendable readies.

Then there is John Hargreaves, chairman of the hugely successful discount retailer Matalan, who is selling down the family stake by a whopping £200m.

Lower down the scale - but still noteworthy - two directors at the chip designer ARM Holdings have exercised options over 1m shares apiece, and then sold half, raising £3m each to pay their tax bills.

The charts say we should take notice when directors sell lumpy amounts of stock. They always have an excuse (new extension to the house, divorce proceedings, and so on), but in most cases it usually turns out that they thought the share price too high.

In the US, of course, directors buying or selling shares are known as insiders for obvious reasons. And because they are often right -especially when board members are selling - a whole industry has grown up simply to monitor these most knowledgeable of investors.

The examples are endless, although thankfully few are as gruesome as Carl Cushnie's £30m share sale at the trade finance house Versailles before the true construction of the company's balance sheet was revealed.

But before ordinary shareholders follow the example and rush for the exit, there is a need to look at each corporate case individually.

In the case of Autonomy and AIM, the numbers are small enough in relative terms for investors to stay relaxed. The new economy has thrown up some extraordinary paper fortunes, and it would be unrealistic to expect entrepreneurs to avoid spending any of their money.

The Hargreaves family at Matalan has also worked for its wealth and is only selling a fifth of its stake. What raises the alarm bells is the claim from the company that the share sales reflected "pressure" from its broker UBS Warburg to feed hungry institutions with stock.

Whatever Matalan's prospects, or the shape of its share register, history demands that such claims be treated with real suspicion. If you own the stock, sell it now.

webTitle: Shipyard staves off closure with £300m ferries deal

fields.headline: Shipyard staves off closure with £300m ferries deal
fields.trailText: The troubled Belfast shipyard Harland and Wolff announced yesterday that it had won a £300m contract to design and build four roll-on, roll-off ferries, so staving off imminent closure.
fields.body:
The troubled Belfast shipyard Harland and Wolff announced yesterday that it had won a £300m contract to design and build four roll-on, roll-off ferries, so staving off imminent closure.

The development, coming the day after workers narrowly voted to accept an austerity package including a three-year wage freeze and a no-strike deal, means a reprieve for most of the 1,300 shipyard workforce for at least two years. But 300 people are still likely to lose their jobs.

Management had issued 90 day protective notice to workers in March when the yard failed to secure the lucrative contract from Cunard to build the £450 million luxury liner, Queen Mary 2. The first redundancy notices were due to be sent out next month.

The contract, with an option to build two more ships, bringing its total value to £500m, comes from Bahamas-based Seamasters International. The first vessel is due to enter service in 2002, with phased de liveries until 2004 if the extra ships are confirmed.

Management, blamed by the workforce for the yard's plight, tried to secure a tougher cost-cutting package, sparking a workers' march through Belfast last week. They backed off, though still complain the new pay and conditions deal, limiting skilled workers to £310 a week, impacted on their competiveness.

Harland and Wolff, with few reserves, is yet to finalise financing. But the government, which gave the maximum help permissible under European legislation in a frantic effort to help the yard win the Cunard contract, is likely to come up with essential grants and guarantees.

Brynjulv Mugass, chief executive, said the contract for what he termed truly innovative vessels provided the yard with an opportunity to establish itself in the market sector. There was presently a lack of tonnage available for Ropax vessels, especially the sophisticated Atlantic 4000 class the yard would be building.

Sir Reg Empey, the Ulster Unionist who will resume the trade minister portfolio in Northern Ireland if the power-sharing executive is re-formed later this month, said securing the contract was a "magnificent achievement" under the most difficult of circumstances.

Donald McGregor, the GMB union's national officer for engineering, expressed delight at the order. "This is a major and timely boost for the company and its workforce. The GMB will work closely with everyone involved to ensure that this contract goes through smoothly and that Harland and Wolff is in a strong position to continue its long tradition of ship and off-shore construction."

 British Telecom has announced the creation of 160 new jobs in Londonderry. It is setting up a customer accounts centre of excellence as part of an initiative to enhance services to residential and small business customers. It is one of only seven being built in the UK and, coupled with another BT investment in Derry last autumn, brings the company jobs expansion in the city to over 800.

fields.headline: Times-a-changing after Caspian strike
fields.trailText: It is turning into quite a week for what oldies still think of as British Gas. Once the private punter's favourite choice it is now heading for a divorce in the autumn, with the go-getting oil and gas exploration arm BG International splitting from the heavily-regulated pipeline division, Transco.
fields.body:
It is turning into quite a week for what oldies still think of as British Gas. Once the private punter's favourite choice it is now heading for a divorce in the autumn, with the go-getting oil and gas exploration arm BG International splitting from the heavily-regulated pipeline division, Transco.

First off, we had Transco planning to spend hundreds of millions of pounds laying down a high volume telecoms network.

Then yesterday, on the eve of BG's first-quarter results today, Christmas came early for BG International, courtesy of the prime minister of Kazakhstan, Kasymzhomart Tokayev.

The good news out of this huge central Asian nation is that an international consortium that has been test drilling for oil on the Caspian shelf has found major deposits.

The consortium in question? Offshore Kazakhstan International Operating Company, a 14%-odd stakeholder in which is none other than BG International.

webTitle: Spreading wings: British Midland expects New York flights next year

fields.headline: Spreading wings: British Midland expects New York flights next year
fields.trailText: British Midland's chairman, Sir Michael Bishop, yesterday outlined ambitious plans for expansion as he launched the airline's service to Madrid.
fields.body:
British Midland's chairman, Sir Michael Bishop, yesterday outlined ambitious plans for expansion as he launched the airline's service to Madrid.

Insiders say Sir Michael has had indications from the government that the long-awaited deal on transatlantic flights is within sight, allowing it to begin flying to the US within a year. The airline is also looking at new European routes, which could include Barcelona, Lisbon and Zurich.

Expansion is likely to create around 3,000 jobs over the next five years and the airline is likely to be rebranded; Bluebird is one possibility. Sir Michael said: "This will be a year of significant transition, we've got a big job to do."

British Midland has won licences to fly to New York, Washington, Miami and Boston and wants to begin next May.

Sir Michael wants to launch services from Manchester and Heathrow simultaneously. But they cannot start until the long-running "open skies" talks between the British and US governments are resolved.

Sir Michael said: "The tone of statements from the government is very different from at the start of the year." Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, had suggested Heathrow could be a hub for both British Midland's Star Alliance and the rival One World group which includes British Airways.

The Madrid service is a collaboration with Star partners SAS and Lufthansa. The route was previously the preserve of BA and Iberia - both One World members - and Sir Michael expects further challenges to his rivals around Europe.

The airline is Britain's second largest, carrying 7m passengers a year. Sir Michael, who owns 60%, said flotation was a long-term option once the company had secured a strong earnings stream.

fields.headline: Tulipmania Picasso portrait fetches £17m
fields.trailText: Pablo Picasso's 1932 portrait, Nature morte aux tulipes , was sold yesterday for $28.6m (£17.5m) - the tenth highest price for any piece of art ever sold.
fields.body:
Pablo Picasso's 1932 portrait, Nature morte aux tulipes , was sold yesterday for $28.6m (£17.5m) - the tenth highest price for any piece of art ever sold.

The painting of his mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter holding a bowl of tulips was sold by auction at the Christie's spring sale of 20th century art in New York. The painting, from a private collection in Europe, had not been on the market since 1957.

Christopher Burge, honorary chairman of Christie's America, called the sale "a terrific result", noting that the total for the night's sale of $73m was within the expected range of $64m to $84m.

The eyes of the art world are trained on this week's sales at Christie's and Sotheby's, the powerhouses of the auction world, as well as on a Thursday sale at Phillips, the distant third house that is making a serious bid to play in the big league.

An investigation in the US and possible charges against Christie's and Sotheby's for alleged price fixing have been a focus of the auction world since the scandal broke early in the year.

Picassos were the hottest items at yesterday's auction, making up the four highest lots.

However, other artists did not fare so well, with featured works by Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, Franz Kline and Henri Matisse going unsold when bidding failed to reach the reserve prices.
AP, New York

fields.headline: BOC carve-up bid called off
fields.standfirst: US regulators reject plan for £7bn split
fields.trailText: BOC Group, the industrial gases specialist, will strike out on an independent course after the expected failure of a carve-up by Air Liquide of France and Air Products of the US.
fields.body:
BOC Group, the industrial gases specialist, will strike out on an independent course after the expected failure of a carve-up by Air Liquide of France and Air Products of the US.

Restrictions placed on the deal by regulators in Washington have effectively scuppered the bid, which will lapse at the end of the week.

The company - which accepted the £7.2bn bid in July - said yesterday it had undergone significant restructuring and reorganisation over the past two years and was confident of its ability to develop its business unaided.

Air Liquide and Air Products said they are prepared to consider whether a new offer acceptable to BOC can be made. Any such new offer would involve a different structure and price, they said.

Four giant groups dominate the world's industrial gases market, with a total 60% share. The Air Liquide-Air Products deal was always going to hit regulatory problems, given that two of these groups were proposing to carve up a third between them.

Prior to the joint offer, the conventional wisdom had been that only one merger at the most, involving two of the four, would be permitted, giving a huge incentive to be first in the race to get together.

To that end, BOC opened talks with the largest gases group, America's Praxair, but they stalled in early 1999.

BOC then started talking to Air Liquide about a friendly tie-up, but Air Liquide surprised BOC in June by proposing a break-up bid involving Air Products.

Initially, BOC threw out the the offer but in July agreed to end 130 years of independence and recommend the deal to shareholders.

Under the proposals, Air Liquide would take over BOC operations in Britain and Ireland, half of its activities in the US its subsidiaries in Japan and those in some other Asian countries.

Air Products would take those in Australia and New Zealand, the other half of BOC's US operations and the remaining businesses in Asia.

Negotiations opened with regulators in Brussels and with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) in Washington. In the event, it was the FTC which was to prove the stumbling block.

Air Products and Air Liquide said yesterday that during 10 months of discussions with the commission they had made "a number of comprehensive and practical proposals, including divestitures, which responded to the demands of the FTC."

But it had recently become clear that the FTC would not approve the offer by the May 12 expiry date, and so the offer would not go ahead.

During the negotiations, the companies said, they had explored with the commission whether the sale of all BOC's US businesses would clear the path for approval.

They said they would continue these talks with the aim of considering whether a new offer may be made.
