webTitle: It's a telephone, your Majesty. And it's got a lobster on it

fields.headline: It's a telephone, your Majesty. And it's got a lobster on it
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Jones offers the
Queen, who cuts the ribbon at the Tate Modern today, a brief guide to the new 
gallery
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones offers the Queen, who cuts the ribbon at the Tate Modern today, a brief guide to the new gallery
fields.body:
"Your Majesty, here we have Marcel Duchamp's The Bride Stripped Bare By Her Bachelors, Even, which depicts a bunch of lonely chocolate grinders squirting their love gasoline at a distant object of desire. They're wasting their time, your Majesty, just grinding their own chocolate... oh no, that's not suitable. What about Richard Hamilton's painting of a solitary Orangeman washed up by history, probably the closest thing to a loyal subject in the museum. Or something by Salvador Dali, a devout Spanish monarchist. Take his Lobster Telephone. It's a telephone, your Majesty. And it's got a lobster on it."

Chances are the curators of Tate Modern won't even try to explain what all the fuss is about when the Queen opens Britain's first national museum of modern art this morning. The Queen may need, however, a brief guide to probably the biggest cultural event her reign has seen. Besides, she may want to annoy Prince Charles by asking him what he thinks of Mondrian. So here goes:

One lump or two?
The familiar and reassuringly British custom of taking tea, practised throughout the colonies, is suggested by the sugar lumps in Marcel Duchamp's Why Not Sneeze Rose Sélavy? (1921). The trouble is the sugar lumps are locked in a cage, and the title - with the name of Duchamp's transvestite alter ego pronounced Eros C'est La Vie - is a dirty joke. Why not sneeze, why not ejaculate. We're back to chocolate grinders, I'm afraid.

Supermarket
A supermarket, your Majesty, is a place crammed with mass-produced produce where ordinary people find it convenient to shop. Andy Warhol painted supermarket produce including Brillo boxes and Campbell's Tomato Soup, but never, oddly, a Fortnum and Mason hamper. "A Coke is a Coke," said Warhol, "and no amount of money can get you a better Coke than the one the bum on the corner is drinking." Coke is short for Coca-Cola, an American soft drink.

Video
The best way to comprehend video art is to compare it to the royal Christmas message. You get the same agonising sense of time passing, of each second turning into an eon as film is shown in slow motion or as the annual report to one's sub jects is read deadpan to camera, with that totally frozen shot of the royal face. But beware: with video art you're more likely to see an anus than hear about an annus horribilis.

Beuys
Those huge chunks of rock are not bits of masonry the builders forgot to move but Joseph Beuys's epic sculpture The End of the Twentieth Century. Beuys wore a felt hat and whatever he touched took on a magical quality. He claimed to be able to channel ancient spiritual currents into modern life. Prince Charles might want to check him out as a potential new guru. Suggest he have himself swaddled in fat as a way to popularise the monarchy.

Bourgeois
Not an insulting description of one's subjects but a famous French-born artist who is in her late 80s. Louise Bourgeois trained with the Cubist Fernand Léger, exhibited in the 1940s at Peggy Guggenheim's legendary Manhattan gallery, Art of This Century, and now occupies the equivalent position in the art world to the Queen Mother. But with less of the waving, more of the spiral staircases and giant spiders.

Cremaster
A muscle that suspends the testicles and the name of a film series by Matthew Barney, an American, and one of the lively and interesting young people who have exhibits in Tate Modern.

King and Queen
Henry Moore's famous sculpture of a royal couple was transformed by Sarah Lucas, another young person with plenty of personality, into a filthy mattress with a cucumber and a couple of oranges representing Him and two melons and a bucket standing in for Her Majesty. Think of this scabrous "young British art" as a bit like punk. You must remember punk, your Majesty. God Save The Queen? The Sex Pistols?

Picasso
A president of the Royal Academy once proposed to horsewhip Pablo Picasso. Relations between the British ruling class and modern art have never been good - although Edward VII used to hang around Paris nightclubs in the age of Toulouse Lautrec, it was not for the art. So take a good look at the Picassos, not to mention Matisses, de Chiricos and Pollocks, and reflect that finally Britain is throwing its cultural conservatism into the Thames. And then cut the ribbon.

webTitle: BSkyB shareholders fear cost of own-goal policy

fields.headline: BSkyB shareholders fear cost of own-goal policy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BSkyB shares fell almost 10% yesterday despite the satellite broadcaster unveiling smaller-than-expected losses and a long-awaited acquisition that plugs a hole in its internet strategy.
fields.body:
BSkyB shares fell almost 10% yesterday despite the satellite broadcaster unveiling smaller-than-expected losses and a long-awaited acquisition that plugs a hole in its internet strategy.

Analysts blamed what one described as "a mixed bag" of quarterly results and market fears that BSkyB could be forced to pay up to £2bn to renew its cornerstone contract for exclusive live broadcasts of premiership football matches for a 178p fall in the share price to £13.34.

Some also questioned whether it had overpaid for ther soccer website and tax-free betting company, Sports Internet, by agreeing a £303m all-share deal. BSkyB and chairman Rupert Murdoch have been accused of being slow to recognise the importance of the internet but chief executive Tony Ball insisted the acquisition was a sound one and puts its own web development strategy one year ahead of schedule.

The costs of rolling out its digital service continue to weigh heavily on BSkyB's balance sheet, accounting for a fourth consecutive quarter of losses. However, analysts say the investment has been worthwhile.

BSkyB added 316,000 new digital subscribers during the three months ended March 31 and with a further 398,000 existing analogue customers making the switch it had 3.4m digital subscribers by May 9. Mr Ball wants to have 5m digital subscribers by the end of the year. "In the past 12 months we have attracted an additional 2.3m subscribers to the digital platform, underlining what has been the fastest digital launch by any European platform," he said.

Peter Misek, analyst at Chase H&Q, said: "BSkyB is way ahead of its rivals with its digital numbers. However, there is a lot of uncertainty because of the football rights. If they win them for less than £1.5bn I'd be happy for them. Anything more would be a short-term negative for the stock."

The quarterly pre-tax loss of £28.4m compared with a profit of £16m year-on-year. Operating costs rose from £345.2m to £443.9m, while sales rose from £391.1m to £467.2m.

Peter Wilkinson, Sports Internet's main shareholder, stands to receive around £130m worth of BSkyB shares for his stake, has been tied into the company for two years.

He is expected to use BSkyB's financial muscle to move into new sports - notably horse racing - and advise on how the broadcaster can leverage his Planetfootball.com brand into its interactive television service.

Other Sports Internet shareholders celebrating the deal include Chris Akers, the company's executive chairman whose holding is valued at £17m, and Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood.

webTitle: Three blunders that led up to rail disaster

fields.headline: Three blunders that led up to rail disaster
fields.standfirst:
Paddington crash inquiry Driver had not been properly trained or warned about the risks of passing signals at red

Paddington train crash: special report
Ladbroke Grove inquiry
fields.trailText: Train driver Michael Hodder was ignorant of three key factors which could have prevented the Paddington rail crash, the opening of the official inquiry into the disaster was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Train driver Michael Hodder was ignorant of three key factors which could have prevented the Paddington rail crash, the opening of the official inquiry into the disaster was told yesterday.

His training questions did not cover the busiest section of his route between Paddington and Ladbroke Grove, he was not told about the risks of passing red signals, particularly signal 109 at Ladbroke Grove, and his company failed to send him on a special red signal awareness day.

It was also revealed for the first time that Mr Hodder should not have been driving because he had a criminal record.

The inquiry, opened by Lord Cullen in London, heard that Mr Hodder, who was among the 31 people who died in the crash, had failed to disclose at his interview with Thames Trains that he had been convicted by magistrates a year earlier of assault and affray, and been given a conditional discharge.

Robert Owen QC, counsel to the inquiry, said that Thames Trains would probably not have offered Mr Hodder a job if it had known of the conviction.

Mr Hodder, a married father of two, drove his three-carriage train through signal 109 just after leaving Paddington on October 5 last year. He continued for 700 metres into the path of a Great Western express, operating between Cheltenham and London.

The two trains collided at a combined speed of 145 mph two miles outside Paddington station, in west London. More than 400 people were injured in the crash.

Mr Owen said the inquiry would hear how Railtrack failed to respond to earlier incidents of trains passing signal 109 at danger, in spite of at least three clear written warnings from Great Western prior to the crash.

"This horrific tragedy has cast a long shadow," he said. The crash, coming so soon after the 1997 Southall disaster in which seven people were killed, had "severely shaken the confidence of the travelling public in the safety of our railways".

The inquiry will be told how Alison Forster, Great Western's operations safety director, wrote to Railtrack 14 months before the accident pointing out that she had noticed that there had been another signal passed at danger incident (spad) at signal 109.

Her letter said: "I believe this to be the eighth spad at this signal. I should be grateful if you would advise me as a matter of urgency what action you intend to take to mitigate against this high risk signal."

She wrote again to Railtrack on December 22 1998 about a spad at SN 85 nearby, which had occurred the previous week. "It is clear from all the spads in the Paddington area that there is a serious problem with drivers misreading signals. This has been known for some time and very little action has been taken by Railtrack to date."

Four months before the crash, she wrote to Railtrack again saying that she remained "seriously concerned" at the failure by Railtrack to deal with the problem.

At one stage, the inquiry heard, Great Western also tried to press Railtrack to make certain lines outside Paddington unidirectional. But the official reply was that the plan was unworkable if existing train service patterns were to be maintained.

Mr Owen said: "There would certainly appear to have been a conflict between issues of operational safety and commercial considerations.

"The critical question for Railtrack to answer is how a situation was allowed to arise and to persist in which there could be so many spads on the new Paddington layout, some extremely serious, in a period of a little over six years."

Matthew Spencer, Railtrack's signal engineer, told the inquiry that no consensus existed on what to do about the signals and SN 109 in particular, "beyond what had already been done".

Mr Owen also recalled the situation in Slough signal control room, where a signalman had just started his seventh consecutive 12-hour turn of duty, the maximum permitted under official rules, on the day of the crash.

He was alerted that an accident was about to occur and had 25 seconds to stop it happening. He had no direct radio link to the driver of the Great Western train, but he could have warned railway control at Swindon, which could then have sent out an emergency broadcast to all trains on the national network.

Another solution would have been for the signalman to press a "signals on" button on his computer, which would have immediately changed all signals to red in the Paddington area.

But his instructions did not allow him to do so. Mr Owen said that the inquiry would have to consider whether such a restriction should be imposed on signallers.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The London Metal Exchange yesterday took the first step towards ending its 123-year history of mutual ownership and turning itself into a limited company.
fields.body:
LME calls time on mutuality
The London Metal Exchange yesterday took the first step towards ending its 123-year history of mutual ownership and turning itself into a limited company. A review of the market's operations suggested also that an electronic trading system be established, working in parallel with the traditional practice of ring trading. But "LME plc" would be owned by its members as shareholders and not turned immediately into a full-blown commercial concern. The exchange wants the flexibility of a company structure while keeping the benefits of ownership by firms trading on the exchange. All changes will need to be approved by a 75% majority of the 100-odd member firms but, were the LME to decide to end mutual ownership, it would be following a number of City markets, including the futures and commodities exchange Liffe, the stock exchange and, after much debate, the International Petroleum Exchange.

Old Mutual brokers merge
Old Mutual, the South African life insurer, said it had merged its UK stockbrokers Albert E Sharp Securities with the institutional division of Greig Middleton to create a new broking arm, Old Mutual Securities, to be launched later this month.

The move follows Old Mutual's acquisition of Sharp in August 1998 and recently completed £525m takeover of Greig Middleton's parent, Gerrard. The group said it was part of a strategy to expand beyond its core life assurance business in South Africa.

Edmond Warner, chief executive of the new group (pictured above), said it planned to become a major force in UK stockbroking, filling the gap left by firms bought by European banks, "who have sought to expand in Europe at the expense of their traditional UK client base."

British Energy shares crash
Shares in British Energy crashed yesterday to their lowest level since privatisation four years ago after the nuclear generator halved the dividend for 1999 and warned of possible losses this year.

Britain's largest power generator said falling electricity prices had triggered a "major deterioration in financial performance for the current financial year" and it could not "exclude the possibility of incurring a loss". The shares dived 21.25p to 147p, even though pre-tax profits were at the top end of market estimates, at £241m. The dividend was halved to 8p.

webTitle: The survivor, the victim and the bereaved

fields.headline: The survivor, the victim and the bereaved
fields.standfirst:
Paddington train crash: special report
Ladbroke Grove inquiry
fields.trailText: •Pam Warren, who was severely burned in the accident, arrived for the beginning of the inquiry with her face in a mask and her hands covered. She has to wear protective gloves and a mask to prevent scarring.
fields.body:
Pam Warren, who was severely burned in the accident, arrived for the beginning of the inquiry with her face in a mask and her hands covered. She has to wear protective gloves and a mask to prevent scarring.

Mrs Warren, who has had 22 operations and will have many more, said: "We are supposed to be one of the three great powers in the world yet we have a third world railway industry."

Mrs Warren, who was on board the Great Western train, spent almost three months in hospital. She could not speak for five weeks and has now had to give up the pension advisory business that she ran with her husband, Peter. They have been forced to sell it because looking after her is a 24-hour job.

She was in coach H which was burnt to a cinder. She lost all her hair, the tips of her fingers, and the skin from the back of her legs and hands.

Robin and Diana Kellow sat behind a graduation picture of their daughter, Elaine, 24, who died in the crash. Mr Kellow, who travelled from Yorkshire yesterday, had no doubt about where the main blame lay.

"It all comes down to Railtrack. They set the track and we know that there was a loose section of track prior to signal 109." He called for Railtrack's board to face prosecution. "They haven't done their job. They took all the profits."

He added: "My worst nightmare happened on October 5 last year. I can't believe we have a railway network that is over 150 years old and we don't know how to run it properly."

An American, Birgit Andersen, who lost her daughter, Emily, flew from Washington, and described the crash as a "national shame for Britain".

Her daughter had been due to return to the US after finishing a secondment at ICI in Slough.

Mrs Andersen said that nothing less than state of the art equipment should be fitted on the railways.

She criticised the decision of the crown prosecution service not to bring charges of corporate manslaughter against individual companies.

"I came here yesterday on a 747 with at least 400 people and they had three or four people in the cockpit."

Comparing this with the single inexperienced driver of the Thames train, which passed through a red danger signal, she said: "It does not seem possible that he missed the signal."

fields.headline: Censorship struggles
fields.standfirst: The British courts seem to be getting it wrong about free speech on the internet
fields.trailText: Imagine you lived in a primitive island community. One day a bright spark - let's call him Fred - offers to carry messages between islanders, a service that rapidly becomes very popular. Then he has another good idea: he clears one side of a big tree and encourages people to carve messages on it.
fields.body:
Imagine you lived in a primitive island community. One day a bright spark - let's call him Fred - offers to carry messages between islanders, a service that rapidly becomes very popular. Then he has another good idea: he clears one side of a big tree and encourages people to carve messages on it.

Who should be held responsible if one islander defames another, or wrongly accuses him of a heinous crime? Simple, surely: whoever wrote the message. At any rate, not Fred. But what if Fred begins removing messages he does not like from his tree? And what if it becomes impossible to track down the authors of specific messages?

Judges and lawmakers around the world are currently grappling with similar questions as they struggle to frame a new set of rules for another primitive community. Last week's ruling by the US supreme court that an internet service provider (ISP) could not be held liable for statements made by one of its subscribers highlighted how far we are from agreeing about how the laws of the old, unwired world should be applied to the wild reaches of cyberspace.

In the American case a New York lawyer had sued the net company Prodigy after an imposter sent obscene and threatening messages purporting to come from his 15-year-old son, Alexander Lunney. Messages had been sent to an individual and a bulletin board.

The case was thrown out by New York state's highest court in a ruling (the one upheld by the supreme court) that smacked of common sense. "Email is the day's evolutionary hybrid of tradi tional telephone line communications and regular postal service mail," observed Judge Rosenblatt. "In this respect, an ISP, like a telephone company, is merely a conduit."

Rosenblatt conceded that the status of bulletin boards was trickier, but ruled nevertheless that Prodigy could not be considered to be the publisher of the bulletin board because it did not edit the vast majority of postings.

On the face of it the Lunney decision appears diametrically opposed to what passes for case law on this side of the Atlantic. In the only ruling on the subject to date, Mr Justice Morland decided that the internet company Demon was liable for defamatory comments posted about the physicist Laurence Godfrey because it acted as publisher.

The decision wasn't quite as draconian as it sounds: the judge ruled that Demon be came a publisher only after Godfrey complained about the postings on a newsgroup. Until then it could claim it did not know the content of the material it was disseminating and could not therefore be held responsible.

Fair enough? Perhaps, until you consider what happened next. According to lawyers in the field, service providers are now routinely shutting down sites as soon as they receive a complaint. "They say they just can't take the risk," one told me. ISPs were reluctant for the extent of their self-censorship to be known, she said, for fear it would trigger more complaints.

If all this sounds messy, consider that some of the trickier questions haven't even been addressed by a court yet. What, for instance, if someone posts a defamatory message on a bulletin board maintained by a pub lisher like the Guardian? Will they be considered publishers of all messages on the boards? If they were, few would take the risk of hosting discussion areas at all and a vibrant, democratic area of the internet would be snuffed out.

A lot of nonsense is talked about freedom of speech on the net. Is there any philosophical reason why people should be allowed to say things on the net that they can't say in the real world? Of course not. But there are practical reasons why they can and will continue to.

Quite simply the net cannot be policed the way the real world is. Remember what happened during the McLibel case: while lawyers fenced in the High Court, Ronald McDonald's foes made sure every last allegation was available from several websites around the world. When the company attempted to shut down one site, its online detractors promised that at least two more would carry the material. In the face of this hydra-like threat, a corporate giant was forced to retreat.

Those of us who admire the American approach must also be comfortable with the idea that ISPs should be compelled to finger alleged defamers where possible. But the nature of the medium means that it will always be easy to post information anonymously, or to do it from a country where you face little danger of legal action.

Given the difficulty any victim of an online slur would have tracking down their accuser, it is hardly surprising that the aggrieved parties go for the messenger. And, however much you care about freedom of speech, it doesn't seem right that Alexander Lunney and Laurence Godfrey should have no way of protecting their reputations in cyberspace.

Ultimately the courts will have to rethink the perpetual compromise between freedom of speech and the right to protect your reputation. Last week's US Supreme Court ruling suggest our courts have got it wrong. The good news is that it will be difficult for them to keep it that way.

webTitle: Special care nurse jailed for breaking baby's leg

fields.headline: Special care nurse jailed for breaking baby's leg
fields.trailText: A nurse who broke a baby's leg while it was being treated in a hospital incubator was yesterday jailed for eight months.
fields.body:
A nurse who broke a baby's leg while it was being treated in a hospital incubator was yesterday jailed for eight months.

Sister Shirley Ball, 45, of Longbanks in Harlow, Essex, a nurse for 28 years, injured the 10-month-old boy who weighed just over 2lb, after momentarily "losing control", Chelmsford crown court heard.

Judge Gareth Hawkesworth said "accumulated stress and tiredness" had caused the "out of character piece of recklessness". But he said the offence was so serious he had no option but to impose a jail sentence.

The baby, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, was born 35 weeks into his mother's pregnancy. He weighed 2lbs 8oz at birth and measured 35cms.

The child was being given "high dependency care" in an incubator at the special care unit of Princess Alexandra hospital in Harlow in July 1998 when the injury happened, the court was told.

Ball, who had worked at the unit for 15 years, was convicted of causing the child grievous bodily harm by a 10 to two majority verdict. It was alleged that Ball had squeezed the baby's face and caused bruising - an allegation she had denied.

Rosamund Horwood-Smart, prosecuting, said the excess force being used would have been obvious to Ball and the baby would have shown signs of distress for up to half an hour afterwards.

The injury was discovered after nurses noticed the child was not moving his left leg. It could have been caused by the leg being rapidly twisted.

The baby's mother told the court in a statement that she had noticed nothing wrong the evening before doctors diagnosed the fracture.

"I couldn't understand how he had broken his thigh bone," said the mother. "After the injury his leg was swollen. I would have noticed if there had been anything wrong the previous evening."

Ball, who showed little emotion as she was sentenced, told the court she had done nothing which could have caused the injury.

She said she had not touched the baby on the night he was injured and that she had fed the boy through a tube while standing outside his incubator.

She no longer works at the hospital and is expected to be struck off the nursing register.

Sentencing, Judge Hawkesworth said: "I accept that this was an out of character piece of recklessness.

"On the jury's verdict, by a reckless action, you broke the left femur of a baby in your care - a baby who was at the time helpless, vulnerable and who weighed just over 2 lbs. It is almost unbelievable."

webTitle: Panic usurps peace as rebels close in

fields.headline: Panic usurps peace as rebels close in
fields.standfirst:
Peacekeepers and refugees flee in anticipation of a repeat of last year's violence but UN says military plans are in place to protect capital

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The pretence of peace dissolved in Sierra Leone yesterday as Foday Sankoh's rebels fought their way to within 25 miles of Freetown and advanced along the main road towards the capital. The assault sent United Nations peacekeepers fleeing once again, along with thousands of refugees. But the government's newly rearmed forces claimed to be holding their own.
fields.body:
The pretence of peace dissolved in Sierra Leone yesterday as Foday Sankoh's rebels fought their way to within 25 miles of Freetown and advanced along the main road towards the capital. The assault sent United Nations peacekeepers fleeing once again, along with thousands of refugees. But the government's newly rearmed forces claimed to be holding their own.

Amid a growing sense of crisis, the UN pledged that Freetown would not be abandoned to the brutalities of the Revolutionary United Front. But it declined to discuss details of its strategy.

"We have laid our plans and the necessary steps are being taken militarily to protect the capital. Plans have been made to ensure that Freetown remains exactly what it is called - a free town," said UN spokesman, David Wimhurst.

The UN's promise to resist the RUF raises fresh concerns over the fate of 498 peacekeepers held by the rebels. UN officials believe the men have been dispersed beyond the areas where they were captured, making a rescue attempt all but impossible.

Reconnaissance flights

British officials in Freetown again called on the several hundred British, Commonwealth, EU and other citizens who qualify for evacuation to leave immediately after the numbers seeking to be airlifted out dropped to a trickle.

The British army said it was moving UN equipment to help defend towns on the road into Freetown, and is flying reconnaissance flights beyond the city. It was also helping to dig in UN forces around the capital to provide, as one officer put it, some "backbone" to the peacekeepers.

But the immediate responsibility for stopping the rebels from advancing on Freetown falls to the Sierra Leone army and young Kamajor militiamen, many still in their teens and wearing charms to ward off bullets.

As hundreds of government troops and militia poured into the war zone, thousands of refugees flooded out of the town of Waterloo, 18 miles from the capital and the next target for the rebels.

They know only too well what happens when the RUF seizes control after the rebels briefly occupied Waterloo at the beginning of last year. Besides the systematic decapitations and shootings of anyone connected to the government, ordinary people lived in perpetual fear of arbitrary amputations of arms and legs by machete and gang rapes.

At the UN checkpoint at Jui, edgy Jor danian soldiers fingered their guns. A few feet away, Special Johnson, a 31 year-old market trader, said he was in Waterloo when the RUF occupied it last time.

"As soon as we heard the shooting last night, we knew it was time to leave. These rebels can just appear from nowhere. It's like magic. One minute they are not there and then they are everywhere," he said. "I was lucky to survive last time. It was a miracle because here I am, a man, and the rebels want men to fight or they kill them. I will not be so lucky again, so it was better to leave quickly."

fields.headline: Mother's pleas for trapped family
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The three children in the photographs Adama Sandy clutches beam broadly, or smile shyly - radiating reassurance and communicating anxiety to their mother many miles away.
fields.body:
The three children in the photographs Adama Sandy clutches beam broadly, or smile shyly - radiating reassurance and communicating anxiety to their mother many miles away.

For Alusein, seven, his brother, Mohamed, six, and their sister, Hafsatu, three, are stranded in Freetown, and their mother, a British national who fled before the last bout of bloodshed, is in a council flat in Mitcham, Surrey.

Their separation came about because Ms Sandy, who was born in south-east London but moved to Sierra Leone at the age of three, was allowed on the plane which evacuated Britons from the troubled west African country on Christmas Eve 1998, days before Revolutionary United Front rebels temporarily seized the capital leaving 6,000 dead.

But, despite having registered her children as British citizens a month earlier, Ms Sandy, 26, was not allowed to bring them with her because they had no British passports.

Sixteen months on, the situation has not altered; and, with the imminent threat of further massacres, the youngsters - taken by their Sierra Leonean father to the hotel-turned-evacuation-centre - are among the many who have been turned away.

It is a situation which leaves Ms Sandy, a cleaner at a London teaching hospital, feeling helpless and desperate.

"At times, I'm crying all the time. I don't want to eat, I can't sleep. And there's this terrible fear of not knowing what's happening out there.

"I just fear the nightmare is going to start once more - and I am just begging them to let my kids be evacuated. I am praying for it."

It is a battle she has been pursuing - via the refugee council, the Red Cross and the British high commission - since her arrival in Britain.

Photocopies of her passport and hers and her childrens' birth certificates have been faxed to officials in Freetown, as advised by the Foreign Office hotline, but despite the Home Office last night confirming they were British, it seems that, in Freetown, they still are not deemed to be. Any criticism of her leaving her children in such a situation dissipates when she speaks of the panic and the bureaucratic confusion, which preceded her departure.

"At six in the morning on Christmas Eve, we heard on the radio that the rebels were just 20km from the city and that all British citizens were being advised to leave the country," she says.

"I went straight to the high commission, asked them if it was true and asked for a place for me and my kids on the plane. But they told me that without British passports, there was no way they could let them through.

"Then they told me the next helicopter flight to the airport was in an hour, and, because of the roadblocks, I didn't have time to tell my children.

"But I regretted it as soon as I got on the plane. I was crying, saying: 'Let me back to my kids. My kids are left behind and I'm going back.'

Since then, poverty has prevented her saving the £1,200 to pay for their flights over, but any money not sent to feed them, is spent, almost daily, on phone calls to them.

webTitle: How gap between rich and poor has grown

fields.headline: How gap between rich and poor has grown
fields.trailText:
Inequalities: Report shows 3m children below the poverty line
The gap between the rich and the poor in Britain continued to grow right through the 1990s, according to an official report on social inequalities published today.
fields.body:
Inequalities: Report shows 3m children below the poverty line
The gap between the rich and the poor in Britain continued to grow right through the 1990s, according to an official report on social inequalities published today.

The figures do not show whether the gap has started to narrow after three years of a Labour government which has boosted the incomes of the poorest 10%. But the report highlights the scale of the social justice problem, with April 1998 figures showing that about 3m children were still living below the poverty line in families with incomes of less than 60% of the median - the middle value - income.

The report is a first for the office of national statistics and is a mark of a new official recognition of the need to tackle social exclusion. Such a publication never appeared during the 18 years of Conservative governments.

The report also shows that the pay gap between men and women remains as wide as ever. Average gross annual earnings for April 1999 show that men in full time jobs earned about £23,000 a year - 42% more than the average £16,000 a year earned by women in full time work.

Despite this growing pay gap between men and women the ONS reports confirms that girls continue to do better than boys at school with 50% of girls getting five or more good GCSE passes compared with only 40% of boys. There has also been a much more rapid expansion in the number of young women in higher and further education from 1m in 1970 to about 2.5m by 1998.

The ONS report confirms some of the seismic shifts in the profile of Britain's population of 59m people. There are 4m from minority ethnic groups, who have a younger age profile than the white population. Between 1961 and 1998 the proportion of households headed by a lone parent rose from 2% to 7% and a quarter of black families are lone parents with dependent children.

In one crucial area - infant mortality - the gap between rich and poor has narrowed slightly in the last 29 years. In 1976 the death rate for babies born to families of "unskilled" workers was more than twice that for babies born to those with "professional" jobs. By 1997 the infant mortality rate for children of unskilled workers had fallen to just under twice that of the professional group.

The ONS report also reveals that during the 1970s the income of households at the top, middle and bottom of the scale grew at roughly the same pace but during the 1980s income inequality rose. The top 10% saw their incomes grow by 38% over the decade while the bottom 10% only saw incomes rise by around 5%.

During the 1990s there was greater stability but the figures show that the rate of growth of the incomes of the top 10% con tinued to outstrip improvements at the bottom. At the start of the 1970s the incomes of the richest 10% were three times higher than the poorest 10%. By the end of the 1990s they were four times higher.

The report shows that the distribution of wealth - as opposed to income - has altered little in the past 20 years and is even more unevenly distributed. In 1996 1% of the population owned 20% of the wealth - about £388bn. Over half the total wealth was owned by 10% of the population. In the same year, the wealthiest 50% owned almost all the wealth, 93%.

In 1997-98 about 30% of households said they had no savings and over half had savings of less than £1,500. Only 14% of households had savings of more than £20,000.

Gender: Men earn 42% more than women with full time jobs
The pay gap between men and women remains as wide as ever with men in full time work earning on average £23,000 a year, some 42% higher than the average income of £16,000 a year for women in full-time jobs, according to the office of national statistics report.

This pay gap appears to be true across all jobs with women working full time earning on average 60% to 70% less than men in the same occupational group.

About 45% of working women are employed on a part time basis, with men in similar jobs getting an hourly rate about one third higher than that paid to women.

The ONS report does show, however, that over the last 20 years the proportion of men who work has fallen from 88% in 1984 to 84% by 1999, and over the same period the proportion of women of working age with jobs rose from 66% to 72%.

The increasing role of women in the workforce is put in stark relief by a comparison of occupations in 1891 with those in 1991.

At the end of the 19th century about 1.5m women - by far the largest single group - worked as domestic servants. By 1991 the figure for women working as cleaners and housekeepers had fallen to 800,000.

By the end of the 20th century women still dominated some occupations such as nursing and teaching but the variety is as great as it is for men.

The ONS survey also hits at the idea that the "job for life" is a thing of the past. It shows that over the last decade there has been little change in the overall numbers of people of working age who have been with the same employer for five years or more.

Education:Money and class still affect exam results and future
Boys are still matching girls' performance in maths and science subjects but in arts subjects, including English, French, history and geography, girls are now doing much better than boys across the board at GCSE level, according to the ONS social inequalities report.

But poverty and class differences are still an important influence on educational attainment. The report says high levels of children eligible for free school meals generally correspond with lower GCSE attainment levels.

When it comes to social class, the differences are even more striking. In 1998 only a fifth of those whose parents were in unskilled manual jobs achieved five GCSE passes at grades A to C. In contrast, more than two-thirds of children of the professional and managerial classes got five GCSEs at this standard.

Educational success is also linked to ethnic background but not necessarily in a straightforward way. The 1998 figures show that children from Indian families are outperforming white children when it comes to examination success. But black, Pakistani and Bangladeshi pupils do less well - though the latter appear to be improving the most rapidly with the proportion getting five GCSEs more than doubling from 14% in 1992 to 33% in 1998.

Also of concern is the fact that 8% of all boys and 5% of all girls received no graded GCSEs or their equivalents in their final year of compulsory education. Men without qualifications are four times more likely to be unemployed in 1999 than those who had a degree level education.

The report highlights the changing place of women in higher and further education. The number of university students trebled from 620,000 in 1971 to almost 2m in 1998, mostly as a result of the rising number of women entering higher education. Thirty years ago, 33% of university students were women; now there are more women than men.

webTitle: Tigers 2 miles from Jaffna city centre

fields.headline: Tigers 2 miles from Jaffna city centre
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger rebels say they captured a strategic bridge less than two miles from the centre of Jaffna yesterday during a massive early morning offensive which could prove to be the prelude to a final assault on the city.
fields.body:
Sri Lanka's Tamil Tiger rebels say they captured a strategic bridge less than two miles from the centre of Jaffna yesterday during a massive early morning offensive which could prove to be the prelude to a final assault on the city.

The rebels landed in darkness at 3.30am on two peninsulas to the south-east of Jaffna, bombarding Sri Lankan military positions with heavy artillery. They later claimed to have seized the key Navatkuli bridge on the outskirts of Jaffna, cutting off a section of the main supply road to thousands of government troops, who are now trapped to the east. Ferocious fighting continued all day.

The Sri Lankan military imposed an immediate curfew on Jaffna's 500,000 civilians and mortar fire could be heard across the city.

"It is tense. There is a lot of tension. It is very difficult. We can hear shelling," said one aid worker in Jaffna last night. "It is unclear exactly what is going on. We are not allowed to leave our office."

"There is a heavy attack taking place," another added.

Announcing the assault on the city, the rebels advised the residents of Jaffna to move to safer places. "Our fighting cadres are moving towards Jaffna city. We advise people in Jaffna to move to safe places so that they can avoid the fighting," the clandestine Voice of Tigers radio said.

The government last night denied Navatkuli bridge had fallen. But it admitted that its defences had been overrun at Ariyalai military base, on a peninsula to the south-west of Jaffna. The town itself remained firmly in Sri Lankan army control, officials said.

"[The Tigers] have breached the line but now we are consolidating in the area," a military spokesman, Brigadier Palitho Fernando, said. "Of course this is a fast-changing situation. The fighting is still going on."

Military sources last night said that Navatkuli bridge was now in no-man's land - between rebel positions dug in to the east of the bridge, and government forces to the west.

Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) troops were also trying to infiltrate into Jaffna, they added.

The Sri Lankan information ministry claimed that suicide attackers - many of them women and children - had taken part in the offensive. "Terrorists continued to fire a heavy volume of artillery and mortars. Troops fought back effectively, repulsing a number of human waves of the attackers," a government statement added.

The attack came 24 hours after Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, flatly rejected a temporary ceasefire offer by the Tigers to allow the 40,000 Sri Lankan troops marooned in Jaffna to evacuate. The rebels had warned that rejection would lead to "disastrous consequences".

In a statement from its London headquarters, the Tigers yesterday said that their commando units launched a massive offensive on three fronts in the early hours of yesterday morning, attacking Sri Lankan army bases at Thanankilappu, Ariyalai and Navatkuli.

The rebels described yesterday's attack as part of an ongoing operation dubbed "Unceasing Waves 3". The operation, which began in November, has seen the Tigers make their most spectacular gains since they lost Jaffna and much of northern Sri Lanka to a government advance in 1995.

On April 22 they seized Elephant Pass, a key military base and gateway to the peninsula. Ten days ago they seized a second military base at Palali, before scaling back hostilities while Indian diplomats secretly tried to broker a ceasefire.

Government forces had expected the rebels to continue their attack on Kilaly, a naval base 14 miles from Jaffna, close to the rebel front line. Instead, around 400 elite LTTE troops are believed to have set off in the dark by boat from Pooneryn, on the opposite side of the Jaffna lagoon, before landing at Ariyalai and Thanankilappu.

"It was a classic pincer movement," one analyst said. "They simply went around the left flank. The LTTE [now] have numerous options. They are highly motivated and extremely well trained," he added. "The question is whether the Sri Lankan army troops will stand and fight."

The attack came 24 hours after Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, flatly rejected a temporary ceasefire offer by the Tigers to allow the 40,000 Sri Lankan troops marooned in Jaffna to evacuate. The rebels had warned that rejection would lead to "disastrous consequences". In a statement from its London headquarters, the Tigers yesterday said that their commando units launched a massive offensive on three fronts in the early hours of yesterday morning, attacking Sri Lankan army bases at Thanankilappu, Ariyalai and Navatkuli. The rebels described yesterday's attack as part of an ongoing operation dubbed "Unceasing Waves 3". The operation, which began in November, has seen the Tigers make their most spectacular gains since they lost Jaffna and much of northern Sri Lanka to a government advance in 1995. On April 22 they seized Elephant Pass, a key military base and gateway to the peninsula. Ten days ago they seized a second military base at Palali, before scaling back hostilities while Indian diplomats secretly tried to broker a ceasefire. Government forces had expected the rebels to continue their attack on Kilaly, a naval base 14 miles from Jaffna, close to the rebel front line. Instead, around 400 elite LTTE troops are believed to have set off in the dark by boat from Pooneryn, on the opposite side of the Jaffna lagoon, before landing at Ariyalai and Thanankilappu. "It was a classic pincer movement," one analyst said. "They simply went around the left flank. The LTTE [now] have numerous options. They are highly motivated and extremely well trained," he added. "The question is whether the Sri Lankan army troops will stand and fight."

webTitle: Protest for prisoners Five Palestinians shot in clashes with Israeli troops

fields.headline: Protest for prisoners Five Palestinians shot in clashes with Israeli troops
fields.trailText: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded five Palestinians during a clash with more than 500 protesters in Bethlehem who were calling for the release of 1,650 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails.
fields.body:
Israeli soldiers shot and wounded five Palestinians during a clash with more than 500 protesters in Bethlehem who were calling for the release of 1,650 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails.

Troops fired rubber-coated metal bullets at the crowd, who threw stones and set fire to tyres. Witnesses said some protesters sustained light injuries but an army spokeswoman said she had no confirmation of casualties.

During the last 10 days, hundreds of Palestinians have demonstrated in the West Bank as part of a campaign to press the Israeli and Palestinian authorities to address the release of prisoners during peace talks. For many Palestinians, those being held are political prisoners and their continuing detention - some have spent more than 20 years in jail - is a bitter disappointment.

The latest round of protests began ten days ago with a hunger strike launched from Hadoorim prison, and has spread to other Israeli jails.

 The president of Israel, Ezer Weizman, collapsed yesterday at his official res idence during a reception for diplomats, Israel Radio reported. His condition is not yet known.

Mr Weizman, 76, is to retire from his largely ceremonial post early - possibly this year. He recently weathered a scandal over cash gifts he received from a French businessman.

webTitle: Chop and change 'Plant British' campaign to fend off foreign trees

fields.headline: Chop and change 'Plant British' campaign to fend off foreign trees
fields.trailText: The British landscape is under threat from a glut of cheap foreign trees that may end up as firewood, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The British landscape is under threat from a glut of cheap foreign trees that may end up as firewood, it was claimed yesterday.

Home grown varieties of beech, ash and oak are being supplanted by imported central European competitors while the growth of new conifer forests is being stumped by an influx of sawn timber from abroad, the Horticultural Trades Association said.

The £3bn a year industry called for government incentives to "plant British" and for new checks on the origins of saplings.

It followed car workers and farmers in appealing to patriotism to safeguard livelihoods - though with some trees the finished product could take a century to arrive. A paper sent to MPs on behalf of nurseries selling seeds and seedlings also called for more control of squirrels to protect young trees.

It estimated that half of all new planting of broad leaf trees was now made up by seeds of foreign trees, many of inferior quality from Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland, while conifer planting had fallen to a fifth of what it was 10 years ago. Trees would no longer go into furniture, or building.

Derek McDonald, a spokesman for the association, said hawthorns were being imported in large numbers for planting alongside motorways.

At present the government provides nearly £60m a year to aid planting in forests, woodland and on former agricultural land, although this is expected to rise sharply soon.

webTitle: Catholic to head Ulster civil service

fields.headline: Catholic to head Ulster civil service
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's civil service, long seen as a bastion of Protestant bias, is to be headed for the first time by a Catholic, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's civil service, long seen as a bastion of Protestant bias, is to be headed for the first time by a Catholic, it was announced yesterday.

Gerry Loughran, 58, permanent secretary at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Industry, is to succeed John Temple, 59, who retires in the summer. He has a no-nonsense approach, which some ministers have disliked in the past.

The announcement underlined the change afoot in Northern Ireland and the appointment was backed by Ulster Unionists.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, and SDLP deputy leader, Seamus Mallon, approved the decision. They will be Mr Loughran's chiefs as first and deputy first ministers if devolution returns, as the government hopes, on May 22.

Sir Reg Empey, a leading Ulster Unionist, welcomed the decision. He worked with Mr Loughran while he was trade minister in the executive.

Mr Loughran, who declined requests for interviews yesterday, will be in charge of 23,000 workers and the biggest employer in Northern Ireland. He will attempt to knit together the work of the 10 government departments.

Three years ago Mr Loughran lost out on the most powerful non-political post in Northern Ireland government after he was pulled into a row with Lady Denton, a Tory minister, over allegations of sectarianism. She denied accusations that she was trying to scupper his chances, but the job went to Mr Temple.

fields.headline: Moscow 'ensured Milosevic's defeat'
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's role in forcing Slobodan Milosevic to withdraw Yugoslav troops from Kosovo was "pivotal", General Sir Mike Jackson, who led Nato's multinational force into the province last summer, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Russia's role in forcing Slobodan Milosevic to withdraw Yugoslav troops from Kosovo was "pivotal", General Sir Mike Jackson, who led Nato's multinational force into the province last summer, said yesterday.

He went out of his way to praise the Russians, including their present role in the K-For peacekeeping force, in evidence to the Commons defence committee. He singled out Viktor Chernomyrdin, Moscow's special envoy, who told President Milosevic in early June last year that Belgrade was alone. A few days later, Mr Milosevic buckled.

Shortly after that, Gen Jackson was embroiled in a furious argument with General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, who asked him to deploy British troops to prevent Russian paratroopers from taking Pristina airport.

He received London's backing to rescind the order after reportedly telling Gen Clark that he did not want to be responsible for starting a third world war.

He refused to be drawn when asked about the episode yesterday. He was less coy about what he thought of the impact of Nato's bombing campaign. "I do not believe it is sensible to conclude that Milosevic conceded purely by military action," he told MPs.

He said that while strategic bombing of Serbia was beginning to hurt, "it is a matter of record that the actual damage [in Kosovo] was rather less than the estimated damage. Certainly when we entered Kosovo we did not have to clear away hundreds of burnt-out tank hulls."

The Pentagon disclosed this week that a US air force damage assessment team sent into the Serbian province shortly after last year's Nato bombing, found the destroyed remnants of only 14 Serb army tanks, 18 armoured personnel carriers and 20 artillery and mortar pieces.

Gen Jackson also told the Commons committee yesterday that Nato had come close to having to decide on whether to assemble a ground force for an opposed invasion of Kosovo.

A decision would have to have been taken by late June given the time needed to assemble the force before winter encroached. He said it would have needed a force of around 150,000 soldiers with 50,000 from Britain.

He said he had "every confidence" that such a force could have been raised and would have been successful in defeating the Yugoslav army in a "short but sharp" conflict.

fields.headline: Virgin sacrifice appeases sun god
fields.trailText: It sounds like a Naked Chef recipe: take several slabs of sun-dried flesh, drizzle with virgin olive oil, and marinate in a cool place before returning to the sun.
fields.body:
It sounds like a Naked Chef recipe: take several slabs of sun-dried flesh, drizzle with virgin olive oil, and marinate in a cool place before returning to the sun.

The flesh, in this case, is your own. In a discovery set to have holiday beaches smelling like a foodie's kitchen this summer, Japanese scientists have found that applying virgin olive oil to the skin after sunbathing protects against skin cancer.

A team led by Masamitsu Ichihashi of Kobe University decided to try the olive oil treatment after realising that it was rich in a set of substances called antioxidants.

Antioxidants, which include vitamins E and C, can mop up a pernicious type of molecule called a free radical, which can damage cells and genes.

Free radicals are generated naturally by the body's absorption of oxygen but they are also created by the ultraviolet radiation in sunlight, which in turn can lead to skin cancer.

The latest edition of New Scientist magazine reports that the Kobe team tanned hairless mice under a sunlamp three times a week. Shortly after the tanning sessions some of the mice were painted with regular olive oil and some with virgin oil.

After 18 weeks under the sun lamp, unoiled mice and those treated with regular oil began to develop skin tumours.

The virgin oil mice did not show any sign of cancer for a further six weeks, and when they did, the tumours were smaller and fewer. Their skin had also suffered less genetic damage.

The Japanese researchers do not propose that olive oil is useful as a sunscreen, but say that the results in mice suggest it could help protect against skin cancer from the sun if applied after tanning.

The report is a further boost to the olive oil industry, already a beneficiary of the north European fad for high quality Mediterranean ingredients and evidence that olive oil can help protect against heart disease.

Virgin olive oil, the product of the earliest pressing of the olive harvest, is significantly more expensive than the regular variety.

webTitle: Dubya edges towards the presidency. An ugly prospect

fields.headline: Dubya edges towards the presidency. An ugly prospect
fields.standfirst:
George W Bush has all the advantages but few of the qualities he needs

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: John McCain is a popular politician. Around 20% of Americans say they would still like the maverick senator to be president. His endorsement of George W Bush draws Bush closer to the threshold of the White House.
fields.body:
John McCain is a popular politician. Around 20% of Americans say they would still like the maverick senator to be president. His endorsement of George W Bush draws Bush closer to the threshold of the White House.

It was supplied through gritted teeth, to a man whose competence and priorities McCain eviscerated during the primaries. But it came this week, and with it the prospect of an ugly lurch in Anglo-Saxon politics which not enough Europeans seem to understand.

Living, pace William Hague, with contests that rotate around what is roughly decipherable as the centre, we need to be clear that if Bush defeats Al Gore, there will no longer be business as usual.

Dubya, as he is known in Texas, is a cunning politician. Even his enemies admit that. As governor, though with powers that are weaker than those of any other in the union, he has been good at acquiring friends and boxing clever.

He straddles the ground between party moderates and the religious right who, as his biographers say, "get more sermons than blood, sweat or policy out of Bush", and yet still support him.

Installed as the Republican presidential candidate, he gives the shrewd impression of backing towards the other side, paying his dues to centrists with the promise of a health programme and some serious attention to education.

The right, who detest all these things, are putting up with them because they are insatiably hungry to win the presidency.

A deep-dyed anti-abortion rightist like Phyllis Schlafly, veteran of the cause since Barry Goldwater captured the party 35 years ago, says that even a pro-choice vice-president wouldn't stop her voting for Dubya.

So far so political. But this doesn't make Bush a plastic cypher. His record and mentality need to be better known.

Ronald Reagan seems by comparison like a genial old boy of moderate disposition who didn't quite know what he was doing.

Bush would bring to the presidency a set of biases that are brilliantly chronicled, Texas-style, by Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose, in a mischievous book called Shrub, which manages to be brief and thorough, humorous and devastating, scornful and deadly serious, and deserves to be more widely available than from Random House ($19.95). Three themes emerge from Dubya's political biography.

The first concerns his personal limitations, of character and public competence. He made his money by parlaying investment from friends of his father, then vice-president and Reagan's presumptive successor, in oil businesses that they excused him for failing to make pay.

He lost $2m of other people's money but somehow left with $840m in his own pocket. An entrepreneurial coup, you might say, but scarcely the stuff of substantive achievement. As governor he maintained the pattern, showing little serious interest in policy detail, while maintaining heavy rightist attitudes.

As an alternative to Clinton, Bush seems to embody a tenth of the natural intelligence, and not obviously more of the famous "integrity" which McCain and the right pretend he will bring back to the White House.

Insider share-dealing, documented by Ivins and Dubose, made Bush millions more than Clinton could ever have got out of Whitewater. He cleared a cool $15m after investing in the Texas Rangers baseball club, built almost entirely at taxpayers' expense.

Second comes his adoration for the corporate world. His two-term governorship has been an exercise in incessant mutual support between Texas business and Texas politics.

He received hundreds of thousands of campaign dollars from oil companies that got tax breaks, and corporate interests whose main priority was so-called "tort reform", a rearrangement of the law that makes it virtually impossible for consumers or employees to sue them.

Raising money is the apogee of Bush's political skills, and opposition to financial giving-limits the fiercest of his obsessions. The case for campaign finance reform has begun to inch forward, but Bush preaches a regime that would formalise politics as an activity for rich men only.

His policy priorities are arranged accordingly. Environmental controls, especially, are anathema. In water quality and air quality, Texas has the worst record of any big state.

Laws about toxic emissions, like membership of regulatory bodies, have been dictated by industry lobbyists. The agenda that failed to pass in Washington at the height of Newt Gingrich's supremacy is law in Texas.

This is not a man driven unwillingly to keep political clients sweet, but one who would bring to the White House the most explicit anti-environment prejudices any president has ever had.

Third, his concern for society at large is tightly confined by his greater concern for those who have succeeded. It is sometimes tempting to regard British politics, Tony Blair's included, as having abandoned a preferential option for the poor, in favour of tax advantages for the aspirational. But that's nothing.

In Bush's Texas, the governor fought for property tax breaks while denying children elementary healthcare. For most of his time, the welfare allowance for a woman and two children was $188 a month , recently raised to a princely $201.

As governor, Dubya hasn't had a foreign policy. The advisers assembled round him in this field range between the hard-line sensible and the ideologically rampant, who would tear up the anti- ballistic missile treaty without a second glance, and encourage their neophyte master on a new and uncertain trajectory of American nationalism.

His internationalist father comes from another era. The shallowness of W's own approach to the world was exposed when he pulled out of a European tour that was meant to show off his credentials this spring to the peer-group of leaders he expects shortly to join.

The advisers decided they couldn't risk it. A single unexpected question from one of those beastly European journalists might expose him as a fool.

The imminence of his presidency is an alarming prospect. Seldom has a candidate's trimming to the centre seemed so unconvincing, softly though he talks and amiable though he looks and pedigreed though he is.

The trouble is that the name is what he started with, and it has never been improved by his works. The name brought the money, and the money may bring the job.

Devoid of a vote, we're accustomed to saying, especially in the post-cold war world, that American elections don't matter much. But the final legacy of Clinton's folly may be upon us.

Desperate to exorcise him, and burning for vengeance, Republicans will pay any price to elect a man without qualities, save deep pockets and an empty smile - and a set of prejudices that will seriously upset the world.

webTitle: Plea to loyalists to dump arms

fields.headline: Plea to loyalists to dump arms
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday pleaded with loyalist paramilitaries to follow the IRA example and pledge to put their weapons beyond use in secure dumps.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday pleaded with loyalist paramilitaries to follow the IRA example and pledge to put their weapons beyond use in secure dumps.

He also pleaded in the Commons for an end to punishment beatings, shootings and attacks which paramilitaries on both sides are inflicting on members of their own communities in increasing numbers.

Enormous progress had been made in Northern Ireland, and the government aimed to restore devolution in 11 days after the IRA's unprecedented move to allow third parties to inspect some arms dumps. That will depend on Ulster Unionists' reaction to the IRA statement.

The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, was planning tomorrow to call a meeting on Saturday week of his 860-strong ruling party council to decide on a return to government with Sinn Fein.

But Trimble loyalists fear the Irish government was blocking a minor concession on the RUC's name, designed to entice the sceptical council. Negotiations on flags and other emblems are continuing.

Those issues need to be resolved today to meet the planned schedule. Mr Blair and Mr Trimble are to speak later.

Mr Blair said: "Loyalist paramilitary weapons must be treated in exactly the same way as republican weapons. They do equal damage, were they to be used and not put beyond use as they should be."

Loyalists are split on the IRA statement, with the Progressive Unionist Party, allied to the paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force, giving it a warm welcome.

But the Ulster Democratic Party, linked to the Ulster Freedom Fighters and Ulster Defence Association, is angry because it was excluded from the recent talks to save the two-year-old agreement.

But neither is planning a reciprocal gesture. They are instead adopting a wait and see approach. Unionist opponents and supporters of the agreement are better organised than before, with the meeting of the 858 delegates the fourth in seven months.

Anti-agreement Ulster Unionists have a detailed database of all delegates. They are aiming for the middle ground - about 60 people who will decide the fate of the agreement.

webTitle: Abolish BBC governors, Channel 4 chief urges

fields.headline: Abolish BBC governors, Channel 4 chief urges
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The chief executive of Channel 4 last night called for the abolition of the BBC's governors and warned the Treasury that he would not stand for the privatisation of his station.
fields.body:
The chief executive of Channel 4 last night called for the abolition of the BBC's governors and warned the Treasury that he would not stand for the privatisation of his station.

Michael Jackson, a former controller of BBC1 and BBC2, questioned the impartiality of the corporation's governors. A single regulatory structure would promote expansion and competition in the industry, he said. "The BBC's board of governors is not an adequate or sustainable form of independent regulation."

The government is expected to publish a communications white paper later this year, and Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has indicated that he wants to simplify the plethora of organisations that oversee television and radio in Britain.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is also pressing for the inclusion in the white paper of a proposal to privatise Channel 4, which would raise at least £2bn for the Treasury.

Delivering the annual Fleming lecture to the Royal Television Society, Mr Jackson said he was implacably opposed to any such move. As a private company the channel would be obliged to its shareholders, he said.

The broadcaster's investment in expensive areas of programming such as news, which does not always deliver huge ratings, might not have been possible in the private sector. "At the moment, we provide our dividend to viewers. We don't need to maximise revenue from every part of the schedule."

Some commentators point out that while Mr Jackson is genuinely opposed to privatisation, he has cleverly positioned the channel as a commercial success which would ensure the survival of the broadcaster should a sell-off become a a political inevitability.

Mr Jackson made it clear last night that Channel 4's approach would continue because the nature of minority had changed since he arrived in 1997.

"The channel had a unique character - non-conformist and sceptical. But some of those things had to be applied differently, for an audience that was more relaxed about its pluralism, that wanted the diversity of Britain reflected in more complex ways."

Channel 4, he said, was now aimed at a single, broad constituency - "the open-minded, the inquisitive and the forward-thinking."

In a move to strengthen the channel's commercial strategy, Mr Jackson announced a partnership with Warner Brothers to make at least two big-budget films a year.

"We aim to be the most influential film studio in Britain," he said.

Plans are already well advanced to launch a subscription general entertainment channel, E4, to complement its movie channel, FilmFour.

Last night, the BBC rejected Mr Jackson's call to abolish the governors. A spokesman insisted they performed a valuable role because of the way the BBC was funded through the licence fee.

The debate about broadcasting regulation is likely to intensify over the summer. The Independent Television Commission, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, the BBC governors and the Radio Authority have differing responsibilities, many of which overlap.

It is thought that Mr Smith favours a smaller number of light touch bodies: perhaps one to uphold standards of taste and decency in programmes and another to regulate technology and ensure fair competition.

Mr Jackson believes that these new bodies should cover the BBC as well.

The regulators are already jostling for position. The ITC, severely criticised in many quarters for allowing ITV to abolish News at Ten, has recently been attempting to flex its muscles, using unusually strong language to exhort ITV to maximise the viewing figures for its news bulletins.

webTitle: MP uses Commons privilege to attack surgeon

fields.headline: MP uses Commons privilege to attack surgeon
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: A cosmetic surgeon whose speedy operations allegedly left patients scarred and in pain was denounced in the Commons yesterday.
fields.body:
A cosmetic surgeon whose speedy operations allegedly left patients scarred and in pain was denounced in the Commons yesterday.

Ann Clwyd, Labour MP for Cynon Valley, said nose, stomach and breast operations by David Herbert, of Southwell, Nottinghamshire, had generated a huge number of complaints.

"The dossier of evidence I have about him is as gruesome as it is wrong," she said, using parliamentary privilege to launch a scathing attack on a surgeon whose own colleagues, she said, had described him as a psychopath.

He had been dubbed "the flying doctor" because of "the speed with which he carries out his surgery and the brief time he spends with patients.

"He carries out 35 surgical procedures a week and he carries out a face lift in just 40 minutes. Other surgeons tell me it should take between two and four hours.

"One woman allegedly nearly died after a bowel infection following a tummy tuck. One woman - and these are all allegations, obviously - was left with a gaping hole in her stomach after a tummy tuck.

"A number of women have had to have corrective surgery after he performed breast surgery, and he performed a face lift without using enough anaesthetic. The list of allegations and complaints goes on and on.

"It is just incredible that this man should be continuing to operate given the complaints against him."

Yesterday Mr Herbert, a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of England and co-founder of the British Associ ation of Cosmetic Surgeons, was operating at the Cromwell Clinic in Huntingdon.

In a statement released through the Medical Protection Society he said the complaints had come as a great shock and that he would consult his lawyers.

"I have been a cosmetic surgeon since 1978 and have always done everything I could to achieve the best possible result for every one of the many patients I have treated during that time."

The General Medical Council confirmed last night that it had received a large number of complaints about Mr Herbert and was pursuing them "as urgently as the present law allows".

The council was investigating him under "pattern of poor performance" procedure rather than isolated incidents of misconduct.

"The performance procedures allow us to assess a doctor when there is evidence of seriously deficient performance and where necessary to suspend the doctor or to impose conditions."

But the council had no power to suspend a doctor being considered for investigation under the performance procedures. "You don't need a qualification in plastic surgery to become a plastic surgeon."

The Royal College of Surgeons said it had no powers to discipline Mr Herbert because he worked entirely in private practice.

Mr Herbert, 62, is said to be a pioneer of the scar-free facelift. He trained in London and Edinburgh and has worked in plastic surgery units in Liverpool and Birmingham.

He now operates at clinics in Nottingham, Preston and London in addition to Huntingdon and deals with up to 1,300 patients a year.

In February he told the Not tingham Evening Post that he had had "fewer than eight" complaints. "In this country, about 4% or 5% of people are unhappy with their surgery based on a plastic surgeon who does no more than 150 cases a year. It's very subjective surgery and everyone has the right to complain."

Susan Wiseman, a cosmetic surgery adviser at the Cromwell Clinic, said: "Mr Herbert is disgusted at the comments made by Ann Clwyd. She referred to him as a psychopath.

She makes these comments under the protection of the House of Commons and it would be very interesting if she were to make those comments outside the Commons.

"Mr Herbert has been investigated by the GMC. A Look East televison crew came here to investigate us and we threw open the doors for them. We had nothing to hide at all."

Mr Herbert saw many patients who had been worked on by other surgeons who came to him to have problems put right .

"Mr Herbert works entirely in the private sector and has done for the past 25 years. He was one of the first surgeons to dare to leave the NHS to work privately. He offers a very high level of service and professionalism."

webTitle: Badly trained, ill-defined and underfunded - UN peacekeepers endure humiliations

fields.headline: Badly trained, ill-defined and underfunded - UN peacekeepers endure humiliations
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations intervention in Sierra Leone has been flawed since the beginning. It misjudged the peace agreement last summer, its mandate is so limited it is self-defeating, and the performance of its troops has been shambolic and at times humiliating.
fields.body:
The United Nations intervention in Sierra Leone has been flawed since the beginning. It misjudged the peace agreement last summer, its mandate is so limited it is self-defeating, and the performance of its troops has been shambolic and at times humiliating.

Many, including Human Rights Watch, believe the UN's first mistake was in accepting the peace agreement brokered in Lome last summer between the Sierra Leone government and the rebels that left the rebel leader Foday Sankoh in charge of the diamond-producing areas. The agreement inexplicably failed to contain penalties for non-compliance.

The UN mandate, agreed in February this year, also cre ated surprise. Both the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence regard it as too limited: the role of the peacekeepers is simply "to monitor adherence to the ceasefire", not to engage the rebel forces, no matter what they do.

This motley, multi-national army has been arriving in dribs and drabs, underfunded and without the necessary equipment.

Fred Eckhard, spokesman for the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, admitted yesterday that Sierra Leone was not proving to be the UN's finest hour. Mr Eckhard put the blame for one of the most serious panics, the UN report at the weekend that the rebel Revolutionary United Front was on the doorstep of the capital, on the Jordanian and Guinean forces' inadequate radio equipment. It was these overblown reports that led to the British decision to send in paratroopers to help evacuate its citizens.

Lack of proper communications between headquarters in Freetown and forces in outlying areas also contributed to the biggest humiliation yet, the loss of 500 UN peacekeepers, most of them Zambians. A Sierra Leonean said yesterday: "It's crazy. I could have understood 10 or 12 of them being disarmed by a band of rebels. But 500 of them?" The 500, and 13 armoured personnel carriers, are still being held by the rebels.

Thirty-two countries are involved in the force, though neighbouring African countries provide its bulk. So far 8,699 have been deployed and further battalions from Jordan, India and Bangladesh are on their way to bring the force up to 11,000.

The pace of deployment had to be speeded up because of the unexpected push by the rebels and the surprise departure last week of the Nigerian contingent.

Francis Fortune, a Canadian working for a conflict resolution group in Bo in the south of the country, complained yesterday there were 27 different nationalities in the UN peace monitoring team based in the town, none of whom spoke the local language. "They are working in isolation and become the em perors of everything. They have a huge bureaucratic organisation that can't even organise themselves."

David Malone, Canada's former deputy ambassador to the UN, joined in the criticism yesterday: "In Sierra Leone, the mission is largely made up of Africans, and while it's no reflection on the troops themselves, a number of these units will not have trained specifically for peacekeeping duties and many of them are poorly equipped."

The US, after the loss of 18 soldiers in Somalia in 1993, is reluctant to get involved in Africa, arguing that such conflicts should be resolved on a regional basis.

The heart of the UN's problems are both structure - the division of power between the secretary general and the security council - and lack of funding, the latter reinforced by the US failure to pay its share of bills. Mr Eckhard said the lack of funds prevented the UN from doing the "the kind of professional job we would like to". He added: "We're doing peacekeeping these days on a shoestring."
