webTitle: Russia attacks Nato for neglecting Serbs

fields.headline: Russia attacks Nato for neglecting Serbs
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Russia attacked Nato for its Kosovo policy yesterday at the first meeting between senior military officers since relations were ruptured over last year's war in the Serbian province.
fields.body:
Russia attacked Nato for its Kosovo policy yesterday at the first meeting between senior military officers since relations were ruptured over last year's war in the Serbian province.

General Anatoly Kvashnin, the chief of the Russian general staff, complained before starting talks at alliance headquarters in Brussels that Nato was not doing enough to protect Serbs from attacks by ethnic Albanians.

"No positive signs can be seen in the situation," he said. "Nato is trying to present a better picture than actually exists."

Gen Kvashnin's remarks cast a cloud over what Nato had hoped would be the resumption of friendly relations with Moscow, and came amid Serb protests.

In Kosovo, Serbs demonstrated in the ethnically mixed northern town of Mitrovice, demanding speedy trials for jailed friends and relatives.

"We are aware of the problems regarding Kosovo's judicial system," the local Nato commander, French Brigadier General Pierre de Saqui de Sannes, told the protesters, alluding to a backlog of cases awaiting trial because of lack of personnel and inadequate legislation.

In Belgrade, the families of several hundred missing Kosovo Serbs held a march demanding that their loved ones be released or at least accounted for.

Several Serbs were yesterday reported wounded in a grenade and machinegun attack in Cernica, an ethnically-mixed town 20 miles south-east of Pristina.

Alliance leaders acknowledge that violence remains a serious problem in Kosovo, but insist there has been some progress in achieving peace.

Russia opposed the bombing of Yugoslavia and its relations with Nato were effectively frozen until February.

Russian troops serve alongside the Nato-led K-For peacekeeping troops, but Moscow remains on good terms with the regime of President Slobodan Milosevic.

Meanwhile, the European commission yesterday announced a revamp of its aid efforts to Kosovo by cutting red tape and speeding up delivery.

Chris Patten, the external relations commissioner, warned that if the EU wanted to be taken seriously in foreign policy it must back up words with deeds. "We cannot go around making huge spending promises to people unless we put it in the budget," he said. "I'm embarrassed by the size of the gap between committed and spent aid."

The EU is footing half the bill for reconstructing Kosovo, because the US paid most of the cost of the war. Brussels will spend £464m in the Balkans in 2001, £203m of that in Kosovo and £23m in Serbia.

Earlier this week the EU announced it was giving an immediate £11.7m to Montenegro to bolster the stability of its pro-western regime.

webTitle: Major told to reveal foreign earnings

fields.headline: Major told to reveal foreign earnings
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: John Major was yesterday ordered to disclose details of his lucrative speaking engagement contract to promote his memoirs following an investigation by the Commons standards and privileges committee.
fields.body:
John Major was yesterday ordered to disclose details of his lucrative speaking engagement contract to promote his memoirs following an investigation by the Commons standards and privileges committee.

The former prime minister, who is believed to have made large sums from promoting his book worldwide, was however cleared of breaking parliamentary rules because he had taken advice on his entry in the register of members' interests.

Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards ordered Mr Major to deposit details of his employment agreement with the booking company which arranges his engagements.

Her move followed a complaint by Labour MP Desmond Turner over Mr Major's entry in the register of members' interests in which he listed seven overseas speaking tours, including trips to the US, Bermuda and Saudi Arabia, but did not declare his earnings.

As prime minister, Mr Major appointed Lord Nolan's commission which led to the current disciplinary arrangements. Mrs Filkin's ruling means MPs will be advised to declare earnings above £500 for any series of speeches arranged by agents.

webTitle: Doing the dirty work for us

fields.headline: Doing the dirty work for us
fields.standfirst:
Someone other than the UK has to impose genuine peace in Sierra Leone. And it won't be pretty
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: The British should not be surprised when the people of Sierra Leone express hope that the paras will do more than merely to evacuate anyone who is either white or in possession of a full set of the right papers. Britain invented the country, after all, as a haven for freed slaves.
fields.body:
The British should not be surprised when the people of Sierra Leone express hope that the paras will do more than merely to evacuate anyone who is either white or in possession of a full set of the right papers. Britain invented the country, after all, as a haven for freed slaves.

That may not in itself be a reason for Britain to feel responsible for what happens, but it is one reason for Sierra Leoneans to hope that she will. Yet this British government has been bruised by Sierra Leone before.

Had it cared to take the lesson, the promise to restore Ahmad Tejan Kabbah to power in 1997, and the arms-to-Africa scandal that followed, was an early example of the old truth that wishing a result is not the same as obtaining it.

When Robin Cook began to appear decisive and commanding this week, there was an unmistakable whiff of old ghost to be laid.

The peace agreement imposed with British and US backing in July last year is another, more serious case of wishful thinking.

Foday Sankoh - or Vice-President Foday Sankoh as he became after the Lome peace accord - has been committing atrocities in Sierra Leone for more than 10 years and was a prime candidate for a war crimes tribunal. But it was easier, then, to give Sankoh an amnesty and make him minister of mines.

It is easy to blame the United Nations and certainly the UN has an almost unique capacity to generate overpaying jobs that permit under-performing bureaucrats to enjoy first world comfort in third world countries.

But the UN is little more than the sum of its parts and the resolve of the UN can be nothing more than the collective will of its key members. Just as the UN failure in Rwanda was our failure, so the Unamsil (UN mission) failure in Sierra Leone is our failure too.

But what is it that has failed? Is it the idea of peacekeeping, or our commitment to it? The rhetoric says we will intervene wherever there is a humanitarian need. Reality suggests that we will do so in selected, relatively small countries in which we can argue both a strategic or humanitarian imperative and the possibility of a result. The evidence is building, though, that even that limited commitment is beyond us.

Two previous African interventions are relevant here: Somalia, where 18 American and 24 Pakistani soldiers died; and Rwanda, where, after the grisly murder of 14 Belgian peacekeepers, the UN abandoned the Tutsi population to its fate.

The decisions now taken on intervention in Africa are weighed against this history and seem to be informed by two principles: that it is unacceptable to stand by while civilians are butchered, and that white lives must not be lost in any attempt to prevent it.

In Sierra Leone, Britain and the US backed last July's peace agreement and voted for the UN peacekeeping force, but refused to participate in it. The result - an ill trained, under strength and ill equipped force with a mission to enforce a non existent peace - suggests another question.

Is the effort to save democratic government and bring peace to Sierra Leone important or is it not? If it is, then should it not be done properly? If it is not, then should it be done at all?

There is an argument that says that conflict only ends - and peace only comes - when one side or the other wins the war. Yet to send heavyweight fighting forces is a political impossibility, since so many voters are, on the whole, unwilling to see their young men die keeping the peace in a country they cannot find on the map.

So what are the alternatives? One is to let the war happen, however painful, then to go in when it is over and salve the international conscience by rebuilding the hospitals and schools and bandaging the wounds of the survivors.

The other is to intervene on the side that we think is in the right, to try to hasten the victory. These are not pretty choices, but the experience of recent years suggests that they are realistic.

We could evacuate the UN peacekeepers and leave Sierra Leone to fight it out, hoping that the government side will win and the hostages will be rescued, but keeping a shady deal handy in case the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) wins.

There would be costs: abject humiliation for the United Nations (something that unfortunate body is more than used to); and of course, the risk that a mass murderer might end up as dictator of Sierra Leone. But if we were prepared to give Sankoh an amnesty and the diamond mines instead of the death sentence he would otherwise have faced last year, allowing him the whole country does not seem such a big step.

There would be a cost in the lives of the people, including those who have fled to Freetown to escape the advancing RUF (the last time the RUF had the upper hand, 6,000 people were butchered).

And finally, if the UN forces have to flee, the next casualty would be the UN hopes of intervention in the far more complicated and intractable war in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

If the experience of Sierra Leone is anything to go by, a pause for reflection there might not be a bad thing.

A second option is to use the fact that the British have secured the airport to reinforce Unamsil while negotiating the return of the Nigerian troops who were the only force who managed to keep the RUF at bay and the semblance of a peace intact.

Robin Cook's formulation of the British forces role - that they will not be fighting as part of the UN forces in Sierra Leone - is characteristically ambiguous. But whatever fighting the paras find themselves in, neither Robin Cook nor Tony Blair is likely to wish them to remain in Sierra Leone for long enough to get a result.

Propping up the UN forces is fine in the short term, but I think we know by now that, even at the best of times, UN forces cannot bear much weight. Even at full strength, this would still be a force made up of badly trained men who speak different languages.

Besides, unless its mission statement is drastically rewritten, it will be back in the same situation in short order.

If we want to keep a non-existent peace, then we must have no illusions that someone has to be prepared to do the dirty work involved in bringing it about.

The Nigerian vice-president, Alhaji Atiku Abubakar, says that Nigerian troops are ready to return to Sierra Leone as "peacekeepers" provided that the UN pays the bill. He also said that that Nigeria wants unrestricted operational orders for its forces.

The Nigerians are reportedly preparing to deploy new forces in the next few days, backed by a battalion from Ghana and Guinea. It is clear that the Nigerians are prepared to return only if they can fight this war their way.

That may not be a pretty sight, but there are no good options in Sierra Leone. It may prove to be the least worst of them.

webTitle: Dozens convicted in child sex video trial

fields.headline: Dozens convicted in child sex video trial
fields.trailText: France's biggest and most controversial paedophile trial ended yesterday when a court in Macon sentenced a supplier of child sex videos to three years in prison and handed down suspended jail terms to more than 50 others.
fields.body:
France's biggest and most controversial paedophile trial ended yesterday when a court in Macon sentenced a supplier of child sex videos to three years in prison and handed down suspended jail terms to more than 50 others.

Bernard Alapetite, the chief executive of Platypus, a Paris publishing company, was found guilty of copying foreign child porn videos - some featuring rapes of boys under 15 and young children having sex with animals - and selling them for between £80 and £100 each.

Fifty-one other men who were found with child sex videos in their homes received suspended sentences ranging from two to six months.

The case followed an unprecedented police crackdown in 1997 which prompted widespread alarm at the extent of paedophilia in France. More than 2,500 police searched 800 homes, questioned 700 men and detained 300 suspects, finally bringing charges against 61.

Elsewhere in France, more than 100 unrelated paedophile cases were opened following the two-day operation, codenamed Ado 71. Several hundred more men were arrested for "receiving objects obtained by means of the corruption of minors". Six were also charged with child rape.

But the operation also led to public concern at a "name them and shame them" policy that saw five suspects commit suicide immediately after being released from custody.

The Human Rights League said the mass arrests were "scandalous round-ups, an anti-paedophile witch-hunt", while the justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, asked whether such a "spectacular series of coups" was necessary or appropriate.

Those on trial included priests, doctors, lawyers, a managing director, a tax inspector, a banker, a pharmacist, a bus driver, a scriptwriter and an advertising executive.

Aged between 30 and 92, all had bought child porn videos from a mail order company in Macon in the central region of Burgundy.

The youth and sports minister, Marie-George Buffet, was subsequently forced to promise tougher controls in schools, youth clubs and summer camps after several teachers were among those in the dock.

But while Mr Alapetite had numerous previous convictions for similar offences, his clients either strongly protested their innocence or broke down during the court case last March as they tried to express their remorse.

The case raised questions about definitions of paedophilia in French law: half the suspects were in court for being in possession of one video. One was a retired schools inspector who had bought his sole cassette 25 years ago "because morals were degenerating and I wanted to find out how and why".

Several others produced medical evidence showing that they had long recognised their "deviant tastes" and "attraction for young boys", but had never molested anyone and had been undergoing psychiatric treatment.

"I have never molested a child in my life," sobbed one retired office worker during the trial. "I am on medication. I bought two cassettes from a catalogue. And now my children and my grandchildren will not speak to me."

Almost half the suspects claimed they were not guilty of any crime. Some pointed out that their tapes had been seized during a previous operation by the Paris vice squad, and subsequently returned to them as perfectly legal.

Others said the tapes had been advertised and sold to them through legitimate channels. Two expert witnesses brought by the public prosecutor, Jean-Louis Casta, sowed further confusion by disagreeing in court on the likely ages of the boys involved.

But despite public doubts, Marie-Thérèse Hermange, a member of the European parliament and French expert on child abuse, said it was essential that the trial took place.

"We have to stop hiding our heads in the sand," she said. "This is a global problem which we in France have only recently begun to wake up to.

"What is needed now is a proper, permanent surveillance system, particularly on the internet - and decent medical and psychological treatment for offenders."

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: The Prince of Wales
fields.body:
Bad day

The Prince of Wales. A number of Labour and Plaid Cymru members of the Welsh assembly have turned down an invitation to dine with him tonight. David Davies, Tory chief whip at the assembly, said: "It is a gross insult and an utter disgrace." A Labour spokesman said the dinner clashes with a speech in Cardiff by former Labour leader Neil Kinnock.

Good day

Mo Mowlam, who appears to be taking the weight of office off her feet. The Cabinet Office enforcer has reportedly been seen in St James's Park, having her pedal extremities massaged by Lord Falconer.

Today

Commons: Trade questions. Debate on common agricultural policy. Lords: Political parties, elections and referendums bill, committee.

fields.headline: Goodbye, cruel world
fields.trailText: It begins like chaos theory. A butterfly beats its wings in Norfolk as polar bear cubs die of the heat in Alaska. Conurbations of coral are bleached white in the Maldives while a tiny toad, as golden as sunflowers, disappears forever into the clouds of Costa Rica. In a natural world as densely diverse as ours, it could just be the ecological equivalent of fractals - evolution erasing species and making way for more. Only it isn't.
fields.body:
It begins like chaos theory. A butterfly beats its wings in Norfolk as polar bear cubs die of the heat in Alaska. Conurbations of coral are bleached white in the Maldives while a tiny toad, as golden as sunflowers, disappears forever into the clouds of Costa Rica. In a natural world as densely diverse as ours, it could just be the ecological equivalent of fractals - evolution erasing species and making way for more. Only it isn't.

"We changed the world too fast and left it behind", was just one of the perversely poetic moments in Warnings From The Wild (BBC2), a frighteningly comprehensive and comprehensively frightening Nature Special. Showing there is nothing chaotic about the appearance of 22 species of butterflies from southern Europe in Norfolk and the disappearance of some 50 species of frog and toad in the Monteverde Cloud Forests, it joined the dots and presented a picture of a world being slowly strangled by global warming.

While we were bombarded with statistics - the 1990s were the warmest decade since records began, 1998 the warmest year ever; ice cover in the Arctic has been reduced by three to five per cent per decade; since 1860, there has been a 33 per cent rise in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere - which were all very sobering, it was the images of Warnings From The Wild which hammered home the gravity of global warming. Fish danced over albino coral cities paled by El Niño, swallows swimming in the English spring air made it summer, and polar bears waited patiently for death.

And while the extinction of some frogs in a faraway place may be considered by some as a tiny footnote in the book of the world, the extreme weather, the social and agricultural dislocation, and the spread of disease which will also result from global warming made the fate of the golden toad a warning for us all. A lucid, unsensational piece of television, its message was clear. Unless we act, the world will end with neither a whimper nor a bang but with the steady drip-drip-drip of melting ice. Comfortable viewing, this wasn't.

The Body Hunter (BBC1) was equally challenging. Following Chief Inspector Martin Hemingway from south Yorkshire to southern Kosovo, it charted a month in the search for the disappeared ethnic Albanians of the war-torn region.

Hemingway and his team spent their time both digging in suspected mass graves for bodies and searching their humanity for the fortitude to continue, for the sake of justice and for the sake of those grieving in Kosovo. "It is desperately disrespectful, but we are trying our best", Hemingway explained over and over. By finding bodies, Hemingway's team were trying to give the people whose relatives were missing some peace of mind. The team themselves however had no peace ("We have to separate. Put it in a little box..." an army major said with haunted eyes), but continued their grim task with a sense of duty alien to most of us.

Yet hammering home the horror of Kosovo with the fiercest impact was the recurring idea that so much evil occurred amid such ordinariness. In a shopping centre, a whole family were executed. A wedding video recorded the last gloriously happy day of a gathered clan. Tonka-yellow diggers uncovered bags and bags of rotting human meat. Grandchildren had to identify their grandmother's body by the cardigan she was wearing when she was herded off. Not until then did I realise the full horror of what went on in Kosovo; the anaesthetic provided by the same news reports over and over again suddenly worn off.

In King Of The Hill (C4), Peggy was head-to-nearly-toes in plaster after a parachuting accident, dim Didi had given birth and kept forgetting where she left the baby, and Bobby was left to care for it. In the end, an incapacitated Peggy calmed the crying baby, soothed a guilt-ridden Hank and gave viewers a cosy thought. Who would have thought such a misanthropic cartoon would provide such comfort?

And speaking of two-dimensional characters, Gail had a dinner party in Coronation Street (ITV) in an attempt to matchmake Gary "The Mullet" Mallet and Rebecca, unaware that Rebecca was at it with Mr Gail, Spindly Martin. With all that love triangle tension in the air, the atmosphere was a tad frosty. Though that might just be because Gail forgot to defrost the garlic bread. A meltdown surely approacheth.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Navy arrests protestors
The leader of Puerto Rico's Independence Party was detained inside the US navy's Vieques island range yesterday as his civil disobedience campaign continued to stop the navy using the island for bombing practice.
fields.body:
Navy arrests protestors
The leader of Puerto Rico's Independence Party was detained inside the US navy's Vieques island range yesterday as his civil disobedience campaign continued to stop the navy using the island for bombing practice.

Ruben Berrios and another activist were arrested after they entered the range before dawn. Mr Berrios had camped on the range for nearly a year before he and 223 others were removed in a US operation that began last Thursday. [AP, Vieques, Puerto Rico]

Nine killed in Algeria attacks
Nine people died in three attacks this week in Algeria, national media reported yesterday.

An armed group shot dead four child shepherds near Medea, 43 miles south of Algiers, on Tuesday. On Monday attackers killed three family members in Souk El Had, 186 miles west of the capital. An attacker was killed as he fled. A bomb in nearby Mascara killed one solider and wounded six. [AP, Algiers]

US defends its war on torture
The US denied yesterday that it was halfhearted in its determination to wipe out torture as it responded to allegations of brutality in prisons and among police forces from human rights groups.

"We believe the US record ranks near the very top," the assistant secretary of state, Harold Koh, said after appearing before the UN committee against torture. He rejected claims that the US set its own standards for deciding whether it had committed torture. [AP, Geneva]

Iranian Jew denies spying
A suspect in Iran's Jewish spy trial pleadednot guilty yesterday, becoming the first defendant of seven heard so far to deny being a member of an Israeli spy ring. Farzad Kashi told the Revolutionary Court in Shiraz he had not passed material to Israeli intelligence, his lawyer said. [Reuters, Shiraz]

webTitle: Saudis claim victory in war for control of web

fields.headline: Saudis claim victory in war for control of web
fields.standfirst:
As governments try to control the internet, a new invention may beat the censors for good

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There are now many internet cafes - constructed to keep male and female surfers apart - and around 30 commercial internet service providers, but the apparent range of choice belies the fact that all traffic passes through the King Abdulaziz City of Science and Technology in Riyadh, which is the country's only link to the web.
fields.body:
There are now many internet cafes - constructed to keep male and female surfers apart - and around 30 commercial internet service providers, but the apparent range of choice belies the fact that all traffic passes through the King Abdulaziz City of Science and Technology in Riyadh, which is the country's only link to the web.

For a wealthy country, Saudi Arabia may appear slow in adopting the internet but, in the words of Saleh Abdulrahman al-Adhel, the president of the KACST, the kingdom was waiting until the technology was available to ban access to "material that corrupts or that harms our Muslim values, tra dition, and culture".

The Saudis are not alone in their fears. Other governments have tried to block internet access using cruder methods. The Chinese, for example, have tried to restrict access to modems.

The director of the Saudi government's internet monitoring system, Dr Fahad al-Hoymany, says he believes his team are blocking all major pornographic sites.

Saad Fagih, of the exiled opposition Movement for Islamic Reform in Arabia, testifies to the system's effectiveness and says millions of other websites have been blocked, including "all the hot political sites, such as Amnesty International".

Computer industry sources say the Saudis' system works in two ways. First, it caches all approved web pages in a 500-gigabyte storage system. Users get these sites from the computer in Riyadh rather than the original source on the web.

This means that frequently-used pages can be accessed quickly without the system having to check their suitability each time.

Requests for pages that are not stored in the cache are passed to the second stage of the system, supplied by a US-based company, Websense, which lists and can filter out 30 categories of potentially unsuitable sites.

Experts concede that these filters are imperfect. One said: "You're always half a step behind because of the growth and change of the internet."

Another said: "Filter systems are very difficult to administer and are likely to over-censor - for example cutting out information about breast cancer or Aids in order to exclude sex sites."

Saudi opposition sources say that despite the filtering, government control of internet use is more fragile than it might appear. They say some cafes have illegal, direct satellite links to the internet, to which the authorities frequently turn a blind eye. Last month a women's internet cafe near to Mecca University was closed down after a complaint that it was being used for "immoral purposes".

Individuals who want unrestricted access to the internet can, if they wish, simply obtain a service provider in a neighbouring country.

While some complain that the main purpose of the filtering system is to block politically sensitive material, Dr Hoymany argues that it is designed to give assurance to Saudis that when they log on to the internet their social or religious traditions will not be offended.

This suggests to some observers that the Saudis' approach to the internet may be more subtle than it appears.

For a time, it was unclear what attitude strict Muslims - not only in Saudi Arabia but throughout the Islamic world - would adopt towards the internet.

Perhaps surprisingly, they have taken to it with great en thusiasm, deciding that it can be a useful vehicle for spreading their message.

The economic future of Saudi Arabia may depend on making full use of the internet and a filtering system which reassures conservatives may be the key to exploiting the new technology.

However, Saudi Arabia's slow start may prove costly. Unlike some of its neighbours it still has neither internet banking nor a legal framework for e-commerce.

Andrew Puddephatt, executive director of Article 19, the campaign against censorship, argues that government monopoly of communications, and internet monitoring and filtering, is ultimately incompatible with e-commerce.

"There's no possibility of developing e-commerce unless they allow liberalisation and the growth of independent service providers," he says. "It's a choice between surrendering control and being shut off from the electronic future."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Material World | Why Did We Do That?
fields.body:
Quentin Cooper immerses himself in that topsy-turvy world where the smallest is usually the greatest. His guest in Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) is Dr Russell Cowburn, a nanotechnologist from Cambridge who has been working with tiny magnets 40 millionths of a millimetre in length. Their atomic structure suggests that silicon chips of the future will be able to fit 250,000 million transistors into one square centimetre. Just what we always needed, the whole of the British Library handily stored on our mobile phone.

A rather more depressing technical advance is that chronicled by Chris Bowlby in his new four-part series dissecting public policies which changed our lives. The opening topic for Why Did We Do That? (8.0pm, Radio 4) is the runaway development of factory farming. The change did, of course, bring us cheap food. But it also brought health hazards ranging from scary antibiotics in the food chain to mad cow disease.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Man in court over stabbings
Unemployed Edward Alexander Crowley, 52, of no fixed address, appeared before Highbury magistrates in north London charged with the murder of Diego Pineiro-Villar, 12, in Covent Garden on Sunday.
fields.body:
Man in court over stabbings
Unemployed Edward Alexander Crowley, 52, of no fixed address, appeared before Highbury magistrates in north London charged with the murder of Diego Pineiro-Villar, 12, in Covent Garden on Sunday.

He is also charged with the attempted murder of a 15-year-old boy. He was remanded in custody until May 17. [Press Association]

Mother charged with murders
A Salisbury mother whose three babies were all found dead in their cots was yesterday charged with their murders and bailed to appear before local magistrates.

Shop assistant Angela Cannings, 36, was arrested after the death of her four-month-old son Matthew last year. Detectives exhumed the bodies of two others - Gemma, who died in 1989 aged three months, and Jason, who died at two months in 1991.

'Reservoir Dogs' attacker jailed
Steven Craig, 35, was jailed for life at Bristol crown court yesterday after he was found guilty of dousing his lover in petrol and setting her alight as he acted out a torture scene in the film Reservoir Dogs. Jackie Kirk, 42, of Twerton, Bath, can now only speak through a tracheostomy tube.

Craig also raped and tortured a woman of 37 in her home at Easton in Bristol.

He was found guilty of two charges of causing grievous bodily harm with intent and one of rape.

Wire mesh kills driver
A 55-year-old car driver died after a wire mesh roll fell from a lorry, crashing through his windscreen on the A68 near Corbridge, Northumbria, police said yesterday. [Press Association]

Fewer pupils barred
The government yesterday welcomed a 15% fall in the number of pupils permanently excluded from school, from 12,300 in 1997-8 to 10,400 in 1998-9. [Will Woodward]

webTitle: Work in progress: Ben Moor, actor/comedian

fields.headline: Work in progress: Ben Moor, actor/comedian
fields.trailText: The work that's most in progress is just about the most exciting thing I've done for ages. I've just been acting in a proper play at the Bristol Old Vic. Called A Busy Day, it was written in 1800 by Fanny Burney (the mother of English fiction, according to Virginia Woolf) but was never performed at the time. Kind of a Regency farce (imagine Are You Being Proud And Prejudiced?) with lots of mistaken identities, silly assumptions and ridiculous comeuppances.
fields.body:
The work that's most in progress is just about the most exciting thing I've done for ages. I've just been acting in a proper play at the Bristol Old Vic. Called A Busy Day, it was written in 1800 by Fanny Burney (the mother of English fiction, according to Virginia Woolf) but was never performed at the time. Kind of a Regency farce (imagine Are You Being Proud And Prejudiced?) with lots of mistaken identities, silly assumptions and ridiculous comeuppances.

I've just written a two-hander romantic comedy for me and a fabulous Irish actress called Janice Phayre. It's called Three Wishes and it's about a couple getting engaged. Then the Earth enters a mysterious cloud in space and everyone in the world gets three wishes. But when you know you'll get what you wish for, are you sure about what you really want? It also features an analysis of William Golding's Flies Of The Lord, his forgotten classic about a planeload of savage boys who crash on an English public school and swiftly resort to fagging and giving each other daft nicknames. Look out for a production in the autumn.

My most confusing project is still Elastic Planet - the sitcom David Lynch would have written for the cast of the Animaniacs. It involves a scientist building a supercollider for the family while his wife walks around the world on a tightrope; meanwhile his friend is receiving nuisance phone calls counting down from 12 - what happens when they reach zero? It's been rejected by virtually every TV commissioning editor for being too full of ideas, too different and, in one case, too like a film. I guess it needs to be less interesting, less original and more like everything else on TV to get made. As someone once said, originality is its own punishment.

I struggle on.

 A Busy Day is at the Lyric Theatre, Shaftesbury Avenue, London (020-7494 5045) from June 19

fields.headline: Preserving the mould
fields.standfirst: A maverick starts to look like a mouse
fields.trailText: The decision of John McCain to endorse George W Bush as the Republicans' presidential candidate will disappoint the many voters who supported his primary campaign earlier this year in the hope that he could break the mould of American politics.
fields.body:
The decision of John McCain to endorse George W Bush as the Republicans' presidential candidate will disappoint the many voters who supported his primary campaign earlier this year in the hope that he could break the mould of American politics. Mr McCain failed to persuade the Texas governor to adopt his key policy proposals for long overdue campaign finance reforms and increased social security funding (in place of the inflationary $460bn tax cuts with which Mr Bush hopes to bribe the electorate in November). To those who followed Mr McCain's Washington career as a long-serving senator from Arizona before this year's race, his attempt to portray himself as a political outsider tilting at the establishment was always less than totally convincing. Now he is left looking more like a mouse than a maverick.

The calculation behind Mr McCain's capitulation is indeed highly conventional. Having divided the Republican camp, particularly with his contentious, deserved, and vastly enjoyable assaults on the Christian right and corporate fat cats, he needed to stitch up the wounds if he was to continue to prosper within the GOP. In his only significant concession, Mr Bush agreed that his former rival should speak at this July's nominating convention in Philadelphia. Mr McCain, who long ago ruled out running for vice-president on the Bush ticket, is expected to use this platform to set down a marker for another presidential bid in 2004 - if Mr Bush loses this autumn (and, just possibly, even if he wins).

The McCain endorsement is a potential blow for the Democrat Al Gore, who is trailing in the polls, since the moderate party voters and independents who supported Mr McCain could yet decide a tight election. Mr Gore's bandwagon seems to have damp spark plugs. He was slow to get going, picked up speed in his race with Bill Bradley, but has coughed and spluttered ever since. He badly needs a jump-start ahead of the home stretch.

fields.headline: The man they couldn't hang
fields.standfirst: Kasimir Malevich was one of Russia's leading artists. But when Stalin's henchmen took against him and his family, his paintings were scattered around the world. As his work finally goes to auction,  Tony Wood investigates
fields.trailText: Kasimir Malevich was one of Russia's leading artists. But when Stalin's henchmen took against him and his family, his paintings were scattered around the world. As his work finally goes to auction, Tony Wood investigates
fields.body:
At 5pm today at the American Craft Museum in New York, bidding will begin for Suprematist Composition by Kasimir Malevich. This is the first painting by Malevich to be auctioned on the open market since the artist's death in 1935, a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to acquire an important work by one of the founding fathers of abstract art. Rumours vary as to what it will fetch, but "it's got to be worth $15m", says Howard Rutkowski of the auctioneers, Phillips.

The sale comes after six years of negotiations between the Museum of Modern Art in New York and Malevich's heirs, who last June received the painting plus $5m in an out-of-court settlement as compensation for the museum's "appropriation" of 21 works, including Suprematist Composition. Alfred Barr, a former director of MoMA, bought four works and borrowed another 17 in 1935, and when the man who lent Barr the works died in 1957, the labels saying "on loan" changed. However, it is only since the fall of the Soviet Union that the Malevich family has been able to file a claim, and it still has several lawsuits pending, notably against the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam. In 1958 the Stedelijk, which has the best Malevich collection outside Russia, paid $29,000 for 36 works, but there are doubts as to whether those who sold it the works were authorised to do so. If the Malevich family's claim is successful, the sums involved could dwarf those in the case against MoMA.

Kasimir Malevich was born in Kiev in 1878, and studied art there and later in Moscow; his main contribution to 20th-century art came in December 1915, when he exhibited a roomful of Suprematist works in St Petersburg, then called Petrograd. The paintings feature geometric planes of colour suspended in infinite white space, conveying dynamic spatial relations by minimal but forceful means. The painting being auctioned today was executed in 1919 and 1920, by which time Malevich was a leading figure in the new Soviet artistic establishment, and Suprematism, with its austere but iconoclastic energy, had all but become the official revolutionary school of painting.

In the spring of 1927 Malevich travelled to Berlin to take part in the Grossekünstausstellung, where he was due to exhibit around 70 paintings, drawings and architectural models. At this time it was becoming increasingly difficult for Russian avant-garde artists to work freely, and Malevich used the trip to investigate the possibility of emigrating. In April he went to the Bauhaus in Dessau to try to get a teaching post, but his German wasn't up to scratch and Walter Gropius, the director of the school, eventually had to refuse. Disappointed, Malevich left Germany on June 6, almost four months before the Berlin exhibition was due to finish, and left his works in the care of his friend Hugo Häring.

Malevich clearly hoped to return one day, and left no precise instructions as to what was to happen to the works if he didn't come back. But Stalin's lieutenants were entrenching themselves in all spheres, and Malevich was arrested and interrogated for several days in 1930, his correspondence with Häring abruptly cut off.

In Germany, meanwhile, the Nazis were targeting "degenerate art". Häring, fearing for the works' safety, left them in the care of Alexander Dörner, the director of the Hanover Museum. It was from Dörner that Barr borrowed several Malevich works in 1935, and it was Dörner who took one painting and a drawing with him when he emigrated to America in 1938; these two works are held in the Busch-Reisenger Museum, which still has them but in December acknowledged the Malevich family's ownership.

Malevich died of cancer in May 1935, and after his death his family were scattered across the Soviet Union. In the words of Clemens Toussaint, a German art historian who has been instrumental in the Malevich family's claim, the family "had to run for their lives", moving to provincial towns in Russia, Ukraine and Turkmenistan to avoid Stalin's purges. Malevich's works were not exhibited again in the Soviet Union until 1962. In the early 90s, Toussaint was contacted by Malevich's granddaughter, Ninel Bychkova, and he set about the task of locating Malevich's surviving descendants. In all, Toussaint found 31 descendants from Malevich's three marriages, including not only those still in the former USSR but also others in Canada, Poland and the UK. A few family members will be at the auction today.

Toussaint and the Malevich estate presented their case to Lawrence M Kaye of New York lawyers Herrick, Feinstein LLP, who specialise in the repatriation and recovery of art. Speaking on behalf of the Malevich estate, Kaye says that the family believe the success of their claim to be "a justified triumph", adding: "It is important for the international community of art collectors and museum curators to have the opportunity to compete for the first time for a Malevich." Howard Rutkowski of Phillips, however, notes that although he "would love to see it go to a museum, unfortunately there are very few with those kind of finances", and Suprematist Composition is more likely to go to a European or American collector.

Toussaint describes the MoMA case as "a long, hard adventure". Even now, nine years after the collapse of the USSR, the Malevich estate is the first from the former Soviet Union to claim works in the west, and Toussaint seems sceptical about the possibility of still more avant-garde heavyweights resurfacing. "It's now more a question of re-establishing legal relations between countries than re-establishing the avant-garde," he says, pointing out that there are more than a million and a half objects in Russia - largely those taken from Germany by the Red Army in 1945 - whose fate remains unresolved.

Marian Douma of the Stedelijk Museum calls the repatriation of art "a question for Europe", referring to so-called trophy art, Nazi thefts and even the Elgin marbles. Indeed, today's auction marks more than the restitution of a family's heritage, since Malevich's works followed a tortuous route through totalitarian terror, a world war and emigration. Not only is Suprematist Composition an icon of 20th-century art; it stands for the dislocations and dispossessions of 20th-century history.

Not only is Suprematist Composition an icon of 20th-century art; it stands for the dislocations and dispossessions of 20th-century history.

fields.headline: Time to unbend
fields.standfirst:
Doctors have been too arrogant

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: It has been a bad week for doctors. First came a report from an NHS investigation in Staffordshire, which found doctors pursuing clinical trials on babies using totally inadequate procedures for obtaining informed consent from parents.
fields.body:
It has been a bad week for doctors. First came a report from an NHS investigation in Staffordshire, which found doctors pursuing clinical trials on babies using totally inadequate procedures for obtaining informed consent from parents. In the words of Lord Hunt, health minister in the Lords and a former health manager, it documented the need for a cultural change in the NHS with a shift in the balance of power towards patients. Then came yesterday's interim report, produced by the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry, into the removal of hundreds of organs from dead children across the country without parental knowledge or consent. Professor Ian Kennedy, chairman of the inquiry, spoke yesterday of the "professional arrogance" of doctors, who had produced "a social and ethical time bomb waiting to go off. It is no surprise that the explosion of anger, when it came, was huge." Now our health correspondent reports that the British Medical Association, which in the wake of Bristol was ready to accept revalidation - testing of a doctor's continued fitness to practise - is backtracking; one reason why yesterday's report is so timely.

To be fair to modern medics, attitudes are changing. The conservative profession has been forced to change, not least because of the huge increase in information now available to patients. But it is not just the web. Sir Cyril Chantler, dean of London's largest medical school, set out other reasons why doctors had to become more open: "Medicine used to be simple, ineffective and relatively safe. It is now complex, effective and potentially dangerous. The mystical authority of the doctor used to be essential for practice. Now we need to be open and work in partnership with our colleagues in health care and with our patients."

Professor Kennedy recognised the conflict of interests between doctors wanting organs to help advance medical care and parents expecting to be properly consulted about their dead children. He rightly rejects the idea that this is irremediable. The aim should be to see consent as a process, giving parents time to reflect and recognise the needs of medical science. The report sets out an enforceable new code, calls for an end to the separate rules governing hospital and coroners' post-mortem examinations and insists on the new procedure being open and honest. A profession intent on restoring public trust will back not just these proposals but revalidation too.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
 "I am appalled to find how the dynamics of a relationship change when you move from being just a woman in the relationship to becoming the breadwinner ... The effect is alarming"

Joanna Trollope, Aura

 "It was a part of my feminist battle against pornography that I would not tackle up. A century ago, randy little boys would pore over the corsetry ads in women's magazines and as the pornography industry has grown up, it has elaborated this voyeuristic fixation. The passivity and vulnerability of the female subject is accentuated by her being captured, as it were, as she undresses... Corsets are uncomfortable; lace is supremely uncomfortable; suspender belts are ridiculous; most brassieres fake rather than control the bosom. There are men who secretly yearn to wear all this kit. We may ask even of the men who do not, is it us they love or these fetishistic garments?"

Germaine Greer on why she says down with underwear, Observer

 "Men's interest in ladies' underwear goes back a while. Adam only got it together with Eve when she started wearing the first fig-leaf thong. But men do not, repeat not, fancy the fetish clothing for itself, any more than they would be turned on by a pair of disembodied breasts that arrived in the post. It's the heavenly combination of person and package that matters"

John Walsh disputes Greer's knickerless twist, Independent

 "I could never work out why they seemed to give me four bosoms"

Jane Goldman, star of the new Fantasie bra ad campaign, on the ill-fitting variety, Sun

 "Of course, on the road I had hundreds of girls, so I wrote about that - but I don't drag you into the bedroom for every sweaty detail"

Paul Daniels gives a little too much detail on his autobiography, Hello!

fields.headline: I used to work here
fields.standfirst:
Twenty five years ago, Malcolm Dennett was the boss at
Bankside, London's city-centre power station. As it
reopens as Tate Modern, he gives Oliver Burkeman his
first impressions.
fields.trailText: Twenty five years ago, Malcolm Dennett was the boss at Bankside, London's city-centre power station. As it reopens as Tate Modern, he gives Oliver Burkeman his first impressions.
fields.body:
It is the silence that hits you first - an overpowering, high-ceilinged vault of air you feel you could never puncture, however loud you shouted - but Malcolm Dennett must feel the silence more than most. Twenty-five years ago, when he last prowled the turbine hall of Tate Modern, it was a fully-functioning 300 megawatt oil-fired power station, helping to quench London's burgeoning thirst for energy, and Dennett, now 67, was its manager.

It is the noise - its omnipresence then, and its absence now - that he notices first. Every day, he walked the length of the turbine hall to the control room to check that everything was running smoothly. "The turbines were grinding away, there were people everywhere," he remembers. "Walking the building, talking to everyone - it was the only way to get a sense of how things were going on. You had to go and look, and feel, and smell." Like all the power stations he worked in, he says, there was "an immense smell of oil and grease".

Today, the handful of frenzied security guards and black-polo-necked denizens of the art world scuttling across the hall do so silently; the predominant smell is of expensive perfume. The intervening platforms have been ripped out and the huge space is dominated by Louise Bourgeois's three bronze towers, echoing the turbines Dennett inspected daily.

He shows more gratitude for what has remained than sadness at what has gone. "Now, look at this ducting," he exclaims with relish, almost backing into Cézanne's Still Life With Water Jug (1892-3) and eliciting audible gasps from gallery attendants. "They're using it as the ventilation system, but we had to walk everywhere on it. That's why women were frightened to go round the plant, because people could see their knickers."

It took 16 years to build Bankside, from Sir Giles Gilbert Scott's initial design to its opening in 1963 - by which time London was crying out for it. The capital's power requirements were doubling almost twice a decade, and no adequate technology had yet been developed to transport electricity from out-of-town sites. "People look at this building today and they say, 'What the hell does anybody want to put a power station in the middle of London for?' But after the war, demand was tremendous, and you just had to build the supply near the demand."

Much of the Bankside manager's working life was spent waiting for the call from the National Grid to say that the station's power was required to meet a surge in demand. The Miss World contest was always a particularly stressful time - everyone would switch on their kettles simultaneously, and energy requirements would skyrocket. The night BBC2 was launched, Battersea power station, just down the road, gave up the ghost completely. It was a night recalled with shudders by station managers for years afterwards.

That was all a long time ago, Dennett says, and it's hard to remember exactly what was where - but there's still a sense of belonging, an air of proprietorialism, evident in his manner. He spots Sir Nicholas Serota gliding past. "I think you've done a marvellous job, keeping all these signs of what the building used to be," he tells the Tate director warmly, rather as if he was congratulating one of his engineers on a particularly impressive piece of handiwork. Sir Nicholas looks genuinely enchanted, but it's time to move on.

"This was the boilerhouse, generating steam to feed the turbines," Dennett explains, gesturing at Tate Modern's ultra-trendy shop, its tables piled high with glossy art books and gallery sweatshirts. And it is still the boilerhouse, in some sense, he says. "It's good that they've kept the girders, the rusty ductwork, the dirty bricks: there's a relationship to the plant as it was."

The gallons of Thames water required to cool the plant flowed in roughly at a point now occupied by a particularly confusing installation by Peter Fischli and David Weiss, designed to give the impression of being a room of the gallery still under construction, littered with the detritus of a building site. "Peter Fischli and David Weiss delight in the clutter of brightly coloured consumer products that surrounds us all," says an explanatory notice. "I have to say, I prefer classical art," says Dennett.

By the time the plant was decommissioned in 1981, Dennett had moved on, to a career that traced the development and fracturing of the British energy industry: first to work on developments in nuclear power, masterminded from offices just over the road from Bankside; then several years spent closing down other city-centre power stations as technology rendered them obsolete. It was a job requiring a lot of sensitivity, he says, and it's nice to see a decommissioned building getting a new lease of life instead. "The most exciting things you usually see in our industry are chimney stacks being exploded and falling to the ground."

Dennett retired in 1992, to an active life in Rotary Club affairs and a house in Cheam, where he lives with his wife Joan. It was sad to see Bankside go, but it was never going to last, he says: it wasn't long before one modern 660 megawatt turbine could outstrip the station's entire set, and still have spare capacity left over. "There was a lot of dedication to duty here, from the lowest labourer through the craftsmen to the engineers," he remembers. "But I've never been a person for wanting to live in the past. I don't believe in dwelling on things, on going and meeting people at pensioners' dos and saying 'Oh, wasn't it wonderful?' and all that. You've got to move on."

webTitle: Our emails met across a crowded room

fields.headline: Our emails met across a crowded room
fields.standfirst: Modern lovers do it without leaving their desks:  Libby Brooks on the art of virtual seduction
fields.trailText: Modern lovers do it without leaving their desks:  Libby Brooks on the art of virtual seduction
fields.body:
What does he look like, your lover? Are his eyes dark or steely? Is his mouth soft as kittens? When you bury your face in his neck, does his skin smell of melon? Or don't you know? In cyberspace, no one can see you squint.

How many emails will you send today? Six out of 10 new internet users in the UK are women and one in five Britons claims to prefer email to traditional methods of communication (we are over eye contact). With two-thirds of the population worrying about the size of their in-box, virtual seduction is becoming an art form.

Occasionally this has devastating results. Police yesterday launched a nationwide hunt for 16-year-old Karen Churcher, who ran away from home after running up a £873 phone bill through her obsessive use of internet chat rooms. Police believe she had a circle of at least 100 people with whom she kept in email contact.

As a nation, our enthusiasm for email is unstinting. We send and receive between one and 150 messages each day, with an average of 33 regular contacts. And, as with all innovations, it is swiftly suffused with the obsession of the age: sex. Talking about it instead of doing it (there's no time, we're too tired). What started out as "Thank you for your prompt reply" now requires reading between the lines.

Email eroticising has become the dissembler's art. Who do you want to be today? Instantaneous in name only, your respondent will never know the time it took to craft that superlative triple entendre around the word "badger". Blushes are spared, boundaries pushed and, like that other most solitary of activities, it delivers maximum satisfaction with minimum commitment.

Nannied as we are, privacy is at a premium. Notwithstanding worst case scenario where your boss retrieves that weevil gag from the server, there is something deeply intimate about chuckling softly into your terminal while all around you lose their heads, arms and sometimes legs. No one will ever know about that over-moist exchange with ... no, I couldn't possibly. Nor do private endearments bear blistering public scrutiny (remember Prince Charles' "I want to be your t*mp*n" comment?), placed out of context by people out of love.

But ought we not to be celebrating this return to the wit of wooing? Modern liaisons have lately appeared perforated with a terminal lack of endearments. Heartache is a tabloid shorthand, romance a high Hello! count. Actress Amanda Holden this week justifies apparently behaving badly with co-star Neil Morrissey with the hardly mellifluous: "He's very cute."

Even the poets disappoint these days, preferring to riff on the latest line of capri pants, safe in their Marks & Spencer-funded sinecure. Weigh modern epic poet Craig Raine's Sexual Couplets ("Here we are, without our clothes/ One excited watering can, one peculiar rose") against 17th-century John Donne's The Good Morrow ("For love, all love of other sights controules/And makes one little roome, an everywhere").

Could email be responsible for sexual renaissance and, more pressingly, what's in it for the lassies? According to conventional wisdom, while men respond to the visual, women prefer a subtler erotic stimulus - which is perfect if you want your life to be like a Galaxy advert and tedious for the rest of us. Thus, present a man with a pair of lacy knickers and he will want to rip them off with his teeth. Present them to a woman and she'll want to iron them. The female erotic bone is located in the ear, not the eye. Granted, it is a crass generalisation to suggest that all women are hardwired to head for the horizontal at a whispered rendition of Save Your Love (some of us prefer the theme song off Dirty Dancing), but a vivid verbal imagination can make up for all manner of unfortunate physical tics.

Anais Nin considered herself mute without the written word: "I talk in writing." For the shy (and the work-shy), e-flirting offers uncharted sexual territory ripe with erotic possibility. There is sensuality in our sentence structure. And as our collective libido drains off into the pool of long-hours angst, wouldn't you rather do it sitting down?

fields.headline: Nice and sleazy does it
fields.standfirst: Escort agencies may soon be allowed to advertise on TV. But what exactly are escorts? And are the agencies just a front for high-class prostitution?  Diane Taylor finds out
fields.trailText: Escort agencies may soon be allowed to advertise on TV. But what exactly are escorts? And are the agencies just a front for high-class prostitution?  Diane Taylor finds out
fields.body:
Kimberly Kay Hamilton looks impossibly beautiful in her internet ad: like many of her peers, she sports lengthy stilettos and a glossy mane of hair. Everything about Kimberly is discreet; there are no naked breasts, no itinerary of sexual services, no euphemistic reference to massage and absolutely no mention of the word prostitute. Instead she tells us she is "a well dressed and intelligent lady with natural conversational skills". For £250 an hour, she offers a tête-à-tête at her home, evenings out or cosy-sounding visits to a local pizza parlour.

Welcome to the world of the escort agency. Of course, not every agency offers sex but, after investigation, it appears that the majority employ at least some women who do. And if the government's official regulator, the Independent Television Commission (ITC), gets its way, ads for these services could for the first time make the leap from the internet, downmarket tabloids and contact magazines, into our living rooms. This is a world in which women are always ladies or girls, in which Oxbridge degrees are boasted of alongside the command of languages, a horsey hobby and, most importantly, a high-class pedigree.

Like so much else relating to the British attitude to sex, this latest proposal from the ITC is mired in hypocrisy. To sell sex is legal, to buy sex is legal, but to solicit or run an escort agency where women offer sex rather than platonic companionship is illegal. As usual, cash is the bottom line. The ITC has realised that there is a lot of money sloshing around in the higher echelons of prostitution and sees no reason not to tap into that, arguing: "It is not clear what is specific to such businesses, or what mischief there is to be prevented that would justify banning these companies from advertising on television." As long as escort agencies advertise in U certificate code and keep the sex furtive and discreet, everyone is happy.

But while detente is wafting through the higher end of the market, where ads are always a tasteful fudge, war is being waged on the women who advertise sex for sale rather more bluntly at the cheaper end of the market. Westminster Council, BT and the government tut in unison at the sleazy cards Soho sex workers place in central London telephone boxes and have pledged to purge this eyesore once and for all - a move likely to drive this group of women into further financial hardship and more dangerous working practices.

The inconsistencies of the argument are not lost on Hilary Kinnell of Europap (European Project for Aids Prevention in Prostitution). "Any change that increases sex workers' control over their situation and reduces stigma is welcome," she says. "But this proposal suggests discrimination in favour of those at the top end of the industry, while street and brothel workers suffer controls that increase their vulnerability to violence and exploitation."

According to criminal lawyer John Blandford, the anomalies surrounding the legal and illegal sale of sex are down to the mixing up of the law and morals. "We need to unmix them. As it stands, the law is a hypocritical farce."

The women who sell escort sex pride themselves on their moral and financial superiority over the street sex workers, while the men who buy into this high-class hooker fantasy place themselves above furtive old men in mucky macks. An hour with an escort costs around four times as much as straight sex with a street worker and the price fuels male fantasies about buying a "nice girl". This is designer label rather than supermarket shopping.

Former escort agency boss Lesley Fernando divides the business into clean sex and dirty sex. "At least 90% of the girls on the streets are being fed crack and heroin by pimps. It's not like that with escort girls - they might put a bit of charlie up their noses but they're not drug addicts.

"Escort agency girls know how to conduct themselves and you are not ashamed to walk down the street with them. The girls who worked for my agency were often nurses or air hostesses or were in the middle of doing a degree. Or they might have been going through a divorce and needed a bit of extra cash. For the top few, it's possible to make a fortune. I know of two girls who live in £500,000 houses provided for them by rich clients, but most earn a few hundred pounds a week, at rates of £150-£250 an hour, of which their agency takes a cut of about one third."

One major difference between escort and street work is the absence of men in charge at the upper end. "It's a girl power thing," Fernando says. "Most agencies are run by women and both the escorts and the men feel more comfortable knowing that. When I started an agency, I saw it as just another business venture. I don't like those dirty pimps who control the girls who work the streets and when someone pointed out that I was pimping, too, I decided to get out."

Melanie Rose, who works for Annabelle's escort agency in Brighton, agrees that it is the women who call the shots in her line of work. And she is quick to shrug off the qualms of the moral majority. fields.headline: Christopher Marlowe
fields.trailText: Occupation: Elizabethan playwright (no, not that one).
fields.body:
Occupation: Elizabethan playwright (no, not that one).

Age: Well, he was 29 when he was killed in a Deptford tavern in 1593.

Appearance: He was stabbed in the eye, so probably not pretty, in his final moments at least.

Killed to hide the fact that he was author of the so-called "Shakespeare" plays? Conspiracy theories have kept the biographies coming: was he a secret agent? Was it revenge for his atheist views (the privy council had just issued a warrant for his arrest)? Was it the lone killer in the book depository? Or was it, more mundanely, a bar brawl?

Looked at someone's bird? More likely the bloke holding the pint, if you believe the movies.

I don't. Fair enough, but scholarly opinion agrees that Marlowe was gay. One new film, to be announced at Cannes this week, will have a stab (ho ho) at painting him as a ladies' man. But a rival pic, A Dead Man in Deptford, aims to give the playwright a 21st century makeover as "a non-heterosexual action hero".

An action hero who couldn't handle himself in a pub fight? There is the theory that he was killed with his own dagger before he could do an adversary any damage. But he might well have been something of a Tudor James Bond. There was, possibly, stint in the army. And he was almost certainly a government secret agent. And he wrote plays.

Action adventures? Tragedies, although his radical use of blank verse can set some pulses racing. As can his depiction in Edward II of the man who would rather not be king, preferring to spend time with "intimate friend" Piers Gaveston.

And did Marlowe have any intimate friends? Well, he probably knew one William Shakespeare, who fondly called him "dead shepherd" in As You Like It. But he was rather chummier with Thomas Walsingham, cousin of Elizabeth I's spymaster, Sir Francis. Did I mention the theory that he was behind the murder?

Do say: "Come live with me and be my love."

Don't say: "I think you've got something in your eye."

webTitle: Train design goes off the rails

fields.headline: Train design goes off the rails
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: First it was leaves, then it was snow, now Railtrack is suffering from the wrong kind of platform - and it is having to shave the edges after trains costing £70m were built too wide.
fields.body:
First it was leaves, then it was snow, now Railtrack is suffering from the wrong kind of platform - and it is having to shave the edges after trains costing £70m were built too wide.

The 27 trains, bought by First North Western, were due on routes across north-west England and north Wales at the end of last month. Railtrack is now trying to fit them into stations before the May 28 summer timetables start. But some changes may take two months.

Peter Maynard, of Railtrack, said the trains could hit trackside equipment, or smash into platforms.

"It is only in the past three or four weeks that Railtrack has received definitive information about how much space these trains require," he said. "We are working to resolve issues of passenger safety as quickly as possible. It might just require a handful of simple measures like stopping trains from scraping against platform edges, concrete signs or bridges."

Railtrack is in talks with First North Western, who ordered the trains from the manufacturers, Alstom, about who will pay for the platform alterations.

Mr Maynard added: "This happens when train companies buy direct from manufacturers and don't come to Railtrack for specifications. Companies buy the same trains for different routes regardless of platform sizes."

First North Western will operate with 30-year-old trains on its north Wales route until the work has been carried out.

The Class 175 Coradia trains have low pollution diesel engines and are said to be the quietest in Europe.

fields.headline: Gene that puts 'high' in heroin
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists have found the gene that puts the "high" in heroin. They have genetically engineered mice that do not become addicts of opiates such as morphine.
fields.body:
Scientists have found the gene that puts the "high" in heroin. They have genetically engineered mice that do not become addicts of opiates such as morphine.

The discovery, reported in Nature today, could open up new ways to help heroin addicts kick the habit. But it could also lead to safer painkilling drugs.

"The gene seems to separate the analgesic properties of opiates from their pleasurable-addictive effects," said Stephen Hunt of University College London.

"It could be possible to tease apart the analgesic and addictive properties of these drugs, offering a way to develop drugs that can be more safely used to alleviate pain."

Narcotics act upon chemical receptors in the brain to produce a feeling of euphoria. The researchers identified a gene that carries the blueprint for a protein that acts as a receptor for a chemical in the brain, substance P. This turned out to be one of the messengers of pleasure in opium-based drugs.

Opiates are the only drugs strong enough to alleviate the pain of many cancer patients. If they could be administered with a second drug which blocked the substance P receptor, there would be less risk of dependency.

fields.headline: Lockerbie clue 'found in debris'
fields.standfirst:
Lockerbie: special report
University of Glasgow Lockerbie trial briefing
Lockerbie trial documents (Libyan site)
fields.trailText: A woman told the Lockerbie trial yesterday how she found an instruction booklet for a radio cassette player in fields near her home around 70 miles away from the Scottish town.
fields.body:
A woman told the Lockerbie trial yesterday how she found an instruction booklet for a radio cassette player in fields near her home around 70 miles away from the Scottish town.

Two men, who deny causing the jumbo jet disaster, are alleged to have caused a suitcase containing an umbrella, clothing and an improvised explosive device concealed within a radio cassette recorder to be placed on board Pan Am flight 103.

The device allegedly detonated on board the aircraft on December 21 1988 killing all 259 passengers and crew and 11 Lockerbie residents.

The hearing at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands was told how 64-year-old Gwendoline Horton, from Morpeth, Northumberland, scoured fields with her husband for debris after the plane was blown out of the sky above Lockerbie.

She said she found a document, about eight inches long by eight inches wide, with writing on it which referred to a radio cassette player. "We went out with the specific idea of collecting this stuff and my neighbour had said to hand it to the police."

A retired police constable, Brian Walton, of Northumbria police, told how Mrs Horton handed the item to him at his station in Alnwick.

He said: "It was pieces of an instruction handbook. It had tiny bits of singeing on some of the edges.

"At that time, the day after the crash or the following day, it didn't have the significance that it obviously might have now with hindsight."

Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, have pleaded not guilty to three alternative charges of conspiracy to murder, murder, and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act. They have lodged special defences of incrimination, blaming others for the atrocity.

The court was adjourned to allow the prosecution to consider a document from the defence which could allow the two sides to agree evidence relating to the recovery of debris and so speed up the trial.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Women On The Verge Of A Nervous Breakdown | Hard Eight | Boogie Nights | Repulsion
fields.body:
Women On The Verge Of A Nervous Breakdown (Pedro Almodovar, 1988)

FilmFour

Possibly Almodovar's most crowd-pleasing film - which is as much a curse as a blessing since its success encouraged some of his worst excesses.

It's farce of the highest order, with the kind of pacing, stylised angst and madcap complexity no one's pulled off since the 50s. Leading the mass neurosis is freshly jilted Carmen Maura, whose attempts to avenge herself snowball into a mass of frantic liaisons, misunderstandings and slapstick.

Repulsion (Roman Polanski, 1965)

am, FilmFour

Polanski's riveting psychological shocker delves into the hallucinating mind of a young Belgian woman (Catherine Deneuve) as she goes mad in her sister's Kensington flat, painting her fears in disturbing black-and-white images - sinister shadows, hands coming out of walls. Both attracted and repelled by sex, she starts to slaughter the men who call on her, a deranged inversion of Psycho's Janet Leigh.

Boogie Nights (Paul Thomas Anderson, 1997)

2.20am, Sky Premier

Hard-edged but affectionate portrait of the 70s porn business in the San Fernando Valley. It follows the rise and fall of porn star Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg), who is taken into an extended family of blue movie actors and technicians, headed by Bruce Reynolds' benign director, Jack Horner. It's a seedy world, but full of human warmth and frailty.

Hard Eight (Paul Thomas Anderson, 1996)

2.50am, Sky MovieMax

Second part of the Paul Thomas Anderson double bill is his first feature, a spare and subtle modern noir that, like Boogie Nights, has a group of characters making a dodgy living on the fringes of the law. Philip Baker Hall is a revelation as Sidney, an ageing gambler who takes young John (John C Reilly) under his wing. In Reno, the latter becomes involved with Gwyneth Paltrow's cocktail waitress-cum-hooker and bad boy Jimmy (Samuel L Jackson). Snappy script, bursts of violence: an ace.

fields.headline: Dissidents to regain online anonymity
fields.trailText: Freenet, a new piece of internet software which allows people to publish and exchange information anonymously, could become a potent weapon in the fight against internet censorship.
fields.body:
Freenet, a new piece of internet software which allows people to publish and exchange information anonymously, could become a potent weapon in the fight against internet censorship.

The software - created by a 23-year-old Irish programmer, Ian Clarke, working at Edinburgh University - could easily circumvent the censorship activities of 20 governments, including Saudi Arabia and China.

Mr Clarke and a band of fellow programmers follow the "open source" creed - which makes software freely available for people to adapt, rather than allowing it to be patented by big corporations.

Freenet is a decentralised system of information exchange, which bypasses government-approved or commercially-driven ISPs. Encrypted information is spread across individual computers, or "nodes", of volunteers; this could confound both government censorship and hackers.

"What a country would need to do [to stop it] is ban encrypted data travelling across the internet," he said. "Now that would kill e-commerce in that country and make the internet useless. It strikes me as very unlikely that any country would risk crippling their economy. Information should be free."

Corporate America has voiced its concern about the copyright implications of such ventures. Court cases are pending over the use of Napster, a system similar to Freenet, to exchange MP3 music files.

webTitle: Police hunt source of killer heroin

fields.headline: Police hunt source of killer heroin
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Police and public health officials in Glasgow are trying to identify what might have killed eight heroin addicts and left 11 more seriously ill in the past two weeks.
fields.body:
Police and public health officials in Glasgow are trying to identify what might have killed eight heroin addicts and left 11 more seriously ill in the past two weeks.

The search for an explanation has centred on the possibility that a batch of contaminated citric acid, which addicts use to dissolve heroin before injecting, may be to blame.

In most of the cases the illness has started as an abscess at the point where heroin had been injected.

Abscesses are not uncommon among drug users but in the recent cases they became uncharacteristically large and severe.

Laurence Gruer, consultant in public health medicine with Greater Glasgow health board, has said the fact that seven of the dead are women supports the citric acid theory.

"Most of the patients appear to have been injecting into their muscles or have accidentally missed the vein," he said.

"The most likely explanation is that they have injected heroin, or a substance used to dissolve it, which has been contaminated with infective or toxic material ...

"Women tend to run out of veins more quickly than men and have to resort to muscles to get drugs in."

Citric acid is available as a household product but health board officials said the wider community was not at risk. Preliminary tests on one batch of acid have proved negative.

Officials were also looking at the possibility that a bad batch of heroin may have caused the illness. Thirteen of the victims came from the Govanhill area and the others all lived in the north of the city.

Addicts were urged to seek medical help if they developed an abscess or severe inflammation.

"Women tend to run out of veins more quickly than men and have to resort to muscles to get drugs in." Citric acid is available as a household product but health board officials said the wider community was not at risk. Preliminary tests on one batch of acid have proved negative. Officials were also looking at the possibility that a bad batch of heroin may have caused the illness. Thirteen of the victims came from the Govanhill area and the others all lived in the north of the city. Addicts were urged to seek medical help if they developed an abscess or severe inflammation.

fields.headline: I am your Tory reader
fields.trailText: In your election study not one Guardian reader registered as voting Tory, the only newspaper to show 0% (Analysis, May 9).
fields.body:
In your election study not one Guardian reader registered as voting Tory, the only newspaper to show 0% (Analysis, May 9). I'd like to register as the "quirk" who has always voted Tory. (Are there any others out there?)

Admittedly, this is now a very lukewarm feeling, but I would never vote Lib Dem and can't quite bring myself around to voting Labour. However, I still prefer the Guardian to the other newspapers. As your slogan says, "free thinkers welcome".
Trevor Clarke,

 Prof Whiteley missed some fascinating data.
