fields.headline: Pensioner poverty alleviated, marginally
fields.trailText: In defending the government's pensions policies (Bowing to the power of pensioners, May 10), Polly Toynbee says: "All the extra money has been targeted on the poorest 1.6m pensioners."
fields.body:
In defending the government's pensions policies (Bowing to the power of pensioners, May 10), Polly Toynbee says: "All the extra money has been targeted on the poorest 1.6m pensioners."

This is incorrect. Included with the winter fuel payment in the total are payments for the minimum income guarantee (MIG) which do not reach pensioners entitled to, but not receiving, such supplementary income support.

Up to a million of the poorest pensioners do not receive MIG. The government's latest figures show that twice as many pensioners as in 1979 (2.4m compared with 1.2m for England alone) have incomes below half average income.

That figure was rising in the mid-1990s and there is no evidence yet from the present parliament that it has been arrested, still less reversed.

Only a substantial increase in the basic retirement pension (say £10 or more on the single rate), together with renewal of the earnings link, will help reduce pensioner poverty.
Prof Peter Townsend,
London School of Economics

 Your report (Pensions to rise by up to £5 a week, May 10) misses two crucial points. First, the government's pensions policy has benefited the very rich as well as the very poor.

Anything provided tax free - winter fuel payments, free TV licences - is of particularly high value to those who pay tax at the top rate. Net, it also costs the taxpayer more - because none of it comes back in tax.

The government should therefore consolidate all its tax-free extra hand-outs into the state pension - which is taxable.

Second, the minimum income guarantee does not benefit all the poorest pensioners. Many of those with the lowest incomes (mainly women) live in households which include someone above the limit.

These women do not qualify for the minimum income guarantee. The extent of sharing within households varies, and the state pension is their only income in their own right.

Whilst the focus on increasing the income of the poorest households is right, please can the government remember that this does nothing to help many women who worked, unpaid, all their lives, providing caring services.
Mary Campbell,
London
mcampbell@london.edu

fields.headline: In search of justice
fields.trailText: Do we really live in a country where a man is jailed for spraying paint on a statue (Churchill protester is jailed) and yet it is deemed that nobody will stand trial for 31 deaths in the Paddington rail crash (Corporate killers to be brought to book, May 10)?
fields.body:
Do we really live in a country where a man is jailed for spraying paint on a statue (Churchill protester is jailed) and yet it is deemed that nobody will stand trial for 31 deaths in the Paddington rail crash (Corporate killers to be brought to book, May 10)?
Scott Thomas
London Scott@itb.co.uk

 The DPP implies that companies are outside the law. Meanwhile, the government and most of the media fail to even discuss the global injustices that May Day was all about. It is no wonder people take to the streets.

Talybont

Caro O'Callaghan
Heston, Middx

Fai Lee

fields.headline: Straw and the racist
fields.trailText: I could not agree more with Francis Wheen's criticism of Jack Straw for sharing a debating platform with Charles Murray (G2, May 10).
fields.body:
I could not agree more with Francis Wheen's criticism of Jack Straw for sharing a debating platform with Charles Murray (G2, May 10). Murray not only espouses the nonsensical theory that black people are more stupid than white, but he also claims that people who live on low incomes ("the poor") are genetically inferior, hence their impoverishment.

Sadly many on the centre-left, whilst disagreeing with his conclusions, have allowed him to set the agenda. The word poor to describe people living on low incomes or benefits is especially offensive - the dictionary definition is: belonging to a socially inferior group. And the so called underclass are in reality young, unemployed, working-class people. Give them a job and a decent environment and they will quickly turn their lives around as, with the current fall in the numbers of unemployed, many of them already have.
Mick Hall
Grays, Essex

 Murray's success in fuelling conservative fears by invoking the spectre of a growing underclass has been achieved by maintaining the fiction that a person's intelligence is unchangeable, in the face of massive evidence to the contrary.
Prof Michael Howe
Exeter

 New Labour's love affair with all things transatlantic is never ending. Jack Straw could have found plenty of discredited British right-wing polemicists with whom to share a platform. Even US racists are, it seems, to be preferred to our own.
Prof Robert Moore
Holywell, FlintshireT

 The fallacies in the racist arguments of Charles Murray and others have been exposed not only in "obscure academic journals" but also in the excellent and readable book, The Mismeasure Of Man, by Stephen Jay Gould.
Richard Burnham
Shrewsbury

fields.headline: Reflections on war image
fields.trailText: I applaud your decision to print the photograph of that unutterably vulnerable, young dead victim in Sierra Leone (Front page, May 9).
fields.body:
I applaud your decision to print the photograph of that unutterably vulnerable, young dead victim in Sierra Leone (Front page, May 9). Of course such pictures cause distress; there are those (and I am one) who carry such images in their heads and need no reminders.

However, comforted as the world was by the description of "smart" bombs and "collateral damage" in the Gulf war, it was a decision of considerable courage by your sister paper, the Observer, to print the picture of the Iraqi soldier, his face melted to the windscreen of his tank, showing the world the reality of that "clean" war. The little naked girl running down the road in terror in Vietnam, brought reality of a distant, far away conflict for all time.

John Hereward's distress at his 17-year-old daughter's reaction to the picture (Letters, May 10) is, of course, right - but the picture poses a truly moral question: as wars are presented in sound bites as in Iraq and the Balkans and fought from high in the skies, the incalculable human cost is forgotten and truth, like the dead, lies silent.

The slaughter in Rwanda was largely ignored, the coun try was poor, black and had no assets the west wanted. Sierra Leone is in danger of being dubbed another warring African basket case, engendering exasperation rather than pity and a desire to mediate and offer succour. That picture showed reality: a young man who was some mother's son, maybe some child's father and some young widow's husband.
Felicity Arbuthnot
London

 As a psychologist, Barbara Quin (Letters, May 10) would probably agree that it is easier to imagine one's self in a given situation - how else do human beings learn to be sympathetic or empathic to others? - and, hence, she may be right about racism: it may be harder for white people to sympathise with black people unless they see the horror for themselves.

There is plenty of sympathy in our press for the white murder victims in Zimbabwe without the need for graphic pictures. But just as Michael Buerk's legendary report of the 1983 famine in Ethiopia brought the realities of that people's suffering to white westerners, so this image em bodies the full horror of the situation in Sierra Leone.

It is rather too convenient for Ms Quin to hide behind emotive upbraidings against liberal conscience (and altogether repellent that she even needs to qualify herself as a victim) when she gets upset at the sight of blood.
Simon Gilman
London simon.gilman@lineone.net

 This kind of photo is common abroad, especially America, but thankfully we do not experience this crass exploitation here. I appreciate the picture is meant to shock, but ultimately its impact is diminished as people become more blasé. As a father I have difficulty explainning such a painful image to my two young children.
John Sugar
London
john.sugar@WiseBuddah.com

 My six-year-old often retrieves the paper from the mat, luckily not this morning. It seems OK to photograph and reproduce black or ethnic people's dead or damaged bodies without much thought for their dignity. This man is a human being, yet you have not even honoured him with a name.

Maybe the most awful thing about the photograph is that it is so beautifully framed - I very much hope that this was by accident.
Sally Hain
Neath, W Glamorgan

 It seems as if some readers are not yet aware of the fact that war, killing and blood are real. Perhaps you could provide them with colouring books and crayons, with sachets of tomato ketchup for the more adventurous?
Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife
Tom.Locke@kscl.com

fields.headline: Loo lottery
fields.trailText: Ken Powell states (Spiralling costs of public building projects, May 8) that "After the thing has been awarded to the architects, inevitably the client wants to monitor the project, they want twice as many lavatories, more offices, more space."
fields.body:
Ken Powell states (Spiralling costs of public building projects, May 8) that "After the thing has been awarded to the architects, inevitably the client wants to monitor the project, they want twice as many lavatories, more offices, more space."

We have worked on more than 100 Lottery funded capital projects with budgets up to £50m and we find, in every case, the architect has costed in the absolute minimum (sometimes less) for sanitary provision.

A visit to a new building is too often memorable, especially for women and disabled people, because of its badly designed, cramped loos.
David Burdus,
Burdus Access Management

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report on Sierra Leone and the diamond trade, How precious resource has stoked the fires of conflict, page 4, May 9, we gave the impression that De Beers was still indirectly involved in the diamond trade in the region. De Beers has asked us to emphasise that its involvement in Sierra Leone, which began in the late 1950s, ended in 1985, a decision taken because of the deteriorating political and economic environment and the country's growing corruption. De Beers says it closed its buying operations in Liberia at that time for similar reasons and has not bought diamonds from either of those countries since then.
fields.body:
In our report on Sierra Leone and the diamond trade, How precious resource has stoked the fires of conflict, page 4, May 9, we gave the impression that De Beers was still indirectly involved in the diamond trade in the region. De Beers has asked us to emphasise that its involvement in Sierra Leone, which began in the late 1950s, ended in 1985, a decision taken because of the deteriorating political and economic environment and the country's growing corruption. De Beers says it closed its buying operations in Liberia at that time for similar reasons and has not bought diamonds from either of those countries since then.

George Stevenson, the MP for Stoke-on-Trent South, has pointed out that he was among the Labour rebels who voted against the government on the issue of the part-privatisation of air traffic control. He was missing from the list we published, page 10, yesterday.

In our piece about the Queen's formal dedication of the millennium footbridge over the Thames, page 4, yesterday, we said the estimated cost on completion was £18m. We should have said £16m. The bridge is, in fact, about 75% complete (we said about one-third). The Millennium Bridge Trust says the bridge is meeting the schedule announced a year ago, of being dedicated in May and opened to the public in June.

In a report, England pick Jerusalem etc, page 32, May 9, we attributed a quote to "The actor Martin Allen ..." We meant the comedian, Keith Allen.

In a piece about the Casement diaries, page 22, May 8, we quoted "a Casement expert" as saying, "... had they been forged surely they would have been burned once the deed had been done, not kept for prosperity." We meant to say "for posterity".

fields.headline: Music producers back down
fields.standfirst: Federal trade commission acts on CD prices
fields.trailText: Five of the world's biggest music companies are expected to agree to stop anti-discounting practices that have led to higher prices for compact discs in the US.
fields.body:
Five of the world's biggest music companies are expected to agree to stop anti-discounting practices that have led to higher prices for compact discs in the US.

Standard industry behaviour in the US is for music companies to prevent retailers from advertising discount prices. Since about 1995, large music companies have withheld substantial promotional revenues from any retailer that advertised cheaper prices.

While chains such as Wal-Mart have offered cheaper CDs, this threat has stopped them from introducing large-scale discounts and promoting them.

The federal trade commission is to announce the results of its investigation into the industry in Washington today. Time Warner, Sony, Bertelsmann, EMI and Seagram are all expected to agree to stop the practice without either admitting or denying the charges brought by the regulator.

It was unclear yesterday how the move would affect Europe, where CD prices can be significantly higher than in the US. The average price for a new release in the US is about £10, for example, compared with more than £13 in the UK.

Today's announcement is expected to lead to several new promotions from large US retailers for CDs sold for less than the manufacturers' minimum price.

Analysts warned that the development could hurt small retailers that are unable to discount heavily. The FTC is expected to call today's announcement a significant development for CD pricing.

The practice was originally introduced by large music manufacturers to stop huge electronics superstores like Circuit City from undercutting. However, industry analysts believe that increased competition from online music sites is a greater threat.

webTitle: Defence and law and order face cuts

fields.headline: Defence and law and order face cuts
fields.trailText: The price of pumping billions of pounds into voter-friendly increases in spending on the NHS, education and transport could be belt tightening in the rest of Whitehall, a senior Treasury minister acknowledged yesterday.
fields.body:
The price of pumping billions of pounds into voter-friendly increases in spending on the NHS, education and transport could be belt tightening in the rest of Whitehall, a senior Treasury minister acknowledged yesterday.

Despite the drubbing in last week's local elections and the government's substantial budget surplus, Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, admitted to MPs that some "tough choices" would have to be made in the new spending round now reaching a climax.

His comments to the Treasury committee fuelled fears in Whitehall that defence and law and order may have their budgets trimmed to pay for extra spending on the government's priority areas.

In a new report, David Walton, senior economist at the US investment bank Goldman Sachs, who advises the committee, points out that the extra £19bn committed to health over four years in the Budget, plus sizeable increases expected for education and transport will leave little in the pot for anyone else.

"Defence and law and order will once again be the relative losers unless the government accords a lower priority to education," says Mr Walton.

NHS spending is due to rise by 5.6% a year in real terms from 2001-02 to 2003-04, compared to 2.5% overall, under the broad outline of plans announced by Mr Brown in March.

Goldman Sachs says a substantial increases in spending on transport will account for most of the expected rise in capital spending while the education budget will need to grow by 5.1% a year in real, inflation-adjusted terms, to match the rate of the last spending review.

Asked about the scope for spending increases, Mr Smith said: "Some tough choices will have to be made - that's the nature of of the review which is based on sticking to tight fiscal rules."

Answering questions about the new system of fixing Whitehall budgets over three-years instead of one, Mr Smith said it gave government departments the opportunity to plan ahead and avoided the traditional end-of-year scrabble to spend cash leftover in order to avoid cuts next time round.

His comments to the Treasury committee fuelled fears in Whitehall that defence and law and order may have their budgets trimmed to pay for extra spending on the government's priority areas. In a new report, David Walton, senior economist at the US investment bank Goldman Sachs, who advises the committee, points out that the extra £19bn committed to health over four years in the Budget, plus sizeable increases expected for education and transport will leave little in the pot for anyone else. "Defence and law and order will once again be the relative losers unless the government accords a lower priority to education," says Mr Walton. NHS spending is due to rise by 5.6% a year in real terms from 2001-02 to 2003-04, compared to 2.5% overall, under the broad outline of plans announced by Mr Brown in March. Goldman Sachs says a substantial increases in spending on transport will account for most of the expected rise in capital spending while the education budget will need to grow by 5.1% a year in real, inflation-adjusted terms, to match the rate of the last spending review. Asked about the scope for spending increases, Mr Smith said: "Some tough choices will have to be made - that's the nature of of the review which is based on sticking to tight fiscal rules." Answering questions about the new system of fixing Whitehall budgets over three-years instead of one, Mr Smith said it gave government departments the opportunity to plan ahead and avoided the traditional end-of-year scrabble to spend cash leftover in order to avoid cuts next time round.

fields.headline: Nowhere near equal
fields.standfirst: Another shaming report on women's pay
fields.trailText: We cannot really be shocked by the statistics that the government report, Social Inequalities, published yesterday, throws up about the inequality of women's pay.
fields.body:
We cannot really be shocked by the statistics that the government report, Social Inequalities, published yesterday, throws up about the inequality of women's pay. In recent months, similar conclusions have come from government-sponsored research at the London School of Economics as well as from studies done by the Trade Union Congress and the Equal Opportunities Commission (EOC). Yet each fresh piece of evidence is remarkable.

Shamingly, Social Inequalities finds that women earn an average of 42% less than men. The gap yawns wide in the highest skilled end of the job market, where men earn an average of £36,000 compared with women's £24,000. The problem of unequal pay will not simply wither away as women's employment skills improve. Girls are achieving better than boys at almost every level of the educational system, but there can be no room for complacently assuming that this will solve the problem. Even when boys and girls leave school at 16 with the same qualifications, by the time they reach 20, the boys will be earning 10% more.

It says much for this government that it has been prepared to commission and publish this kind of statistical analysis. Social Inequalities is Britain's dirty linen - unequal pay is only one among many other equally shabby facts. By exposing them, the government bravely opens itself up to increased demands and expectations. For over a generation, we have accepted the argument for equal pay as an issue of justice, but the level of women's pay also has a practical knock-on effect on two of the most vulnerable groups in society whose plight the government is explicitly pledged to improve: children and women pensioners. Since women spend more of their income on their children than men do, any improvements in their pay will benefit their offspring. A woman on lower pay does not have the resources to invest in as good a pension as a man: the inequality lasts a lifetime.

So far the government has been better at publishing information than at putting in place the strategy for change. It must first put its own house in order. Progress is being made, especially in the National Health Service and local government. But as in the case of NHS speech therapists, it can be painfully slow: 16 years to settle the case. In another blatantly unjust instance, the higher education sector, David Blunkett, the secretary of state for education, has been making the right noises but is under pressure to find the money from his allocation in the comprehensive spending review this summer - and the bill is put at around £9m.

These are only the most egregious measures. Beyond them lies the issue of reforming a 25-year-old equal pay act which has palpably failed. The most urgent reform needed - for which the EOC has been campaigning - is that where a group of women constitute a particular trade or profession, tribunals should not deal with it simply on an individual case by case basis, but through group actions. The government needs to rally some political energy for a high-profile campaign to make pay audits a standard part of good employer practice. Inequalities have to be flushed out; secrecy has served women poorly. Finally, the qualitative research exposes a workplace culture which has to be challenged by employee and employer alike, in which outdated assumptions that the man is the breadwinner while the woman's wage is merely supplementary (not much more important, in essence, than pin-money) are proving surprisingly persistent.

fields.headline: Luminar's £585m boogie with rival
fields.trailText: Contrary to movie suggestions that we have seen The Last Days of Disco, Luminar and Northern Leisure yesterday created Britain's biggest boogie and bar brand.
fields.body:
Contrary to movie suggestions that we have seen The Last Days of Disco, Luminar and Northern Leisure yesterday created Britain's biggest boogie and bar brand.

Nightclub owner Luminar unveiled a recommended offer for rival Northern Leisure, creating a hot spot empire worth £585m, the largest nightclubs and bars group in Britain.

It also provides a long-sought exit route for Northern Leisure's founder Nick Oppenheim.

Luminar owns 24 nightclubs and 33 bars under the Chicago Rock cafe brand. Its best known nightspot is the Hippodrome in London's West End.

The combined group will include 250 clubs and restaurants across Britain, with chief executive Steve Thomas assuming overall control.

"It's a good deal for both sides and will create a hugely cash generative machine," said Nick Batram, leisure analyst at Granville Baird.

However, a number of Northern Leisure's key directors will not be joining the party. Adam Mills and Peter McEnhill, two entrepreneurs who engineered a reverse takeover of Northern in 1999, having previously built a fortune running the National Express coach group, are resigning along with three other directors.

Northern Leisure chairman Don Hanson, one of the executives planning to quit, said in a statement that the deal would create the "opportunity for cost savings and other operating efficiencies".

Hanson will resign once the takeover is declared unconditional, while the firm's managing director Clive Preston will join Luminar's board.

The deal comes during a period of increasing consolidation in Britain's entertainment industry.

European private equity firm Cinven bought the Odeon cinema from Rank Group Plc for £280m in February, while Waterfall Holdings said last week that it had agreed to a takeover offer from rival group Allied Leisure.

Last year Luminar bought 27 bars and nightclubs from Allied Leisure for £34.5m, including the Hippodrome and Camden Palace. Allied had itself recently acquired those venues through its takeover of European Leisure.

Luminar's executives include Tony Marshall, the former managing director of Butlins.

Luminar shares yesterday fell by 22.5p, to 747.5p at the start of trading in London, while Northern Leisure rose as much as 13.5p, to 174p.

The all-share deal would result in a company pressing for entry into the FTSE 250 Mid Cap group of stocks.

fields.headline: Vitamin pills to carry warnings
fields.trailText: Vitamin pills are due to carry cigarette-style health warnings, making it clear that taking too many of them is bad for your health and that their medicinal value is nil. Far-reaching rules endorsed by the European Commission yesterday are expected to come into force in the UK in 2002 and will also specify exactly what vitamin and mineral manufacturers can put in their pills.
fields.body:
Vitamin pills are due to carry cigarette-style health warnings, making it clear that taking too many of them is bad for your health and that their medicinal value is nil. Far-reaching rules endorsed by the European Commission yesterday are expected to come into force in the UK in 2002 and will also specify exactly what vitamin and mineral manufacturers can put in their pills.

Only ingredients which appear on a list approved by EU scientists will be allowed to be used, and manufacturers will be banned from making any claims they cannot substantiate.

EU officials yesterday said that taking too many vitamin pills could seriously damage health.

"Taking too much vitamin C and E, for example, can lead to diarrhoea, hair loss and internal bleeding. The substances (contained in vitamins) are not dangerous in themselves but our consumption habits can be," one official said.

Although the exact wording of the health warning has yet to be agreed, manufacturers will be forced to call their products "supplements" and to make clear that they are no substitute for a varied diet. Recommended daily doses will also have to be included.

The rules have to be approved by the European parliament and EU health ministers before they can take effect and could be watered down if lobbying by pharmaceutical companies pays off.

webTitle: Man fined for cruelty to horse

fields.headline: Man fined for cruelty to horse
fields.trailText: A man was fined £1,000 by Nottingham magistrates yesterday after admitting attempting to drag a horse into a horse box using a Land Rover.
fields.body:
A man was fined £1,000 by Nottingham magistrates yesterday after admitting attempting to drag a horse into a horse box using a Land Rover.

Joshua Swindell, 48, was accused of causing unnecessary suffering to the mare at a show in Hucknall, Nottinghamshire, last August.

The court was told that after the show, in which the animal was placed fifth, it refused to be loaded into its box for the journey back to Swindell's home in Twodales, Matlock, Derbyshire.

His wife, Valerie, 43, attempted to load the horse but it proved stubborn and bolted, dragging Mrs Swindell through a hedge.

Tim Shock, prosecuting, said: "An attempt to get the horse loaded using a lunge-line failed so a rope was passed through the horse box and tied to the back of a Land Rover.

"The horse was being dragged by the neck and it slipped on the ramp and suffered a cut to its head."

The animal needed stitches.

Defending, Bertie Mather said the Swindells had owned the horse since 1996.

Following the incident the animal was seen by a horse psychologist who said it was unwilling to accept its place in the family hierarchy.

Swindell was fined £1,000 and ordered to pay £600 costs.
Press Association

fields.headline: André Jarrot
fields.standfirst: Resistance hero and post-war politician with a lingering taste for dare-devilry
fields.trailText: Few individuals more perfectly embodied the dare-devil and heroic image of the French Resistance which has endured in the popular imagination than André Jarrot, who has died aged 91.
fields.body:
Few individuals more perfectly embodied the dare-devil and heroic image of the French Resistance which has endured in the popular imagination than André Jarrot, who has died aged 91.

Born in the village of Lux (Sane-et-Loire), Jarrot was the son of a railway employee. Trained as a mechanic, he worked in a garage in the 1930s, but his real passion was motor-cycle racing. In 1937 he was the French motor-cycle racing champion and in 1938 he won the world record for the distance covered in 24 hours.

Jarrot was taken prisoner during the fall of France, but escaped almost immediately and returned to his home in Burgundy. Jarrot's garage in Lux was just inside the unoccupied zone, and he started working for a network smuggling people - especially escaped prisoners of war and allied aviators who had been shot down - across the Demarcation Line dividing occupied and unoccupied France. In the first two years of the Occupation, he assisted over 4,000 people in this way.

In 1942, after being briefly arrested by the Germans, he decided to head for London, where he arrived in the spring of 1943 after various vicissitudes (including a period of incarceration in the notorious Spanish internment camp of Miranda). In London, Jarrot was given training in sabotage by the Gaullist section of the Special Operations Executive and was parachuted back into France as one of two leaders of the "Armada" sabotage mission. Over the following months, Armada carried out an extraordinary number of operations, including the destruction of power stations in the Burgundy area, the destruction of the Le Creusot industrial plant (which the RAF had failed to destroy in 1942), the immobilisation of numerous canals, the destruction of power cables (187 pylons were brought down on one day in October 1943), and the breaching of the Grigny barrage near Chalon.

Of Jarrot's multifarious Resistance activities, the most important was the disruption of the water transportation system of much of north-eastern and central France at a time when the Germans were trying to send torpedo boats and submarines to disrupt the imminent allied landings in Italy. By immobilising the canal traffic between the Ruhr and the Mediterranean at such a crucial moment, the Armada mission contributed significantly - possibly decisively - to the success of the allied landings at Anzio and Salerno. The official historian of the SOE rightly described the contribution of the Armada mission as the most "striking demonstration of the sabotage possibilities of clandestine warfare" and "the most remarkable instance in France of sabotage directed to serve a strategic end". Jarrot was one of the select band of Companions of the Liberation created by de Gaulle.

After the war Jarrot founded one of the main organisations of former resistance fighters. The Resistance had created deep bonds between individuals from varied backgrounds who saw themselves as having earned the right to a leadership role in post-war France. But not all resisters followed identical political trajectories. Jarrot had been on the left in the 1930s, but after the war loyalty to de Gaulle became his guiding principle. When in 1947 de Gaulle set up his Rally of the French People (RPF), Jarrot became regional organiser for the department of the Sane-et-Loire; in 1953 he was elected RPF mayor of Lux; in 1958, he was a founder member of the Union for the Republic (UNR), set up to support de Gaulle's action as president.

Jarrot, however, was never a front rank - or even a second rank - politician. His political career centred on the Sane-et-Loire, for which he was elected deputy in 1958. Having been mayor of Lux since 1953, he was elected instead in 1965 to be mayor of the larger community of Montceau-les-Mines in the same area. Jarrot only emerged from his local role in May 1974, when he was chosen by the newly elected centre-right president Valéry Giscard d'Estaing as minister for the quality of life.

The choice of Jarrot was Giscard's attempt to enhance his reputation among Gaullists - all the more necessary since his family's Vichyite past gave Giscard an ambiguous reputation among former resisters, whereas his rival François Mitterrand was seen as having good Resistance credentials. For this reason, once the Gaullist candidate Chaban Delmas had been knocked out of the race, even some conservative resisters preferred Mitterrand to Giscard. Not Jarrot, however, who could not forgive Mitterrand's anti-Gaullism. He was one of 43 Gaullist MPs who rallied publicly to Giscard's candidacy. The ministry was his reward. But Jarrot failed to make much impact with a portfolio whose brief was ill-defined, and he left the government after a reshuffle in January 1976.

In 1986 Jarrot was elected to represent the Sane-et-Loire in the senate, from where he frequently lambasted Mitterrand, especially for his indifference to the memory of de Gaulle. But this did not stop Jarrot in 1988 calling for a ship to be named after Mitterrand's recently deceased education minister, Alain Savary, who had fought with de Gaulle's Free French: the memory of the Resistance prevailed above all.

In 1995, Jarrot retired from the senate, marking the occasion in characteristically spectacular fashion by a final parachute jump at the age of 86.

 André Jarrot, resistance hero and politician, born December 13 1909; died April 21 2000

fields.headline: Henry Bird
fields.standfirst: Dedicated artist who brought a touch of La Bohème to Northampton
fields.trailText: Henry Bird, who has died in hospital in Northampton at the age of 90, was an artist who had worked, for the past 50 years anyway, mainly for the adornment of his native county. One of his paintings, for Matthew Holding's late Victorian Guildhall, showed the muses contemplating Northampton, and though they must on frequent occasions have had to cover their eyes at some of the changes in the town, they would have been pleased, one suspects, with the contribution of such a talented and indefatigable, if often catankerous, follower.
fields.body:
Henry Bird, who has died in hospital in Northampton at the age of 90, was an artist who had worked, for the past 50 years anyway, mainly for the adornment of his native county. One of his paintings, for Matthew Holding's late Victorian Guildhall, showed the muses contemplating Northampton, and though they must on frequent occasions have had to cover their eyes at some of the changes in the town, they would have been pleased, one suspects, with the contribution of such a talented and indefatigable, if often catankerous, follower.

Henry regarded talent as an obligation and he served his own with exemplary devotion. He could not understand people who appeared to take art less seriously. Many regretted their hastily expressed opinion too late in the face of one of his uncompromising rebuffs. His late wife, the actress Freda Jackson, viewed her own art with similar rigour and both of them tended to disdain small talk. Taking a chair between them in Hardingstone House, their home on the edge of Northampton, could be a bit like sitting on the anvil while the blacksmith was at work. It was a testing experience that survivors valued enormously, perhaps just as much, in retrospect, as the great kindness of which both Henry and Freda were capable.

Henry Bird was born in the Green Street area of Northampton, near St Peter's church and the gasworks. His father had been a baker who, disillusioned after his return from the first world war, committed suicide. His mother came from a family of shoemakers at a time when the smell of leather, the town's daily bread, must have been permanently in the air. They were poor and it was a poor environment which Henry never forgot, but it was not unredeemed. Henry became a chorister in the Norman church, and once said that the beauty of St Peter's capitals, and the skill with which they were carved, helped to point the way to the kind of life he wanted.

He was only 11 when he began to study part time at the art school, taking factory and office jobs to pay his way. Encouraged by the principal, Lewis Duckett, he took the government certificate in drawing and painting, was placed in the first six in England and Wales, and gained a scholarship to the Royal College of Art, where he won most of the big prizes, including a travelling scholarship. The single-minded dedication that was necessary to bring about such a translation was central to Henry's character and therefore never left him.

Some of the early influences, such as Frank Brangwyn and Tiepolo, perhaps never left him either. What he never came to terms with was the declining value placed upon the academic skills which he had worked so hard to acquire, not only in the world at large but also, he felt, at the Royal College itself.

After the Royal College, and a period in which, among other things, he painted a number of inn signs, he became, in 1936, a lecturer in art history at the University College of Wales in Aberystwyth. His knowledge of art history was deep and constantly increasing throughout his life (he never willingly missed Ernst Gombrich's lectures at the Warburg Institute, for instance, and I still feel indebted to him for introducing me to them). He was especially illuminating on artists with whom he felt an affinity - Rubens for example, whose plump women he particularly admired.

Very soon after he took up the Aberystwyth appointment, which he held for five years, he and Freda Jackson married. They had met at Northampton Repertory Theatre, now The Royal (incorporated in the Derngate centre), where the company had included Errol Flynn, with whom Freda was reputed to have had a relationship. Indeed, Freda is said to have remarked, as a joke, that she chose Henry because he was so plain and unlikely to be lured away from her by another woman; or perhaps the story originated with Henry. They were, in any case, devoted to each other - even if the relationship sometimes seemed to outsiders perplexingly antagonistic - and their admiration for each other's work was unflagging.

Their careers ran in parallel for some time. Henry became a scene painter in charge of the studio producing sets for the Old Vic and Sadler's Wells. Then he became the resident designer at the Embassy Theatre until, in 1950, he returned to Northampton to take up a teaching post at the school of art. His classes became legendary. He believed that drawing was the bedrock of art, but before his pupils were allowed to test their aptitude for life drawing, his real passion, he would confront them with an ordinary building brick, and say, "First, draw that." Students were sometimes reduced to tears.

For Henry, sound craftsmanship was the springboard for everything else: if you were not prepared for the necessary application to acquire it, then that was that. His belief in academic skills and qualifications sometimes caused damaging and long-lasting personal conflicts. One of these was with David Gommon, whose appointment as art master at Northampton Grammar School he opposed because Gommon had, to begin with, no conventional qualifications, although he had been rightly praised as a practising artist. Much distress was caused before this was resolved. They lived at opposite ends of the same village and both taught until they reached retirement age, keeping well away from each other.

fields.headline: Jenny Pegler
fields.trailText: When the campaigner and Quaker Jenny Pegler, who has died aged 54, was once introduced by a doctor to some medical students as "someone who is severely disabled", she commented that the remark illustrated society's disability in dealing with people like herself.
fields.body:
When the campaigner and Quaker Jenny Pegler, who has died aged 54, was once introduced by a doctor to some medical students as "someone who is severely disabled", she commented that the remark illustrated society's disability in dealing with people like herself.

Despite her illness - she was diagnosed with a disease allied to MS in 1981 - she was determined to live in her own home, and campaigned for the right of handicapped people to do this. She was a trustee of the self-help group "Ligs" (Living Independently in Gloucestershire) and a powerful advocate for those people who, because of their disabilities, could not represent themselves.

Born in Manchester, she trained as a nurse, but when her illness was diagnosed took an Open University degree in psychology and social work. She raised £1,500 for the MS Society with a parachute jump, and later logged more descents. She also made two memorable voyages on the Lord Nelson, approving of that vessel's dictum that "can't" was a taboo word.

She was married twice, and is survived by a son and a daughter.

Jenny Pegler, campaigner, born February 15 1946; died March 19 2000

webTitle: Rebels consider pleas to free sick hostages

fields.headline: Rebels consider pleas to free sick hostages
fields.trailText: The Philippine military has pulled back its cordon around the jungle hideout where 21 hostages are being held, as the rebels consider appeals to free two of the hostages who are ill, officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Philippine military has pulled back its cordon around the jungle hideout where 21 hostages are being held, as the rebels consider appeals to free two of the hostages who are ill, officials said yesterday.

Troops had withdrawn from their positions around the Abu Sayyaf rebels' mountain camp, down to a road along the base of the mountain on remote Jolo island in the southern Philippines, army lieutenant Abe Sarajian said.

Earlier in the day an envoy, Abdul Rajab Azzarouq, a former Libyan ambassador with extensive personal contacts among the Muslims in the troubled Mindanao region, had hiked up a muddy jungle trail to talk to the rebels.

He asked them to free the two ailing hostages, a German woman, Renate Wallert, 57, whose family says she has had two strokes, and a French man with a urinary infection.

The Abu Sayyaf rebels promised to respond within 24 hours.

The rebels have no ransom demands "at the moment", said Mr Azzarouq. He said they had made some political demands which he could not disclose.

Negotiators expect to receive specific demands for the within 24 to 48 hours, he added. Negotiations can then begin in earnest.

Since January, 81 soldiers have been killed in violence across the island of Mindanao, where Muslim guerrillas are fighting to carve an Islamic nation from the predominantly Christian Philippines. A further 474 have been wounded and 21 are missing, while 115 civilians have been killed, most by guerrilla violence, the military said yesterday.

The hostages - three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns, a Lebanese, nine Malaysians and two Filipinos - were taken from the Malaysian island resort of Sipadan on April 23.

webTitle: Briton in drug smuggling case faces hanging

fields.headline: Briton in drug smuggling case faces hanging
fields.standfirst: Flaws in prosecution evidence fail to stop case against Stoke man on heroin charge in Malaysia
fields.trailText: A British man could face the death penalty tomorrow if convicted of heroin trafficking by a Malaysian court despite contradictions in the prosecution case against him.
fields.body:
A British man could face the death penalty tomorrow if convicted of heroin trafficking by a Malaysian court despite contradictions in the prosecution case against him.

David Chell, 57, a psychiatric nurse from Stoke-on-Trent, will offer his defence in a Penang court. If found guilty by the judge - capital offences are tried without a jury in Malaysia - he will be sentenced to death by hanging.

At a hearing in March witnesses, including the arresting officer, changed their evidence under defence cross-examination and the prosecution was unable to produce key documents, claiming they had been lost.

Mr Chell was arrested at Penang airport on October 7 1998 after customs officers claimed to have found a pouch containing heroin in his underwear. He had travelled overland from Thailand to Malaysia prior to his arrest and was attempting to board a flight to Perth, Australia, when the drugs were allegedly discovered. He was carrying around 7,000 ringgits (£1,200) in cash at the time.

Since his arrest he has been remanded at a Penang prison. Mr Chell, who has asthma, eczema and a minor heart complaint, has spent time on the hospital wing.

Mr Chell is being represented by Karpal Singh, a Malaysian lawyer and former opposition MP. Mr Singh defended the former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, against charges of misuse of power and sodomy last year and as a result faces charges of sedition.

Mr Singh claims there is no prima facie case to answer and that Mr Chell should now be acquitted because the arresting officer, Lance Corporal Nithiyarathan of the airport police, changed his evidence three times under cross-examination:

 He said in a police statement that Mr Chell handed him a black pouch containing heroin, but in court he testified that he had retrieved the drugs from Mr Chell's underwear himself.

 In his statement he said he had searched Mr Chell following a tip-off, but in court he said he had acted by chance.

 Lance Corporal Nithiyarathan told the court he recorded the incident in the station log book, but when the document was produced the relevant page was missing. He then said a female colleague, Corporal Norbaee Ibrahim, had made the entry in the diary, but in fact a third officer, Zaleha Mat Noor, testified that she had filled in the log.

Tomorrow Mr Chell will contest Lance Corporal Nithiyarathan's version of events. The officer claims he frisked Mr Chell and then took him to a private room where he searched him in the presence of two narcotics officers. Mr Chell will say he was taken to the room and left alone until the lance corporal returned with the narcotics officers and then produced the drugs, wrapped in 133 condoms, from under a pillow.

Speaking at the last court hearing Mr Singh said: "These contradictions are material and fundamental evidence of the case. When a tree trunk falls the branches too must fall with it. Thus my client should be freed."

Despite Mr Singh's protests that the case should be thrown out, Judge Zameha Zahari accepted the prosecution's explanation that the inconsistencies amounted to technicalities and were not material.

"Now this evidence has risen to the surface she [Judge Zahari] should acquit, there is no prima facie case to answer. I was suprised when she decided to proceed - it defies logic to accept this evidence," Mr Singh told the Guardian.

Mr Chell's family and friends are convinced of his innocence. "There's absolutely no way David is involved with drugs - he worked for years as a nurse and saw for himself the ravages of drugs. His family and friends firmly believe in his innocence," said Sarah Shaw, a lifelong friend who has been in regular contact with him by mail.

She expressed dismay at the lack of attention his case had received. "Malaysia is a member of the Commonwealth which is supposed to model its judicial system on our own, so why is he still there? Are we not opposed to capital punishment in this country?"

A source close to British consular staff in Malaysia has suggested that some doubt surrounded the prosecution case, given Malaysia's swingeing penalties for drug trafficking. An experienced traveller intending to smuggle drugs would not travel from Thailand to Malaysia, where the death penalty is mandatory.

Doug Durber, who has known Mr Chell for 43 years, is adamant about his friend's innocence. "Without a single solitary doubt he is not guilty. He just would not do something so monumentally stupid as smuggle drugs - he has got two teenage children and he just would not under any circumstances subject them to this," he said.

Those who know him well insist Mr Chell makes an unlikely drug trafficker. Born in Fenton, near Stoke, he trained as a registered psychiatric nurse in the early 1960s at St Edward's hospital in Cheddleton in Staffordshire, and then moved to London where he was one of the first two male nurses to work at University College hospital, London. He qualified as a state registered nurse in 1971.

He won a scholarship to attend Keele University in the mid-1970s after writing a paper on the dangers of illegal drugs, and graduated with a double honours in sociology and history.

Following his graduation he married and settled in Stoke, but the marriage, which produced two children, did not last and he began to travel widely.

He worked for three years on a medical relief project in the Sudan, after which he wrote a paper for the World Health Organisation. In the years prior to his arrest he travelled in Asia, spending much time in Thailand where he had planned to work as an English teacher.

A series of letters written from jail reveal Mr Chell's increasing frustration and disappointment as the case has appeared to turn against him. In a letter to Ms Shaw written while he was still in handcuffs after one hearing, he said: "Sensational developments following Karpal's brilliant cross-examination of arresting officer yesterday ... lies and destruction of evidence shown up in court."

But in an 18-page letter received at the end of April after he was ordered to present his defence the optimism appeared to have drained away. "Henry Cooper, ex-British boxing champion, once said about fighting in Italy that you had to knock your opponent out to get a draw. I rather fancy that might be an approriate analogy ... there's no use hiding the fact that my chances have deteriorated considerably now."

Mr Singh echoes his client's gloomy outlook: "It has become very difficult now. If the judge is willing to accept such tarnished evidence, we will have to work very hard to prove he is innocent," he said.

webTitle: Virgin apologises for bullying Australian firms

fields.headline: Virgin apologises for bullying Australian firms
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has been forced to apologise for the heavy-handed threats made by his lawyers to companies that use the trade name Virgin.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has been forced to apologise for the heavy-handed threats made by his lawyers to companies that use the trade name Virgin.

Sir Richard, who is launching his new Virgin Blue service as Australia's third domestic airline, has been accused of bullying small companies by telling them they could not use the name "Virgin" even if they had already registered it with state authorities and were not direct competitors.

The furore over the company name began when several small firms were told by Coudert Brothers, the law firm retained by Virgin, that they had 14 days to disconnect their phones and hand over stationary for destruction.

The letters asked the firms to give an irrevocable written undertaking to stop using the Virgin name and pay the costs of the legal letter.

"We got a bill basically saying 'Please remit $500 for the cost of our solicitor preparing this document to insult you'," said Mark Kanard, the chief pilot of Virgin Helicopters, which has traded under the name since 1998.

The owner of Virgin Wheel Repairs, Mr Steve Wiessner, who has been operating under the name in west Sydney for three years, said the threat to disconnect phones and faxes would have meant the closure of his company, which employs eight people. He failed to see how his business could be in competition with the entertainment and aviation giant.

Sir Richard, who has assiduously cultivated Australian politicians and fostered his 'cuddly' image, issued a statement in London yesterday to try to head off criticism. He said he had instructed the lawyers to withdraw actions from anyone who had " honestly and innocently" been trading in the past using the name Virgin.

"I am disappointed to hear the harsh tone used and I will certainly be speaking directly with the solicitors about taking a more gentle and understanding approach in the future," he said in a statement. "I am dreadfully sorry."

However, he warned that he would still try to prevent "unscrupulous individuals" exploiting the Virgin name.

In a further blow to public relations, it was discovered that Virgin's travel website has rubbished some of Australia's best-loved tourist attractions and insulted Brisbane, the site of Virgin Airlines' new regional headquarters.

The Queensland state government, which wooed Virgin with a £4m incentive package, was furious to see the website describe Brisbane as a "hick" town until the 1970s which is not worth flying halfway across the world to see. It also said that the city's outback heritage could be seen in the faces of the locals.

webTitle: In townships, the struggle to survive eclipses politics

fields.headline: In townships, the struggle to survive eclipses politics
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: It is a 15-minute drive from the colonial splendour of Harare city centre to the colonial legacy of Dzivaresekwa. You head past the non-stop rallies that have been taking place at the headquarters of the ruling Zanu-PF party, just off Rotten Row, past the air-conditioned comfort of the Sheraton hotel and out of Belvedere, a wealthy suburb to which some of the Asian and black middle class have ascended.
fields.body:
It is a 15-minute drive from the colonial splendour of Harare city centre to the colonial legacy of Dzivaresekwa. You head past the non-stop rallies that have been taking place at the headquarters of the ruling Zanu-PF party, just off Rotten Row, past the air-conditioned comfort of the Sheraton hotel and out of Belvedere, a wealthy suburb to which some of the Asian and black middle class have ascended.

And then you are off into urban wilderness. Just as you think you have left the city and entered the low trees and high skies of the veld, small conurbations pop up.

Like the impromptu religious meetings of followers of the Apostolic faith who dress all in white and congregate in small clusters by the roadside, the townships look as though they have emerged from nowhere.

But they are the product of the warped racial and economic logic of Rhodesian social engineering.

Dzivaresekwa was built to house black domestic servants who worked for white families in the north-west suburbs. Now it is home to black bank clerks, students, labourers and the vast numbers of unemployed. Separate and unequal - the inequities and iniquities of the past literally cemented in the present.

In a private taxi the journey would take a quarter of an hour, but it would cost more than one-third of a week's wages. So, with the exception of the few who have cars, most come in and out of the city in "commuter taxis" - small minibuses which are often so crammed that the man who collects the tickets hangs out of the window.

Amid the crush, office workers struggle to preserve the integrity of their ironed neatness. Children sit on strangers' laps and young women make an effort to keep a dignified distance from young men. From beginning to end, the journey takes about an hour - commuter taxis stop wherever a hand goes out on the road or a voice cries out from within.

At the Ndlovus in Dzivaresekwa two "aunties", Margaret and Faithful, are on the porch surrounded by maize. They have spent most of the day picking the crop - grown on the small allotment near the house - and sitting, chatting and shelling the ears in the shade as the maize dries in the sun. When they are done they will take it to the local shop and have it ground into flour to make their staple food, mealie meal.

At the Ndlovus at the moment it is mealies with everything. "We would like to give you some chicken and rice but with the present situation we cannot afford such things," says Faithful. So mealies it is. Two or three nights a week they have two or three small chunks of beef with it; the rest of the time it comes with vegetables and a little sauce.

After dinner Peter, Margaret's nephew, takes me out. Like most houses in Dzivaresekwa, the Ndlovus' is quite crowded. There are two other families renting from his aunts: seven adults and four children in a five-bedroom bungalow.

There is some common space - a living room, kitchen, inside toilet and washroom -but for it all to work, says Peter, each family lives pretty much autonomously.

Out on the street there is a sound rarely heard in Britain any more apart from on "problem estates" - children playing after dark. Chasing each other, pushing tyres around or just running for no apparent reason, they are unaccompanied and apparently unfettered by fears of random attack and abuse by strangers.

"It is safe here," says Peter. "Apart from political violence, it is very safe. Some thieves, but not many, and not many guns." The most constant source of tension, he says, is between supporters of the Caps and the Dynamos - the two biggest football teams in Harare.

Still he wants to leave. The 27-year-old clerk in a tobacco company dreams of a small place of his own with a wife and no lodgers in a township nearer Harare.

But his dream remains a long way off. In good years tobacco may make millions for the farmers but Peter earns about £14 a week. He spends £2.50 on transport and £2 on rent. By the time he has paid for food, bills and clothes there is little left. In bad years, and thanks to the land invasions of tobacco farms this is about as bad as it gets, he risks getting laid off.

He has a girlfriend in a township some miles away but, given the current state of the economy, he doubts he will ever be able to afford the lobola (bride price). And the house? He shrugs. "I dream and I pray," he says.

There are few distractions for a young man in Dzivaresekwa. One place, a few miles up the road, occasionally shows poor quality films and around the corner from the Ndlovus there is the Kadada nightclub, which has live bands and sometimes a beer-fuelled punch-up.

Otherwise you just stay in and watch state television or go out and wander around until you're bored or tired. During the tobacco sales season Peter has to be at work by 6.30am and is not home until around 6pm so he usually stays in.

Spend one night in a township and you are struck by an incongruity. If there is a race war in Zimbabwe then nobody has told most of the black people who make up more than 98% of the population. The subject of white Zimbabweans did not come up once, unless I raised it, and then it was dismissed pretty quickly.

White Zimbabweans are trying to predict black Zimbabweans' next move on a daily basis; most black Zimbabweans are too busy trying to struggle through their daily lives to worry about their white counterparts. But both black and white are worried about the government and the economy - albeit for very different reasons.

On the way back home Peter stands and stares in front of a poster advertising a rally the next day for the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change. He winces intensely. Even though the huge majority of people who have been killed in the recent political violence are black, there is no contingency plan to rescue them if things go wrong. So politics is for the brave, the rich, the stupid and the powerful.

Peter freely admits he is none of these. He will go to the polls for the MDC but he will not go out on a limb for them. "Here politics is crazy," he says. "They will kill you for a T-shirt. Even if you are not wearing it but you have it in your house. And nobody will protect you."

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText:
• Problem solved

The Post Office is setting out to crack one of the biggest problems for online retailers - how to deliver goods which cannot be slipped through a letter box. It is to launch a service enabling buyers to collect goods from their local post office. The aim is to replace £400m a year income to be lost when the government starts paying benefits directly into bank accounts.
fields.body:
 Problem solved

The Post Office is setting out to crack one of the biggest problems for online retailers - how to deliver goods which cannot be slipped through a letter box. It is to launch a service enabling buyers to collect goods from their local post office. The aim is to replace £400m a year income to be lost when the government starts paying benefits directly into bank accounts.

 Hassle buster

Insurer CGU , which completes its merger with Norwich Union this month, is launching an internet service aiming to reduce the hassle of moving home. Assertahome.com was announced as CGU reported a stronger than expected start to the first quarter of the year.

webTitle: Drugs firms take axe to jobs

fields.headline: Drugs firms take axe to jobs
fields.standfirst: Unions fear doomsday as redundancies and closures accompany £118bn merger
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are to close seven of their 10 administrative sites in the south-east, as part of their forthcoming £118bn merger to form the world's largest pharmaceuticals company.
fields.body:
Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are to close seven of their 10 administrative sites in the south-east, as part of their forthcoming £118bn merger to form the world's largest pharmaceuticals company.

The closures will mean hundreds of job losses and these could be just the tip of the iceberg by the time all the merger plans are carried through. Unions described the news as "terrible", suggesting that their worst fears about the deal could be realised.

In a joint announcement, the two companies said their global headquarters would be in a new facility at Brentford, Middlesex, which SmithKline Beecham began building last year.

SmithKline's nearby head offices, New Horizons Court and SB House, will be shut, as planned. However, additional casualties will include the company's pharmaceuticals centre in Welwyn Garden City - originally the headquarters of the group's predecessor, SmithKline & French.

A SmithKline spokesman said: "It sounds like a lot but we were going to shut some of these anyway. We had a team which looked at things very carefully. What we need is state-of-the-art accomodation in new facilities."

A modern Glaxo Wellcome building at Stockley Park, near Heathrow airport, London, will become the base of the combined company's UK pharmaceuticals operation.

Glaxo's old headquarters at Greenford will be turned into a site for research and development.

Both companies refused to comment on likely job losses in the upheaval. Many more redundancies are likely when manufacturing operations are combined.

The Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union believes the deal as a whole could cost 5,000 jobs in the UK. An MSF spokesman said: "We were saying this deal was a doomsday scenario for a lot of workers when it was first announced. People told us we were wrong but clearly, we weren't."

Casualties among Glaxo's sites will include leased offices in Slough, Ealing Broadway, Southall and Stockley Park Lakeside.

SmithKline's central London town house in Chester Square, which boasts a spacious flat for the group's chief executive, will be axed in favour of Glaxo's similar site in Berkeley Square.

Between them, the two groups employ 16,000 people in Britain. The tie-up has triggered fears in political circles that jobs could be moved overseas, particularly in vital research areas.

Particularly controversial has been a decision to locate Glaxo SmithKline's operational headquarters in New York. This will oversee day-to-day running of the business, while the official Brentford "corporate headquarters" will largely deal with administrative matters, such as finance, human resources and information technology.

The two groups have promised to keep open both their research and development sites - in Stevenage and Harlow. However, Smith Kline's chief executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, told MPs at a select committee hearing in February:

"We are businessmen. Clearly, if there is a dramatic change to the environment in Britain, you would not expect us to stay."

The deal was nodded through on Monday by the European commission, on condition that the two groups sell drugs worth £50m, including treatments for herpes, nausea and smoker's cough.

fields.headline: When love comes in...
fields.standfirst: ...it takes you and everybody else for a spin.  Martin Clark  on a worldwide infection
fields.trailText: ...it takes you and everybody else for a spin. Martin Clark on a worldwide infection
fields.body:
As love sickness goes, it was a near fatal case. Exactly seven days ago, many of us were waking up to some unexpected emails of admiration. Messages marked I LOVE YOU were flooding in to millions of inboxes around the world, piquing the curiosity of users just enough for them to double-click on the enclosed attachment.

One week later, and we know it was a virus: the world's most virulent to date. Combining some quite sophisticated programming with a similarly cunning appeal to the human psyche, it caused widespread damage to data and a massive loss of productivity.

The small program, containing coded instructions to both reproduce and perform tasks, was seemingly written in the Philippines. Once downloaded, it burrowed its way into your system, deleting jpeg (picture) files and hiding MP3 (music) files. Then it emailed copies of your passwords to a website in the Philippines.

Then it fulfilled its need to reproduce, and sent offspring viruses to every email address in your Microsoft Outlook address book. The only way to prevent its spread was to shut down email servers - the now essential tool of most businesses. The cost in lost work time began to add up. Estimates vary on the total, but they are all in the billions, from $2bn to $10bn, and they are growing while the virus continues to do the rounds. An estimated 80% of companies worldwide were hit.

"We estimate $2.61bn of damage has been done," says Samir Bhavnani, a research analyst with Computer Economics. "By Wednesday, the total can reach $10bn. We see damages growing by up to $1.5bn a day until the virus is eradicated."

Police in the Philippines made three arrests on Monday: the trio, including bank clerks Reomel Ramones and Irene de Guzman, were being questioned about the virus outbreak. Clues to the programmers' nationality were apparent early on. "The source code contained references to Manila and the Philippines," says Graham Cluley of Sophos Anti Virus. "The author even included his hacker's codename 'spyder'".

Virus technologist Alex Shipp and his team at Message Labs claim to be the first in the world to capture the love bug. They intercepted an infected email at 12.14am on Thursday, direct from the Philippines. They quickly realised the ensuing epidemic would be huge. "Just seeing how nasty it was, we thought it might be another Melissa," says Shipp, referring to the last major email-attached virus.

"Then someone checked how many of them we'd caught. Normally we get 300 viruses a day, from a sample two million emails. On the first day of Melissa we only got 200. On Thursday we got 13,000 of the love bug," he says. It wasn't just the programming which made this virus ultra virulent. "Making people open the attachment (by using I LOVE YOU) was simply an excellent piece of social engineering," he says.

"The programmer also stole lots of good ideas from lots of other viruses and put them all into one. There was also fairly good timing. Everybody had got over the last virus scare and had got back to their bad habits," concludes Shipp. Britain and Europe were hit disproportionately hard, he says, because of the difference in time zones between Europe and the US. The countries hit hardest depended on wherever the sun rose next," says Shipp.

"As soon as people woke up there was a peak of viral activity, and that peak was in Europe - especially the UK - first. "When it hit, it was 3.40am, New York time. We were able to ring them and say 'this virus is coming towards you in about four hours - get ready.' "Nonetheless, there was very little time delay. It spread almost instantaneously over the globe, with 10 new strains quickly appearing."

All of which paints a grim picture for an increasingly technology dependent world. Why are our computers so vulnerable? "There's a fight between PC functionality and security," says Cluley. "Microsoft could solve, say, the macro virus problem tomorrow - if it wanted. But it won't, for legitimate commercial reasons. It's never going to sell its word processor on the basis that you can't do all kinds of cool things with macros. Security always loses out to functionality. That has been the history of software.

"My three pieces of advice to any company or individual are: one, keep your anti-virus software up to date. Two, put a system on your email gateway to block dodgy attachments like the Visual Basic files we saw here. Lastly, de-install Windows Host, a program invaded by the love bug," concludes Cluley. Consider yourselves warned.

fields.headline: The IT boys and girls
fields.standfirst: Notebooks are replacing jotters, writes Sudipta Dev
fields.trailText: Notebooks are replacing jotters, writes Sudipta Dev
fields.body:
School children in the south London borough of Lambeth now have rather more than text books and jotters to carry in their schoolbags - there's an £800 laptop computer in there, too. In a unique pilot project, 100 Psion Netbooks have been given to three schools within the Lambeth Action Zone in an effort to make learning more exciting for primary students who have no access to computers at home. The plan is to help develop the literacy and numeracy skills of nine to 10 year-olds - and maybe even breed a new generation of IT-savvy schoolkids.

Tim Coulson, Lambeth education action zone's project director, is at pains to point out that these Netbooks are not meant to substitute pen and paper, or handicap writing skills. But, he says, the machines will help build pupils' sentence construction skills, and homework might actually turn out to be a pleasurable exercise after all.

"We hope they will want to work more than now," he says. "The literacy strategy is to load text and mathematical applications. Two specialist IT people are helping the teachers in these schools with this project." The £60,000 project will be evaluated before Christmas by a team from Warwick University, but already Coulson hopes to gain further sponsorships. Psion's Netbook was picked for the trial not just because of its comparatively low cost and light weight: it's also rugged, able to withstand a drop of 1.5 metres. And Psion is quick to emphasise the machine's simple operating system and "on/off" functionality, which means there's no delay between turning the machine on and being able to use it. The Netbooks are loaded with a whole library of software, including an encyclopedia, English and French dictionaries, Alice in Wonderland and Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book.

But for the time being, the young and proud owners of the Netbooks are too excited to think of anything beyond their artistic efforts. "I want to do science, maths and English on these," says Tope, busy selecting a new figure for her drawing. Her friend Charlotte adds that they had typed out a story ("I don't remember which"), and found it better than writing. "The first time I was given this computer I was very excited. We can do all things on it," Saffron informs us, earnestly. Their teacher Jo Mclarnon is evidently proud of the way her pupils have adapted to the computer. "They have only had two sessions and are doing so well. I personally do not think that computers will ever replace writing, it is just another tool of learning and can help in so many ways."

The Netbooks are loaded with a whole library of software, including an encyclopedia, English and French dictionaries, Alice in Wonderland and Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book. But for the time being, the young and proud owners of the Netbooks are too excited to think of anything beyond their artistic efforts. "I want to do science, maths and English on these," says Tope, busy selecting a new figure for her drawing. Her friend Charlotte adds that they had typed out a story ("I don't remember which"), and found it better than writing. "The first time I was given this computer I was very excited. We can do all things on it," Saffron informs us, earnestly. Their teacher Jo Mclarnon is evidently proud of the way her pupils have adapted to the computer. "They have only had two sessions and are doing so well. I personally do not think that computers will ever replace writing, it is just another tool of learning and can help in so many ways."

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: MediEvil II | Star Wars Episode 1: Jedi Power Battles | Slave Zero
fields.byline: Andy Bodle, Jack Schofield and Greg Howson
fields.body:
Laugh? I almost broke a rib
MediEvil II
Sony PlayStation £19.99 SCE Cambridge
Third-person adventure game MediEvil didn't exactly break the mould, it sort of superficially vandalised it, with inane graffiti and a judiciously placed piece of turf. Anyhow, its clever puzzles and self-mocking humour managed to earn it 800,000 sales worldwide, which was apparently enough to activate the automatic-sequel machine.

So now we welcome back Sir Dan Fortesque, the cowardly, one-eyed skeleton: the only computer game hero with waist measurements to beat Lara Croft's. Five hundred years on from his last outing, he's been woken from his eternal slumber to avert a catastrophe in Victorian London. This time it's an industrialist called Lord Palethorn who's up to no good, and all our Dan's got to stop him is his detachable limbs, a friendly but exasperating ghost, a techno-wiz mad professor, a sexy mummified Egyptian princess, and an arsenal to rival the IRA's.

OK, so it's a little harder than that. With its unusual control system and the almost immediate toughness of the baddies, you'll initially be using your memory card more than you use your own memory. What's more, it's not really worth attempting without an analog controller: after complaints about the original's dynamic camera, SCE Cambridge has placed the player in full control of the view. A noble idea, but when there are already two dozen commands to keep track of, it's a big ol' pain in the coccyx.

For those familiar with the medieval MediEvil, the 19th-century MediEvil obeys all the laws of the sequel. It's still got its irreverent wit. The levels are bigger. The graphics are better. New monsters. New weapons. New shmoo. The game's unique selling point is probably the alternative modes in which you can control Dan. Worried about what's round the next corner? Just rip off your head and your hand, stick one on top of the other and, hey presto, a mobile surveillance unit. You can also control the consequently headless Dan, and a mystery "Dan-kenstein" mode becomes available later in the game.

For the uninitiated, MediEvil II a slightly less po-faced Tomb Raider, only without a face. Intrigued? Thought not. (AB)

May the sword be with you
Star Wars Episode 1: Jedi Power Battles
Sony PlayStation £34.99 LucasArts
Yet another Star Wars game, and this time it's a swashbuckler: the swords have been changed for light sabres and the sailing ships for spaceships, but the differences are largely cosmetic.

The plot is traditional, too. You choose one of five different Jedi characters from Obi-Wan Kenobi to Adi Gallia, hack and slash your way through 10 sort-of-3D levels, and beat the boss at the end of each scenario. It's not an intellectual challenge, but the levels are probably big enough to keep you going until you need a hand transplant.

The enemy droids are amazingly unobservant and will stand around for ages waiting for you to dismember them. However, they do have blasters, which is a bit unfair if you only have a light sabre. Luckily, they are very bad shots, and you can bat their bullets back at them, baseball style. You can also "earn" your own thermite bombs, shields, restraining bolts and so on. The best feature of the game is co-operative play: you and a mate against the Federation. If you enjoyed the arcade action-adventure games of the late Sinclair Spectrum/ Commodore 64 era, you'll probably like this. What's more, it also has terrific Star Wars music and better animations than the little stick-like figures familiar from the 80s - though not that much better. (JS)

It's big but it's certainly not clever
Slave Zero
PC £34.99 Infogrames
Miniaturisation is an underused perspective in computer games. Only Micro Machines and its myriad sequels have really delved into realms of Honey, I Shrunk The Video Game. Slave Zero goes the other way with cities dwarfed by your character, the 60ft bi-pedal robot of the title.

Imagine King Kong in Metropolis and you're part way there. And, of course, you're not the only big bot in town with numerous oversized adversaries blocking the way to freedom. Cue mindless blasting, excessive destruction and oodles of fun.

Well, not really. Fiddly controls make steering Zero harder than you'd expect, while the camera is particularly unhelpful. Likewise, the graphics are barely adequate, though the meaty explosions are worthy of praise. No, the real problem here is the questionable longevity of the game itself. Variety is distinctly lacking as you veer from city to boss baddie and back to the samey city level again. It's not long before the mindless stomping loses its appeal and your mind begins to wander.

Unsurprisingly, Slave Zero has been ported to the Sega Dreamcast, where it seems better suited than the stuffier environs of the PC games market. Ultimately, with so many top-notch games around, something so average doesn't seem worth bothering with. Still, if you fancy a quick blast then Slave Zero is willing and able to deliver. However, if you demand slightly more commitment from your gaming relationships then it's probably best to leave well alone. (GH)
